ARAB NATIONS PUSH P.L.O. PEACE ROLE
LEAD: In advance of this weekend's superpower summit meeting off the Mediterranean island of Malta, Arab foreign ministers today petitioned President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to give priority to the Middle East conflict and to acknowledge the Palestine Liberation Organization as a participant in the diplomacy of peace.


Geneva Journal; To the Swiss and Dutch, Tolerance Is Anti-Drug
LEAD: While the United States and other countries intensify their war on drugs, two European countries, Switzerland and the Netherlands, are adhering to a much more liberal approach to their drug problems.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 470 money market mutual funds decreased by $660.30 million, to $367.57 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 145 institutional funds decreased by $325.10 million, to $89.30 billion.
The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were down by $291 million, to $119.21 billion.


Bush Rejects Bill on China Students
LEAD: President Bush today killed legislation that would have allowed Chinese students to stay in the United States after their visas expired.
He said he was taking administrative action to give equivalent protection to the students.


Review/Theater; Art Imitates Art in a Stoppard Play
LEAD: You know you're at a Tom Stoppard play when even the title lends itself to at least three different meanings.

Report Finds Problems With Pentagon Computers
LEAD: The modernization of Defense Department computer systems that are used to store information on anything from personnel records to the purchase of new weapons is a billion dollars over budget, behind schedule and beset by numerous technical problems, a Congressional report made public today says.


Penance for Felling 67 Old Maples: 100 New Trees
LEAD: Admitting that ''we fouled up,'' New York City's Transportation Commissioner, Ross Sandler, said yesterday that his department would plant 100 new trees along Mosholu Parkway in the Bronx to replace 67 Norwegian maples that were cut down this week after department workers had inadvertently chopped off the roots.


South African Detective Is Held in 2 Killings
LEAD: The South African police disclosed today that they are holding a former narcotics detective in connection with the killings this year of two whites who were prominent in the struggle against apartheid.


Meyer Pesin Dies at 88; Ex-Jersey City Official
LEAD: Meyer Pesin, a former corporation counsel for Jersey City and a former president of the Jewish National Fund of America, died Tuesday in Caracas, Venezuela.
He was 88 years old and had lived in Teaneck, N.J., before moving to Caracas four years ago.


5 Withdraw From List For New York Police Job
LEAD: Five of the 11 initial candidates for New York City police commissioner have withdrawn their names, the head of the search panel said yesterday.

Heart Risk Persists After Cocaine Use, Study Says
LEAD: An increased risk of heart attack from taking cocaine can persist for at least two weeks after the start of a withdrawal program, a new study shows.


French, Germans Back Copter Deal
LEAD: The French and West German Governments have approved joint development of a combat and support helicopter called the Tiger, the French arms procurement agency said today.
The contract is worth about $1.2 billion and covers development of the helicopter and construction of five prototypes over 10 years to be built by a consortium owned by Aerospatiale of France and Messerschmitt-Bolkow-Blohm G.m.b.H.


Chiefs' Rookie Sack Specialist Leading Drive Toward Playoffs
LEAD: Derrick Thomas was only 4 years old in 1971, when the Miami Dolphins beat the Kansas City Chiefs by 27-24 after 22 minutes of overtime in a Christmas Day playoff battle that was the longest game in National Football League history.
Thomas, however, is more concerned with making his own history and helping guide the Chiefs into the playoffs.


Occidental Given Oilfield Go-Ahead
LEAD: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation received British Government approval to redevelop the Piper oilfield in the North Sea, where an explosion on a company platform killed 167 men.
The Piper Alpha platform off Scotland exploded in flames on July 6, 1988, and was destroyed.


INSIDE
LEAD:  Rise in New York Cab Fares  An 11.5 percent increase in yellow-cab fares was approved.
Fare rises for subways, buses and commuter railroads are expected to follow shortly.

Shoving Match in Japan  Japan's attempt to deregulate its financial markets has taken five years and followed a bumpy path among banks, securities firms and Government bureaucrats.


Lynn Bari, 75, 'Other Woman' In 30's and 40's Movies, Is Dead
LEAD: Lynn Bari, an actress who appeared in nearly 50 movies, most of them in the 1930's and 40's, died of a heart attack on Nov. 20 in a Santa Barbara, Calif., hospital.
She was 75 years old and lived in the Santa Barbara suburb of Goleta.


Rebels in Phillipine Army Bomb Aquino Palace and Attack Bases
LEAD: Rebel troops bombed the presidential palace this morning after attacking three military camps and three broadcast stations in an attempt to overthrow the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.


At Last, Rutgers Wins Acclaim
LEAD: Rutgers has been trying to make a national name for itself with its football and basketball teams, but national acclaim has come to the school this fall from its soccer team.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Athena Awards To 22 Agencies
LEAD: Wry wit and arresting visual images distinguished 22 print ads that won Athena awards for excellence in newspaper advertising yesterday.
The Newspaper Advertising Bureau, which selected the ads from more than 10,000 entries, honored the 22 winning agencies in a ceremony at the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan.


Alabama Hospital Seeks $53 Million
LEAD: The City of Montgomery, Ala., is offering through the BMC Special Care Facilities Financing Authority $53 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds for the Baptist Medical Center.


TV Weekend; Ambitious Movies Face Off Sunday
LEAD: This Sunday evening at 9, there are two ambitious television movies running against each other.
One, CBS's ''No Place Like Home,'' is a searing account of what it is like to be homeless in today's United States.
The other, ABC's ''Shell Seekers,'' is about an independent, middle-class Englishwoman coming to terms with herself and her grown children.

LEAD: The French Baroque remains opera's last frontier, largely unknown to the world's major companies.

One such group, James Richman's Concert Royal, explored Rameau's first extant opera, ''Hippolyte et Aricie,'' at Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

Pop/Jazz; Conjuring Up The Founder, Jimi Hendrix
LEAD: It's impossible to listen to rock-and-roll today without hearing the ghost of the guitarist Jimi Hendrix.
Using the grammar of blues and rhythm-and-blues, Hendrix wrote the rules of modern rock.
His improvisations, coarse and nasty or smoothly passionate, glorifed the noise and textures of the electric guitar, in the process elevating the instrument to its premier position in pop music.

Disco-Dining the Night Away
LEAD: THE New York club scene is constantly evolving.
In the 1980's, it moved from a style that had been huge and high tech to one that was diminutive and old fashioned.
But with no one quite sure what sort of tastes and manners the 1990's will bring, a burst of new nightspots - fulfilling every mood and whim - has made today a clubgoers' market.


This Old House
LEAD: If the walls of 273 Water Street, N.Y., N.Y. 10004 could talk, the dainty would have to block their ears.
During its more than 200 years this small brick derelict has been a brothel, a home for ''fallen women'' and a saloon called Kit Burns's Sportsman's Hall, where bad men paid good money to watch dogs fight rats.

A University for Addicts
LEAD: In Building A, a group of addicts gathers for yet another bruising therapy session, a staple of their yearlong residential treatment.
In Building B, counselors meet with addicts participating in an experimental program of intensive outpatient treatment.
In Building C, meanwhile, addicts who are also convicts on probation are interviewed to find what kind of treatment would suit them best.

Denver Post Picks New Editor
LEAD: F. Gilman Spencer, former editor of The Daily News in New York, was named editor in chief of The Denver Post on Wednesday.
He replaces Robert W. Ritter, who resigned.
Mr.
Spencer joined The Daily News in 1984 and left recently after a well-publicized disagreement with the publisher, James Hoge.

LEAD: In his first public comments since his killing of two unarmed blacks set off three days of rioting here 10 months ago, a Hispanic police officer testified today that he fired the fatal shot because ''I feared for my life - I thought I was going to be killed.''

Japan's Bumpy Financial Ride
LEAD: For one day earlier this year, the Industrial Bank of Japan rocked Japanese regulators by slipping through a legal loophole and dealing in Japanese stocks in London - without first consulting the Finance Ministry, an almost unthinkable breach of protocol.


Review/Art; From Chillida, Pillars Of Energy and Gravity
LEAD: Eduardo Chillida is very much a European modernist.
His abstract sculpture in metal and clay is intense yet measured, freest when it is most self-contained.
Its edge depends upon its ability to communicate a sense that it is both aware of its limits and entirely at ease with its identity, and yet driven to push those limits and see, feel and know more.


'Batman' Rights to CBS
LEAD: CBS has bought broadcast rights to the hit movie ''Batman,'' the television network said Wednesday.
The network did not disclose the price.
An executive who asked not to be identified said the network would probably not broadcast the film until 1992.

Prostitution Called Link in Rochester Deaths
LEAD: Someone is stalking and killing women in this city's red-light district.
Since March 1988, 12 women have been murdered: nine who the police say were prostitutes, a homeless woman, a mildly retarded introvert who liked to walk in her solitude and a woman whose skeletal remains have gone unidentified.


Colombia Jet Toll Reaches 110
LEAD: The death toll from the crash of a Colombian jetliner rose to 110 today as outrage increased over assertions that the police joined looters in stripping the bodies of valuables.

LEAD: The head of West Germany's largest commercial bank was killed today when terrorists detonated a remote-control bomb, demolishing the automobile in which he was being driven to work.

LEAD: A jury in a state court today found Amtrak guilty of dumping raw sewage into Florida waterways, in the national rail passenger line's first such criminal trial.


Book Theft Laid to Librarian
LEAD: The former head librarian at the University of Texas Medical Branch has been charged with stealing five rare medical books from the school.
The accused, Emil Frey, 62 years old, surrendered to Galveston County sheriff's officials Wednesday and was later released on $23,000 bond.
An indictment charges him with stealing five of 80 books missing from the school's Moody Medical Library.


Amex Details Options Plan
LEAD: Despite objections from some of its rivals, the American Stock Exchange is moving to put into effect a plan that allows stock options to be traded on more than one exchange.

Grace Spinelli, Social Worker, 83
LEAD: Grace Billotti Spinelli, a retired social worker who directed programs at Young Women's Christian Associations in Orange and Passaic Counties in New Jersey, died Saturday at Warren Hospital in Phillipsburg, N.J.
She was 83 years old and lived in Jersey City for 53 years before moving to East Orange about 10 years ago.


The World Of India
LEAD: When India voted, a whole world voted.


Review/Art; War Seen Firsthand
LEAD: The art that recorded Britain's passage through two devastating World Wars doesn't get a lot of space in books about this century's art.
It is not abstract; it tends toward works on paper rather than big, impressive paintings; some of it verges on propaganda, some on illustration.
It was frequently made by artists who did not go on to bigger and better things.

LEAD: The Cablevision Systems Corporation, which operates local systems in New York and 10 other states and whose programming includes the Sportschannel, Bravo and American Move Classics services, has overhauled its management, creating an office of the chairman, and naming a chief operating officer, a vice chairman for development and a programming head.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:  Friday  MARRINER AT CARNEGIE


Ditka Plans to Stay
LEAD: Mike Ditka says he will be back to coach the Chicago Bears next season, and he has received the backing of the team's president, Michael McCaskey. ''He doesn't need a special vote of confidence after all he's done for the Bears,'' McCaskey said on Wednesday. ''I kind of resent the question of whether or not I still have confidence in Mike Ditka.


Survey Finds Americans Favor a Reunited Germany
LEAD: The upheaval in Eastern Europe has left Americans optimistic and ready for even greater change in the region.
Two out of three say East and West Germany should be reunited, and an equal number predict that Eastern Europe will be largely out of Soviet control a year from now.


Prague Regains a Wayward Balladeer
LEAD: One of Czechoslovakia's best-known balladeers looked out at the people packed into an auditorium here tonight, nodded his head and smiled.


Sounds Around Town
LEAD:  A 40's Incarnation


Florence A. Kahn, Executive, 81
LEAD: Florence Abraham Kahn, retired owner and former chief executive of H. Abraham Inc., a Brooklyn glass-fabricating concern, died yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness.
She was 81 years old and lived in Great Neck, L.I.


Houston Seen As Summit Site
LEAD: President Bush has selected Houston as the site of the economic summit meeting in July for the seven leading industrial countries, White House officials said today.


Westchester Airport Cleared to Begin Modernizing
LEAD: The Federal Aviation Administration today approved an environmental plan for Westchester County Airport, opening the way for long-sought modernization and improvement.


Gorbachev Lauds Religion on Eve of Meeting Pope
LEAD: On the eve of an encounter with Pope John Paul II, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said tonight that the Soviet Union had erred in long rejecting religion and now needed its moral force to help make his plans for a restructured society work.


Giants to Open Stadium Talks
LEAD: The San Francisco Giants will open negotiations with Santa Clara County in about two weeks on a potential new home for the National League champions 40 miles south of here, the team's owner, Bob Lurie, said today.


Minimum Bid Reported Set By Campeau
LEAD: The Campeau Corporation has set a Dec. 8 deadline for initial bids on its Bloomingdale's stores and has decided that it will not accept any offers under $1 billion, retail and merger-acquisition executives said yesterday.

German Red Army Faction Is Alive and Is Refining Itself
LEAD: The killing of Alfred Herrhausen today is an ominous reminder that the Red Army Faction terrorist group - which West German police thought was severely crippled by the arrests of its leading members in recent years - is not only alive, but continues to refine its methods.


Spending Drops Off; Income Up
LEAD: Consumer spending fell in October to its lowest level in nearly three years, the Commerce Department said today.
Analysts said continued sluggishness in personal consumption is likely to be a ''major drag'' on the economy in the fourth quarter.

CENTRISTS IN INDIA STRIVING FOR UNITY
LEAD: As the leaders of the centrist National Front continued consultations today on the composition of the Government they hope to assemble as early as next weekend, they sought to dissuade one of their number from challenging the accession to Prime Minister of Vishwanath Pratap Singh, the man who is credited with leading the coalition to prominence.


Drop Those Hyphens And Just Be American
LEAD: To the Editor:


Ford Plans to Shut V-8 Engine Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company told 900 employees at its Windsor, Ontario, engine plant that it will close the factory late next year.
The plant was shuttered in 1981 during the auto industry's deep recession but reopened in 1983 when demand for the larger engines grew.


Rangers Lose Leads and Confidence
LEAD: For the Rangers, the shocks to their defensive system, having gained momentum over the last month, have now begun to take a toll.

LEAD: ''Dance of Hope'' opens today at the Public Theater, just 13 days before the Dec. 14 presidential and congressional elections in Chile, the first since the military coup that overthrew the Government of Salvador Allende Gossens.
The timing is not accidental.

Jimmy Carter's Sister Has Pancreas Cancer
LEAD: Gloria Carter Spann, the last surviving sibling of former President Jimmy Carter, has been found to be suffering from pancreatic cancer, the same disease that killed their father, sister and brother and contributed to the death of their mother.

LEAD: A sign-painter was putting the last touches on the company logo in the lobby as guests arrived early Tuesday evening for the opening of the Alvin Ailey Dance Theater Foundation's new headquarters at 211 West 61st Street, just west of Lincoln Center.

Warning About Tests
LEAD: In at least two decisions, the Supreme Court has indicated its willingness, despite the Fourth Amendment, to uphold the constitutionality of mandatory, random drug testing of workers in ''high risk'' or ''safety-sensitive'' jobs.

LEAD: A Philadelphia school district program that gave preference to minority contractors has been struck down by a Federal district judge, who says it failed to meet a new test established by the Supreme Court.

Vincent's Medical Center in Manhattan, died of cancer Wednesday in Hong Kong, according to word received at the hospital here.
Dr.
Ma was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan until she returned recently to her native Hong Kong.

Review/Rock; 'Songs for Drella,' A Tribute to Warhol
LEAD: For rockers, Andy Warhol's greatest cultural contribution wasn't his pop art, but his early sponsorship of the Velvet Underground - the band that virtually created alternative, anti-pop rock.
In the mid-1960's, Warhol discovered and managed the Velvets, who performed at his Exploding Plastic Inevitable multi-media events.


Japanese Developer Buys Picasso at Record Price
LEAD: A Japanese real-estate developer paid $51.3 million yesterday for Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' and said he planned to hang it at an auto racing resort he is building on the southern Japanese island of Kyushu.


World AIDS Epidemic Draws New Warnings
LEAD: The worldwide AIDS epidemic is gaining momentum and in some regions has shifted from a disease mostly among men to one in which half the victims are women, officials of the World Health Organization said today.


The Dollar Is Mostly Lower; Gold Prices Rise in the U.S.
LEAD: The dollar was mostly lower in light trading yesterday amid uncertainty about the nation's economy.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Backer in Thailand
LEAD: Backer Spielvogel Bates has added Thailand to its growing chain of agencies in the Pacific Rim.
The agency, opened in Bangkok, is called BSB Thailand Ltd. and is a joint venture of Backer and two other agencies in Bangkok: Shrimp Studios, an advertising agency, and Ra-Kahng Associates, a marketing firm.


General Mills, Nestle Plan Europe Push
LEAD: If General Mills gets its way, the continental breakfast will soon include a bowl of Cheerios.


Cards Sign Cox
LEAD: Danny Cox, who missed the 1989 season after surgery on his right elbow, has signed a one-year contract with the St.
Louis Cardinals for $250,000 and up to $500,000 more in bonuses.
Cox, who made $600,000 last year, had surgery in March to repair an elbow ligament.
He hurt the elbow pitching in an exhibition game.


Two Sinkholes Force Evacuations in Jersey
LEAD: Two sinkholes, one more than 25 feet deep, opened here today, forcing the temporary evacuation of at least six homes, the police said.


Cuomo Backers Raise $2 Million For a 3d Term
LEAD: Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo has said he is not yet a candidate for a third term next year, but his friends say they raised nearly $2 million for a third-term campaign last night.


Disinheritance Law Kindles Passion in Louisiana
LEAD: Under mandate of the Legislature, legal scholars here are polishing a new state law that they detest and believe to be unconstitutional.
Their task is to mesh the new law with the complex state civil code.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about the economy misstated the third-quarter change in two price indexes.


In Which Boston Brahmin Law Firms Slug it Out. Genteelly, Of Course.
LEAD: After seven years of litigation, there is still some dispute over whether toxic solvents dumped at a tannery in Woburn, Mass., found their way into the municipal water supply and caused six deaths from leukemia.
But there is no denying that bad karma from the case has seeped even further than the chemicals, crossing the Charles River and into Boston's blue-blooded bar.

LEAD: Stanford Olsen, the tenor who won the 1989 Naumburg Vocal Competition, will sing Schubert's ''Schone Mullerin'' at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday evening at 8.
The pianist will be Phillip Farris.
Tickets are $10.

Gerber to Close Plant in Ontario
LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said it will close its Niagara Falls, Ontario, plant by April, terminating about 150 jobs.
The world's largest maker of baby food is consolidating production in its three United States plants: in Fremont, Mich.; Fort Smith, Ark., and Asheville, N.C.

Marcos's vice presidential running mate, as President.
They surrender two days later.

Drug Use Is a Focus of Crane Inquiry
LEAD: The California Occupational Safety and Health Administration is investigating reports of illegal drug use among workers at a construction job where a crane collapse killed five people.


Rohatyn Urges Dinkins to Hold Spending Line
LEAD: Felix G. Rohatyn, the chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, has warned that Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins should plan to hold spending in next year's New York City budget to the level of this year's revenues, in a drastic no-growth approach.


Should Germany Be Reunified?


Economic Scene; Aid for East Bloc Expected To Be a Vital Summit Topic
LEAD: Economic issues will be crucial in the talks between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev off Malta this weekend.


Review/Art; Ryder and the Disciples Of His Poetic Vision
LEAD: In the work of Alfred Pinkham Ryder (1847-1917) there are images that, once seen, form part of a collective American folk-memory.
One such is ''The Race Track,'' now in the Cleveland Museum, in which a pale rider on a pale horse races round and round an empty racecourse for all eternity.
Another is ''Jonah'' in the National Museum of American Art in Washington, in which the sea that surrounds Jonah's boat is so convulsive we almost think he will be more comfortable inside the belly of the whale.


U.S. Role Seen on Japan Jets
LEAD: Two leading American companies have accepted an invitation from the Japanese Government to participate in a $195 million project to develop jet engines for supersonic passenger aircraft, industry sources said.

Rise of 11.5% In Taxi Fares Is Approved
LEAD: The New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission approved an 11.5 percent rise in yellow-cab fares yesterday, the first in a series of expected fare increases on public transportation systems in the New York metropolitan area.


Sale by Media General
LEAD: Freedom Newspapers Inc. of Irvine, Calif., has agreed to buy 30 weekly newspapers in Southern California from Media General Inc., Media General said this week.
No terms were disclosed.
The 30 papers have a circulation of 470,000 and are published in Orange County and eastern Los Angeles County by Golden West Publishing Inc., a Media General unit.


Injury Removes Carroll
LEAD: Joe Barry Carroll, the Nets' backup center, will be out for two to five weeks with a sprained left ankle.
Carroll hurt the ankle in the second quarter of Wednesday's 118-95 loss to Boston, when he slipped after making a turnaround jump shot.
X-rays showed no fracture, but Carroll will have further X-rays on


Troopers Union Joins Suit on Police Taping
LEAD: The Connecticut state police union today joined defense attorneys and others in a civil lawsuit against state police officials accused of secretly recording telephone calls made from police barracks.


Plea in Pentagon Fraud
LEAD: A former executive at a military contractor pleaded guilty today to conspiring to make illegal campaign contributions and to obstructing the F.B.I.'s investigation of Pentagon procurement fraud.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  SKIING  Swiss Wins Giant Slalom: Urs Kaelin of Switzerland won the giant slalom yesterday at Waterville Valley, N.H., for his first World Cup victory.
Kaelin overcame Lars-Boerje Eriksson of Sweden to win in a combined time of 2 minutes 38.49 seconds through 54 gates over hard-packed snow.
Eriksson, 15th after the first run, moved up with the fastest clocking of the second run, 1:20.91, for an overall time of 2:38.75.


Marvin S. Machson, Lawyer, 74
LEAD: Marvin S. Machson, a lawyer and arbitrator, died of prostate cancer Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mt.
Kisco, N.Y.
He was 74 years old and lived in Somers, N.Y.


2 Columbia Heads Give Key Duties to Lawyer
LEAD: Jon Peters and Peter Guber, the new co-chairmen of Columbia Pictures Entertainment Inc., started putting their imprint on the studio yesterday by naming their longtime lawyer, Alan J. Levine, to run most of the company.


Lawyer for Gambinos Is Guilty in Conspiracy
LEAD: A lawyer for the Gambino crime family was convicted yesterday on Federal racketeering conspiracy charges for helping drug dealers conceal their assets.


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
China International Trust and Investment Corp., Beijing, known as Citic, said it is negotiating to buy a stake in the Hong Kong airline Dragonair, formally known as Hong Kong Dragon Airlines.


Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in moderately active trading yesterday.
Market participants said they were particularly encouraged by a rise in initial unemployment claims for the week ended Nov. 18 and a drop in an index that serves as a proxy for manufacturing activity in the Chicago area, a monthly survey of purchasing managers.


Dow Rises 17.49 Points, To 2,706.27
LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rose moderately yesterday on continued light volume.
The broader market, while also up, gained less vigorously.


Americans Freed After Salvador Siege
LEAD: An American diplomat held at gunpoint in his home for more than 14 hours by leftist guerrillas was freed at dawn today when the rebels withdrew under a temporary cease-fire.


Construction Contracts Fall
LEAD: Contracting for new construction fell 6 percent in October as contracts for highway and bridge building declined sharply, according to a survey by the F. W. Dodge Group of the McGraw-Hill Information Services Company.


Auditor Quits a Company
LEAD: Clean Harbors Inc., a Quincy, Mass.. environmental services concern, disclosed today that Arthur Andersen &amp; Company had withdrawn as the company's auditors and that the accounting firm had found ''material weaknesses'' in the company's internal auditing controls.


Suit Is Filed By Ferranti
LEAD: The British military electronics company Ferranti, which has said it was victimized by fraud in its United States operations, said today that it had filed a lawsuit seeking nearly $400 million from former employees and associated companies.


Reviews/Film; On Vacation Once Again
LEAD: When Chevy Chase finds a good way to hurt himself in ''National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation,'' he generally tries it more than once.
The board that whacks him in the chin is liable to strike again.
Floors will collapse, ladders fall, Christmas trees come hurtling through windows.
The film's penchant for breakage jokes is rivaled only by its taste for gross-out humor, and for the kinds of double-entendres best appreciated by 7-year-old boys.


Owner of Huffington Plans to Sell Company
LEAD: Roy M. Huffington of Houston said today that he intends to sell his Huffington Corporation, a holding company with oil, gas and real estate interests that he started in 1958.
He did not name an asking price, but analysts said it could fetch close to $1 billion.


Rep. Brooks Out of Hospital
LEAD: Representative Jack Brooks of Texas, chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, was released from the Bethesda Naval Medical Center today, where he had been treated there since Oct. 22 for inflammation of the pancreas, his office announced.
The 66-year-old Congressman is expected to return to a full schedule, his staff said.


Prague's Drama Brings Tears in New Jersey City
LEAD: The night she first saw the television newscasts showing hundreds of thousands of people demonstrating for freedom in Czechoslovakia, Vera Hudak cried.


Mae West, Wilt and The King
LEAD: Although Kareem Abdul-Jabbar is now gone from the sports scene, having retired last season after his 20th year in the National Basketball Association, his career scoring record of 38,387 points still lives, and, many believe, may live forever.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 2, 1989
LEAD:  Markets


U.S. Seeking 'Honorable Exit' for Lebanese General
LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that they are working behind the scenes to help peacefully ease the Lebanese Christian army commander, Gen.
Michel Aoun, out of the presidential palace so that Lebanon's newly elected President can finally take charge.


Patents; A Robot Said to Learn Like a Baby
LEAD: A Massachusetts computer scientist patented his ''baby'' this week, a robot called Infant that he says is modeled on the way a human baby learns motor skills.


INSIDE
LEAD:  New Leader for India


Ransom H. Skeen, Executive, 88
LEAD: Ransom Harris Skeen, a retired executive of the Chase Manhattan Bank and Chase International Corporation, died of an aneurysm Thursday at Winter Park (Fla.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 88 years old and had lived in Bronxville, N.Y., for many years before moving to Winter Park in 1987.


Kellogg Outlook
LEAD: The Kellogg Company said it expects 1989 earnings to fall short of last year's record $3.90 a share.
The estimate excludes a gain from a change in accounting for income taxes put into effect in January that resulted in a one-time credit of $48.1 million, or 39 cents a share.
Kellogg said its ready-to-eat cereal sales in the United States continue to fall below expectations.


Time for You to Step Down, Mr. Ceausescu; Troops Out of Europe
LEAD: To the Editor:


NETS END A SLUMP BY ROUTING MIAMI
LEAD: After three agonizing weeks without winning, the Nets found nothing wrong tonight with their 101-77 victory over the Miami Heat.


Carpathians Were a Cradle of Scientists
LEAD: To the Editor:


Editors' Note
LEAD: A chronology on Wednesday under the headline ''An Outline of German History'' gave pivotal dates in the growth of German nationalism and the efforts toward unification since the early 19th century.
It amplified a report about the vision of reunification offered by Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.


When Opera Was a Lark: Six Divas Tell All
LEAD: Singing opera 50 years ago was a friendlier experience than it is today, and the scenery didn't upstage the singers, say the six divas who are to take part in the Met Marathon on radio this afternoon.


Chevrolet Rebate
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Chevrolet division said it had increased the rebate on 1989-90 full-size Blazer and Suburban light trucks to $1,000 from $750.
The increase is in effect until Feb. 2.
Chevrolet said it had also extended until Feb. 2 the $500 incentive on certain models of pickup trucks and its 1989 Astro van.


Beatrice Rosenberg; Prominent Attorney For the U.S. Was 81
LEAD: Beatrice Rosenberg, a lawyer who held high positions in the Federal Government and argued more than 30 cases before the Supreme Court, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Md.
She was 81 years old and had moved to Silver Spring from Washington two years ago.


The New Rush Hours: All Day Saturday
LEAD: More and more, drivers encounter the worst traffic congestion not during commuters' rush hours but on Saturdays, the day for errands and shopping.


UAL Up $12.50 On ESOP Talk
LEAD: The stock of the UAL Corporation rose $12.50 yesterday, to $174 a share, on reports that the company would soon begin talks with its unions and employees about putting together a new employee stock ownwership plan.
In a memo to employees, Paul George, senior vice president of human resources for the company, warned that putting together a new plan involved many ''uncertainties which may affect our ability to complete a new ESOP successfully.


Van Hits Toll-Taker, Races 6 Miles; Chase Ends as Driver Is Shot Dead
LEAD: A man who led authorities on a wild six-mile car chase after his van struck a police officer at the Brooklyn Battery Tunnel toll booths was shot dead as the chase ended on the Belt Parkway during the evening rush hour yesterday.


Dow Soars 41.38, to 2,747.65; Interest Rate Hopes a Factor
LEAD: Stock prices registered their biggest gain in weeks yesterday, buoyed by heavy foreign and institutional buying.


Patents; A System for Avoiding Aircraft Collisions
LEAD: Engineers at Bendix/King Air Transport Avionics, a division of Allied-Signal Inc., have obtained a patent for the heart of a new onboard aircraft collision avoidance system.


Two on Board Face Charges About Hiring
LEAD: Two officials of a local school board in Queens have been indicted on Federal and state charges of illegally using their positions to try to force the district Superintendent to place their relatives, political cronies and friends in school jobs, law-enforcement authorities announced yesterday.


Anniversary Tribute to Neediest Cases Fund
LEAD: In December 1939, Alfred I. Jaffe paid $2 for a license to marry Mimi Muschat. ''Several years ago, I decided to make my annual contribution a tribute to my wife on our anniversary,'' Mr.
Jaffe, who now lives in Somers, N.Y., wrote to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. ''I donated $2 for every year we were married, the $2 representing the original cost of our license.


Beckenbauer Leaving
LEAD: Franz Beckenbauer will quit as manager of the West German national team after the World Cup in Italy next year, the head of the West German soccer federation, Hermann Neuberger, said yesterday in Frankfurt.
Neuberger said Beckenbauer, who coached the team to a runner-up finish in the 1986 World Cup, would become a marketing executive for the federation.


Patents; An Alarm for Wallets
LEAD: Two Taiwanese inventors have patented a wallet containing a pickpocket alarm.
The wallet features electrical contacts on each side, both of which are connected to a small battery and alarm circuit.
If a pickpocket gets hold of the wallet on each side, his fingers close the circuit and trigger the alarm.


Perkin-Elmer Sale Fought
LEAD: Two members of Congress have asked President Bush to invoke a law that they co-sponsored to block the sale of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's semiconductor division to a Japanese company on the ground that it would jeopardize national security.


Innovative Steel Mill Is Off to a Slow Start
LEAD: These should have been heady days for F. Kenneth Iverson, chairman of the Nucor Corporation and a man celebrated for teaching Big Steel a thing or two about operating mills more efficiently.

LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about a mistrial in a sedition trial in Springfield, Mass., misstated the defendants' records.
Two defendants - Raymond Luc


Soccer Top 4 Are Stingy
LEAD: The semifinalists in the final four of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament, who will play Saturday at Rutgers Stadium, have combined for 45 shutouts this season.
Santa Clara (19-0-2), the only unbeaten team in the tournament, has 14 shutouts.
The team's goalie, Eric Yamamoto, has 13 of those and has allowed only 7 goals in 21 games.


U.N. Postpones Vote On Palestinian State
LEAD: Arab members of the United Nations agreed today to postpone until Monday a General Assembly vote on a resolution prepared by the Palestine Liberation Organization that would recognize the existence of a state of Palestine in the Israeli-occupied territories.


Alvin Ailey, a Leading Figure In Modern Dance, Dies at 58
LEAD: Alvin Ailey, who rose from a childhood of extreme poverty in the segregated world of small-town Texas to become a leading figure in the establishment of modern dance as a popular art form in America, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a long illness.
He was 58 years old.

Two Flyers Sign Again
LEAD: Mark Howe, a defenseman, and Derrick Smith, a left wing, signed new contracts with the Philadelphia Flyers yesterday.
The team did not disclose the terms, but Howe said he would earn $1.925 million over the next three years.


Reporter's Notebook; Must You Actually Read The Books to Give the Prize?
LEAD: Robert L. Heilbroner, the chairman of the nonfiction panel for this year's National Book Awards, evoked scattered murmurs and hisses at the awards ceremony on Wednesday when he said he had not read most of the 190 books submitted for the prize.
Instead, he said, he narrowed his selections with such shortcuts as reading the first and last pages of some books, looking at blurbs and examining the index and table of contents.


A Drug Dealer Gets a Sentence Of 7 Life Terms
LEAD: A 30-year-old drug dealer who ran one of the largest and most violent drug rings in Brooklyn and was responsible for 6 murders, 17 assaults, a kidnapping, a maiming and other crimes, was sentenced yesterday to seven consecutive life terms in Federal prison.


Dorothy E. Rowe, Venture Capitalist, 72
LEAD: Dorothy E. Rowe, former senior vice president of the American Research and Development Corporation, died Thursday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
She was 72 years old and lived in Boston.


Company Safety Scrutinized in Crane Collapse
LEAD: The company operating a crane that killed five people when it fell 16 stories in San Francisco on Tuesday had such a poor safety record that its own employees complained to state labor officials here about workplace hazards.


Becker And Lendl Advance
LEAD: The twin superpowers of men's tennis, Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, flicked away short-lived challenges from Stefan Edberg and John McEnroe last night to advance to the semifinals of the Masters with matching 3-0 records.
They completed the week with their egos in matching form as well.


China's Chile Investment
LEAD: The state-owned China Corporation for Agricultural Credit and Investment has bought a 25.6 percent share in a Chilean fishery for $18.6 million.
The move is the largest Chinese investment in Latin America, the People's Daily newspaper reported today.
It said the fishery produces 3.57 million boxes of canned fish a year.


'Very Happy' Comaneci Arrives in New York
LEAD: Three days after she stole across a closed border into Hungary, Nadia Comaneci, the Rumanian gymnast who captivated the world with a series of perfect performances at the 1976 Olympics, arrived in New York yesterday and explained why she had risked arrest to leave her homeland and come to the United States.


Search for Lobstermen Called Off
LEAD: The Coast Guard ended its search today for the five-member crew of a lobster boat that has been missing for 11 days.


5 Believed Dead in Crash of an Army Plane
LEAD: A twin-engine Army cargo plane with four crew members and a civilian on board crashed into a river this morning as it was approaching the Patuxent Naval Air Station near this southern Maryland community.
No survivors were found.


Not the First Coup, and Maybe Not the Last
LEAD: Throughout the fighting in the most serious armed challenge to the presidency of Corazon C. Aquino, no group or figure stepped forward to claim leadership of the rebellion.


Review/Ballet; 'Nutcracker' Recalls the Young Balanchine
LEAD: The New York City Ballet's exquisite production of ''The Nutcracker'' helped establish the ballet as a holiday tradition in America.
Why does the production, first presented in 1954, stand out so from the rest?


Serge Korff, Physicist, Dies at 83; Pioneer in Cosmic Ray Research
LEAD: Serge A. Korff, a physicist who led worldwide observations of cosmic rays in the 1940's and 1950's, using balloons, aircraft and mountaintop observatories, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a brief illness.
He was 83 years old.


For One Board Member, Limelight Is Nothing New
LEAD: For Samuel Granirer, a 48-year-old management consultant accused of extortion and bribery, yesterday was not the first time that his activities with his local school board in Queens had thrust him into the limelight.


Energy Prices Rise Sharply, With Surge in Heating Oil
LEAD: Prices of energy futures rose sharply yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Heating oil jumped more than 5 percent in the last three trading days of the week.


Complaints on Phone And Mail Orders Decline
LEAD: To the Editor: You state in ''Caveats on Ordering by Phone'' (Consumer's World page, Nov. 4) that ''Nationwide, mail and phone orders make up for the greatest number of complaints received by Better Business Bureaus.''


Abitibi Cutback
LEAD: Abitibi Price Inc. said it will close one of the three paper-making machines at its Grand Falls newsprint mill on March 1, terminating about 250 jobs.
The machine being closed was installed in 1926 and is no longer competitive in a weakening market for newsprint, the company said.


A $1.15 Token Now Supported By Transit Staff
LEAD: The staff of the New York City Transit Authority has revised a plan on subway and bus fares and is now proposing that the agency raise the price of a token to $1.15 from $1, but without offering discounts on bulk sales, a spokesman said last night.


Teen-Ager Slain Trying to Shield Brother From Bullies
LEAD: Arnulfo Williams Jr. was the kind of big brother most children would love.
He watched out for his two younger brothers, drove them to school in the morning and stood by them when they were threatened by other teen-agers on the violent streets of South Jamaica, Queens.


Killing of German Bank Chief Seen as Long in the Planning
LEAD: The bombing that killed Alfred Herrhausen, the head of West Germany's largest commercial bank, was a complicated attack, planned weeks in advance and executed with precision, the police said today.


Abu Nidal Was Born In British Palestine
LEAD: To the Editor:


Miniscribe Layoffs
LEAD: The Miniscribe Corporation said it will take a $40 million restructuring charge in its current quarter.
The company said the first step in its restructuring included the layoff of 110 employees.
It said it expects to lay off more employees at the beginning of March.
Miniscribe, a maker of disk drives for microcomputer systems, also said that once the restructuring was completed its Longmont headquarters would house only administrative and sales operations and all final assembly of products would be done at a plant in Singapore.


INDIAN OPPOSITION CHOOSES A PREMIER
LEAD: V. P. Singh won the unanimous backing of the victorious political opposition today and will be sworn in as the eighth Prime Minister of India at noon on Saturday, the office of the President said tonight.


Pinnacle Bid By Pacificorp
LEAD: Pacificorp, rebuffed in its effort to acquire a utility owned by the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, offered today to buy all of Pinnacle West.


Joseph Campbell Mixed Bigotry and Inspiration; His Anti-Semetism
LEAD: To the Editor: I am deeply grateful to Brendan Gill for detailing in public what many of us at Sarah Lawrence College privately knew all along about Joseph Campbell.
Because Campbell has been proposed as a sage for our times, it is particularly important for those of us who have a different estimate of the man and his work to speak up.


Navajo Chairman's Son Pleads Not Guilty
LEAD: The son of Peter MacDonald, the suspended Navajo chairman, pleaded not guilty to two counts of conspiracy today in a tribal court at which he had failed to appear for two arraignments last month.

LEAD: Dominick P. Felitti, a retired government official who worked at the city, state and Federal levels, died Wednesday at the St.
Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan.
He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan.

Also tied for first at 10-under 134 were Bill Britton and Donna White, Andy Bean and Laura Davies and Mike Hulbert and Val Skinner.(AP)

LEAD: President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived today on this Mediterranean island for a summit conference beginning on Saturday during which both hope to start the search for a new world order.

CZECH PARTY CALLS '68 INVASION WRONG
LEAD: The new Politburo of the Czechoslovak Communist Party declared today that the Soviet-led invasion that choked the Prague Spring of 1968 was wrong.


Your Money; How to Take Out I.R.A. Cash Early
LEAD: Many people in their 50's and 60's - and a few even younger - would do well to begin orderly withdrawals from their I.R.A.'s and other qualified retirement plans before the end of the year.
The accounts can provide needed cash for those who have taken early retirement, for example, and withdrawals can lower the long-term tax bite for those who have accumulated substantial sums.

Nynex Workers Return Monday
LEAD: Striking Nynex telephone workers yesterday ratified a contract negotiated last week, ending a strike that began in August.
The workers are planning to return to work on Monday.

LEAD: Frank Cardi, a former president of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers' Association, died on Thursday at his home in West Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 56 years old.


Bridge
LEAD: Intercollegiate competition is showing welcome signs of revival in New York City.
A five-team event was played on Sept. 27 at the Beverly Club, 130 East 57th Street in Manhattan, and two City College teams tied for first place.


Taylor's Ankle Is Broken, but He Feels Better
LEAD: The Giants' Lawrence Taylor has a broken right ankle, two sources with the team disclosed today.
At the same time, in what seemed to be a contradiction, Coach Bill Parcells upgraded the linebacker's availability from out to doubtful for the game here Sunday against the Philadelphia Eagles.


Corrections
LEAD: Two tables yesterday showing arms levels in Eastern and Western Europe, part of a page of charts giving background to the summit meeting in Malta, were described incompletely.
The left-hand table labeled ''Conventional Arms'' gave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's estimate and the Warsaw Pact's estimate of European military strength in NATO countries.


Alan Bowne, Writer, 44
LEAD: Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home outside Petaluma, Calif.
He was 44 years old.


HomeFed to Lift Loan-Loss Fund
LEAD: The HomeFed Corporation, parent company of the HomeFed Bank, said it will add $115 million to its loan-loss provisions in the fourth quarter. ''These general allowances will provide HomeFed greater flexibility to reduce its level of nonperforming assets and restructure its loan and real estate portfolios,'' said Kim Fletcher, chairman of the San Diego-based savings and loan association.


Review/Music; A Pianist's Russian Flair
LEAD: For his first recital at Carnegie Hall, on Tuesday night, the pianist Yefim Bronfman seemed to be staking a claim to the sort of sober, serious Germanic repertory long championed by Rudolf Serkin and, before him, Artur Schnabel.
But curiously, after a deft opening Haydn sonata, his most successful outing came at the end, with Stravinsky's Three Movements from ''Petrushka.


Saying No To Good News
LEAD: Network news people say the biggest good-news story of the modern age, which is the story of Communism's falling dominoes, is box-office poison.
TV ratings depict Americans tuning out in droves despite television's wonderfully moving pictures of freedom sweeping everything before it.


Councilman Williams
LEAD: So that Reggie Williams would not have to miss a practice for tomorrow's key game with the Cleveland Browns, the Cincinnati Bengals staged a City Council swearing-in ceremony at their training site yesterday.
The veteran linebacker was sworn in as an elected member of the Council in a conference room at the Bengals' field because he could not spare the time to attend the official swearing-in at City Hall with the eight other council members.

LEAD: Federal prosecutors said today that they would not retry three people they called dangerous underground militants, ending the case more than three years and millions of dollars after it started.

Patents; A Means That May Aid In Diagnosing Cancer
LEAD: Probing the nucleus of human cells, two scientists in Massachusetts have patented a technology they believe makes it easier to diagnose cancer.


Abortion Foes Get Offer To Hear Clinic Patients
LEAD: The owner of a much-picketed birthing center here that also does abortions has invited anti-abortion leaders to come inside to talk with his patients in counseling sessions rather than scream slogans at them outside.


Purchasers Say Economy Worsens
LEAD: The economy, hurt by declines in production, new orders and employment, continued to deteriorate in November for the seventh consecutive month, the National Association of Purchasing Management reported yesterday as it released its monthly index of economic activity.


Measured Mission in Manila
LEAD: President Bush made a timely and sensible call when he sent American warplanes on ''combat air patrol'' in the Philippines yesterday.
The mission served as a deterrent, helping President Corazon Aquino's democratic Government fight off a dangerous military rebellion while conforming to principled American policy.


U.S. Says Bush Used Fighter Jets To Save Aquino From Rebel Siege
LEAD: President Bush took the unusual step of ordering American aircraft into action against Philippine rebel forces after he was advised that President Corazon C. Aquino was in danger of being overthrown, Administration officials said today.


Hassan Fathy, Architect, 89
LEAD: Hassan Fathy, an Egyptian architect who championed the use of indigenous construction techniques to build housing for the world's poor, died Thursday in Cairo, the Associated Press reported.
He was 89 years old.


Christians in the Soviet Union
LEAD: About half the Soviet Union's 286 million people profess a religious affiliation.
In addition to the groups cited below, there are 40 million to 50 million Muslims, 1.8 million to 2 million Jews and 665,000 Buddhists.
Figures for adherents are Western estimates.
RUSSIAN ORTHODOX: 50-60 million adherents

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Serving Game Birds
LEAD:  Game birds, extremely lean and low in fat, are becoming increasingly popular, especially for holiday meals.
Those sold at retail or served in restaurants are raised on farms or ranches and do not have a strong, ''gamey'' flavor.
It's illegal to sell domestically hunted game, but a small amount of shot game is coming in from Scotland, particularly grouse and pheasant.


Thornburgh Asks Stiff Civil Fines In Cases of Small Drug Amounts
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh proposed regulations today that would allow the Government to impose civil fines of up to $10,000 for possessing small amounts of marijuana and other illegal drugs for personal use.

LEAD: Ahmadou Ahidjo, who served as President of the West African nation of Cameroon for 22 years after it won independence from France in 1960, then fled into exile in 1983, died on Thursday in Dakar, Senegal, according to a French radio report quoted by the Reuters news agency.

PHOTOGRAPHY
LEAD: This is the year of the sesquicentennial of photography's entry into the world, and to mark the occasion a number of shows were mounted.
These in turn led to the publication of several books-cum-catalogues that offer quick courses in the history of photography.
Foremost among them are ''On the Art of Fixing a Shadow'' (discussed below), ''The Art of Photography 1839-1989'' (Yale University), ''Decade by Decade: Twentieth-Century American Photography'' (Bulfinch/Little, Brown) and, in a vanguard vein, ''The Photography of Invention: American Pictures of the 1980s'' (MIT).

And Now, a Few Words From Jenny Holzer
LEAD: ONE OF THE MOST UBIQUITOUS PRESENCES ON THE current art scene is a 39-year-old maverick named Jenny Holzer, a tricky impresario of language who makes words into visual spectaculars.
A writer who doesn't think the printed page is ''enough of a forum,'' Holzer hatches messages that range from deadpanned aphorisms to dark meditations about the human condition, embosses them on plaques, engraves them on marble or granite benches and sarcophagus lids and - with skilled technological choreography - sets them prancing in dazzles of colored light.

Review/Music; The Ecco Trio in Recital
LEAD: The Ecco Trio found a perfect balance of the familiar and the unusual in its Weill Recital Hall program on Wednesday evening.
Of the three works the ensemble played, only the Schubert Trio in B flat (Op. 99), which took up the second half of the concert, was drawn from the standard literature.
Before the intermission, the group offered two tonal, melodic and traditionally structured 20th-century works, both of which would make worthy additions to any piano trio's repertory.

COOKING
LEAD: As many times as I have read the instruction to ''brown the meat well,'' I never understood even so simple a requirement until one day I got the chance to watch a real cook do it.
Then I caught on: browning it well meant browning it well - not just giving up in relief as the poorly aged, watery meat finally turned from gray to a sort of beige.

Kids in Paris
LEAD: To the Editor: Your section had an article about a 5-year old child who went to Paris with his parents (''Child's Play in Paris,'' Travel, Oct. 15).
Is this really an amazing thing?
I'm 10 years old and when I was 6 I traveled around France and England with my parents and my 9-year-old brother.
I don't see what the big deal about this kid is.

Installing Shut-Off Valves in Pipes
LEAD: ONE annoyance frequently found in older homes, and sometimes even in homes that are not so old, is the lack of shut-off valves beneath plumbing fixtures.
Shut-off valves permit turning off the water supply to individual fixtures like sinks, tubs and toilets without having to shut off the main water supply or large sections of household plumbing.

Campione d'Italia
LEAD: To the Editor: The article by Paul Hofmann on Campione d'Italia (''Campione: Italy's Little Vegas,'' Travel, Sept. 10) brought back a treasured memory.
In July 1946 I was released from the British Army after serving four and a half years.
My government gave me $:100 and a navy blue suit.
Two weeks later my wife and I set out for Lugano.

'I Felt So Alone'
LEAD: I WAS divorced on a stormy day.
The radio blared flood alerts and warnings.
I had tossed about the bed during a mostly sleepless night.
I missed her so.
I used to get up an hour earlier than she did.
I would drive to the country store to pick up the newspaper and return, have it read, my cereal and banana eaten, and my huge cup of coffee drunk when she would stagger up the stairs to my study.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Nov. 19 about a plan by two former state insurance commissioners to sell automobile insurance below current market rates misstated the effect on policyholders from potential losses.
James J. Sheeran, one former commissioner, said a $750,000 surplus would be maintained to shield policyholders from losses; the losses would not be shared with policyholders.

Fishing for Shrimp in Flanders
LEAD: IN the North Sea on the Flanders coast, Belgium's gray shrimp are caught beneath an almost perpetually gray sky.
The bulk of them are harvested by boat, but at Oostduinkerke, shrimp fishermen on horseback still drag their nets at low tide to scoop up these tiny glistening delicacies.
A basketful of gray shrimp can be a comically monstrous sight; each shrimp is less than an inch long and, before they are cleaned, all appear weirdly mustached.

LEAD: Seeing a chance to open more than a half-mile of prime Manhattan waterfront as public parkland, a coalition of three civic groups has advanced a proposal to rebuild the elevated West Side Highway at ground level, on the former railroad yard where Trump City is proposed.

Must You Shout Into My Hearing Aid?
LEAD: WHENEVER I go to my hairdresser, I remind him not to cut my side hair too short because I want to keep my hearing aid out of sight.
I do this so as not to embarrass others rather than to hide my hearing impairment.
When people notice I have something in my ear, they either look away or pretend that they do not see it.

'Georgia O'Keeffe: A Life'
LEAD: To the Editor:


New Fires Burn In Korea's Kilns
LEAD: SOUTH KOREA'S centuries-old kilns, out of operation for more than 50 years, are going full blast again.
Shut down during the Japanese occupation (1910-1945) and throughout the Korean War, the pottery centers reopened one by one after the war ended in 1953, as the country undertook rebuilding and reclaiming its 5,000-year-old culture.

LEAD: The chairman of the House Select Committee on Aging is renewing his attack on a Federal rule that prohibits pilots from flying jetliners after they turn 60 years old.

LEAD: Elaborate, large-format - which is to say expensive - architecture books this year seem to fall into two categories: monographs on the work of a particular architect, of which there are fewer than in recent years, and generic books on particular styles or types of buildings, of which there are many more.

Strung Up
LEAD: IT MIGHT JUSTIFIABLY BE called a cable car, but it is equally fitting that the device supporting the workmen who are replacing 177,000 feet of steel cable on the Brooklyn Bridge is known as a spider.
Unlike, say, the Williamsburg Bridge, just up the East River, which is supported by vertical cables, or other spans, which employ a system of diagonal stays, the Brooklyn Bridge has both.

Installing Shut-Off Valves in Pipes
LEAD: ONE annoyance frequently found in older homes, and sometimes even in homes that are not so old, is the lack of shut-off valves beneath plumbing fixtures.
Shut-off valves permit turning off the water supply to individual fixtures like sinks, tubs and toilets without having to shut off the main water supply or large sections of household plumbing.

INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS
LEAD: I feel intimidated by these tales of people who find the experience of having cancer to be a source of inspiration and personal growth.
I suspect that most ordinary mortals would fall short of this ideal.
I suspect that this presentation of critical illness as a path to growth through adversity gives a patient unreasonable models and is likely to encourage friends and family to react unsympathetically when one fails to measure up.

PITCHING DOCTORS
LEAD: Every time I read another doctor-bashing article in your magazine, I wonder why you don't provide space for a rebuttal from the other side.

Physicians rely on their own experience, on other physicians' advice and on the literature.

A Europe no longer of disparate, strange, even feuding countries, but one happy family of nations living in harmony and sharing a common culture.

Some doggy Japanese debt he's holding as a favor to another trader is blotting his performance record.

Review/Film; Stories of Manhattan By Student Directors
LEAD: Short films are so pitilessly noncommercial that they become havens of freedom; film makers might as well give up any idea of reaching a large audience and do the most wildly inventive work they can.
The exception to this rule occurs in film schools, where fledgling producers, directors, writers and cinematographers put together brief films commonly known as ''calling cards'' to the industry, meant to show agents and producers that these students have become professionals.

LEAD: To the Editor: We spent part of last summer in Montana's Glacier National Park and Waterton Lakes National Park in Alberta, Canada.

Question Of the Week; Is There Bounty Hunting in The N.F.L.?
LEAD: Pro football is one of two sports (boxing is the other) where physical destruction of your opponents pays such big dividends that bounty hunters will soon be replaced by body counters.
Who orders it?
We do.
Every time we boo our losses.
Who pays it?
We do.
Every time we buy from television sponsors.

On the Scaffolds, a Delicate Labor in the Duomo
LEAD: The aluminum-shafted elevator slowly makes its 196-foot climb from the floor of the Duomo to the base of the 16-level scaffolding that rings the interior of Filippo Brunelleschi's cupola.
The scaffolding has been in place for nearly 10 years, its green and gray safety netting concealing the 10,500-square-foot surface of frescoes by Giorgio Vasari and Federico Zuccari.

Installing Shut-Off Valves in Pipes
LEAD: ONE annoyance frequently found in older homes, and sometimes even in homes that are not so old, is the lack of shut-off valves beneath plumbing fixtures.
Shut-off valves permit turning off the water supply to individual fixtures like sinks, tubs and toilets without having to shut off the main water supply or large sections of household plumbing.

Fashion; Hats With a Sense of History
LEAD: Uptown or downtown, the newest hats combine warmth with whimsical historical flourishes, preferably those of old England.

LEAD: EARLY BIRDS are an acquired taste that you should cultivate if you're visiting your folks in Florida this winter.

As an Official Guest, you'll eat Early Birds, too, so start training now, before heading south.

ART
LEAD: The price of books on art has been rising steadily, though by no means as fast as the price of some kinds of art at auction.

Pastimes; Aroung the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: If old flower stalks of perennials are still standing, cut them to near ground level.
Don't forget to move hoses inside and shut off outdoor faucets for winter.
Also, the power tools should be cleaned and stored, especially mowers.
Apply anti-desiccant sprays any time this month to conifers, rosebushes and broadleaved evergreens to cut down on drying out; the colorless material wears off in a few months and may need to be re-applied in February.

This armchair gardener has found comfort in a winter book harvest that is certain to brighten the wait until spring.  *

LEAD: More than a million East Germans are expected to pour into the Western half of the divided former capital and across the West German border this weekend, the first of the holiday shopping season.

LEAD: SOMETIMES losing an enemy can be more unsettling than losing a friend.
The world order that since the end of World War II has shaped American politics, its view of the world and itself has suddenly come crashing down.

LEAD: CONSTRUCTION has begun on Tower Place, a $60 million retail mall in the center of downtown that will make two existing department stores on adjacent blocks - Saks Fifth Avenue and McAlpins - the mall's anchors.
They will be linked to the mall by skywalks.

No-Show Decision
LEAD: For more than two years, Manfred Ohrenstein, minority leader of the New York State Senate, has served under the cloud of an indictment for using the legislative payroll to hire full-time campaign workers.
The fraud and grand larceny charges against the powerful Democrat should have been resolved long ago.


Outdoors; Drawing a Bead on Gun Safety
LEAD: Shooting accidents have been markedly reduced throughout the country in the last decade, and much of this can be attributed to the hunter-education courses now required of first-time license holders in most states.


Marijuana in Bus Driver's Bag
LEAD: The driver of a chartered bus on which two ABC executives were killed when it was struck by a commuter train last Monday had about five grams of marijuana in his possession, the police said Friday.
They said the driver, Patrick Cang, 34 years old, had a carrying case on his bus that contained the marijuana and a pipe.


Biotechnology Poised for Breakthroughs
LEAD: ''THIS lab is bugged,'' reads the hand-lettered sign on the door of Eugene Premuzic's laboratory at Brookhaven National Laboratory in Upton.
The bugs in question are not transmitters for clandestine eavesdropping, but micro-organisms for cleaning up toxic geothermal energy byproducts.


A Cautionary Guide for Little Customers
LEAD: Television commercials for children are not kid stuff.
About $500 million a year is spent promoting toys, games, foods and other goodies to young consumers.
There may be two sides to the question of whether any advertising is appropriate on programs aimed at grade-schoolers and under, but nobody is likely to take public exception to the principle that youngsters should not be fooled by adults.

Mr.

Review/Music; Tom Harrell on Trumpet
LEAD: The trumpeter Tom Harrell's first set at the Village Vanguard on Wednesday night began in earnest halfway through.
With Joe Lovano on soprano saxophone and Mr.
Harrell on fluegelhorn, the band picked up some speed and finally began playing as an ensemble.
Using arrangements by Mr.
Harrell - he makes careful use of repeating patterns for the rhythm section - the band began abstracting the basic material of the tunes, using it as fuel for improvisation.

LEAD: To the Editor: On a recent trip to Greece I had an experience that I would like to share with your readers.
In ancient Olympia I saw a copy of a Cretan bull in a shop window.
A young man in the shop told me that he was the artist and that it was his signature painted on the underside of the bull.
I told him I would buy the piece, whereupon he disappeared into a basement where,

The Banker Who Would Be Scrooge
LEAD: AT 10 O'CLOCK ON THE MORNING OF OCT. 17, CARL E. REICHARDT, the chairman and chief executive of Wells Fargo &amp; Company, presided over a meeting of the board of directors in the Sheraton Grand Hotel in Los Angeles.
He had nothing but good news to report for the third quarter.
Net income would be strong (the final figures showed it at $153.7 million, a 17-percent rise over the 1988 figure) and costs, one of the chairman's obsessions, were well in hand.


Care and Heeding of Knee Injuries
LEAD: PROBABLY no injury is as debilitating to an athlete as one involving a knee.
And this is the time of the year when athletes have already begun or are about to return to the slopes.
Although other sports - indoor tennis, squash and racquetball to name three - are often associated with knee damage, skiing is perhaps the most demanding on gimpy knees.

The Editorial Notebook; European Marxism, 1848-1989
LEAD: ''A specter is haunting Europe -the specter of Communism,'' wrote Karl Marx in January 1848.
It took a century for that red specter to become iron gray reality in Eastern Europe.
Yet just weeks after the 29-year-old German philosophy student wrote those words, Europe was swamped by a continental wave of liberal, nationalist revolutions.

Salomon Sues State
LEAD: Salomon Brothers Inc. filed a $150 million countersuit last week against West Virginia in Federal court here.
The state had sued Salomon, County NatWest Government Securities Inc. and three other firms in October, blaming them for $279 million in losses suffered by the state's consolidated investment fund in 1987-89.

Question Box
LEAD:  No Heisman for Brown  Q. Before Jim Brown became a great running back for the Cleveland Browns, he was a star at Syracuse, but he was never voted the Heisman Trophy as the country's outstanding college player.
How close did he get?
A.
Not close enough to call for a measurement.
In 1956, Brown's senior year at Syracuse, he barely cracked the top five among Heisman finishers, earning a little more than half the point total accumulated by the winner, Paul Hornung, quarterback at Notre Dame.

Eric S. Purdon, retired, who commanded one of the ships that helped integrate blacks into the Navy's regular ranks, died of prostate cancer Saturday at his home in the Annapolis suburb of Harwood, Md.
He was 76 years old.

LEAD: After eight years in exile, Eden Pastora Gomez, the renegade Sandinista hero and former contra leader, returned to Nicaragua today, vowing to forge a ''third path'' in the country's polarized political life.


100 Chinese Defy a Ban
LEAD: About 100 Chinese today defied a Government ban on ''English Corner,'' a glade in a Beijing park where people have gathered for years to practice English-language skills with foreigners.
Cordons sealed off the glade, in the Purple Bamboo Park, which has served as a Sunday venue, and official notices nearby proclaimed that ''English Corner has been withdrawn.


Eagles Turn Giants' Mistakes Into a 24-17 Victory
LEAD: The Giants gave it away today.
They let the Philadelphia Eagles score all their points off four interceptions and fumbles, and when they fought back to tie the score, they let their chances slip away.


Books of The Times; Mamet's Freaks and Psychology
LEAD:  Some Freaks  By David Mamet  180 pages. Viking. $16.95.


The Malta Summit; ECONOMIC PLEDGES CHEER SOVIET AIDES
LEAD: Pleased Soviet officials said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had achieved his major goal at the summit meeting: a critically needed turn away from economic cold war by President Bush.


Walesa Prods British to Invest
LEAD: Lech Walesa urged Britain today to seize business opportunities created by the wave of change in Eastern Europe.
Ending a five-day visit, Mr.
Walesa, a founder of the Polish union Solidarity, said at a news conference that while West Germany had 380 companies operating in Poland, Britain had only 10 or 15.


Officials Begin Seeking Wreckage of Fishing Boat
LEAD: Coast Guard officials began searching yesterday for the wreckage of a 110-foot charter-fishing boat that sank Saturday afternoon near the entrance to New York Harbor, killing two people.
Coast Guard radio broadcasts warned mariners of the approximate location of the submerged ship, which could pose a hazard for harbor traffic.


Reviews/Music; The Jazz Generation Pays Tribute to Jimi Hendrix
LEAD: Jimi Hendrix receives a tribute, acknowledged or not, in virtually every hard-rock guitar solo.
A different kind of tribute took place on Friday night at Town Hall, where members of the jazz generation that grew up in the rock era played their own arrangements - usually radical reworkings - of Hendrix songs.

Aggravating Is Kind Word
LEAD: IN all his important games as the Giants' quarterback, Phil Simms had never made so many costly mistakes as he did yesterday.
His second fumble positioned what turned out to be the Philadelphia Eagles' decisive touchdown in a 24-17 victory.
His first fumble created the Eagles' first touchdown.
When he was intercepted later in the first quarter, Clyde Simmons returned it 60 yards for the Eagles' second touchdown.

Richard R. Salzman, Editor, 69
LEAD: Richard R. Salzmann, the editor in chief of the Research Institute of America, publisher of tax guides, from 1965 until he retired in 1985, died of a heart ailment on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M.
He was 69 years old and had lived for many years in Pound Ridge, N.Y.


Reviews/Television; Mixing Fact and Fiction In Howard Beach Case
LEAD: Early on the morning of Dec. 20, 1986, three black men from Brooklyn were walking through Howard Beach, a nearly all-white part of Queens, after their car broke down nearby.
An auto with several local teen-agers approached; racial slurs were exchanged.
Shortly afterward, a dozen young whites, brandishing a baseball bat and screaming racial curses, set upon the men and chased them through the neighborhood.

They never even took their coats off.
Their cozy Saturday dinner and their Sunday stroll on deck were called because of rain.

Clamor in Europe; All Leaders of East German Communist Party Quit
LEAD: The East German Communist Party leadership under Egon Krenz collapsed today after a mounting wave of popular anger at its close identification with abuses under Erich Honecker, who was ousted as party leader last month.


85-Mile California Quake
LEAD: A moderate earthquake under the San Jacinto Mountains was felt in an 85-mile stretch of southern California Saturday, but there were no reports of damage or injury.
The temblor came at 3:16 P.M. and measured 4.3 on the Richter scale of ground motion, a California Institute of Technology spokesman said at Pasadena.

LEAD: Laura Shapiro dealt with interesting themes in a program of new solo dances on Friday night at the Dia Art Foundation.
The simplicity of her theatrical touches and choreography was just right for the development of those themes.
But the most compelling ingredient in the work was Miss Shapiro's own presence - quiet, intelligent and nicely down to earth.

LEAD: Jonas Savimbi, the leader of the rebel movement in Angola, said tonight that he was ready to sign an immediate cease-fire agreement with the Angolan Government.


Metro Datelines; Man, 74, Found Dead, Gagged With Tape
LEAD: A 74-year-old Brooklyn man whose eyes, mouth, hands and feet had been bound with tape was found dead in his Coney Island apartment, the police said.


Exports Rise for 3 Nations
LEAD: The world's three largest trading nations all showed a big increase in the value of their exports in the first half of the year, compared with the first six months of 1988, the International Monetary Fund reported today.


Coup Fails, Manila Says Amid Fighting
LEAD: The Government said Sunday that it had quelled the military rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino after three and a half days of fighting that killed about 100 people and wounded 300 others.


Critic's Notebook; A Film Festival With the Spirit of Margaret Mead
Gods, shamans, peasants and chorus girls populate the works at the Margaret Mead Film Festival, which begins today and runs through Thursday at the American Museum of Natural History.
The annual festival, named for the influential anthropologist, may suggest endless accounts of Samoan initiation rites.
But the 48 nonfiction films to be shown are eclectic enough to include Hindu pilgrims, rangers at Yosemite National Park and a Chinese-American bubble dancer.
A sampling of the films (most of which run about an hour) suggests that several are models of innovative documentary film making, while in many others flabbergasting images fight with the sort of droning voice-overs that give documentaries a bad name.


Clamor in Europe; Czech Emigres Hail Events, but Enjoy Life in U.S.
LEAD: Prominent Czechoslovak emigres in the United States praised the political upheaval in their homeland in interviews last week but for the most part said they would continue to live in this country.


Onetime Abortion Foe Isn't So Sure Anymore
LEAD: In his first three years in the Illinois General Assembly, Representative William B. Black was counted a consistent enemy of abortion.
When the issue came to the floor, he voted with abortion foes nine times out of 10.


Browns Are Beaten By Bengals, 21-0
LEAD: Boomer Esiason threw two touchdown passes, including a 38-yarder to Tim McGee on a trick play, as the Cincinnati Bengals revived their playoff hopes with their first shutout since 1980, beating the Browns, 21-0, today.


Clamor in Europe; Czech Students Belatedly Assail China Crackdown
LEAD: In a belated expression of sympathy, several thousand Czechoslovak students marched here today to protest the violent suppression of China's pro-democracy movement in June.


Strife Over Style and Substance Tests Princeton's Leader
LEAD: When Harold T. Shapiro left the University of Michigan two years ago to become president of Princeton University, he brought with him no small burden of expectations.
An economist who, as president, had steered Michigan through a time of financial hardship, he arrived here after an unusually brief search and to a chorus of praises.


A Ring Rivalry That Won't Die
LEAD: THE fight defies the laws of probability.
Back in 1980, when they last boxed, what soothsayer would have had the gall to prophesy that nine years later Roberto Duran and Sugar Ray Leonard would still matter enough to generate big-fight excitement one more time?


Abraham Neuwirth, Retired Educator, 73
LEAD: Abraham Neuwirth, the superintendent of the Bellmore, L.I., school district from 1967 to 1982, when he retired, died Saturday in a Great Neck, L.I., nursing center.
He was 73 years old and had homes in Great Neck and in Alford, Mass.


Richard W. Welch, 69, A Top Boeing Executive
LEAD: Richard W. Welch, who rose from accounting clerk to president of the Boeing Company's commercial aircraft division, died last Tuesday of a neurological disease.
He was 69 years old.


Hong Kong Journal; Sad Flotsam, the Boat People Must Drift Home
LEAD: Hong Kong, straining to house the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people who have arrived in the last 18 months, is making final arrangements to force them to return to the country they risked their lives to escape.


Women Say They Face Obstacles as Lawyers
LEAD: Women at the nation's largest law firms say that although they believe their pay equals that of their male counterparts, they lack the same chances for top job assignments, litigation experience and promotions.


Gold Seen as Barrier to Fall in Interest Rates
LEAD: A sharp rise in gold prices, often viewed as a harbinger of a rising inflation rate, may inhibit further declines in long-term interest rates for the balance of the year, some analysts contend.


New Harvard Business Review Chief
LEAD: Rosabeth Moss Kanter, a Harvard Business School expert in organizational behavior and a noted management consultant, took over the top editorial job at The Harvard Business Review on Friday, succeeding Theodore Levitt, who will return to teaching.


Revised UAL Plan Seen
LEAD: Three unions of United Airlines have met with officials of its parent company, the UAL Corporation, to draft a revised employee-led buyout proposal, a company spokesman said today, and the carrier's flight attendants said a new offer would come this week.


The Budget Fix Needs Fixing
LEAD: The 1985 Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law was supposed to eliminate Federal deficits by next October.
It won't.
Worse, the law distorts budget decisions, encourages deceit and risks turning recession into disaster.


Man Is Held in Youth's Killing
LEAD: The police have charged a 24-year-old man in the slaying of Preston (Little Man) Simmons, a 14-year-old marijuana peddler, on Thanksgiving Day in the sprawling East Bronx housing project where both lived.


Lebanese General's Allies Confer
LEAD: Commanders loyal to Gen.
Michel Aoun, the Maronite Catholic military leader who refuses to recognize the country's new Government, met today to coordinate their forces in the face of a possible attack by Syrian troops to dislodge the defiant general from the presidential palace.
