LEAD: The opposition Democratic Progressive Party today expressed strong satisfaction with its showing in elections on Saturday, and said its performance would have been more impressive if it were not for vote buying and election fraud.

LEAD: Perhaps the boldest single project envisioned during the last decade of China's economic restructuring was a plan to copy the success of Hong Kong, 300 miles to the northeast, here on southern China's Hainan Island.

LEAD: George Zahringer 3d has been the most successful amateur golfer of the decade in the New York metropolitan area, thanks primarily to the teaching of Jim McLean, the head professional at Sleepy Hollow Country Club Scarborough, N.Y.

LEAD: Four days after a group of enraged black men knocked down a 14-by-16-foot painting of a white-skinned, blond, blue-eyed Jesse Jackson, Mr.
Jackson made a visit today to see the portrait for himself and found it inoffensive.

LEAD: The low ratings and shortage of hit programs at CBS Inc. have posed problems for advertisers dependent on reaching mass audiences increasingly drawn to videocasette recorders, cable television and other entertainment media.
On Friday, the day after the network's chief programming executive, Kim LeMasters, announced his resignation, several leading advertising agency media executives were asked what advice they would give the new program head.

Mortgage Rates Steady
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 9.74 percent last week, unchanged from the previous week, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders asked an average initial rate of 8.46 percent last week, down from 8.47 percent the week before.

But just as Mr.
Gershon was reaching for the door, a man darted out from behind him and leaped in.

Bridge
LEAD: There is little doubt that New York City could defeat any other city in the world in a match between women's teams.
Of the 16 living women who have earned the grandmaster rank of the World Bridge Federation, five live in New York City, and five other New York women are currently world titleholders.

LEAD: Students at Wake Forest University agree that Timothy W. Bell acted heroically last June when he carried videotape of the Tiananmen Square massacre out of China.

LEAD: Lawrence Taylor played for the Giants today on what the club said was a hairline fracture at the base of his right tibia.

LEAD: Responding to intensified protests by animal-rights advocates, the American fur industry has begun its first national advertising campaign in an attempt to reassure consumers that no one has the right to take away their ''freedom to buy and wear fur.''

Business Scene; Chrysler Loses Industry Rhythm
LEAD: ''THERE are rhythms in the auto industry, and Chrysler is out of sync with them today,'' says Raymond Vernon, a Harvard Business School professor.
The current rhythm rewards the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company because they have big operations in Europe, where profits are easier to come by than in the United States.

LEAD: The Rangers' 6-0 loss to the Los Angeles Kings was just minutes old, and the silence in the visiting team's locker room was split only by the angry rip of tape as the players tore it from their ankles and wrists.

Mr.
Mead had supervised the Toyota Motor Corporation account as creative director of Saatchi &amp; Saatchi/Southern

Subway Service Still Disrupted On Five Lines
LEAD: Service on four IND subway lines and the JFK Express will remain disrupted at least through the middle of the week because of a water main that ruptured and flooded a subway station in Harlem over the weekend, a spokesman for the Transit Authority said yesterday.

Congress Report Tells of Security Lapses at Nuclear Weapons Plant
LEAD: A secret inspection of the Lawrence Livermore nuclear weapons laboratory in California turned up serious security lapses last spring, including poor protection of plutonium, a Congressional report shows.


Toyota Recalls A Lexus Model
LEAD: The Toyota Motor Corporation confirmed on Saturday that it is recalling all 8,000 of the Lexus LS 400 cars that it has sold in the United States to correct three problems.


DEALS
LEAD:  BASEBALL  MILWAUKEE (AL) - Signed Dave Parker, designated hitter, to a two-year contract.

Named Jim Wright pitching coach of Scranton-Wilkes-Barre of the International League.
SAN FRANCISCO (NL) - Named Larry Hardy pitching coach and Tim Ireland assistant pitching coach of Phoenix of the Pacific Coast League.


Malta Seeks to Fill Beirut's Shoes
LEAD: The Republic of Malta, a crossroads between East and West long before the summit meeting of President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is promoting itself as a new international financial center, to fill the role once played by Beirut, Lebanon.


Sri Lankan Rebels Kill 17 Soldiers in Ambush
LEAD: Ethnic Tamil rebels ambushed an army truck and killed 17 Sinhalese soldiers today in the Vavuniya district about 110 miles north of Colombo, a military official reported.


National Magazines Challenge Local Publications for Ads
LEAD: The technology that has given national magazines the ability to split their circulation into hundreds of editions is also beginning to give city and regional magazines anxiety about a possible loss of advertising.


U.S. Grants Aquino's Military Quick Sale of Anti-Tank Arms
LEAD: Fearing that Philippine soldiers loyal to the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino were losing ground again, the Bush Administration granted a Philippine request late Saturday for the quick sale and transfer of hundreds of anti-tank weapons from American bases to Mrs.
Aquino's forces, officials said today.

Prudential-Bache
LEAD: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has raised the commissions it charges individual customers by about 3 percent, a spokesman for the firm said yesterday.
The move was viewed by industry analysts as a reflection of the continued pressure on retail brokerages' profits.
Prudential-Bache has also informed its 6,500 retail brokers that it was reducing the amount of commission revenue it shares with its lowest-producing brokers.


Stocks Extend Gain as Dow Advances 5.98
LEAD: Stock prices extended their gains yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average advanced 5.98 points, to 2,753.63.


Bush Asks Aquino to Insure Safety of Americans
LEAD: President Bush called President Corazon C. Aquino of the Philippines tonight to express concern for the safety of some 200 United States citizens trapped in Manila hotels occupied by rebel soldiers, a White House official said.


Service for Alvin Ailey
LEAD: A memorial service for Alvin Ailey, founder and director of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, will be held on Friday at 10:30 A.M. at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, 112th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.
Mr.
Ailey died of a blood disorder last Friday at the age of 58.

LEAD: A showdown between three Pentecostal ministers and a prosecutor over the confidentiality of a burglary suspect's confession in church ended today when the man pleaded guilty to grand larceny.

LEAD: THE world's population of whooping cranes, on the brink of extinction just 50 years ago, has nearly doubled this decade and now appears on the brink of a remarkable comeback.

Home Sales Down 0.5% In October
LEAD: Sales of new homes fell five-tenths of 1 percent in October, the Government reported today.
Analysts said that overall purchases were driven down by a 24.7 percent decline in the West because of the San Francisco Bay-area earthquake and the effects of the slowing economy.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Nov. 23 about a guerrilla takeover at a hotel in San Salvador referred incorrectly to 12 American Green Berets trapped there for a day.


Lin Backs Takeover By McCaw
LEAD: After months of resisting takeover bids from McCaw Cellular Communications Inc., the Lin Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that its board had decided to recommend that shareholders accept the latest offer of $154.11 a share, or $3.38 billion, for roughly half of Lin's stock.


Israeli Sees Failure to Halt Uprising as It Nears 3d Year
LEAD: As the Palestinian uprising enters its third year, Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin acknowledges that the Israeli Army has not succeeded in bringing the revolt under control.


Channel 4, Seeking Ratings, Is Shuffling Daytime Lineup
LEAD: Channel 4 announced plans yesterday to shuffle its daytime programs in late January, scheduling soap operas earlier in the day and using game shows to lead into the late-afternoon lineup of Phil Donahue's talk show and local news.


Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Agree To Hear Case On Water Use
LEAD: The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve an intensifying conflict between the Federal Government and the states over regulating the environmental impact of hydroelectric power plants.


Fidelity Is Freeing Its Funds To Be Assertive Investors
LEAD: In another sign of the increasing power of institutional investors in takeover battles, one of the country's largest mutual fund organizations is taking steps to give it more influence over companies in which it holds stock.
Fidelity Investments, whose mutual funds own shares worth $46 billion, has removed investment limitations from 26 of its stock mutual funds in recent months and expects shareholders to approve the removal in its 37 other stock funds by the end of the year.


Comaneci in Florida
LEAD: Nadia Comaneci, the former Olympic gymnastics champion who fled Rumania last week, arrived in Miami last night and said she would be settling in southern Florida.


Dinkins Gets Proposals On Efforts for Families
LEAD: The Citizens' Committee for Children of New York said yesterday that it has asked Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins to reorganize the city's efforts for families.


Jordan's Premier Is Replaced By Ally of Fundamentalists
LEAD: Prime Minister Zeid bin Shaker resigned today and was replaced by Mudar Badran, who has held the office twice before and is sympathetic to Islamic fundamentalists.

LEAD: About 200,000 people poured into Wenceslas Square today to shout their rejection of a new Government formed on Sunday and to applaud a call for a general strike next Monday if it is not replaced.

LEAD: Over the weekend the people of Czechoslovakia and East Germany made it vividly plain that their goal was to eliminate Communist Party rule over their nations - and that they would not rest until they reached it.


Jury Selection Begins California Lawmaker's Trial
LEAD: The influential chairman of the State Senate's Business and Professions Committee went on trial today on Federal charges of bribery, extortion, racketeering and money laundering.


Fire Kills Mother and 2 Girls
LEAD: An overheated wood stove caused a house fire on Sunday night that killed a mother and two daughters, the authorities said.
The dead were identified as Patricia A. Risley, 27 years old, and her daughters, Michelle, 5, and Danielle, 3.
Mrs.
Risley had sent two sons, John, 2, and Joshua, 1, out of the house and had gone back for the girls, the authorities said.

LEAD: When Deion Sanders, a.k.a.
Neon Sanders, intercepted a pass and ran it back a long way for the Altanta Falcons on Sunday, he proceeded to engage in a whoop of exultation that, on the street, would have brought a screaming ambulance carrying men with a white coat to the scene.

LEAD: COMPUTER games make great stocking-stuffers for grown-ups, although they may be too big for most stockings.


Higher Mortality in Scotland
LEAD: Higher mortality in Scotland may be attributed to more adverse social and economic conditions in that region than elsewhere in Britain, researchers have concluded.


Pension Fund Strategy Shift Is Assailed
LEAD: With politicians nationwide eyeing pension fund surpluses as a way to finance new roads, bridges and other such projects, a group representing 60 state and union pension funds has struck back.
It issued a broadside yesterday against those who would like to see more pension fund money channeled into local economies.

LEAD: The retaliatory spirit (you strike us, we bomb you) that has long prevailed in the Middle East seems to have infected public television.
Hardly has the commotion begun to subside over the broadcast of a pro-Palestinian documentary about the uprising on the West Bank than a pro-Israeli documentary is upon us.

LEAD: Pervis Ellison of the Sacramento Kings, the No. 1 pick in the 1989 National Basketball Association draft, will sit out the next three weeks because of a sore right foot.
Ellison has played in only four games.(AP)

LEAD: Experts on Central America said today that the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, would have difficulty stopping the flow of arms through Cuba and Nicaragua to Salvadoran guerrillas even if he made assiduous efforts, as President Bush has demanded.


The Cost of Drug Abuse: $60 Billion a Year
LEAD: Economists say the cost of illicit drugs to American society has risen substantially in the last few years, to far more than $60 billion annually.
At the same time they are discovering vast new areas of additional economic impact that they are only now beginning to understand.

Tight Limits Proposed for Popular Farm Chemical
LEAD: The Government today proposed banning for most uses a class of chemicals widely applied to fruits and vegetables to control fungal diseases because of concerns that they may cause cancer.


The Editorial Notebook; A Judge for Life
LEAD: His obituaries inevitably identified him as a Supreme Court nominee rejected by the Senate in 1969, but the most telling thing about Clement Haynsworth was that he remained on the Federal bench for the rest of his life.
His death at 77 revives memories of his defeat without doing justice to his nature.

LEAD: A state judicial panel has cleared Francis T. Murphy Jr., one of New York State's most powerful judges, of improperly interfering in disciplinary proceedings against several prominent lawyers, officials close to the case said yesterday.

LEAD: Richie Adubato, who last week was appointed interim coach of the Dallas Mavericks, yesterday accepted the coaching job through the rest of the season.

LEAD:  Baseball


Fear of Death Intensifies Moral Code, Scientists Find
LEAD: THE preacher's fire-and-brimstone warning that death will bring a dire judgment for moral wrongs is a masterful psychological ploy, judging from recent research findings.
New studies show that confronting people with the fact that they will die makes them cling tenaciously to their deepest moral values.


Arnold Arnstein, 91, A Music Copyist, Dies
LEAD: Arnold Arnstein, a music copyist who worked with Gian Carlo Menotti, Samuel Barber and other composers, died of respiratory failure on Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.


L.I. Man Indicted in Death With Fireworks Is Arraigned
LEAD: A man from Suffolk County, charged in the first indictment relating to a fireworks death on Long Island, pleaded not guilty to the charge today.


Edberg Completes a Final Mission
LEAD: If men's tennis, which last week closed out the decade with the final staging of the Nabisco Masters in New York City, can be briefly considered an apple cart, then unassuming Stefan Edberg of Sweden surely upset it on Sunday with his four-set elimination of Boris Becker, the defending champion.


Stars Past and Present Meet
LEAD: Andy McCarroll, a Vanderbilt linebacker from Memphis, was asked to stand and express his feelings about being one of the 11 scholar-athletes chosen this year by the National Football Foundation for academic and football achievements.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Second Top Editor Leaves Family Media
LEAD: Family Media lost its second top editor since announcing a corporate reorganization last week.
Annalyn Swan, the editor in chief of Savvy Woman, the company's magazine for women executives, yesterday announced her resignation.
The company immediately named Martha Nelson, the magazine's executive editor, to succeed her.

LEAD: Like nearly everyone else in this history-obsessed nation, Jeong Ho Lee has a passion for remembering.


Durables Lead Factory Orders Drop
LEAD: New orders for manufactured goods fell for the second consecutive month in October, the Government said today, in a new sign of slack economic growth.


Laughter Is Still Music to Victor Borge's Ear
LEAD: Victor Borge was at the Bosendorfer concert grand in the studio of his estate on Greenwich Harbor.
He was being photographed and did not seem very happy about it.
He observed his 80th birthday this year, and the celebrations, on a worldwide basis, involve being photographed.


Williams Sidelined
LEAD: John Williams, the Washington Bullet forward, will be sidelined for at least three months following arthroscopic surgery to repair torn ligaments in his right knee.
Williams was hurt in last Saturday's loss to Utah.
Williams had played in 255 consecutive games since November 1986. (AP)


Business and Health; Worries Abound On Medicare Shift
LEAD: MANY employers and insurers are worried that their expenditures for employee health care will increase as a result of changes in the rules for paying doctors in the Federal Medicare program, which Congress adopted last month.


Newspaper Agreement
LEAD: The Justice Department's antitrust division recommended approval today of a joint operating agreement between The Las Vegas Sun and The Las Vegas Review Journal.
It said they should be granted an antitrust exemption under the Newspaper Preservation Act, allowing themto combine certain operations.


Czech Opposition Forum To Enter Free Elections
LEAD: Civic Forum, the two-week-old opposition movement in Czechoslovakia, took its boldest step yet by announcing today that it would endorse candidates when the country holds its first free elections since the postwar Communist takeover.

LEAD: Richard R. Salzmann, the retired editor in chief of the Research Institute of America, a publisher of tax guides, died of a heart ailment on Saturday at his home in Santa Fe, N.M.
He was 69 years old and had lived for many years in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

LEAD: Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants seldom criticizes his players publicly.
But today, disappointed and irritated by Sunday's 24-17 home-field loss to the Philadelphia Eagles, Parcells seemed plainly upset with the performances of Phil Simms and Dave Meggett.

LEAD: The injury to Vyacheslav Fetisov's left knee that kept him out of the last five games includes slight cartilage damage, the Devils said yesterday.
Dave Freed, a team spokesman, said, however, that the damage was so limited that the Soviet defenseman might not need an arthroscopy.
He said that Fetisov may return to action before the weekend.

Critic's Notebook; Ern Malley's Triumph: How a Hoax Became Myth
LEAD: The very idea of fakery sets critics trembling.
What if the book they are reading, the score they are hearing or the dance they are watching is not some kind of creative innovation, but a hoax?
And should the thought then occur that the hoax may be a deliberate attempt by an artistic malcontent to make both new trends and their critical admirers seem foolish, the trembling may increase a thousandfold.

Officials' Jets Being Recycled
LEAD: Fifteen Soviet-built jetliners once reserved for use by top East German Communist officials will be put into passenger service, the Government press agency A.D.N. said today.
Klaus Henkes, the general director of the national airline Interflug, was quoted as saying about half the planes were ready for immediate use on charter flights and the rest would be converted for regular passenger flights.

LEAD: The Amdahl Corporation is withdrawing Fujitsu Ltd. supercomputers from the United States market because of poor sales, a Fujitsu spokesman said.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Time Zones  Q.In what time zone are the poles?
A.The time zones are marked by theoretical lines running roughly from pole to pole to match the 24-hour turning of the globe, so the points where the lines meet might be considered to be in none or all of them.

Britain's Reserves Fall
LEAD: Britain's reserves of gold and foreign currency fell by $931 million in November, the Government said today.
In October, the reserves dropped by a record $2.9 billion.
The latest decline was viewed as showing reduced intervention by the Bank of England in the foreign exchange markets to support the British pound.

LEAD: WHEN the Department of Energy said last week that it had lost confidence in its latest effort to find a safe place to bury nuclear waste, a gnawing question resurfaced: is the task possible?

Santa Claus, North Pole, 33d Street
LEAD: Each year about 18,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus arrive in Manhattan's General Post Office, and you can read them like a script for New York itself: tales of need and greed and shining expectation, of entitlement or estrangement, of a chance to get something for nothing, or even, at times, to gain nothing at all but the chance to give to someone else.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Wednesday about the crane collapse that killed five people in San Francisco misidentified the manufacturer of the equipment.
The crane was made by Peiner A.G. in West Germany, not the American Pecco Corporation.
The crane was owned by American Pecco and leased to a subcontractor.


Man and the Apes
LEAD: Biologists from Harvard Medical School who compared a gene that is present in people, chimpanzees and gorillas have concluded that the chimpanzee and gorilla are the closest cousins.
That means that neither is the clear direct ancestor of humans.

Review/Theater; Joe Orton's 'Up Against It,' a Screenplay Staged
LEAD: In ''Up Against It,'' his unproduced screenplay for the Beatles, Joe Orton tried to combine the irreverent spirit of ''A Hard Day's Night'' and ''Help!'' with his own far more mordant sensibility.
Since the playwright's death, the screenplay has remained a tantalizing footnote to Orton's career.
Although the film script is not in the same class as his plays, the published version exists for reading and imagining, raising the question of what the movie would have been like.

LEAD: Presidential Airways Inc., which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five weeks ago, discontinued all of its flights effective Monday.

AIDS Drug Causes Cancer in Animals
LEAD: The AIDS drug AZT has been found to cause cancer in laboratory animals, the drug's manufacturer said today.
But doctors emphasized that AIDS patients should continue to take the drug because the risk is still only theoretical.

LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said yesterday that it had developed new computer chip technology that would improve the performance of its HP Precision Architecture RISC-based minicomputers and work stations by at least 70 percent.
The company said the technology reduced chip size and allowed it to couple many central processing units together.

LEAD: Carriage drivers have obtained a temporary restraining order while they prepare a court challenge to a city law restricting the use of the horse-drawn taxis in midtown Manhattan.
The law, which was sought by animal rights organizations and approved by the City Council over Mayor Koch's veto, bars the carriages from midtown for most of the day.

George L. Nardi, 66, Pancreas Illness Expert
LEAD: Dr.
George L. Nardi, a surgeon who was an expert on diseases of the pancreas, died of cancer yesterday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
He was 66 years old.
Dr.
Nardi, who lived in Boston, received his medical degree from the University of Chicago in 1944, when he was 21.
Except for service as a medical officer in the Navy, he spent his entire medical career at Massachusetts General.

LEAD: John Brunetti, the owner of Hialeah Park, wants to close the historic race track as soon as possible because he is losing an expensive battle for bettors with nearby Calder Race Course.

Australian Lending Lags
LEAD: Australians' demand for credit is slowing, central bank figures showed today, and economists said the trend was evidence that the economy was cooling.
The Reserve Bank of Australia said private sector borrowing rose 16.6 percent in the 12 months ended in October, the smallest rise in five years.
It compared with an 18.3 percent rise in the 12 months ended in September and a 25 percent rise in the 12 months to October 1988.


Bridge
LEAD: The first charity bridge event in the New York metropolitan area to designate AIDS patients as its beneficiaries was played Sept. 24 at the Grand Bridge Studio, Franklin Square, L.I., and will be repeated next year.
Most of the top-ranked Long Island players took part in a partly Pro-Am format, and since the playing space was donated and the directors were volunteers, virtually all the income of $3,500 went to the People with AIDS Coalition of Long Island.

Bush Aides Say Gorbachev Sees Economy as Key
LEAD: In a discussion of Soviet domestic problems with President Bush in Malta, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called his campaign to end consumer shortages in the Soviet Union ''the ultimate test'' of his leadership, senior Administration officials said today.
The Soviet leader reportedly left some American officials with the impression that he was at a loss over how to solve his economic problems.


Tracing Evasion of Campaign Laws
LEAD: In a study that traced the path of $28.5 million in 1988 campaign contributions, a nonpartisan research group today provided new evidence of how wealthy donors were able to skirt Federal laws regulating contributions to Presidential campaigns.

LEAD: A Canadian television network is close to signing a deal to cover the 1991 Pan American Games in Havana, which would allow the Cubans to sidestep a United States embargo, sources close to the organizers said today.

LEAD: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday priced $450 million in notes due in 1996 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

LEAD: Prime Minister V. P. Singh puzzled citizens today when he named 15 people to his Cabinet but did not say which positions they would hold.

LEAD: INDEX arbitrage trading - the form of program trading that has been most criticized - appears to have slumped dramatically.

LEAD: THE old cliche that the essence of real estate is location is coming under increasing challenge in Manhattan's midtown leasing market.

LEAD: A nursing supervisor in Queens was sentenced yesterday to 200 hours of community service for refusing emergency-room treatment for an 81-year-old.

Kodak Minilabs
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said it would stop manufacturing photo minilab equipment at the end of the year, three years after it entered the business.
It said the Noritsu America Corporation would service existing Kodak minilab equipment in the United States and distribute Kodak's Create-a-Print enlargement system, which Kodak would continue to manufacture.

LEAD: The management of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, met Monday with representatives of the pilots' union to outline a new buyout proposal that would give the unions a big stake in the airline, people familiar with the meeting said.
They said the union was reviewing the proposal.
Details of the plan could not be learned yesterday.

LEAD: Faced with voters who threaten them with political and even physical harm, Massachusetts legislators are trying again this week to figure out how to go about the distasteful business of raising taxes.

LEAD: The sign said the white tigers would not be on display in their casino habitat this night.

AFGHAN CAPITAL NOW FEARS FAMINE
LEAD: In the Pul-i-Baghmi bazaar, down by the muddy waters of the Kabul River, the old trader smiled.
Although there were no customers on hand, his sacks of flour, rice and other grains were overflowing.
With food prices edging up every week, the trader could see little ahead but profit.


Review/Art; Bonnard's Graphics Illuminate His Entire Output
LEAD: ''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' is a major contribution to the understanding of a French modernist revered for the lushness and luminosity of his color and light and for his discreet yet voluptuous vision.
Bonnard (1867-1947) arouses such loyalty not only because of the poetry of his painting but also because of its integrity.

LEAD: Dave Dravecky, who battled back from cancer to pitch for San Francisco this season, will have surgery in January because of a recurrence of a tumor in his left arm.
Dravecky, 33, will undergo the procedure at the Sloan-Kettering Memorial Cancer Center in New York on Jan. 4.


Car Sales Off, With Big 3 Hurt the Most
LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and trucks fell in late November and were down sharply at the Big Three.
Japan's auto makers, however, continued to show relative strength.

LEAD: Baba Goya, the title character and earth mother in the 1973 play by Steve Tesich now being revived at the Second Stage Theater, starts the morning with an Italian love song and a cup of strong Turkish coffee.
As long as her household is full of warm bodies, Goya is undaunted by all of the messy problems they can pose.

LEAD: Marvin Gelfand grew up in a Brooklyn family faithful to a tradition prevalent when housing was far more abundant.
They moved twice a year to take advantage of the month's free rent offered to new tenants.

LEAD: Despite an entire life lived here in car country, in Southern California, I only very recently succumbed to full-blown car lust.
For a month and a half I lurched, with my husband along, from showroom to showroom, sizing up the new cars and trying to decide which one to buy, which one was really me.

LEAD: Angelo Ruggiero, a longtime friend and close associate of John Gotti, died of cancer Monday at his home in Howard Beach, Queens.
Mr.
Ruggiero, who was 49 years old, had four major cases against him pending in Federal and New York State courts and was free on $1 million bail when he died.

LEAD: Two months after police units began beating East Germans arrested in Dresden, Leipzig and East Berlin for demonstrating against the Government of Erich Honecker, there is still no official acknowledgment that many were severely wounded.


American Red Cross Campaign by Cabot
LEAD: Cabot Advertising in Boston makes its national, pro-bono television advertising debut on Dec. 15 with a new and unusual campaign for the American Red Cross urging people to give blood.
In an appealingly languorous style that diverges from the dire mood of much public service advertising, the all-text spot tells people, ''When you give blood, you give another birthday party, another wedding anniversary, another day at the beach, another night under the stars, another talk with a friend, another laugh, another hug, another chance.

LEAD: NASA today scheduled the launching of the space shuttle Columbia for Dec. 18, but it said the 10-day flight could be delayed a day or two if a renovated launch pad is not ready.

Many of them agree with David Reisman, the Harvard University sociologist, who calls it ''a case of absolutely crucial importance to the academic life of the country.


4 Hurt in Pakistan Bombing
LEAD: A bomb exploded in a crowded bazaar tonight, hurling shrapnel that wounded four people, the police said.
No one claimed responsibility and no arrests were made.
Similar bombings in this border city have been blamed on agents of the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul, the Afghan capital.

LEAD: The United States offered today to sell one million metric tons of subsidized wheat to China in what would be the first such sale since China's army crushed a pro-democracy movement in June.

Niger in First Vote Since '60
LEAD: Voters in this West African country go to the polls on Sunday in the first presidential and legislative elections since independence from France in 1960.
About three million voters are expected at the polls to elect 93 deputies to Parliament.
President Ali Seybou faces no opposition in the election.


Ethics Rules Are Postponed
LEAD: The City Council yesterday postponed until April putting new conflict-of-interest rules into effect for many New York City employees.
The vote was 26 to 8.
The postponement, from Jan. 1, is intended to encourage some officials to continue in their jobs during the transition between administrations.

LEAD: Though President Bush announced in September that he was sending several hundred million dollars to fight drugs in South America, no new funds have reached Peru and Bolivia, the world's two main growers of coca.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about Czechoslovak emigres in the United States misidentified Dr.
Charlotta Kotik.
She is a great-granddaughter of the Czechoslovak statesman Thomas G. Masaryk, and not of Jan Masaryk.
Jan Masaryk, who was also a Czechoslovak statesman, was Dr.
Kotik's great-uncle.

LEAD: Source Perrier S.A., the French maker of the mineral water product, plans to sue Pepsico Inc. for breaking its franchise contract, Perrier's managing director, Frederick Zimmer said today.


Mozartean-Style Trios
LEAD: One of Mozart's experiments with the clarinet hit upon a combination so potent that composers since the 18th century have followed it enthusiastically.
The instruments in question are the clarinet, the viola and the piano - the subject of his great Trio in E flat and also of the two less familiar works played by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday afternoon.

He was 68 years old.

Australia Tobacco Bans
LEAD: Australia plans to ban advertising of tobacco products in newspapers and magazines, the Health Minister, Neal Blewett, said today.
Mr.
Blewett said legislation covering print media will be introduced next year and take effect within 12 months of being passed by Parliament.
Cigarette and other tobacco advertising has been banned from Australian television since 1976.

He was 69 years old and had suffered from depression for 20 years, a family member said.

Art Prices Are Still Astonishing, But Fever Seems to Be Cooling
LEAD: Art is still commanding breathtaking sums in the auction houses.
Pablo Picasso's ''Pierrette's Wedding'' was bought last week by a Japanese real-estate developer for $51.3 million, the second highest price ever paid for a painting.
But indications are that the feverish buying of recent years is beginning to cool down and that buyers are becoming more selective.

Oil Production Report
LEAD: Oil production in the non-Communist world is back where it was at its peak in 1979 before soaring prices pinched demand and created a glut, the International Energy Agency said today. ''In November, world oil supplies outside the centrally planned economies are estimated at 54.7 million barrels per day,'' the West's energy agency said in its Monthly Oil Report.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today expanded the scope of one of the most important Federal civil rights laws, ruling that state and local governments can be sued for damages if they intervene improperly in labor negotiations.

LEAD: Last year's Federal fair housing amendments wisely added discrimination against families with children to the list of forbidden real estate practices.

A Show of Bronx Art
LEAD: ''Bronx Views,'' an exhibition of paintings depicting landscapes in the Bronx, will open a new art gallery today at the Kingsbridge Center of the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged, 100 West Kingsbridge Road, in the Kingsbridge section of the Bronx.
The exhibition, co-sponsored by the Bronx Museum of the Arts, features 30 works by 6 artists who live in the Bronx: Rikki Asher, Garin Baker, William Behnken, Dina Bursztyn, Daniel Hauben and Leslie Lowinger.

Greenpeace Asserts Navy Was Malicious During Protest at Sea
LEAD: The protest group Greenpeace today accused the Navy of maliciousness in ramming its flagship during a protest of the test launching of a Trident 2 missile off Florida on Monday.


Gasoline Price Drops
LEAD: A gallon of gasoline cost about a half-cent less at the nation's pumps in the last two weeks because of the traditional fall-winter decline in driving, an industry analyst said.
The average service-station price, including taxes, was $1.0697 a gallon as of Friday, a survey of 13,000 stations by the analyst, Trilby Lundberg, found.

LEAD: A judge today delayed a requirement that the actress Zsa Zsa Gabor spend 72 hours in jail and pay fines totaling $2,937 until after appeal of her misdemeanor conviction for slapping a police officer.
But the judge, Charles G. Rubin of Municipal Court, refused to delay the 120 hours of community service that was also a part of the sentence.

LEAD: TLC Beatrice International, the multinational food company controlled by Reginald F. Lewis, said it had reached an agreement with the Sanson family settling a 1987 lawsuit meant to prevent Mr.
Lewis from taking control of Beatrice.
The Sanson family owns 30 percent of Gelati Sanson, an ice cream company based in Italy, and TLC Beatrice controls the rest.

LEAD: George Selden Thompson, the author of ''The Cricket in Times Square'' and other children's books, died of complications from a gastrointestinal hemorrhage yesterday at St.
Vincent's Hospital.
He was 60 years old and lived in Greenwich Village.


To Cut Agency Abuses, Government Lists Its Risks
LEAD: In the first stage of a process intended to combat mismanagement and abuse, the Office of Management and Budget has identified areas of high risk in the way the Government handles its business, especially in contracting, credit and insurance programs and financial accounting systems.

Academy of Design Dismisses Employees
LEAD: The National Academy of Design, the school, museum and society of artists on upper Fifth Avenue, abruptly dismissed about one-fourth of its 40-member staff yesterday and said it planned to cut its educational programs and the hours for its exhibition galleries because of financial problems.


Judge Delays Drug Test Plan
LEAD: A judge yesterday temporarily blocked New York City's plans to give random drug tests to some city employees.
Justice Kenneth Shorter of State Supreme Court issued the order at the request of three unions - District Council 37, the Teamsters and the Fire Alarm Dispatchers Benevolent Association.
Under the order, which affects some 140,000 employees, including police officers and firefighters, most city workers who test positive for drugs have the option of getting help or getting out.


Arabs at U.N. Relax Stand on P.L.O.
LEAD: Arab countries backed down today in a quarrel with the United States over the status of the Palestine Liberation Organization.
The dispute has threatened to lead to a cutoff in American financing for the United Nations.

Liv Ullmann Appears at GAF Trial
LEAD: Liv Ullmann had hoped that as the final witness yesterday in the GAF stock manipulation trial she could tell the jurors details about the character of the main defendant in the case, a senior GAF executive.
But like her two books and many of her films, her testimony was limited mostly to her own character.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury today indicted two associates of Jim Bakker for lying during the PTL fraud investigation.


Education; Lessons
LEAD: When business executives take up the cause of public education, they usually end up doing things like volunteer tutoring or picking up the tab to send the senior class to Washington.


Small Shop Benefits From A Big Client
LEAD: SLATER HANFT MARTIN is a small advertising agency that is every large agency's nightmare.


Jordan's New Prime Minister Delays Naming Government
LEAD: The new Prime Minister, Mudar Badran, delayed naming a Government today amid pressure from a parliamentary bloc over cabinet posts.


Testimony On Boeing
LEAD: The Boeing Company maintained a secret library of classified documents through much of the 1970's at a marketing office in Kent, Wash., a retired employee of the aerospace giant testified today.


50 Arts Organizations Receive Gift Technology
LEAD: The National Endowment for the Arts has announced that the International Business Machines Corporation and Nynex Business Centers have donated computers, software and technical support to 50 arts organizations around the country.
Each organization also received a one-time $1,000 grant from Nynex.
The arts organizations will use the donation to improve their business operations.


Metro Datelines; Tentative Accord Ends Bus Strike
LEAD: New York Bus Service and its striking drivers reached tentative agreement yesterday on a three-year contract.
It will allow service to resume this morning for 13,000 express bus riders from the north Bronx.


Full Service on IND Lines May Resume by Friday
LEAD: Full service on some IND lines in Manhattan may be restored by Friday, if repairs go smoothly, the Transit Authority said yesterday.
The lines were inundated on Saturday morning when a water main broke at 135th Street and St.
Nicholas Avenue, spilling 18 million gallons.

LEAD: The repertory the Saturday Brass Quintet presented in its First Annual Contemporary Music Concert at Washington Square Church on Friday evening, consisting almost entirely of premieres and first New York performances, ranged from high pretense to low humor, and it was sometimes difficult to tell the difference.

LEAD:  A Concerned Collins


Lord Elwyn-Jones, 80, Nuremberg Prosecutor
LEAD: Lord Elwyn-Jones, a prosecutor at the Nuremberg war-crimes trials and Britain's chief legal officer under the last Labor Party Government, died of cancer on Monday at the age of 80.


Vermont Court Blocks Homes in Deer Habitat
LEAD: The Vermont Supreme Court has blocked the construction of a vacation-home development on the ground that it would deprive about 20 whitetail deer of a vital winter habitat.


The Editorial Notebook; The Foul Mystery of North River
LEAD: Some call it ''the Versailles of sewage treatment,'' and for good reason.
The majestic North River Water Pollution Control Plant on Harlem's western waterfront is a delight to behold.
Its sweeping arches, graceful lines and breathtaking vistas engage the eye and the imagination.


Johnson Says He Pondered Quitting the Mets
LEAD: Davey Johnson, manager of the Mets, ended two months of silence on the tumult that swamped the team at the end of last season and said today that he had been so troubled by his loss of authority, he thought about quitting.


Arbitration Offered
LEAD: John Tudor, a pitcher, and the outfielder John Shelby were among five free-agent players who were offered salary arbitration by the Dodgers yesterday.

Savings Industry's New Curbs
LEAD: Four months after President Bush signed legislation to bail out and change the savings and loan industry, most savings institutions have taken major steps toward meeting strict new rules intended to make them safer and more conservative.


Fernandez Names Schools Critic to Be Top Deputy
LEAD: In his first major appointment, Joseph A. Fernandez, who will become New York City's Schools Chancellor next month, yesterday named one of the school system's most vocal critics to be a new deputy chancellor and the chief operating officer.


Greenwich's Private Deal for Public Problem
LEAD: When the Greenwich Board of Education went shopping for a new superintendent this year, its members knew that it would be difficult to offer a package of pay and perquisites large enough to enable an out-of-town administrator to buy a home here.
After all, the average price of a four-bedroom colonial on one and a half acres is $837,000.


STUDY CHALLENGES HIGH-RISE SAFETY
LEAD: Scientists studying the effect of sonic booms on Los Angeles buildings have determined that skyscrapers may be more vulnerable to earthquakes than previously believed.


American Charged in El Salvador
LEAD: An American religious worker who was arrested after the police found ammunition and explosives buried in her backyard was charged with terrorism by Salvadoran authorities late today.


Addenda
LEAD: *
Abreu Advertising in Speonk, L.I., has changed its name to Abreu/ Mitchell Advertising, in recognition of Kim Mitchell, who has joined the agency as a partner.


Quaker Oats Sees Weakness in Toys
LEAD: The common stock of the Quaker Oats Company plunged $3.75 a share today, to $58.75, on the New York Stock Exchange after the company disclosed weakness in its Fisher-Price toy business.
Quaker said it expected earnings for its second quarter ending Dec. 31 to fall below 1988's 47 cents a share.


When He Sips, Vintners Tremble
LEAD: IN a Bordeaux restaurant a few weeks ago, a prominent American wine importer ordered a 1982 Chateau La Grave Trigant de Boisset, from a little-known property in Pomerol.
His guests, all professionally involved with wine, found it pleasant.


Why a Squeezable Bottle Is Under Attack
LEAD: When the H. J. Heinz Company introduced a squeezable plastic bottle for its ketchup in 1983, the consumer-products industry hailed it as a major advance.
The diner could gently squeeze out ketchup with far more accuracy than the conventional glass bottle allowed, yet the ketchup could last without spoiling almost as long as that in a glass bottle.


After the Summit; COMMUNIST PARTY BEGINS TO SPLINTER UNDER GORBACHEV
LEAD: While President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has been applying his diplomatic skills to the stability of Europe, his own Communist Party is beginning to splinter along ethnic and ideological lines.


After the Summit; Rapid Change in East Is Taking a Toll on the Western Allies
LEAD: After President Bush's meeting with Western European leaders in Brussels on Monday, it has become apparent that the rapid pace of change in Eastern Europe is creating political and personal strains within the European Community and the Western alliance, officials and diplomats here say.

LEAD: In what amounted to a political valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch offered yesterday an ardent summation of his 12-year tenure, advised his successor to ''be not afraid'' and strongly criticized the Federal Government as being unfair to the city.

Review/Television; The Familiar Rumpole, In the Bailey and Beyond
LEAD: Leo McKern first appeared 11 years ago as Horace Rumpole, the roguish, lovable barrister.
Since then, the actor has regularly insisted that he is through with the role.
He would rather be remembered, evidently, for his often acclaimed interpretations of Shakespeare.
But Mr.
McKern and the grumbling husband of She Who Must Be Obeyed are by now inseparable, and the author John Mortimer, himself a former barrister, shows no sign of running out of ''Rumpole of the Bailey'' stories.

EATING WELL
LEAD: CLOTHING for fat children, in the not too distant past, was sold in the ''chubby'' department.
Stores are no longer so insensitive that they call attention to obese children in this way.
But the children's peers have no such qualms: fat children are still subject to cruel taunts.

High Yugoslav Inflation
LEAD: Yugoslavia said Monday that its annual inflation rate neared 2,000 percent last month.
The Federal Statistics Office reported that prices rose in November by 42.4 percent after a 45.6 percent jump in October.
The annual increase in the inflation rate between November 1988 and last month was 1,975.7 percent.

LEAD: A smoky fire in a nine-story building used by garment makers sent panicky workers scurrying today down fire truck rescue ladders and up to the roof, where Fire Department helicopters plucked 15 people to safety.

LEAD: In a major concession to the opposition, the Communist leadership agreed today to accept a minority role in one of the country's two principal regional governments.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the collection of premiums under the Medicare Catastrophic Coverage Act included an incorrect assertion by a spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services about refunds to be made because of repeal of the program last month.
The spokesman said Medicare beneficiaries would receive no refunds of either monthly premiums or the surtax paid this year for the expanded health insurance.


After the Summit; Include Navies in Arms Talks, Some in NATO Urge
LEAD: The United States is coming under pressure from some of its NATO allies to drop its rigid opposition to including naval forces in arms reduction talks with the Soviet Union, diplomats and other Government officials in several European capitals say.


Federal Agent Shoots Suspect in Drug Bust
LEAD: One of three drug suspects was shot and wounded last night during a buy and bust operation conducted in Upper Manhattan by Federal drug enforcement agents, officials said.

LEAD: Reports of the stunning ignorance being created by the American educational system make it hard to write for a mass audience.

LEAD: As Kirby Puckett, Rickey Henderson and Mark Langston escalated baseball salaries to record heights in the last two weeks, Don Mattingly watched with more than a passing interest.
But Mattingly did not start counting the days - 321 from today - until he could become a free agent and see what barriers he could break.


Pope Harshly Rebukes Lands That Foster Ecological Crisis
LEAD: Pope John Paul II warned today that the world was caught in an ecological crisis that violates human rights and ''lays bare the depth of man's moral crisis.''


Economic Worries Push Dow Down 11.95
LEAD: Stock prices were broadly lower yesterday amid continued uncertainty over the economic outlook.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 11.95 points, to 2,741.68.


Treasury Issues Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities again traded in a very narrow range yesterday on extremely light volume.
For the second straight session, market participants chose to ignore news developments that at other times would normally have had a beneficial effect.

LEAD: Pergament Home Centers, a chain that sells home-improvement products, said yesterday that Michael H. Lurie had been named president and chief operating officer to fill one of the posts held by Murray Pergament, the longtime president, chairman and chief executive.

LEAD: B'nai B'rith International is ready to expel its 120,000-member women's unit for declaring itself ''a separate, autonomous organization'' that is identified with B'nai B'rith but not subject to its will.


New Cabinet Named in Jordan
LEAD: Prime Minister Mudar Badran announced the formation of a Cabinet today that excludes the fundamentalist Muslim Brotherhood movement, which makes up the largest bloc in Jordan's new Parliament.

LEAD: A Democrat who had been barred by the Roman Catholic Bishop here from receiving communion because of her support for abortion rights won election to the California Senate Tuesday night.
The result tipped the balance of the Legislature in favor of abortion rights for the first time in several years.

LEAD: Ozzie Smith, the shortstop of the St.
Louis Cardinals, won his 10th consecutive Gold Glove Award yesterday, becoming the only major league player to receive the honor bestowed in balloting by managers and coaches in each year of the 1980's. LEAD: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about a recovery in the supertanker business referred incorrectly to an investment by the Belzberg family of Canada in Marine Transport Lines.

Boxing's Lost-Luster Factor
LEAD: rrWhen a popular champion loses his luster, boxing judges are sometimes the last to know.
Or at least the last to acknowledge it on their scorecards.
More than a decade ago, many people thought that Muhammad Ali lost to Ken Norton at Yankee Stadium and to Jimmy Young in Landover, Md.
The judges in those heavyweight title bouts, apparently still blinded by Ali's flash and dash, awarded him the decision each time.


Teachers Leader Argues for More Metal Detectors
LEAD: The president of the United Federation of Teachers, Sandra Feldman, urged the New York City Board of Education yesterday to put metal detectors in each high school that requests them.

LEAD: A rocket scientist convicted of trying to ship advanced United States missile technology to Egypt has been sentenced to 46 months in prison.

LEAD: Kingfisher P.L.C., one of Britain's largest retailers, made a hostile $724 million offer for the Dixons Group P.L.C., a consumer electronics retailer.
The bid values Dixons at $1.88 a share.


Defendant Confesses, Ending Murder Trial
LEAD: A security guard interrupted the third day of his murder trial yesterday to confess that he had sexually abused and then killed an 18-year-old waitress.


Emirates Rejects Quota
LEAD: The United Arab Emirates' oil minister, Sheik Mani Said al-Otaiba, said this week that his country was ready to limit its oil output, but not to the extent demanded by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
He said the United Arab Emirates was willing to reduce its current output of 2.6 million barrels a day to less than two million in the first half of 1990.

LEAD: IN 1983, a small group of UCLA architects, planners and historians formed the Power of Place, a nonprofit corporation whose mission is to identify historic sites important to Los Angeles.

A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.

LEAD:  Debt


Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Redwood Protection  Q.I have redwood patio furniture and am interested in the best way to protect it from the weather.
Is applying a redwood stain enough?
A.Most paint and hardware stores and many redwood furniture dealers carry sealers or protective coatings for just this purpose.
A simple transparent stain would help restore the color but would not provide much protection against water penetration and soiling.


Times to Raise Delivery Price
LEAD: The price of The New York Times delivered directly by The Times in the metropolitan area will increase to $4.50 a week on Jan. 1, William L. Pollak, the vice president for circulation, announced yesterday.
Most customers now pay $4.25 a week.
The increase will not affect suggested newsstand prices or direct home-delivery rates outside the New York area.


HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: FOR safety, efficiency and economy, your furnace should be professionally inspected and serviced before the heating season.
Just as important for efficiency and economy is an annual inspection and tuneup of the heating system's delivery points: ducts and registers in hot-air systems; radiators and convectors in steam and hot-water systems.

Taiwan Gold Imports Up
LEAD: Taiwan's gold imports rose sharply in November, to the highest level since April, the Finance Ministry said today.
Physical imports, including gold bars, coins and plate, totaled 13.67 tons in November, up 23.9 percent from 11.03 tons in October.
The November figure brought Taiwan's total gold imports to 147.4 tons, valued at $1.81 billion, for the first 11 months of 1989.

Car Imports Up in Japan
LEAD: Sales of imported vehicles in Japan are expected to total just under 180,000 units in 1989, up from a record 133,583 in 1988, an official of the Japan Automobile Importers Association said today.
The growth was helped by Japanese tax revision, increased demand for luxury cars, low interest rates and increases in disposable income, he said.

New York Fines 32 Food Stores On Overcharges
LEAD: Customers of supermarkets with automatic checkout scanners were overcharged in 32 of the 33 stores surveyed by state inspectors this year, state officials said today.

RAPE GUILTY PLEA, AFTER ACQUITTAL
LEAD: A man who was acquitted in a Florida rape case in which the jury foreman said the victim had ''asked for it'' pleaded guilty on Tuesday to raping a woman in Decatur, Ga., and was sentenced to life in prison.


POLICE SAY WOMAN KIDNAPPED BOY TO HAVE HIM BEG FOR CRACK
LEAD: A Staten Island woman was charged yesterday with kidnapping the 5-year-old son of a friend and using the boy to panhandle for money for crack, the police said.


Lithuanians Vote to End Communists' Monopoly
LEAD: The Lithuanian Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to abolish the Communist Party's political monopoly in Lithuania, but fell barely short of the number of votes needed to change the constitution.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on the Education page yesterday about national educational goals misattributed the 1983 report ''A Nation at Risk.'' The report was written by the National Commission on Excellence in Education; Diane Ravitch, a professor at Columbia University's Teachers College, was not a co-author and has never been a member of the commission.


Christmas Programs At World Trade Center
LEAD: ''Twelve Noons of Christmas,'' a series of free afternoon performances, is to feature performers who figure into the lyrics of the song ''The Twelve Days of Christmas.'' ADVANCE REPORTED ON MIDEAST TALKS
LEAD: Egypt has agreed, with some conditions, to Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's plan to prepare for a dialogue between Israeli and Palestinian representatives, the State Department said today.


Air Canada to Cut Stake in Concern
LEAD: Air Canada said it would sell part of its 14.6 percent stake in the Irish aircraft leasing company GPA Group P.L.C. to raise cash and reduce debt.


5 Hurt in Cruise Ship Fire
LEAD: A fire broke out today on a cruise ship moored for repairs, injuring five people before it was contained, the harbormaster said.
About 450 workers and crew members were on the 618-foot Bermuda Star, which was moored at Swan Island when the fire broke out shortly after 1 P.M. in an area where welders were working, said the harbormaster, Mell Pittmon.


Miami Police Prepare As Jury Deliberates
LEAD: The Miami Police Department today canceled all vacations and days off and put its 1,100 officers on 12-hour shifts as it prepared for the possibility of disorder when a jury renders its verdict in the case of a Hispanic officer accused of manslaughter in the killing of two unarmed black men.

Common Sense About Abortion
LEAD: The latest round of Supreme Court abortion arguments requires the justices to apply not constitutional theory but horse sense.
A realistic look at parental consent laws in Minnesota and Ohio will expose their practical effect.
These are not laws that, in practice, promote family values.
They are laws that make abortions harder to get.


5 More Arrests in Killing of Apartheid Opponents
LEAD: The South African police confirmed today that they had detained five more men believed connected to a white conspiracy that led to the assassination of two leading white opponents of apartheid this year.


Calling Client a Monster, Nurse's Lawyer Asks Lesser Charge
LEAD: A defense lawyer summed up his case today by calling his client ''a monster in nurse's whites'' who may well have killed four hospital patients but should not be convicted of murder.


Fed Survey Calls Economy Stable to Growing Modestly
LEAD: Economic activity in most sections of the country is ''stable to modestly expanding,'' with even generally becalmed manufacturing displaying ''pockets of strength,'' a survey by the Federal Reserve Board of its 12 district banks stated today.


Grain and Soybeans Climb On Prospects of Export Rise
LEAD: Prices of grain and soybean futures closed higher in active trading yesterday as traders reacted to prospects of increased export activity.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Business Day yesterday about a reduction in the work force of the International Business Machines Corporation misstated the change made by Moody's Investors Service in the company's debt rating.
Moody's reaffirmed its top rating, Aaa, for I.B.M.'s senior debt.
It altered its rating for only $11.5 billion of convertible subordinated debt, downgrading it from Aaa to a slightly lower rating,


Injured O'Brien May Sit When Jets Play Steelers
LEAD: Last week, the Jets' quarterback, Ken O'Brien, was nominated for the Travelers N.F.L. man of the year award by the Pro Football Hall of Fame for his charity work.
Today his good friend Tony Eason had another award in mind for him.


Beijing Journal; English Spoken Here (by Would-Be Expatriates)
LEAD: A class of 40 nervous students looked blankly at the teacher who had just asked a sample question on an English test, about the purchase of shoes from a catalogue. ''Class, what is a catalogue?'' the teacher asked.


Diet Additive Blamed In Additional Illnesses
LEAD: Federal health officials said Tuesday that the number of cases of a rare blood disorder linked to the diet supplement L-tryptophan had risen to 707.


G.M. May Expand Role in Hungary
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said it was negotiating to expand its business in Hungary.
G.M. has had a trade agreement with Hungary for two years under which it buys auto parts from Hungarian companies for its European operations.
In exchange, G.M. sells Opel cars in Hungary.
Opel is a G.M. subsidiary.


Swiss Vote Cheers Critics of Army
LEAD: The outcome of a recent referendum, in which an unexpectedly large minority voted in favor of abolishing the army, has unsettled the Swiss military establishment and heartened those pushing for a reduction of the military budget and other changes.


Map of Manhattan showing location of Tompkins Square Park (NYT) (pg. B2); Neighbors' Attitudes Shift as Park Declines
LEAD: The ramshackle encampment of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park is drawing mounting criticism from residents of the Lower East Side, a community where rioting broke out last year when the police tried to sweep the homeless from the park.


5 NATIONS SEIZE COCAINE PROFITS
LEAD: The United States and four other nations have frozen $61.8 million invested in American and European banks by an associate of the Medellin cocaine trafficking ring of Colombia, the Drug Enforcement Administration said today.

LEAD: As the morning rush hour unfolded at the Westchester County Airport this week, business commuters were greeted by the usual affronts: a packed parking lot with cars left helter-skelter on muddy hillsides, a drab, drafty Quonset-hut terminal, a waiting area little bigger than a corporate jet. IND Lines Resume Local Service on West Side
LEAD: Partial service on the IND lines in Harlem and on the West Side resumed yesterday in time for the morning rush hour.
A, B and D trains made all local stops, but C trains, which usually travel between Queens and the Bronx, were again turned around, at the northern terminus at 59th Street-Columbus Circle.


Witness in Pappy Mason Trial Admits Crimes and Addiction
LEAD: The prime witness against Howard (Pappy) Mason, on trial in the murder of a police officer, was in tears yesterday as she admitted being a drug addict and a thief willing to lie to avoid death or injury.


Metro Datelines; Yale Called Unfair In Action on Officers
LEAD: Two Yale police officers disciplined for their handling of a confrontation at a gay studies conference were made scapegoats to appease the gay community, the Yale police union asserted Tuesday.


Dry Dock Lays Off 24 in Real Estate
LEAD: The Dollar Dry Dock Bank said it laid off 24 people last week in its residential real estate lending department because of the slow pace of home sales.
Robert H. Steele, Dollar Dry Dock's chairman, said originations of new mortgage loans had been running 60 percent below the bank's projections.


Lutheran Church Gets a Bigger Role
LEAD: With the virtual collapse of the East German Communist Party, the leading moral authority in this part of Germany is once again what it has been for most of the time since the Reformation, the Lutheran Church.


Defaults by Bond Issuers May Be Highest of Decade
LEAD: Defaults by bond issuers are likely to reach the highest levels of the decade this year, Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday.


Abortion Curb Gains in Michigan; Veto Is Vowed
LEAD: Unmarried girls under the age of 18 would have to get parental permission before obtaining an abortion in Michigan under a bill passed today by the House despite the Governor's promise to veto it.

Fed Says It Sold Dollars in Third Quarter
LEAD: The Federal Reserve actively sold dollars from August through October in an effort to prevent further appreciation of the dollar in foreign exchange markets, the central bank reported yesterday.

LEAD: A young man with a rifle killed 14 women and wounded 12 other people at the University of Montreal engineering school yesterday before committing suicide, the police said.

LEAD: East Germany's fallen Communist chief, Egon Krenz, gave up his remaining state positions today amid the continuing political turmoil.
The foundering Communist Party advanced its emergency congress to Friday and is expected to shed its Stalinist structures and even its name.

Fixing Fabric, the Older the Better
LEAD: ''IF it's a fabric, we can fix it.'' This is the slogan at Helene Von Rosenstiel's Brooklyn studio.
A textile conservator, Ms.
Von Rosenstiel restores everything from wedding gowns to military uniforms, quilts and christening dresses.
She even sewed new sequins on one of the ruby slippers that Judy Garland wore in ''The Wizard of Oz.

LEAD: The Phelps Dodge Corporation, the nation's leading copper producer, said today that it would take a $375 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings after writing down the value of several closed mines.

Judge Punishes 'the Enemy'
LEAD: A Federal district judge, who said he grew up in the same area as the defendant, today sentenced a 22-year-old Los Angeles drug dealer to life in prison without possibility of parole for selling five ounces of crack. ''I know the neighborhood, and I know the way it has changed,'' the judge, David Williams, said in passing sentence on Richard Van Winrow.

Edwin N. Altman, 71, An Airline Executive
LEAD: Edwin N. Altman, an executive in the airline and maritime industries for nearly 50 years, died Sunday at Overlake Hospital in Bellevue, Wash., after a long illness.

Cherkassky Replaces Bolet
LEAD: The pianist Shura Cherkassky is to make his first appearance in Lincoln Center's Great Performers Series on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Avery Fisher Hall.
Mr.
Cherkassky is replacing Jorge Bolet, who has canceled his recital because of illness.
Mr.
Cherkassky is to play works by Beethoven, Schumann, Tchaikovsky, Rachmaninoff and Liszt.


Macmillan Case Accord
LEAD: The former chairman of Macmillan Inc. and two senior executives settled Federal civil charges today that they failed to disclose that the company was developing a restructuring plan to ward off an expected hostile takeover attempt, almost one year before the plan was announced.


Shell Plans Deep Drilling Off Texas
LEAD: The Shell Oil Company said today that it would develop a promising oil and gas field at a record depth of 2,860 feet in the Gulf of Mexico, more than 250 miles southeast of Houston.
It estimated the cost at $1.1 billion.


Banks Lost $744 Million in Quarter
LEAD: The nation's banks lost $744 million from July to September after earning record profits in the first half of the year, Government regulators said today.

LEAD: The police in this southern Swiss city said today that they arrested five Colombian drug traffickers late last month and news reports said they included Severo Escobar, a nephew of the fugitive Colombian drug trafficker Pablo Escobar.

LEAD: Adam Michnik, editor of Solidarity's daily newspaper, said today that ''explosions of anti-Polish phobia'' among Germans were threatening the democratic order in Europe.

LEAD: Barneys New York, the retail clothing company, said it would open a 19,000-square-foot store in Dallas's Northpark Center shopping mall next August.

LEAD: The Norwegian company Saga Petroleum A.S. said it would halt development planning for its $1 billion Midgard offshore field until buyers are found for its natural gas reserves.
Plans for Midgard, which is off central Norway, depended on selling enough natural gas to justify building a $2.2 billion pipeline.

Arnold Ordman, Ex-N. L. R. B. Counsel, 77
LEAD: Arnold Ordman, who served two terms as general counsel to the National Labor Relations Board and later was an administrative law judge and arbitrator, died of heart failure Tuesday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md.
He was 77 years old and lived in Bethesda.

Review/Music; With Sounds of Christmas
LEAD: There are close parallels between the Tallis Scholars and Les Arts Florissants.
The English group was founded in 1978 by Peter Phillips, the French group in 1979 by William Christie.
Both now count as their countries' leading vocal ensembles for Renaissance and Baroque music, enjoying notable successes on tours and recordings.

LEAD: Phoenix Technologies Ltd., a software development company, yesterday named Ronald D. Fisher as its president and chief executive.

Broadway Actress Has Quick Start on Her Career
LEAD: In Scene 5 of Tom Stoppard's ''Artist Descending a Staircase,'' a young woman named Sophie talks with three artists about the meaning and relevance of modern art.
The time is the 1920's and, reacting to the work of the day, Sophie says that art should not be easy.
One purpose of art, she says, is to celebrate the ability of the artist.


France Pushes Integration of Arab Immigrants
LEAD: Faced with mounting resentment against the estimated 3 million Muslim Arab immigrants living in France, the Government of Prime Minister Michel Rocard today presented a 48-point plan to speed up the process of integrating them while tightening controls against illegal immigration.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Allegheny International Inc., Pittsburgh, an appliance maker, said a Federal judge had approved a $6.25 million settlement of shareholders' lawsuits that accused company officials of securities law violations.


1,500-M.P.H. WINDS FOUND ON NEPTUNE
LEAD: Neptune is swept by 1,500 mile-an-hour winds, the fastest yet discovered in the solar system, scientists have determined from analyzing photographs taken by Voyager 2.


NEW VERMONT LAW HINDERS CAR SALES
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will not be able to sell some models in Vermont in 1992 because of the state's air pollution law, a company official said today.


Mother Talks of Transplant
LEAD: It was more painful than she expected, but the woman who gave up part of her liver for her baby girl in the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor says she would do it again.


DePaul Dean Named Pace University Head
LEAD: The dean of faculties at DePaul University in Chicago has been named president of Pace University.


Rockefeller Labs, Roosevelt Homes
LEAD: Two development proposals deserve continuing strong support of the outgoing Koch administration and a welcome from the incoming Dinkins government.
They are the $80 million expansion of Rockefeller University's laboratories and a scaled-down housing plan for Roosevelt Island.


Gaming Panel Fines Caesar's, Saying Casino Catered to Bias
LEAD: State gaming regulators fined Caesar's Hotel Casino $250,000 today for removing black and female employees from a table to satisfy a high-stakes gambler.


Nicaragua Shaping a Risky New Strategy to Gain Leverage Against U.S.
LEAD: A light plane that crashed while carrying sophisticated antiaircraft missiles from Nicaragua to Salvadoran rebels was part of a risky new Nicaraguan strategy to gain negotiating leverage against the United States, diplomats and Sandinista officials say.


Philippine Rebel Troops Surrender In Business District of the Capital
LEAD: Philippine Army rebel troops who nearly succeeded in a rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino that began seven days ago agreed this morning to surrender and return to barracks, apparently concluding the gravest challenge yet to her deeply battered administration.


MBIA in Pact With French Firm
LEAD: MBIA Inc., a financial-guarantee insurance company based in White Plains, said it had agreed to exchange professional services and jointly develop financing opportunities in Europe with Credit Local de France, a specialized French institution that provides nearly half of the financing for French municipal and regional authorities.

LEAD: Sammy Fain, who wrote the music for such well-loved popular songs as ''I'll Be Seeing You,'' ''That Old Feeling,'' ''Secret Love'' and ''Love Is a Many-Splendored Thing,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at the U.C.L.A.
Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 87 years old.

LEAD: Just who was the Ray Charles Leonard who climbed into the ring last June against Thomas Hearns?
Was he a fighter who finally, and unexpectedly, showed his advanced boxing age of 33?

LEAD: After nearly a week of suspense and speculation, India's new Government took shape today as Prime Minister V. P. Singh announced Cabinet assignments.

LEAD: An injured construction worker was trapped in rubble for two and a half hours today when a vacant building on the Upper East Side collapsed, the police said.

LEAD: Hans Werner Henze has almost enough imagination to keep his socialist political beliefs from debilitating his musical illustrations of them. ''Memorias de el Cimarron,'' a kind of narrative suite for the guitar that Hubert Kappel brought to Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night, relates in six episodes the exploits of a runaway slave.

Burma Rebels' Radio Station
LEAD: The main rebel alliance in Burma has set up a radio station at a jungle base close to the Thai border, a rebel spokesman said today.
The Voice of the Democratic Alliance of Burma began news broadcasts in Burmese and English on Saturday.
The rebels have fought the Government for four decades.

Mitterrand, in Kiev, Warns Bonn Not to Press Reunification Issue KIEV, U.S.S.R., Dec. 6 (Reuters) -President Francois Mitterrand of France warned West Germany today not to push for reunification with East Germany, saying it could upset the delicate balance in Europe and slow integration of the European Community.   Speaking after talks here with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Mr. Mitterrand, who last month said ''I am not afraid of reunification,'' made it clear that he and the Kremlin leader agreed that stability in Eastern Europe was a major priority.   ''We must avoid at all costs anything that could poison what is already a very complex situation,'' Mr. Mitterrand told a joint news conference that was remarkable for the apparent similarity of French and Soviet views on German reunification.   ''None of our countries, and especially one whose weight is so great and whose geographical position is such, can act without taking into account the balance of Europe,'' he said in a clear reference to West Germany. Backing for the Status Quo    Mr. Mitterrand's remarks contrasted with those he made last month in Bonn after meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany.   ''I am not afraid of reunification, '' Mr. Mitterrand said then. ''I think the desire for reunification is legitimate for the Germans. What counts above all is the determination and will of the people.'' Since then, Mr. Kohl has outlined a 10-point vision for eventual German reunification. Mr. Kohl presented the outline to the West German Parliament last week without prior consultation with the Western allies, and his ideas drew expressions of concern from some North Atlantic Treaty Organization members, including France, during President Bush's briefing in Brussels on Monday on his weekend meeting in Malta with President Gorbachev.   The French President, in Kiev on a brief visit to discuss the results of the Malta summit meeting, also expressed his support for a Soviet proposal to hold a 35-nation conference on European security as early as next year.   France currently holds the European Community's rotating presidency, and Mr. Mitterrand's visit to the Soviet Union was widely seen as a sort of Soviet-European Community summit meeting.   Mr. Gorbachev, also stressing dangers in upsetting the status quo established after World War II, said East and West should proceed from the fact that there are two independent, sovereign German states. France to 'Speak the Truth'    ''I have been asked this question many times in the last few days,'' he said. ''My position has not changed. We proceed from the assumption that each people has the right to choose, to solve its own problems of independence in its own interests, but also taking into account the interests of other countries.''   Mr. Mitterrand said France, a close ally of West Germany, should be prepared to ''speak the truth'' to Bonn over the issue of German reunification and make clear to the West German leadership the attitude of other European countries.   Mr. Mitterrand stressed that the German question should not divert the European Community from reaching agreement on an ambitious program for greater unity of its 12 members, due to be discussed at a community summit meeting in Strasbourg, France, on Friday.   ''We should not begin by talking about changing borders,'' Mr. Mitterrand said. ''Seen from the West, it is more urgent to reinforce the structure of the European Community.''   Mr. Mitterrand said he favored Mr. Gorbachev's proposal to bring forward to next year a 35-nation conference on European security.   ''President Gorbachev floated the idea,'' he said. ''I cannot speak for the other 33 countries who are not here, but as for me, I would say if this happened in 1990 it would be good.''   Mr. Mitterrand and Mr. Gorbachev left Kiev late this evening. The Soviet leader returned to Moscow, while Mr. Mitterrand flew to Paris.  Party's Dominance Protested    KIEV, U.S.S.R., Dec. 6 (Reuters) - Several hundred people demanding an end to the Communist party's monopoly on power demonstrated in Kiev today as Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Mitterrand met.   In Moscow, Andrei D. Sakharov, the human rights campaigner who is a leader of the dissident bloc in the Soviet Parliament, called for a two-hour general strike next week to back demands for a debate on the issue.   The Kiev protesters, many of them members of the Ukrainian mass movement Rukh, waved nationalist flags and banners demanding publication of their movement's program and an end to censorship.   The police did not try to break up the demonstration, which was held in the Ukrainian capital's central Revolution Square opposite a building where Mr. Gorbachev and Mr. Mitterrand were scheduled to hold a joint news conference on their talks.

The fire, in a five-story former apartment building at 1234 Lincoln Place in the Crown Heights section, was reported at 7:10 P.M. and was under control at 9:27 P.M.

LEAD: A landmark of sorts was reached yesterday at the Corroon &amp; Black Corporation when Robert F. Corroon stepped down as chairman and the New York-based insurance brokerage found itself for the first time without a member of the founding Corroon family in top management.

Alexander Is Retiring
LEAD: Dan Alexander, the Jets' right guard, whose 13 years of seniority is surpassed only by the 16 years of Pat Leahy, the place-kicker, and equaled only by Wesley Walker, a receiver, announced his retirement at the end of the season.
