Board Drops 1876 Building As Landmark
LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins, joined by almost every other member of the New York City Board of Estimate, voted yesterday to overturn the landmark status of a 113-year-old building on the Avenue of the Americas that was designated in October as ''a forerunner of the skyscraper type.''


Scholar Wins His Libel Case Over Statue
LEAD: The Renaissance scholar at the center of a dispute about a plaster statue he has said was the model for Michelangelo's David has won $:7,500 (around $12,000) in damages in an English High Court in a libel case against The Independent newspaper.


Economic Scene; Terrorist Victim's European Vision
LEAD: THE complex job of rebuilding the international economic order in the wake of the upheaval in the Communist world and the apparent end of the cold war will require dedicated and brilliant leaders like those who created the Marshall Plan after World War II.
The late chief executive of West Germany's biggest bank, the Deutsche Bank, Alfred Herrhausen, who was murdered by a terrorist bomb near Frankfurt last week, was such a leader.

LEAD: Just in time to enliven Albany's dreary year-end political scene, Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo and the state's Chief Judge, Sol Wachtler, today began their annual squabble over the state judiciary budget.


Soviets Buy More Wheat
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought 410,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in 1989-90, the seventh year of a long-term grain supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.

LEAD: An obituary on Saturday about Alan Bowne, a playwright and author, misstated the date of his death.
It was Nov. 24.

LEAD: Benjamin J. Lucarelli, a contractor whose company built some of New Jersey's best-known apartment and hotel complexes, died yesterday at his home in Spring Lake, N.J.
He was 82 years old and had lived in Jersey City and Sea Girt, N.J.

Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Monday about cast changes in ''Rigoletto'' at the Metropolitan Opera referred incorrectly to a radio broadcast celebrating the company's 50th season.
The program, heard on Saturday, was a mixture of live interviews and excerpts from previous years' broadcasts, not a recording of Richard Strauss's ''Frau Ohne Schatten.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $431.4 million, to $367.14 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $714.9 million, to $88.58 billion.
The assets of the 228 general-purpose funds were up by $319.6 million, to $119.53 billion.


Hewlett-3Com
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it had completed its purchase of 5 percent of the 3Com Corporation.
The move is part of an alliance between the computer companies.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Hewlett-Packard, based in Palo Alto, Calif., said it had acquired its 1.45 million shares for an average of $18.89 each.


Just One More Flop
LEAD: The Federal Government's decision to abandon its current development of the Yucca Mountain Nuclear Waste Depository in Nevada, and to start again on a new plan for the same site, repeats an old, discouraging story: a ballyhooed ''solution'' to the radioactive waste problem that turns out to be just one more flop.


WESTERN EUROPE MOVES TO EXPAND FREE-TRADE LINKS
LEAD: Western European governments plan to announce an agreement later this month to establish a free-trade zone that includes the 12 nations of the European Community and 6 others, diplomats and community officials said in recent days.


The Editorial Notebook; Prague's Invisible Liberator
LEAD: An oddly revealing sight in Prague is the Museum of Czech Literature in the ancient Strahov Library.
Here visitors are shown the books and authors that supposedly formed the consciousness of a nation - yet Thomas Masaryk is absent, which is like blotting Jefferson from American literature.


Crewmen Indicted in Grounding of Freighter
LEAD: Two brothers who were crewmen aboard a ship that rammed a fragile coral reef in October have been indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of operating the vessel recklessly and while intoxicated.


New Method of Creating Antibodies Hailed as a Research Aid
LEAD: In what is considered a major advance in biotechnology, a team of California scientists have devised a new method of creating monoclonal antibodies, which are widely used in medical diagnosis, experimental cancer treatments and basic research in immunology and disease.


No Cause Found For the Sinking Of Fishing Boat
LEAD: The captain of the Bronx Queen testified yesterday that he felt a thump at the stern just before the charter-fishing boat began to sink near the entrance to New York Harbor on Saturday.
But neither the captain nor a diver who inspected the submerged ship could determine the cause of the accident.


Users of Steroids Risk Addiction, Two Researchers at Yale Report
LEAD: Research suggests that people who take anabolic steroids to promote muscle growth may become addicted to the drugs, scientists at Yale University have found.

LEAD: Nearly two-thirds of the advisory and fund-raising board for the National Academy of Design resigned yesterday during an emergency meeting called to discuss the academy's growing financial problems and a dispute over the institution's policies.

Mrs.
Ashley was jailed on Nov. 25 for violating a village ordinance prohibiting raising poultry without a permit. ''The chickens can wait,'' Mrs.
Ashley said upon her release. ''I just want to be with my family and have a nice hot cup of tea.

LEAD: John Payne, an all-around actor who starred in nearly 50 films, mostly in the 1940's and 50's, died of a heart ailment Wednesday at his home in Malibu, Calif.
He was 77 years old.


Iraq Announces Test of a Rocket; U.S. Fails to Confirm Launching
LEAD: Iraq was reported to have said today that it has tested a large rocket capable of carrying satellites into space.
Such a move would step up the Middle East arms race because missiles that can carry satellites could also be used to carry warheads.


Gannett to End Partnership With Tinker in TV Concern
LEAD: Grant Tinker and the Gannett Company said yesterday that they had agreed to end their partnership in the GTG television production company.


Job Cuts Planned By Kelsey-Hayes
LEAD: The Varity Corporation's Kelsey-Hayes Company unit said it would cut 1,000 jobs because of substantial operating losses and a soft automotive market.
The company also said it would reorganize into four units.
The job cuts will come through layoffs, early retirements, voluntary resignations and terminations, the company said.


Dance
LEAD: Balletomanes sometimes bemoan the presence of children at performances of ''The Nutcracker.'' Aside from occasional candy-wrapper fidgeting that adults do even better, children make an ideal theater audience.
But what is good children's theater?
Some theater that bills itself as that is pretty awful and bores the kids as well, condescending to its audience by talking down and skimping on imagination and production elements.


Truck Tire Kills Motorist
LEAD: Robert T. Schwaegerle, 66, of Westport, Conn., was killed Wednesday and his wife, Beverly, seriously injured as a tire fell off a truck and struck the roof of their car on Interstate 80 in Clearfield County.
The car hurtled over an embankment and stopped in a ditch.
The tire apparently came from an 18-wheel tractor-trailer, and the truckman might not have been aware what had happened, the State Police said.


Officials in Philippines Tell How Leadership Nearly Lost
LEAD: As Philippine rebel troops returned to their barracks in an uneasy truce, officials here said today that the top military and political leadership of the country was nearly toppled a week ago at the height of the military rebellion against President Corazon C. Aquino.

LEAD: The president of the Alabama chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People began serving a four-year jail term here Wednesday on Federal bribery charges.
Thomas Reed, 61 years old, was ousted from his seat in the Alabama Legislature after he was convicted in September 1988 of accepting $10,000 as a bribe.

Theater
LEAD: Children at the theater are at once the most open-minded audience and the toughest critics.
Or such has been my experience with the children I have taken to the theater most often - boys between the ages of 4 and 10.
I have watched a 6-year-old who didn't know Dickens from Seuss eat up seven hours of ''Nicholas Nickleby'' (as well as a dinner-break pizza), held spellbound by the teeming action and the poignant figure of Smike.

Review/Art; Andres Serrano: Provocation And Spirituality
LEAD: ONE of the few, unintended benefits of the Congressional outrage against Andres Serrano is that it has brought widespread attention to a good artist.
His photographs are indeed provocative.
They are also serious art.
There are 14 of them at the Stux Gallery, including the reviled and dreaded one from 1987, with its 13-inch plastic-and-wood crucifix upright in a Plexiglas tank filled with the artist's urine.

Aid to Poland Sets Off a Fight Over Shipping
LEAD: American ships carrying food aid began arriving in Poland last week.
But they will deliver less food than they could, critics say, with correspondingly fewer benefits to American farmers, because of a law that results in higher shipping costs.

U.S.S. Iowa Returns to Port
LEAD: The battleship U.S.S.
Iowa, its No. 2 turret still sealed after an April explosion that killed 47 sailors, arrived today to cheers from the crew's family and friends after a six-month deployment in the Mediterranean.
The crew lined the rail as the Iowa docked at its home port.
About 1,000 family members and friends, who greeted the sight of the ship with cheers, waited patiently for her to dock.

Dining Out
LEAD: When I was a typical wide-eyed youngster coming to New York City from rural New Jersey with my mother to see the holiday sights, fine dining was not exactly high on my shopping list.
Sitting in a hushed dining room for an hour would have been as torturous as being shackled to the sofa on Christmas morning and watching my sister tear open all my presents.

Upheaval in the East; Warsaw Curbs Statue Rallies
LEAD: The Solidarity-led Government said today that it will not tolerate more demonstrations at a monument to Lenin where anti-Soviet protesters trying to destroy the statue have twice clashed with the police.

LEAD: The East German Communist Party leadership moved up the opening of its critical party congress to Friday because of growing fear that the country would fall into chaos if it waited seven more days, senior officials said today.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.H.L.
Flyers 4, Sabres 3: Ron Sutter scored 1 minute 24 seconds into overtime last night in Philadelphia, beating the goalie, Darren Puppa, with a backhander from the goal mouth after Buffalo had forced overtime by rallying from a 3-1 deficit on a goal by Mike Foligno with 11 seconds left in regulation.


South Brazil Cheers Break In Berlin Wall
LEAD: Only weeks after Oktoberfest, church steeples here have cause for celebration again: the breach in the Berlin wall.


Parking Rules
LEAD: Because of the Feast of the Immaculate Conception, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today.
Other regulations remain in effect.


Many Wrongly Losing U.S. Payments
LEAD: Many beneficiaries of a Social Security program for poor people who are aged, blind or disabled have been mistakenly dropped from the rolls because a reduced staff cannot handle the workload, an agency study says.


C. M. Dellums, 89; Led Rail Porters Union
LEAD: C. L. Dellums, a labor and civil rights leader, died yesterday of cardiac arrest in Oakland, Calif., where he lived for the last 66 years.
He was 89 years old.


Players and Owners Taking Divergent Courses in Talks
LEAD: Not that anybody expected baseball's labor negotiations to proceed smoothly and quickly, but with the two sides talking on two different planes, the owners and the players will very likely take a long time to get nowhere.


L.I. Doctor, Fined in Prostitution Case, Kills Himself, the Police Say
LEAD: A Southampton, L.I., doctor convicted of prostitution for soliciting college students to have sex with his wife was found dead yesterday, apparently a suicide victim.


Sheldon A. Vogel, 68, A Retired Lawyer, Dies
LEAD: Sheldon A. Vogel, a former partner in the Manhattan law firm of Thacher Proffitt &amp; Wood, died of respiratory failure on Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan.
He was 68 years old and lived in Manhattan and Coronado, Calif.


Dow Falls By 15.99; Chevron Off
LEAD: Stocks moved broadly lower yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 15.99 points, to 2,720.78.

LEAD: Washington is embarking on another drug-of-the-month war, the third since 1986.
Like its predecessors, our nation's latest war is destined to be another fool's errand because of its narrow focus on illegal drugs and its failure to confront society's pervasive problem of addiction.

Review/Theater; Everett Quinton Seeks the Foulness Within in 'Dr. Jekyll'
LEAD: There's a psychotic killer loose in Coxsackie, N.Y., the setting for the Ridiculous Theatrical Company's new production of ''Dr.
Jekyll and Mr.
Hyde.'' The killer, a formerly mild-mannered librarian, has dismembered 16 1/2 bodies.
Dr.
Henry Jekyll of the Coxsackie Medical Institute believes this is no ordinary criminal.


F.B.I. Arrests Advocate for the Wrongly Convicted
LEAD: The head of a newly formed advocacy group for people wrongfully convicted has been arrested on Federal drug and conspiracy charges after a Federal agent recognized him in newspaper photographs taken at a fund-raising event.


Broncos Are Playing For Home Advantage
LEAD: The Denver Broncos (10-3) have clinched the American Conference West title but have plenty to gain in a rematch of Super Bowl XXI against the Giants (9-4) Sunday in Mile High Stadium.


When New York, to a Child, Is a Stocking Full of Gifts
LEAD: Everyone talks about how magical New York is for children at Christmas, but coping with the city at holiday time is never easy.
Here and on page C22 are suggestions from seven New York Times critics on how to give children the best of New York in every realm, from architecture to theater to restaurants.


Firefighters in Yonkers March on City Hall
LEAD: About 300 Yonkers firefighters and their families marched on City Hall today, as their union leader accused the Fire Commissioner of neglecting them.


Man Admits Killing Parents for Drug Money
LEAD: A 23-year-old Brooklyn man admitted yesterday that he fatally beat his parents and nephew with a baseball bat before stealing money from them to buy drugs.


European Jobless Rate
LEAD: The unemployment rate in the European Community held steady at 9.1 percent in October, the same as in September, but was down from 9.7 percent a year earlier, the community's statistical office, Eurostat, said today.


Fiber-Optic Tie Sought For Soviets U S West Plans Fiber-Optic Telephone Line for Soviets
LEAD: U S West Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to lead a corporation formed by the Soviet Union and seven other international telephone companies that plans to lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union, linking Japan and Europe.

Saidenberg of Manhattan wrote in the short note she enclosed this week with her $150 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases


Bonwit Sale Move
LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation said it would seek approval of a Federal Bankruptcy Court in Manhattan to retain Financo Inc. to sell its Bonwit Teller and Sakowitz Inc. specialty stores.
Financo is a New York investment banker specializing in mergers and acquisitions.
Sanford C. Sigoloff, Hooker's chief executive, said Bonwit Teller continued to show improvement, but ''Hooker management felt that the best way to maximize returns was through a sale.


BRIEFS
LEAD:  Debt


Obscenity in Art Cannot Be Generalized
LEAD: To the Editor:


Pearl Harbor Remembered
LEAD: A thousand people gathered at two sites today to remember the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor that killed 2,403 soldiers, sailors and civilians and propelled the United States into World War II.
Simultaneous ceremonies on the 48th anniversary of the attack were held by the Navy aboard the U.S.S.
Arizona Memorial, which spans the hull of the sunken battleship that serves as the final resting place for 1,102 Navy officers and enlisted men, and onshore at the Arizona Memorial Visitors Center.


Option Granted On Fischbach
LEAD: The Miami financier Victor Posner said today that he had granted to American International Group Inc. the option to buy his controlling interest in the Fischbach Corporation, the nation's largest electrical contractor.


Return L.I.'s Barrier Islands to Nature, a Panel Urges
LEAD: A Long Island planning agency recommended today that almost 5,000 houses and businesses on Fire Island and in other shore resort areas threatened by erosion be gradually eliminated and that the barrier islands they stand on be returned to nature.


Review/Film; Streep Spars With Barr In a Comedy of Revenge
LEAD: Watching Meryl Streep at work in Susan Seidelman's ''She-Devil'' is to behold a magnificent illusionist at work.
Miss Streep dives into this thimble-sized comedy and makes one believe - at least, while she is on the screen - that it is an Olympic-sized swimming pool of wit.


Wild Greenwich Tract Being Divided Into Lots
LEAD: The last of the great private estates that helped give Greenwich, Conn., its patrician character - a 169-acre wilderness area in the town's northwest corner - has been sold and the first phase of subdividing it has been approved.


Auctions
LEAD:  Verdi Letters


Prices of U.S. Issues Fall Again
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped again in light trading yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for this morning's release of November employment data.


Hank Jones Trio
LEAD: Hank Jones, a pianist, is leading a trio tonight through Sunday at Carlos 1, 432 Avenue of the Americas, at Ninth Street (982-3260).
Sets begin at 9 and 11 P.M., plus a 12:30 A.M. set tonight and tomorrow.
There is a $10 cover with a $7 minimum at tables and $10 admission at the bar.


India's Chief, at Golden Temple, Vows to Heal Punjab
LEAD: In his first official trip out of the capital since becoming Prime Minister of India, V. P. Singh went to Amritsar today to pray at the holiest shrine of the Sikhs, promising to heal ''the heavy, bleeding heart'' of Punjab state.
Thousands have died in confrontations there in the last five years.


Upheaval in the East; Benin, Too, Gives Up Marxism for Reforms
LEAD: This West African nation today followed the lead of Eastern-bloc countries and abandoned Marxism-Leninism, its ideology for the last 15 years.


Corrections
LEAD: A theater review on Nov. 15 about the Roundabout Theater Company's production of Shakespeare's ''Tempest'' misinterpreted a gesture.
The actors' intent was to portray 18th-century gentlemen taking snuff, not cocaine.


Philadelphia Journal; City Steeped in History: Bell in '76, Bomb in '85
LEAD: Fodor's 1989 guide to this city says it is a place of ''audacious uniqueness'' where the Declaration of Independence was signed, where people shout ''Yo!'' in greetings and where ''the city's first black Mayor, W. Wilson Goode, made a perverse kind of history by approving the bombing of a neighborhood.


Click: Up, Down and Out at Kodak
LEAD: In an unusually blunt shoot-out at the top, the Eastman Kodak Company announced yesterday that Kay R. Whitmore, the company's president, will succeed Colby H. Chandler as chief executive next year and that his chief rival for Mr.
Chandler's job, J. Phillip Samper, will retire as vice chairman by the end of the year at the age of 55.


Nissan Sued by U.S. Couple; Was Boarder Really a Spy?
LEAD: To Stephen and Maritza French, the Japanese businessman boarding in their home for six weeks seemed a polite guest who worked at improving his English and even volunteered to help wash the family car.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, DECEMBER 9, 1989
LEAD:  INTERNATIONAL


Computers Speed Up Post Office Service
LEAD: New computers have arrived at the United States Postal Service in time to speed some holiday lines.
They are not everywhere yet, but the new devices handle virtually all of the manual transactions once performed by the clerk.


Dinkins Names Eight Appointees, Including Four Deputy Mayors
LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins named eight appointees to his administration yesterday, including an experienced Federal prosecutor to head the New York City Department of Investigation, with responsibility for uncovering corruption in government.


Upheaval in the East; Attack on Depots Discounted
LEAD: East Germany's National People's Army said today that there were no mob attacks on its depots this week.
The denial was issued after Radio D.D.R. reported that that such attacks had taken place.
A spokesman said that groups showed signs of wanting to attack the depots, perhaps to obtain weapons, but that they did not carry out the attacks.


Drifter Charged in Killing on Lower East Side
LEAD: A teen-age drifter who ran away from a Louisiana psychiatric hospital three months ago was arrested yesterday and accused of the fatal stabbing of an advertising executive on the Lower East Side, the police said.


Better Traps Being Built For Delinquent Parents
LEAD: The Delaware County Domestic Relations Court here has devised a new way to find people who fail to pay child support and elude arrest: the court advertises their names on a ''Most Wanted'' list 300 times a week on cable television and once a month in full-page newspaper advertisements.


Your Money; Caution, Patience: Advice for the 90's
LEAD: For investors considering what year-end moves to make in their portfolios, the watchword from Wall Street experts is prudence. ''Nineteen-ninety may well be a year to sow rather than to reap,'' said Robert J. Farrell, chief market analyst at Merrill Lynch &amp; Company. ''Rates of return on stocks could well be below average, in general, after 10 years of far above-average returns in the 1980's.


Chevron Acts to Bar Pennzoil
LEAD: In what some analysts said was a surprisingly fast rush to the barricades, the Chevron Corporation said today that it had asked a Federal court to force the Pennzoil Company to sell its 8.8 percent stake in Chevron and to block Pennzoil from buying more shares.


Corrections
LEAD: A headline in some copies yesterday on the obituary of a labor and civil rights leader misidentified him.

LEAD:  A 64-Billion-Ruble Question


A SOVIET WARNING ON CHANGE'S LIMITS
LEAD: Seeking to forestall internal challenges to its guaranteed leading role in Soviet society, the Communist Party leadership signaled today that the issue is not off limits for discussion but said that such a change would harm the country.


FIFA Rejects NBC's Deal to Televise '94 World Cup
LEAD: The executive committee of FIFA, soccer's international governing body, announced today that it would not approve the television contract arranged between the United States Soccer Federation and NBC for the 1994 World Cup tournament, which will be held in the United States.

Alvin Ailey, typically, never tired of crediting those who inspired him in the late 1940's to become a professional dancer.
These figures were Lester Horton, the modern-dance visionary in Los Angeles who recruited him into his company, and Katherine


Opera, Saturday Afternoon, Live
LEAD: This afternoon's Texaco broadcast of Richard Strauss' ''Die Frau Ohne Schatten'' is a milestone for the Metropolitan Opera, opera in America and corporate support for the arts.
It begins the 50th season of Saturday matinee grand opera on radio, live from the Metropolitan stage.
And it marks the longest continuous sponsorship of any program by one company.


Patents; Keeping the Fizz In Soft Drink Bottles
LEAD: Two brothers have patented a new bottle for people who buy soft drinks in economical two-liter containers and want to drink them over time without losing the fizz.
Working in their kitchen in Cherry Hill, N.J., Stephen and Robert Tullman have fashioned a bottle that they say keeps 68 percent of its carbonation several hours after being drained half empty, compared with about 19 percent for a conventional bottle.


Gold Medal for Architect
LEAD: The architect Fay Jones has been chosen as the 48th recipient of architecture's highest award, the American Institute of Architects Gold Medal, the A.I.A. announced yesterday.
The 58-year-old Mr.
Jones, who was Frank Lloyd Wright's apprentice in the 1950's, is to receive the medal on Feb. 22 as part of the Accent on Architecture awards gala at the National Building Museum in Washington.


Rogers Found Guilty
LEAD: Five hours after beginning deliberations, a Circuit Court jury in Pontiac, Mich., yesterday found Reggie Rogers, a former Detroit Lions defensive end, guilty on three reduced counts of negligent homicide in the deaths of three teen-agers on Oct. 20, 1988, in a car accident involving Rogers.
Circuit Judge Gene Schnelz scheduled sentencing for Jan.


4 Psychologists Cleared in Kitty Dukakis Inquiry
LEAD: A state board has decided not to take disciplinary action against four psychologists who were quoted in a newspaper article that speculated about the possible reasons for Kitty Dukakis's depression and alcohol abuse.


Chang Out 6-12 Weeks After Workout Injury
LEAD: In a year in which he peaked in Paris in May, Michael Chang hit a valley in Florida yesterday.
Chang, the first American man to win the French Open in 34 years, learned he would be sidelined 6 to 12 weeks after fracturing a hip joint Wednesday in practice for a tournament in Palm Coast this weekend.

LEAD: An editorial last Saturday mistakenly asserted that Mackinac Island was in the district of Representative Bob Traxler, Democrat of Michigan and chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee for the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
Mr.
Traxler bought property on Mackinac and championed a H.U.D.

LEAD: Whatever else they were saying at a party congress tonight, the East German Communists had really gathered to bury the remnants of a party that had ruled with an iron hand for 40 years, in the hope that something new could still sprout in its place.

LEAD: These days, nurses from Tri-County Home Healthcare Services Inc. in Coral Springs, Fla., sometimes find more than a sick patient when they visit a home.
Just-delivered boxes of complex home medical equipment may also clutter the doorstep of the ill.


Boeing to Offer A New-Size Jet
LEAD: The Boeing Company said today that its commercial aircraft division would begin offering airlines a new twin-engine jet of a size between the existing 767-300 and 747-400.


CZECH CHIEF LOOKS TO INDEPENDENTS FOR NEW CABINET
LEAD: Czechoslovakia's acting Prime Minister, in his second day in office, said tonight that he wanted half his cabinet to be made up of people outside political parties.
Such a cabinet would put the Communists in a minority and go a long way toward meeting opposition demands.

LEAD: India's new Prime Minister, V. P. Singh, turned his attention today to New Delhi's most pressing foreign-policy problem: the restoration of good relations with Sri Lanka, where 25,000 Indian troops are stationed against the wishes of the Sri Lankan Government.

LEAD: Because Giuseppe Sinopoli is frequently mentioned as a possible successor to Zubin Mehta as music director of the New York Philharmonic, his guest appearances at the head of the orchestra excite more than routine curiosity.
In some respects, the bushy-bearded Italian is a puzzle, a conductor who is fascinated by the largest and gaudiest pieces in the repertory but does not seem to have a natural affinity for such extravagance.

Sinking the Boat People
LEAD: Nothing is more unfashionable than yesterday's victims.
This is the fate of more than 50,000 Vietnamese boat people now threatened with forced repatriation from refugee camps in Hong Kong.
No longer ''victims of Communist tyranny,'' they are merely ''illegal immigrants,'' in the words of Prime Minister Thatcher of Britain.


Upheaval in the East; Castro Says He'll Resist Changes Like Those Sweeping Soviet Bloc
LEAD: In his bluntest public rejection yet of the profound political and economic changes now sweeping the rest of the Soviet bloc, President Fidel Castro of Cuba has vowed to resist all such reforms even if it means a parting of the ways with his allies.


N.F.L. Finds No Proof Eagles Offered Bounties
LEAD: The National Football League said yesterday that it had no proof that bounties were placed on Dallas Cowboy players by the Philadelphia Eagles for a game Nov. 23.
The league also said it did not have any evidence there was intent to cause deliberate injuries.


Weak Market for Exports Pushes Pork Bellies Down
LEAD: Pork belly futures prices plunged yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as concern over lagging exports prompted traders to bail out of the weak market.
Livestock futures were also lower.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded and yields tumbled yesterday.

Israel Unterman; Professor, 68
LEAD: Israel Unterman, a professor of management at San Diego State University, died Dec. 1 from congestive heart failure at his home in La Jolla, Calif.
He was 68 years old.


Salvador Says Rebel Now Ties American to Arms
LEAD: Senior army and police officials say a rebel gunrunner has told them that a woman seized last month in a raid on her property knew that a cache of weapons was buried there.
The woman, who is being held without bond in a Salvadoran prison, has denied knowing of the arms cache.


Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Wednesday about a concert by the American Chamber Players at the Frick Collection on Sunday misidentified the ensemble's violinist.
She is Elisabeth Adkins.

LEAD: The long-running inquiry into Pentagon fraud edged closer to former senior Defense Department officials today when a New York military contracting company admitted in court that it had illegally obtained inside purchasing information from the Navy and Air Force.


Unions, Docile Since '81, Show New Militancy
LEAD: The militancy that has made workers' movements so conspicuous in the struggle for human rights in Eastern Europe, China and Latin America shows incipient signs of resurgence in the U.S. trade unions for the first time since Ronald Reagan fired 11,500 striking Federal air traffic controllers and smashed their union in 1981.


Plan Seen as Hurdle to Correcting Census
LEAD: The Federal Government issued a proposal today that creates new obstacles for New York City and other urban areas that seek to correct the 1990 census to make up for undercounting minorities and the poor.


Seoul and Moscow Set Up Partial Ties
LEAD: South Korea and the Soviet Union today announced an unusual form of consular relations that many analysts consider a significant step toward establishing full diplomatic relations.

Producer Is Accused Of Cruising Projects For Sex With Boys
LEAD: A movie producer was arrested yesterday and accused of picking up teen-age boys in New York City housing projects and taking them to New Jersey motels for sex, the police said.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Holiday Tipping
LEAD: The holiday season is tipping time, and often it is hard to know what is fair or wanted.
There are no hard, fast rules for tipping.
If someone has been serving you all year and you tip regularly, your gift should reflect that fact as well as the quality of the service.
How much you tip also depends on where you live.


At Least 3 Inmates Are Dead In Riots at 4 Polish Prisons
LEAD: Inmates rioted at four prisons today after lawmakers rejected a proposed amnesty for repeat offenders, the authorities said.
At least three prisoners died, the Government said, but the circumstances of the deaths were not clear.

Stone, misstated conclusions of a grand jury that examined the death of 18-year-old Libby Zion after treatment at that hospital.
The jury, which issued no indictment, said ''a definitive cause of death cannot be established.

LEAD: When Martin Keino, a 17-year-old senior at Fork Union Military Academy in Virginia, suddenly emerged this fall as one of the country's top high school distance runners, there was a logical explanation.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Shopping for a Nursing Home
LEAD: The need to find a nursing home often comes suddenly, requiring quick decisions.
Although only 5 percent of the nation's elderly are in nursing homes at any time, about 20 to 30 percent of the population can expect to enter a home during their lifetime.

LEAD: In her first public appearance since the Philippine Government was nearly toppled, an angry President Corazon C. Aquino today named three men - the country's Vice President, its chief opposition leader and her own cousin - as the leading suspects in the abortive rebellion.

John the Divine.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article and a headline yesterday about the Social Security Administration referred incorrectly in some editions to a Government assistance program from which people were suspended.
It was the Supplemental Security Income Program, covering poor people who are aged, blind or disabled; the people were not suspended from the Social Security program.


Deer Hunter Is Indicted in Accidental Killing of Woman in Maine
LEAD: A year after a grand jury declined to indict him, a second grand jury in Bangor today charged a deer hunter with manslaughter in the accidental killing of a 37-year-old woman in her backyard.


Soviets Seek U.S. Venture
LEAD: A Soviet research institute is negotiating to become a part owner of a Silicon Valley high-technology company.


School Government Needs Overhaul, Board President Says
LEAD: The president of the Board of Education, Robert F. Wagner Jr., called yesterday for a radical overhaul of New York City's decentralized school government, saying the new Schools Chancellor would need ''some basic structural reforms'' to succeed.


U.S. Argument In Lincoln Case
LEAD: Government lawyers, trying to justify a Federal takeover last April of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, argued in court today that the company had attempted a number of times to portray itself as profitable when it was not.


U.S. Seizes New Jersey Savings Bank
LEAD: Federal regulators seized New Jersey's largest savings association today after the institution recorded large losses from real estate ventures in New Jersey, Florida and Texas.

LEAD: May Garelick McClintock, an author and editor of children's books, died of cancer Wednesday at the Village Nursing Home in Manhattan.
She was 84 years old.

LEAD: Those stubborn price tags that stick tenaciously to holiday gifts can generally be removed with a little patience and the right remedy.

LEAD: Two Essex County investigators were convicted by a Federal jury today of protecting a drug dealer, who is an admitted killer, in exchange for cocaine, cash and valuables.

LEAD: The dollar ended marginally weaker yesterday against most key currencies after the Government reported that the jobless rate rose last month to a 10-month high of 5.3 percent.

The start would be Ryan's first of the season.

Pfizer Stock Drop
LEAD: The stock of Pfizer Inc. tumbled $4.375 a share yesterday, to $69.125, on the New York Stock Exchange after the health-care concern said it expects a modest decline in fourth-quarter profits compared with the corresponding period a year ago. ''As a result it seems likely that net income for the year 1989 will show a decline of somewhat less than 10 percent as compared to 1988,'' Pfizer said.

LEAD: Joe Reekie, the Islander defenseman who has been an important part of the team's four-game string of victories, broke two bones in his left hand in a car accident in Huntington, L.I., early yesterday and could miss four weeks of play.


Blues forFading Reds
LEAD: Republicans can't believe their luck.
Gorbachev happened on their watch, yet it makes them nervous.
They should be joyous, because in politics you get the credit for good things that happen on your watch and the blame for disasters.


History of Another 'Apres-Midi d'un Faune'
LEAD: Vaslav Nijinsky's strange and haunting ballet ''L'Apres-midi d'un Faune,'' created in 1912 for Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, has enjoyed new popularity in recent years.
But is the popular version entirely authentic?
Ann Hutchinson Guest, the founder and former director of the Dance Notation Bureau in New York, says it is not.


Gunman Kills Four and Then Himself
LEAD: A gunman armed with a shotgun and handgun broke into the home of his former wife early today and killed her, their two daughters and her new husband before killing himself, the authorities said.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Nuggets 103, Celtics 102: Michael Adams scored 18 of his 20 points in the second half as Denver overcame a 16-point deficit last night at Boston Garden.
Trailing by 1 point, Boston got the ball with 23 seconds left when Larry Bird won a jump ball from Adams.
But Kevin McHale missed a 12-foot jumper with 5 seconds left and the ball bounced off the rim and rolled to midcourt as time ran out.(AP)

LEAD:  THE STARS, THE SNOW, THE FIRE  Twenty-five Years in the Northern Wilderness.
By John Haines.  182 pp.
St.
Paul: Graywolf Press. $16.


Fresno State Wins Bowl
LEAD: Ron Cox, a linebacker, led a ferocious defense and returned an interception 58 yards for a touchdown today as Fresno State defeated Ball State, 27-6, in the California Raisin Bowl.


Social Studies: The Christmas Lunch and the Office Party
LEAD: Shoppers teemed like a herd of burden at lunchtime last week.
Balancing bags from F. A. O. Schwarz, Bergdorf Goodman and Henri Bendel, their breath rose like blizzard clouds above them on the frigid Fifth Avenue sidewalk.
Near 60th Street, two panhandlers, cloaked in matching trash bags, shuffled.


TALKING TO HIMSELF, BUT VERY LOUD
LEAD:  THE SECRET SPEECHES OF CHAIRMAN MAO  From the Hundred Flowers to the Great Leap Forward.
Edited by Roderick MacFarquhar,  Timothy Cheek and Eugene Wu.  561 pp.
Cambridge, Mass.:  The Council on East Asian Studies/  Harvard University Press.
Paper, $15.


New Turmoil Over Police in Houston
LEAD: In the last six weeks, two Houston police officers have shot and killed motorists after traffic stops.
Two other officers were found guilty in rape cases.
One more was arrested for heroin possession, one was charged with coercing sex from a prostitute, one was reassigned amid charges of police harassment and two officers' houses were searched as part of a drug investigation.


Borland Returns Home
LEAD: It must have seemed like a good idea at the time - when Borland International Inc. went public on the London Stock Exchange in 1986.
Listing in the United Kingdom was far less costly than in the United States.
But the move has proved a liability because it has made it hard for American investors to buy into the Scotts Valley, Calif.-based software company.


Super Failures Haunt Broncos
LEAD: The Louisiana Superdome in November of last year was the site of a deep soul-searching session by the Denver Broncos.
They had just been destroyed by the New Orleans Saints, 42-0, and had fallen to 6-6.
And what the Broncos would not say about the debacle, the Saints' quarterback, Bobby Hebert, would.


Miss Athans Weds Leonidas Demas
LEAD: Stacey Elaine Athans, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Michael Athans of Garden City, L.I., was married yesterday in Hempstead, L.I., to Leonidas George Demas, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
George Demas of Holiday, Fla.
The Rev.
Nicholas J. Magoulias officiated at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St.
Paul.


Featherweight Title Retained by Paez
LEAD: Jorge Paez, the International Boxing Federation featherweight champion, retained his title today when he stopped Lupe Gutierrez, a game challenger, at 2 minutes 1 second of the sixth round of a scheduled 12-round fight.


POSTINGS: Douglas Elliman Sold; Milsteins Buy Firm
LEAD: Douglas Elliman &amp; Company, one of Manhattan's largest and most prominent residential brokerage and management companies, has been sold, a victim of internal dissension and the sour real estate market.
Founded in 1911, the firm was bought by a partnership involving five members of the Milstein family, which is active in New York real estate.


Old Fighters
LEAD: After nine years the rematch between Sugar Ray Leonard and Roberto Duran was just what a fight fan should have expected: two middleweights who were nine years older, a little slower and a little richer than they were at their last encounter.
But the 16,000 fans who turned up last week in Las Vegas were booing at the lack of action as Mr.

LEAD: An answer in the Q.&amp;A. column on Nov. 26 misstated the registration fee for the Global Home Exchange and Travel Service.
It is $35.


Guard's Allotments in Drug War Approved
LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has approved the state-by-state spending allotments that the National Guard will use for its expanded role in the national war against drugs.

LEAD: After staying up all night to direct a firefight with the American-backed guerrillas besieging this shattered town, Brig.
Gen.
Abdul Sattar made a picture of bullish confidence as he relaxed in the late-autumn sunshine and stroked his moustache.

No Money in the Microwave, Please
LEAD: ONE STORY THEY LIKE TO TELL at the Office of Currency Standards is about the farmer whose cow ate his wallet.
The O.C.S., part of the Treasury Department's Bureau of Engraving and Printing, will replace damaged currency for individuals or institutions, provided the claimant meets certain criteria.


SAVINGS REGULATOR PLANS ASSET SALES
LEAD: L. William Seidman, who manages the special regulatory agency created to liquidate and find buyers for the troubled properties held by failed savings institutions, said today that about 40,000 properties were being prepared for sale in 1990.
About half, he said, are in Texas and Oklahoma.

The Taxi Industry Wins Again
LEAD: In one respect, New York City's latest cab fare increase may be a blessing in disguise.
It doesn't do riders any good, but it might remind Mayor-elect David Dinkins that if he means to serve the public, he has to fight the taxi cartel.


A Slovak Goes From Prison to Power
LEAD: More than anyone else, Jan Carnogursky, a slight, diffident Slovak lawyer and civil-rights campaigner, personifies the rapid dismantling of one-party Communist rule in Czechoslovakia.


A Year-Round Caribbean Resort
LEAD: BY 10 o'clock on a Sunday morning, the disco music was drifting up from the hotel patio and a splashy game of volleyball was going in the mango-shaped swimming pool.
A towel attendant was dancing behind his counter.
A couple of people in bathing suits were playing table tennis.
Most of the lounge chairs were filled with pink bodies yearning for a tan, and the bar was busily turning out pina coladas and rum punches.


CORRECTION
LEAD: Because of incorrect information supplied by Lenz Riecker Publishers, the Q &amp; A column on Nov. 5 misstated the number to use when ordering a copy of the New York State Rent Stabilization Code.


Review/Jazz; Hopkins and Murray Plus 2
LEAD: The bassist Fred Hopkins and the cellist Deidre Murray love music's lower depths.
The quartet they assembled for a concert Wednesday at the Alternative Museum included the baritone Andy Bey and Brandon Ross on electric guitar, and their music rippled and churned in a register most groups use primarily for accompaniment.


Giants Lacking a High Gear
LEAD: They created the most memorable moments of the Giants' victory in Super Bowl XXI: Phil McConkey waving a towel to stir up the crowd, Jim Burt celebrating with his son on his shoulders, Harry Carson dumping Gatorade on Coach Bill Parcells.


WHAT'S DOING IN: Honolulu
LEAD: Honolulu is an easy place to know and love if you give it half a chance.
Some promoters call it a paradise, but it isn't.
It is a city - commercial, expensive, noisy and tacky.
It has traffic, drugs and street people.
It also has abundant natural and manmade beauty, exceptional weather, exotic foods, friendly people, low unemployment, virtually no heavy industry.


Jury Awards $1 Million in Buddhist Suit
LEAD: A State Supreme Court jury has awarded a Westchester County man $1 million after determining that a neighboring Zen Buddhist religious community created a nuisance when it put 200 fluorescent stakes around his property and used chainsaws and power equipment at odd hours.


A TAKEOVER BATTLE LEFT CARBIDE THE MOST VULNERABLE
LEAD: Perhaps the only major chemical company that remains very vulnerable to the commodity-chemical cycle is the Union Carbide Corporation.
As part of a restructuring aimed at warding off a 1984 takeover attempt by the GAF Corporation, Carbide sold its consumer products businesses, its agricultural businesses and most of its European operations.


WEEDS ARE US
LEAD: As I explained to Michael Pollan, ''Time Landscape'' is not a 19th-century greenhouse encased in glass, but a landscape history interweaving with the 20th century, which illustrates the concept of co-existence rather than domination.
It is a narrative and environmental sculpture, recording the history of Greenwich Vilage, from the time prior to human intervention and continuing to the present.


Tasty Options to Costly Gifts
LEAD: SOME friends of mine have never allowed their children to buy them Christmas gifts.
All presents must be homemade.
So over the years they have received the most touching presents, many of which required hours of careful planning and hard work.
Of course, there were the inevitable misshapen pieces of pottery and the peculiar bits of knitting that came unraveled almost at once.


TALKING: Equity Loans; Shopping For the Best Deal
LEAD: SINCE the Tax Reform Act of 1986, equity loans on homes have become one of the few remaining ways to borrow a large sum of money on which interest charges are tax deductible.
Thus it has become an increasingly desirable way to finance anything from a new car to college tuition.


A Sudden 2-Token Limit Is as Quickly Taken Back
LEAD: The Transit Authority in New York City unexpectedly imposed a two-token sales limit yesterday to curtail hoarding, but riders' anger and long lines at token booths - unusual for a Saturday - prompted officials to lift the restriction hours after it was imposed.

WEEDS ARE US
LEAD: In the last few years I haven't had a client who hasn't asked me to design a wildflower meadow for him, thinking it would be maintenance-free, effortlessly and constantly beautiful - and somehow morally superior because it's natural.
I've had a difficult time persuading them that without considerable maintenance they'd end up with the ''weed-filled-empty-lot'' look and that a wildflower meadow isn't at all natural in a 20-by-50-foot city backyard.

Hans Hartung, European Pioneer Of Abstract Painting, Dies at 85
LEAD: Hans Hartung, a pioneer of European abstract painting, a prominent figure in the Parisian art world from 1945 onward and the winner in 1960 of the Grand Prize at the Venice Biennale, died on Thursday at his home in Antibes, France.
He was 85.

Phillies Sign Howell
LEAD: The Philadelphia Phillies have signed the right-hander Ken Howell to a one-year contract worth $615,000 after he posted a 12-12 record last season, tying Jeff Parrett for the team's leadership in victories.
Howell was not a free agent, but could have taken the club to salary arbitration.
Last season, his first with the Phillies after being acquired in the off season from Baltimore, the 29-year-old Howell made $225,000.


Switzerland Is Seeking to Curb Money Laundering
LEAD: Stung by the country's reputation as a place of preference for money laundering by international drug traders, the Swiss Government is showing signs of changing its policy after decades of defending banking laws that made it easy for depositors to hide the origins of money.

LEAD: Two Palestinians were shot and killed today on the second anniversary of the start of the uprising in the occupied territories, as Israeli and Arab figures made it clear that neither side was willing to make concessions to bring the violence to an end.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service is completing a month-long market test of a 25-cent self-stick stamp that does not have to be licked.

LEAD: ''Rod Stewart: Storyteller/The Complete Anthology: 1964-1990'' (Warner Bros. 25987, four CD's only) is an attempt to do for Mr.
Stewart what ''Decade'' did for Neil Young and, not that he really needed it, ''Biograph'' did for Bob Dylan.
In other words, it aims to tie a diverse career together and make a serious case for its subject.

Edward J. Bloustein, 64, Is Dead; President of Rutgers Since 1971
LEAD: Dr.
Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University since 1971, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he was attending a business meeting.
Dr.
Bloustein lived in the president's house on the school's New Brunswick-Piscataway campus.
He was 64 years old.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation has quietly begun selling computer monitors that contain special technology intended to reduce the user's exposure to electromagnetic radiation.

Selling Out
LEAD: The farming community of Taylor, N.Y., is sharply divided over the prospect of a nuclear waste dump being located in the area: it's Arthur Allen versus everybody else.
Mr.
Allen, who says he can no longer make a living from his 730-acre dairy farm in upstate New York, is the only person in New York State who has said he is willing to sell his land for use as a low-level nuclear waste dump.

It's not my regular beat.
My name is Friedman.
I'm a country singer who writes mystery novels.
A perfectly logical choice to investigate Larry Gelbart and Cy Coleman's new Broadway musical.
So I took the case.
The story of ''City of Angels'' - which opens tomorrow at the Virginia Theater - is the story of Stine, a Chandleresque mystery novelist, and his fictional detective, Stone.

LEAD: AT holiday time, it is easy to revise a line by Ford Madox Ford, proclaiming that ''only two classes of books are of universal appeal: the very best and the very worst.'' FICTION
LEAD:  REBEL WITHOUT A CLUE.
By Holly Uyemoto. (Crown, $17.95.) In this deceptive novel, adult concerns like power, fame, intimacy and mortality are tackled expertly, as is realistic dialogue laced with the macho accents of two male adolescents.
But the writer is neither an experienced author nor a man.

LEAD:  CLASSICAL  Mozart: Piano Sonatas (K. 309, 457), Fantasies (K. 396, 397, 475)  Cyprien Katsaris, piano.
Teldec CD 244 191; CD only.
This is not your usual Mozart.
Mr.
Katsaris makes no attempt to imitate a fortepiano or play a ''Classic'' Mozart.
He feels the music Romantically and uses plenty of pedal (without any blurring) and large washes of color.


LOW TALES OF THE HIGHBORN
LEAD: Michael Pye misses the real point, which is that the entire content of a newspaper is virtually gossip (''Low Tales of the Highborn,'' Nov. 12).
Take, as an example, the articles about the youths accused in the attack on the Central Park jogger.
Anything beyond the fact that an attack took place and that one should attend to one's safety is gossip.

Michigan Plane Crash Kills 4
LEAD: A private plane crashed shortly after taking off today, killing the pilot, his son and two other passengers, the police said.
The pilot, Mark A. O'Donnell, 40 years old, died at a hospital about two hours after his single-engine Cessna 172 crashed in a cornfield, the police said.
His son, Mark E. O'Donnell, 10, and the passengers, Richard Maser, 42, and Charles Lawrence, 54, were killed instantly.

Reviews/Music; Opera Students in Stravinsky's 'Rake's Progress'
LEAD: Igor Stravinsky's opera ''The Rake's Progress'' (1951) is a monument to artifice.
Determinedly awash in what the composer called ''the early cliches I have tried to re-establish,'' the libretto of W. H. Auden and Chester Kallman echoes almost every device of 18th-century opera, and the score revels in the results of Stravinsky's three-year immersion in Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte.

What's That I Hear? Far Too Much
LEAD: SOMETIME between its headline-snaring decisions about flag burning and about abortion limits, the United States Supreme Court handed down a decision affirming the right of New York City to limit the volume of rock concerts in Central Park's open-air bandshell.
With luck, the precedent will ripple out to communities everywhere, eventually reducing some of the torment imposed on captive audiences by mega-decibel noise.

Grenada's Pungent, Versatile Nutmeg
LEAD: ONE of the oddest commodities in my mother's kitchen was an institutional-size tin of grated nutmeg that always gave me a funny feeling.
Other mothers bought their spices by the ounce.
Mine invested by the pound.
Going to Grenada finally put that tin in perspective.
As I walked through the nutmeg processing station in the coastal town of Gouyave, peering into spice-filled bins nearly the size of my bedroom and listening to literally tons of whole nutmegs rattling down chutes to be sorted, my mother's tin shrank in my memory to less than the size of a single grated speck of the spice.


Two for Tea, or Rum, or Tennis
LEAD: COMPARED with some of the orgiastic, rum-drenched singles resorts that have flourished in the Caribbean in recent years, Sandals, a couples-only club in Ocho Rios, seems like a religious seaside retreat.
That's not to say that there aren't a lot of bibulous fraternity-bash shenanigans at night, but the difference is that at Sandals the mirthmakers return to the dorm under their own power, and with their wives or steady girl friends.

Truman Capote Answers Robert Morse's Prayers
LEAD: Robert Morse's last Broadway appearance was in ''So Long, 174th Street,'' the 1976 musical version of ''Enter Laughing.'' The show's exit was another matter.

For months afterward, as he rode the bus up and down Broadway, the actor was assaulted with the sight of his name on a ghostly marquee above the gutted theater.

LEAD: The National Collegiate Athletic Association plans to look into comments made by a former University of Oklahoma quarterback, who told a newspaper that he used to receive favors from team boosters and his coach, Barry Switzer, and that he knew of far more serious violations he would not describe.


Japan's Loud Voice in Washington
LEAD: The Toshiba Corporation of Japan was roundly condemned by Congress two years ago for illegally selling high-technology milling equipment to the Soviet Union for use in building quieter submarine propellers.
Some lawmakers were so incensed that they even invited the news media to watch the sledgehammering of the Japanese company's products on the Capitol's steps.

LEAD: One of the six youths accused in the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park in April, was freed Friday on $25,000 bail, said the Rev.
Al Sharpton, who helped to raise the money.


The Far North Shows a Compass Of Styles
LEAD: Eskimo masks - boldly spotted, bespectacled, framed with feathers, conceived as grinning doll-like figures or masks within masks - are among the most arresting artifacts on view in ''Crossroads of Continents: Cultures of Siberia and Alaska,'' an exhibition opening Friday at the American Museum of Natural History.


Tasty Options to Costly Gifts
LEAD: SOME friends of mine have never allowed their children to buy them Christmas gifts.
All presents must be homemade.
So over the years they have received the most touching presents, many of which required hours of careful planning and hard work.
Of course, there were the inevitable misshapen pieces of pottery and the peculiar bits of knitting that came unraveled almost at once.

Review/Music; Armenian Orchestra in Mini-Tour
LEAD: The Armenian Philharmonic's appearance at Carnegie Hall on Thursday night was as much an expression of need as of accomplishment.
The stated purpose of the orchestra's three-city visit to this country is to raise money for rebuilding after the vicious earthquake of exactly a year ago.
Usually the visits of such Eastern-bloc ensembles have been carefully orchestrated expressions of national pride.

LEAD: Mr.

LEAD: ONCE more into the Bronx - for group shows at the Bronx River Art Center and Gallery and at the Longwood Arts Gallery.
They are not related, these alternative spaces, but both are diamonds in the rough and both can be counted on for lively displays graced by a prominent name or two.


CARTER REDUX
LEAD: When Jimmy Carter returned to his home in Plains, Ga., in 1981, after losing the Presidency, he was an all-but-shattered man.
He was pilloried as the author of America's malaise and the architect of its economic stagnation, and humiliated as the remaining 52 American hostages in Iran were released the day Ronald Reagan was sworn into office - after Carter's own rescue effort had died ignominiously in a remote desert in Iran.

JUNE FOUR  A Chronicle of the Chinese Democratic Uprising.
By the Photographers  and Reporters of Ming Pao News.
Translated by Zi Jin and Qin Zhou.


A LITERARY HIGH-WIRE ACT
LEAD: THERE IS UMBERTO AND THERE IS Eco.
Umberto is the author of ''The Name of the Rose,'' an experimental whodunit that overnight became an international best seller; Eco is professor of semiotics at the medieval University of Bologna.
Umberto has now written ''Foucault's Pendulum,'' a novel that is seducing the American literary establishment but was at the center of a heated, yearlong critical debate in Italy.


TIGHTER CONTROLS SEEN IN ZIMBABWE
LEAD: As Zimbabwe approaches its celebration of a decade of independence, people here are increasingly apprehensive that their country, which in the view of some has been relatively democratic, is following the political pattern of many other African nations.

LEAD: WHEN holiday shoppers want the money they spend to support their favorite charities, they head for shops run by museums and nonprofit organizations.

Where Boomerangs Are Not Exotic
LEAD: RUTH MORRISSEY keeps Down Under close by.
She runs the Australia House in Mystic, where she sells Australian opals and aboriginal paintings, sculpture and didgeridoos.
She also tells of the mining of opals and the making of didgeridoos, the traditional musical instrument of the aborigines.


New Liver Transplant Recipient in 'Outstanding' Recovery
LEAD: A 15-month-old girl was showing an ''outstanding'' response today after undergoing the nation's second living-donor liver transplant, but she faces a tough battle in the next few weeks, hospital officials said.


Question of the Week; Should the Knicks Play Strickland, Jackson, Or Both?
LEAD: The Knicks are squandering the considerable talents of Mark Jackson.
First, Stu Jackson started yanking him in the crucial last minutes of close games.
Then the news media hopped on the Jackson-bashing bandwagon, and his confidence has suffered.
Jackson has earned his role as playmaker.The Knicks should play Jackson and Strickland together regularly.


If You're Thinking of Living in: Wallingford
LEAD: INCORPORATED in 1670 on the same 39.6 square miles of the Quinnipiac River Valley that it occupies today, Wallingford is one of Connecticut's oldest towns and one of the most stable.
The scent of its early agricultural economy still drifts downwind from the handful of remaining dairy farms where cows graze, withered cornstalks rustle in the wind and pumpkins dot the wintry fields.


Alvin Ailey: Believer in the Power of Dance
LEAD: Alvin Ailey was at the peak of his creative power when he died, on Dec. 1, at the age of 58.
Yet he, more than most of his generation in dance, had accomplished what he set out to do.
And those accomplishments had a resounding impact on modern dance.

2 Killed in Fire on Soviet Ship
LEAD: Two seamen were killed and 80 crew members rescued on Friday when a Soviet fish-factory ship caught fire in the Bay of Biscay, the British Coast Guard said.
A Belgian freighter spotted the ship, the Vitautus Putna, ablaze 550 miles off Land's End at the southwestern tip of England.
The freighter launched lifeboats while members of the coast guard summoned other nearby ships to help in the operation.


Corrections
LEAD: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on Nov. 26 included an erroneous entry under the heading ''Unrestricted Fare.'' The $298 round-trip fare offered by T.W.A. between New York and Chicago is available on Saturdays only; it is not unrestricted.

A Woman Blessed With the Gift of Compassion
LEAD: BISHOP Rosetta Wheeler, head of the 80-member Mount Hebron Church of God in New Haven, ran her hand along her living room wall and gave thanks.
She gave thanks for the chairs and the tables and the soft drink she held in her hands.
She then told the story of North Carolina where, as a sharecropper's daughter, she picked cotton from dawn until dusk and went home to sleep in one bed with five of her sisters and brothers.

Now the Recyclable Trash Is Overwhelming New York
LEAD: NEW YORK CITY recycles 800 to 900 tons of trash every day: newspapers, magazines and cardboard that the Sanitation Department picks up in Manhattan and Queens and glass that Staten Island residents are required to separate from the rest of their trash.
Last week, the number of households taking part in the city recycling programs under a five-month-old law passed the one-million mark.

Reviews/Music; Mozart and Schubert, By Austrian Pianist
LEAD: Thomas Larcher's evening of piano music at Weill Recital Hall Wednesday night included not a single virtuoso piece, yet one could hardly imagine a more challenging collection of pieces to present at a New York debut.
C-minor profundities began and ended the program - Mozart's Fantasy and Sonata, and then the Schubert sonata from the last year of his life.

Into the Void, and Back
LEAD: NO ONE had a camera, but the picture is etched in my mind.
I am preparing for my first open-water dive, hung about with hoses, mask and snorkel, bent double from the weight of the cylinder of compressed air on my back.
I have somehow twisted my instrument console and extra regulator together and buckled my buoyancy compensator and weight belt over them both, which necessitates taking off everything except my bathing suit and beginning the whole clumsy and confusing process of gearing up all over again.

Tasty Options to Costly Gifts
LEAD: SOME friends of mine have never allowed their children to buy them Christmas gifts.
All presents must be homemade.
So over the years they have received the most touching presents, many of which required hours of careful planning and hard work.
Of course, there were the inevitable misshapen pieces of pottery and the peculiar bits of knitting that came unraveled almost at once.

Herman Fried, died at the age of 55.

His life was cut short because, in those days, people were not as aware of the dangers of radiation as they are today.

50,000 in Bulgaria Demand Faster Movement Toward Democracy
LEAD: Tens of thousands of Bulgarians rallied here in the capital today to demand swifter democratic change, including an end to the Communist Party's constitutionally assured leading role and the resignation of its entire Central Committee.


Talks Go On in India Over Woman's Kidnapping
LEAD: Negotiations between the Government and militant Muslims holding a Cabinet minister's daughter hostage appeared deadlocked today after the abductors demanded the release of seven jailed confederates, officials said.

Walker Hitting Stride
LEAD: The Knicks had to lose one player in the expansion draft.
Choosing between Kenny Walker and Sidney Green was not easy.
Both were capable of playing two positions, Walker at small and big forward, Green at center and power forward.
The decision came down to whether Green's size was more beneficial than


E. German Perquisites Draw Fire
LEAD: Until the current wave of political reform began sweeping across Eastern Europe, East Germany nudged its way into Western consciousness about once every four years.
In the Olympic Games, this small country of 16 million people and modest means would prove itself a superpower.

LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria has affirmed in a published interview that he would not hesitate to use his forces in Lebanon to dislodge Gen.

The Fossil Marxist
LEAD: Compared with the change sweeping through Eastern Europe, Fidel Castro seems a Marxist museum piece - staging show trials, jailing dissenters, resisting any dilution of dogma.
Now he edges closer to an open break with his Soviet benefactors.
In a tirade Thursday, he complained that Mikhail Gorbachev's reforms were ''slandering socialism, destroying its values, discrediting the party and liquidating its leading role.


Ms. Otterbourg Weds A. L. Weissman
LEAD: Laura Ann Otterbourg, a New York tourism executive, and Arthur Lewis Weissman, a political reporter at The Record in Hackensack, N.J., were married yesterday at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton by Rabbi Stanley Asekoff.

Datapoint Cuts Payout
LEAD: The Datapoint Corporation, a struggling computer company based in San Antonio, said on Friday that it had cut dividends on its preferred shares and had hired Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company to determine alternatives for getting the most value for shareholders, including a possible sale of the company.
The company also reported a loss of $13.1 million for the first quarter of its current fiscal year, which ended Oct.


A New Idea Returns
LEAD: Aside from the fact that it isn't baseball, the main thing wrong with hockey is that the games last too long.


Authors Taking Charge of Their Own Publicity
LEAD: ''Hi, this is Dan Greenberg,'' says Dan Greenberg, phoning yet another bookstore. ''Can you spare 60 seconds for me to tell you about my new book?''


More Charities Turn to Paid Ads to Raise Money
LEAD: The competition for free television time is getting far tougher - in large part because of the glut of public service advertising about drug abuse and AIDS - and many leading charities are being forced to consider paying for broadcast time in order to get their messages on the air.


Publishers Favoring Additional Imprints
LEAD: To counteract the bureaucracy and inefficiency that have accompanied publishing mergers and acquisitions, a number of houses are creating more imprints - semi-independent fiefdoms of two to a dozen or more people who have considerable flexibility to acquire and publish books.


Touchdown On '3d and Arkansas'
LEAD: IN the fifth round of this year's National Football League draft, the Giants were waiting their turn.


Thousands Continue East German Protests
LEAD: Tens of thousands of demonstrators today continued to press demands for democratic change in East Germany.


Chile Is Getting Independent Central Bank
LEAD: In the first attempt in Latin America to free a central bank from Government control, Chile's central bank will begin functioning autonomously on Monday under a five-member board.
The governing panel was named last week in a surprisingly harmonious agreement between the departing Government of Gen.


Joy and Apprehension Among East Berlin's Jews
LEAD: The handful of citizens who are observant Jews or of Jewish ancestry in this country are viewing the current political upheaval here with a peculiar combination of elation and fear.


Surgery Stops Bleeding By Recipient of Liver
LEAD: The recipient of the nation's first liver transplant from a living donor underwent surgery today for the second time in two days to stop bleeding on the surface of the new organ, hospital officials said.


Phone-Call Thieves Hitting Corporations' Switchboards
LEAD: The people who steal long-distance calls are increasingly using the telephone switchboards of large corporations to place the calls at no expense to themselves.


Wallace a Million-Dollar Man
LEAD: Rusty Wallace isn't a man who is easily distracted from his work.

The Airline Lorenzo Dreamed Of
LEAD: Nine months into a strike by the vast majority of its work force, Eastern Airlines is close to emerging from bankruptcy protection as the low-cost carrier Frank A. Lorenzo has been trying for three years to create.
But the airline's survival remains uncertain, depending largely on whether it can successfully reach beyond the bargain-hunting passenger on which it has relied since spring, before the cash from its asset sales runs out.


POINDEXTER AIMING TO SHOW REAGAN KNEW OF IRAN PLOT
LEAD: As the trial of John M. Poindexter nears, it is clear that the former national security adviser is adopting a defense strategy that portrays Ronald Reagan as a knowing and active participant in the Iran-contra affair, not the disengaged President depicted by Mr.
Poindexter in his testimony before Congress.

Dalai Lama, Accepting Prize, Urges Peaceful Tibet Solution
LEAD: The Dalai Lama accepted the Nobel Peace Prize today and said he remained committed to nonviolence in seeking an end to China's 40-year occupation of Tibet, his Himalayan homeland.

LEAD: The Moscow Puppet Theater, in a United States debut, has settled into an experimental ''downtown'' theater with ''Kashtanka,'' a spectacle of warmth and ingenuity.

Susan A. Wright Is Married
LEAD: Susan Ann Wright and Richard Harold Kail were married yesterday at St.
Mark Lutheran Church in Morris Township, N.J., by the Rev.
Eddie A. Nilsen.
Mrs.
Wright-Kail, 31 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Robert Wright of Convent Station, N.J.
A graduate of Ithaca College, she is a vice president of the United Jersey Bank in Hackensack.

Military Budget Waste Linked to Congress
LEAD: Congress wastes millions of dollars by loading down the Defense Department budget with special tidbits for constituents and by imposing excessive restraints on spending programs, according to a Pentagon draft report made public today.

LEAD: A campaign march by hundreds of opposition supporters turned violent today.

New Jersey Bank Takeover May Imperil Other Realty Lending
LEAD: The Government takeover of New Jersey's largest savings institution last Friday could cramp the state's already ailing real-estate market by making other lenders more cautious about backing large housing developments and office projects, experts said today.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Woman Dies After a Blaze In Her East Side Apartment
LEAD: A 65-year-old Manhattan woman died yesterday and her husband was hospitalized in serious condition after a fire broke out in their Upper East Side penthouse apartment, the police said.


Is New Scandal in the Wind in Chicago?
LEAD: It is not the icy blasts off Lake Michigan but yet another Federal inquiry into allegations of corruption that is spreading a deep chill these days through City Hall and the Cook County courts.


Vietnam Rice Crop Up
LEAD: Vietnam has produced 18.02 million tons of unmilled rice this year, 4 percent more than expected and 8.5 percent more than last year's crop, the official Vietnam News Agency said in a report made available Friday.
The high output was attributed to three good harvests and to policy changes made in 1988 after riots forced the Government to abandon an unpopular drive toward group cooperation.

Rocket Launching Is Put Off
LEAD: Trouble with a fuel tank pressurization system today forced the Air Force to postpone for one day the launching of a military navigation satellite.
Lieut.
Col.
Ron Rand, an Air Force spokesman, said the trouble was a faulty pressure regulator for helium for the Delta 2 rocket's fuel tanks.
The Delta 2 is to take aloft a satellite that will join four others that tell United States and allied military forces where they are within 50 feet anywhere in the world.

We Must Help Besieged Salvador
LEAD: For more than a month, Americans have watched El Salvador turn ugly.
Staring at the blood and chaos, Americans are now asking, once again, whether U.S. policy there is working.
It is.

Today, it is a working democracy that has held four fair elections.

Edward J. Bloustein, 64, Is Dead; President of Rutgers Since 1971
LEAD: Dr.
Edward J. Bloustein, the president of Rutgers University since 1971, died Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, in Nassau, the Bahamas, where he was attending a business meeting.
Dr.
Bloustein lived in the president's house on the school's New Brunswick-Piscataway campus.
He was 64 years old.

LEAD: One person died and another was injured when a fire broke out today in a room at the Eatontown Motor Lodge, officials said.

Mortgage Rates Climb
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.76 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That rate was up from a rate of 9.74 percent in the previous week.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.39 percent last week, down from 8.46 percent the week before.

Johnson Matthey Shift
LEAD: Eugene Anderson, chief executive of Johnson Matthey P.L.C., resigned last week to pursue other business interests.
He will be succeeded as head of the precious metals and engineering group by Joseph Stevenson, previously an executive director who has been with the company since 1958 and has been on its board since 1982, the group said.

Argentine Inflation Up
LEAD: Argentina's cost of living rose 6.5 percent in November, indicating that inflation is heating when the Government had promised it would be stamped out.
The monthly increase was the second lowest this year, but it was higher than the 5.6 percent October figure, reversing a trend that had been downward since July.

Review/Theater; Middle-Class Male Looks in a Mirror
LEAD: In ''Progress,'' the British playwright Doug Lucie argues that peaceful co-existence between the sexes is impossible because almost all men are pigs.
But the play, which opened yesterday at the Hudson Guild Theater, takes a sardonic view of its characters' basest motives.
Until the final harrowing moments, you don't realize just how depressing a message it contains.

The Blot on Turkey's Name
LEAD: Over the years, Turkey has offered two replies to charges that its police routinely engage in torture - that the charges are exaggerated, and in any case things are getting better.
The sad inadequacy of those answers is documented anew in a devastating report by the human rights committee of the New York City Bar Association.

Some Ideas for the Holiday Shopper Biking in the winter has its own special needs. Performance Inc., of Chapel Hill, N.C., uses three layers of fabric to make its Performance Winter Century Cycling Glove. The inside layer is Thermolite, a DuPont insulation material. The next layer is an insert made of Gore-Tex, a wind- and water-resistant fabric that allows perspiration to escape. The outside is made of Lycra, a nylon stretch material, and terry cloth, for wiping the brow. The leather palm contains a foamlike material to absorb shock. Available in red, silver or green; sizes XS to XL. Price: $29.95. Telephone (800) 727-2453.  SKIING  The opportunity to go skiing often depends on the children. Casby Inc., of Conneaut, Ohio, has developed a device to allow parents to take their children onto the slopes with them. The Ski Starter, for youngsters 3 years old or more, is designed with a waist belt of nylon webbing, and an eight-foot harness for holding the child in check on a ski slope. The harness clips off the waist belt for the child's ride on a chair lift. Adhesive squares applied to the tips of the skis and a tether between them keep the child's skis in a snowplow position. Price: $24.95. Telephone (216)224-0060.  GOLF  The Tee-Off platform trainer allows a player to practice anywhere there is enough room to raise a club. The Tee-Off comes with a high-impact plastic ball suspended by a nylon cord from a steel arm. It is attached to a two-foot-by-one-foot base of fiberboard covered in artificial turf. The Tee-Off Company, of Madison, Wis., includes a diagram to show the golfer how to gauge a hit by the way the ball rotates around the arm of the device. Available in right- or left-handed models. Price: $34.95. Telephone (800) 533-9791.  RUNNING  Shoes that are laced too tight can cause aching feet. Shoestring Inc. of Ketchum, Idaho, has come up with an idea for elastic laces that are secured with a plastic locking device the size of a nickel called Willy's. Once the right tension is found, the laces are threaded through the lock and snapped shut. Release the lock, and they are adjustable. Available in 31 colors, including neons and metallics. Price: $4.65 per pair for 20-inch and 30-inch laces, and $5.65 per pair for 60-inch. Available in New York at Super Runners Shop (six locations), or telephone Shoestring at (800) 999-2342.  FISHING    A video, ''Encyclopedia of Saltwater Sport Fish,'' takes the angler one step further than most books in teaching how to catch a fish and identify a species. The viewer can see his prey as it is being caught. Bennett Marine Video of Marina del Rey, Calif., produced the 60-minute film. James Marsh, the commentator, shows footage of catching the 36 species (from the amberjack to the wahoo) he discusses. Price: $29.95. Telephone (800) 262-8862; in California, (213) 821-3329.  TENNIS  A new version of the pitch-back, the portable rebound net for practicing tennis, has been designed in Australia. Known as the Roobound, th Price: $79 to $89. For local dealer, telephone (415) 777-4004.  YACHTING  The current court battle over who keeps the America's Cup, San Diego or New Zealand, is only one part of the event's controversial past, which dates to 1851. In his new book, ''A Picture History of the America's Cup,'' John Rousmaniere has delved into the archives of the Mystic Seaport Museum of Mystic, Conn., for a century's worth of black-and-white photos, mostly from the Rosenfeld Collection of Stanley Rosenfeld and his father, the late Morris Rosenfeld. The 128-page book, published by Mystic Seaport Museum Stores Inc., places the event in perspective for the armchair sailor. Price: $39.95. Telephone (800) 331-2665; in Connecticut, (203) 572-8551.
LEAD: Sports gear of every kind is flooding the market this season.
A kaleidoscope of neon and metallic colors enlivens products from shoes to tennis racquets.
Exotic new materials do more than keep you warm; they wick away moisture and trap air.
Practice devices take players beyond fun and on to perfection.

Corrections
LEAD: A chart yesterday and a chronology on Nov. 25 about political changes in Eastern Europe gave an incorrect date for the start of Communist rule in Hungary.
The Communists took control in stages in the late 1940's, culminating in the establishment of the Hungarian People's Republic in 1949.
