Shareholder Group Is Suing Chevron
LEAD: A group of shareholders of the Chevron Corporation sued the company in Delaware chancery court to block part of a new ''poison pill'' plan aimed at thwarting a hostile takeover.
The stockholder suit, court documents said, seeks to block an amendment to Chevron's shareholder rights plan that lowers to 10 percent, from 20 percent, the amount of stock held by a third party needed to begin anti-takeover provisions.


Market Place; Are Small Stocks Set to Rebound?
LEAD: IS now the time for small stocks to start outperforming their larger brethren?
Some money managers think so, betting both on the much-heralded ''January effect'' - the phenomenon of small stocks rising rapidly around the beginning of a new year - and on the relative cheapness of small stocks.


Upheaval in the East; Baker Says Unification Isn't Just a German Issue
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, in remarks aimed at Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany, said today that German reunification was not just a German issue but one to be decided in consultation with Bonn's NATO allies, its neighbors and the Soviet Union.


Ford-Jaguar
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company has acquired a controlling interest in Jaguar P.L.C. as part of its $2.5 billion takeover of the British luxury car maker.
Ford, the No. 2 United States auto maker, said that by the close of business Friday, it had acquired 77.4 percent of the outstanding shares of Jaguar stock, including the 13 percent it owned before Nov.


Travel Agents Agree to Merge
LEAD: Thomas Cook Travel Inc. has agreed to merge with Crimson Travel Service and Heritage Travel in a deal that will create the third-largest travel agency in the United States, the two companies said yesterday.


Reviews/Music; 7 Soloists in Aggregate Play An Evening of Brahms
LEAD: Much of the memorable chamber music literature was written before permanent and professional ensembles ever existed.
Beethoven had no Juilliard Quartet at his service nor Haydn a Beaux Arts Trio.
Individuals gathered to perform their music, often with a minimum of rehearsal.
A spirit of adventure (or misadventure) was always in the air.


Ex-Hoechst Executive To Head Unit of Akzo
LEAD: Richard M. Clarke, a former vice chairman of the Hoechst Celanese Corporation, has been named president and chief executive of Akzo America Inc., the North American unit of the Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V.


Joseph L. Ferraro, Lawyer, 67
LEAD: Joseph L. Ferraro, a retired lawyer and former president of the Board of Education in Paterson, N.J., died of complications of heart surgery on Sunday at the St.
Joseph's Medical Center in Paterson.
He was 67 years old and lived in Oakhurst, N.J.


Deadline Passes in India With No Word on Captive
LEAD: A deadline for the release of prisoners set by Kashmiri militants holding the daughter of India's Home Minister passed tonight with no indication of the young woman's fate.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Cavaliers 113, Jazz 110: Craig Ehlo made two 3-point shots for Cleveland in the final 4.3 seconds of overtime, including the game-winner as time expired last night.
Bobby Hansen's fifth 3-point basket of the game put Utah ahead by 110-107 with 1 minute 9 seconds remaining.
Both teams failed to score on possessions before Ehlo's 3-pointer tied the score.


Japan Curbing Foreign Workers
LEAD: Over the objections of groups representing foreign workers, Parliament has approved amendments to the immigration laws that would for the first time impose fines on Japanese companies that employ illegal foreign workers.


Girl, 8, Dies in Suspicious Fire
LEAD: An 8-year-old girl died in a fire in the South Bronx yesterday that might have been arson, officials said.
Officer Fred Weiner, a police spokesman, said the fire broke out at 4:45 P.M. in a three-story house at 448 East 140th Street.
Noraima Guezera was declared dead of smoke inhalation and burns on arrival at Lincoln Hospital, said Aaron Foxx, a Fire Department spokesman.


Homeless Shelter in Church Is Upheld
LEAD: Quoting Scripture as well as the law, a Civil Court judge yesterday dismissed a suit by an East Side condominium that sought to prevent a church next door from sheltering 10 homeless men in its basement three nights a week in the summer.


Editors' Note
LEAD: An article in the Business section on Sunday about the International Business Machines Corporation offered an assessment of I.B.M.'s current financial problems and presented a ''blueprint'' to remedy them.


City Tries Sterilization for an Animal Problem
LEAD: The patient having her Fallopian tubes tied on the operating table had been pulled from a trap near the South Platte River that morning.
Poking out from under the surgical cloth was her flat paddle of a tail.

Upheaval in the East; Soviet Congress Reconvenes Today, the Joy of Spring Nipped in the Bud
LEAD: The Soviet Congress of People's Deputies, inaugurated in the spring in a burst of outspokenness and optimism, is reconvening on Tuesday for a second, far more wintry session of complaint and doubt about the torpid pace of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's promised renewal of the nation.


The Storming of St. Pat's
LEAD: The demonstrators who stormed St.
Patrick's Cathedral Sunday may have hoped to inspire sympathy for the problems of homosexuals in New York City and resistance to the Catholic Church's positions on abortion.
They mostly brought discredit on themselves for demonstrating in a way that obstructs consideration of their arguments.

Gorbachev, to the Communist Party Central Committee last Saturday, as translated by the Soviet press agency Tass: Comrades, implementation of the long-term course of perestroika exerts not only a revolutionary influence on all the spheres of life of Soviet society, but also influences other socialist coutries and developments in the world.


McKinney Fails Test
LEAD: The winner of the bantamweight gold medal in the Seoul Olympics, Kennedy McKinney, faces a hearing in Las Vegas, Nev., Friday after testing positive for cocaine following his last fight, a four-round split decision victory on Oct. 31 over Jose Luis Martinez.
McKinney, 5-0-1 as a pro, could be fined or face possible revocation of his boxing license when the matter goes before the Nevada State Athletic Commission.(

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  COMPANIES  The head of Columbia Savings and Loan is resigning as part of a sweeping effort to disentangle the institution's huge ''junk bond'' portfolio from its savings and loan business.
Thomas Spiegel, the primary architect of Columbia's strategy, said he would devote his time to setting up and managing an operation that would own the junk bond portfolio.


Topics of The Times; The Classic Diaper
LEAD: Last year, in a decision widely criticized as hardhearted, the town leaders of Lisbon, Me., decided that recipients of welfare from the town would be required to buy cloth diapers for their babies.
The town's motive was economy: it costs less to use a cloth diaper over and over than to keep buying new disposables.


Police Seeking Man Who Killed Mugger
LEAD: Law-enforcement officials said yesterday that they were preparing a composite sketch of the unidentified man who fatally stabbed a subway mugger early last Saturday.
They hope the sketch will help in their search for him if he does not turn himself in.

LEAD: The Supreme Court today gave Federal agencies new discretion under the Freedom of Information Act to shield from disclosure some records bearing on criminal investigations.


Court Stops Work At Stewart Airport
LEAD: Construction at Stewart International Airport near Newburgh must be stopped until the State Department of Transportation assesses the impact of the airport expansion on the environment, a State Supreme Court justice has ruled.

It began in 1930, not 1928.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:  Chewing Gum  Q. Is it bad for you to swallow chewing gum?
Does it get digested?
A.
The nonsoluble gum base of chewing gum is not digested, but neither are parts of many foods, like popcorn or lettuce, scientists in the food industry say.

LEAD: THE forest fires that swept vast areas of Yellowstone National Park in 1988 constituted a largely uncontrollable natural event that occurs once every 200 to 300 years, say two biologists who have spent more than a decade studying the ecology of the park.

LEAD: Football players are dripping in armor for good reason.
Without a helmet, without a steel mask, without shoulder pads, elbow pads, knee braces and taped wrists and fists and the occasional neck brace, football players might get hurt - or suffer even greater bumps than they already do.

LEAD: CHUCK Hansen lives in Sunnyvale, Calif., with 20 doves, 60 pigeons and about 5,000 (at last count) once-secret documents that detail the era when the United States exploded hundreds of nuclear weapons that filled the sky with blinding fire and radioactive clouds.

LEAD: Sixty-eight men and women who monitored human rights abuses in their countries were killed this year and 10 others disappeared after being seized by security forces, Human Rights Watch says in its annual report.

LEAD: As Poland, Czechoslovakia and other Eastern European nations move away from communism, they are confronting a thorny problem: what to do with the thousands of managers hand-picked by the Communist Party to run their nations' enterprises.


Child Falls From Helicopter
LEAD: A 9-year-old girl being airlifted for a sprained ankle fell from a helicopter's air-rescue litter, suffering serious head and internal injuries.
Debbie Baisa was in critical but stable condition today at William Beaumont Army Medical Center after the accident on Saturday.
Manny Baisa, the girl's grandfather, said the girl, who fell about 30 feet, underwent surgery for a broken hip Sunday, after having surgery earlier for her head and internal bleeding.


Hospital Defends Limiting of Drug Program
LEAD: A spokesman for a hospital accused of discriminating against pregnant women seeking drug and alcoholism treatment said the hospital denied the women access to its inpatient detoxification program because of financial and medical concerns.


Bank of Boston
LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation said it plans to sell its $590 million credit card portfolio and had hired an investment banker to assist in the sale.
No price was mentioned, but if Bank of Boston received the current market premium of about 20 percent, it would receive about $118 million.
The portfolio has 675,000 Mastercard and Visa card holders, most of whom are in New England.


Left and Right in Greece Denounce the King's Offer to Return
LEAD: Political parties on both the left and the right today criticized Greece's deposed King over a published interview in which he said he would like to return to restore unity to his country.


Chess

LEAD: Three Hungarian journalists who went to Rumania last week to meet a dissident clergyman were detained by the police, expelled from the country and banned from re-entering for five years, it was reported today.
The Rumanian police also confiscated their film and video cassettes.

Acquisition by Unilever
LEAD: Unilever, the diversified British-Dutch consumer products company, said today that it had acquired Compania Productora Nacional de Aceitas S.A. of Chile for an undisclosed sum.
The company, which employs 350 people, manufactures margarine and edible fats and oils, and had 1988 sales of $28 million.


Drunken Driving Is Still Big Killer, Bush Says
LEAD: President Bush said today that despite a decline in deaths caused by drunken driving the problem remains ''as crippling as crack'' and is one of the most serious facing the nation.


Argentine Charged in Money Scheme Is Sent to U.S.
LEAD: An Argentine man charged with laundering $250 million in cocaine proceeds through storefronts in Los Angeles and New York pleaded not guilty today in Federal court here, Judge William Keller ordered the man, Raul Silvio Vivas, held without bail on the argument by prosecutors that he is the mastermind of an international network.

LEAD: Cray Research Inc.'s chairman, John A. Rollwagen, said the company would expand its product line, introducing a lower-price version of its Y-MP supercomputer sometime in the first half of 1990.
The new computer will be priced close to $2 million.
The least expensive Cray now begins at about $5 million.

British Retail Sales Off
LEAD: British retail sales fell sharply last month as the Christmas shopping season began, the Government reported today, indicating gains in the battle against inflation.
Official figures showed sales dropped eight-tenths of a percent in November from the previous month.
Analysts had predicted an increase of one-tenth of a percent.

LEAD: Fighting chronic fatigue caused by thin air and deadly cold, scientists here are assembling a new type of telescope that may reveal the mysterious origin of cosmic rays.


A Savings Resignation Over 'Junk'
LEAD: The chairman and chief executive of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, Thomas Spiegel, said today that he would resign at the end of the year as part of a sweeping effort to disentangle the huge ''junk bond'' portfolio of the institution from its savings and loan business.


Taking Over Repairs For Bridges Is Urged
LEAD: New York City should prepare itself to assume responsibility next year for a 10-year, $1 billion reconstruction program for its four East River bridges, the State Transportation Commissioner, Franklin E. White, told city officials yesterday.


Centers Abundant in Class of '90
LEAD: Help may be near for the many National Basketball Association teams that need centers.
Although there is not another Patrick Ewing or a David Robinson around, centers appear to be plentiful among this season's college seniors.


Wyse Says It Will Take Taiwan Bid
LEAD: Wyse Technology Inc., a one-time Silicon Valley superstar that went into a tailspin, will be sold to an investor group from Taiwan for $10 a share in cash, the company announced today.


Upheaval in the East; Bonn Leader Softens His Plan for German Unity
LEAD: Taking account of foreign concerns, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany softened a vital element of his vision of German unity today as representatives of the four wartime occupying powers met here and insisted on ''the importance of stability'' in Eastern Europe.


Fresh Look in Dressing: The Dress
LEAD: Is the dress bounding back into fashion's foreground after a couple of decades on the back burner?
Donna Karan is one of many influential designers who think it is, citing the easy, nonrestrictive shapes that fit comfortably into women's active lives.

Mr.
O'Conor began making his way through the 32 sonatas in February, when he gave the first of eight concerts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art devoted to the works.

LEAD: An affiliate of an Australian airline that is partly owned by the publisher Rupert Murdoch has purchased $15.6 million worth of debentures in America West Airlines, maintaining its 19.1 percent stake in the regional carrier based in Tempe, Ariz.
In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing,the Australian group said it had bought the debentures, which are convertible into 1.2 million America West shares.

LEAD: THE more times a woman is pregnant, the higher her risks of developing diabetes and impaired glucose tolerance, a precursor to diabetes, researchers at the University of California in San Diego, have concluded.

There's nothing novel about show-stopping songs and performances in Broadway musicals, but how long has it been since a musical was brought to a halt by riotous jokes?
If you ask me, one would have to travel back to the 1960's - to ''Bye Bye Birdie,'' ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' ''How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying'' and ''Little Me'' - to find a musical as flat-out funny as ''City of Angels,'' the new show about old Hollywood that arrived last night at the Virginia Theater.

LEAD: The great chase for Mark Davis ended yesterday when the Kansas City Royals signed the left-handed relief pitcher for four years for a total of $13 million, at an annual average of $3.25 million, more than five times his 1989 salary.
With the signing, the Royals brought two reigning winners of the Cy Young Award together on the same pitching staff for the first time in baseball history.

Japan Growth Forecast
LEAD: Japan's gross national product is expected to grow 5 percent in the fiscal year that begins April 1, according to a research report released today.
The Research Institute on the National Economy, a leading independent research center, said growth would be helped by consumer demand and by corporations' capital spending on technological innovation.

LEAD: Reflecting its expansion into refining and distribution, Saudi Arabia's oil company has emerged as the largest oil company in the world, the Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said in its issue that was published today.

LEAD: MANY people who are mildly depressed can improve with minimal treatment in which they get regular support from a professional but receive no drugs or formal psychotherapy, researchers have found.

LEAD: A man suspected of robbing motorists on Interstate 280 by bumping them with his car and holding them up after they had pulled over was arrested on Monday, the police said.


Prices Up at Disneyland
LEAD: Disneyland has increased one-day admission prices by $2, to $25.50 for adults and $20.50 for children.
Parking prices have risen too, by a dollar, to $4.
A Disneyland spokesman, Bob Roth, said the company had raised prices to offset the costs of its Splash Mountain ride, which opened last summer.
Ticket prices were also increased by $2 a year ago.

Apple's stock dropped $3.25 a share today, to $36, in over-the-counter trading on volume of more than 9.1 million shares.

Review/Dance; Fancies of Rachael Milder
LEAD: Successful fantastic or eccentric dances involve more than an assortment of strange steps or crazy notions.
The steps and notions must be connected and developed in such a persuasive way that the choreographic fancies take flight and invite the viewer along for the ride.
Rachael Milder's fancies remained resolutely earthbound in Wilder Milder Dances, the program this Chicago-based choreographer presented on Friday night at the Merce Cunningham Studio.

LEAD: Another season is missing.
The evidence is in this graph, which charts New York City's recent weather.
October shows peak after peak of summer days.

Fall has been squeezed out.

Continental Orders
LEAD: Continental Airlines has ordered jet engines worth nearly $1.4 billion from CFM International to power up to 40 Airbus Industrie planes, the engine maker said.
CFM International, a venture of the General Electric Company and Snecma of France, said Continental had ordered 20 planes powered by CF6-80E1 engines and 20 powered by CFM56-5C2 engines, with options to buy 20 more of each.

Mr.

60-MINUTE GOURMET
LEAD: Few dishes are steeped in as much snobbery as bouillabaisse.
There are those who deem that it cannot be authentically prepared more than a seashell's toss from the port of Marseille.

I have prepared the real thing often, and it can be astoundingly good.

Review/Opera; At the Met, A Chilling And Chill 'Dutchman'
LEAD: The late Jean-Pierre Ponnelle's production of ''Der Fliegende Hollander,'' imported by the Metropolitan Opera from San Francisco 10 years ago, was generally reviled.
In his version of Wagner's opera, the action all took place in the head of the Steersman, who dreamed the whole thing.
That was an extremely clever concept whose only flaw was that it did not work: attention focused on the psychology of a minor character rather than on the fateful liaison between the ghostly Dutchman and his fanatical lover,

LEAD: WNEW-AM, the venerable New York station that carries big band music and New York Giants football, is being offered for sale.

LEAD: The way ''Blaze'' remembers it, its heroine was just a simple country girl when she first got into stripteasing for a living.

U.S. Savings Bond Sales
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $541 million in November, bringing to $116.96 billion the value of such bonds held by Americans, the Treasury Department reported Monday.
Sales for the first two months of the 1990 fiscal year, which began Oct. 1, totaled $1.13 billion, the same as in October and November 1988.

P.T.A. and Scouts Clash on Liability
LEAD: The Boy Scouts and the National Congress of Parents and Teachers have been unable to agree on who is responsible for scout leaders whose behavior sometimes leads to lawsuits.


Harvesting a Tree in the Woods or on a City Sidewalk
LEAD: ABOUT 35 million Americans are expected to bring Christmas trees home this month.
No one knows how many of them buy their trees at garden centers or tree lots in cities, but a growing number are going to Christmas tree farms to choose and cut their own trees in an effort to re-create one aspect of an old-fashioned holiday season.


Whitney To Consider Its Direction
LEAD: In the wake of reports that it would ask for the resignation of its director, Thomas N. Armstrong 3d, the Whitney Museum of American Art yesterday appointed a committee to ''review the current status and consider future directions of the museum.''


U.S. Aides See No Victory in American's Release
LEAD: United States officials, reflecting the uncertainty about Jennifer Jean Casolo within the Administration, said privately today that the Connecticut woman's release from prison in El Salvador was not seen as ''a victory'' for the Administration.


It's Time to Rethink U.S. Policy on El Salvador
LEAD: To the Editor:


Harris Tweed Weavers Idled by Fashion's Mood
LEAD: Here on Lewis and Harris, a remote island of peat bogs and rocky pastures and black-faced sheep, the talk is about the fashions and the weather in America.


60 Percent Back Testing for Drugs at Work
LEAD: Sixty percent of American workers favor employers' testing their employees for drug use, according to a Gallup poll released today.

LEAD: *
James C. Crimmins has been named executive vice president of DDB Needham Worldwide.


Talks on Indian Ocean Isle Stall
LEAD: A French naval task force cruised off the Comoro Islands today as negotiations to persuade mercenaries to leave the archipelago remained deadlocked for a third day.


Cambodia Agrees to U.N.-Controlled Election
LEAD: The Vietnamese-backed Government of Cambodia is ready to disband its Council of Ministers before a United Nations-controlled election in an effort to end the 11-year civil war, a leading editor with close ties to the Government said.

LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d's blueprint for a new European order won generally favorable reviews today from European statesmen and commentators, but privately many officials predicted that Washington will have a difficult time putting its vision into practice.

John Slawson, 93, Retired Leader Of American Jewish Committee
LEAD: Dr.
John Slawson, executive vice president emeritus of the American Jewish Committee, died of heart failure Tuesday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 93 years old.
Dr.
Slawson retired in 1967 after 24 years as leader of the organization, which was founded in 1906 to combat bigotry and to protect the civil and religious rights of Jews here and abroad.


Changes On Benefits In Texas
LEAD: Texas lawmakers approved changes on Tuesday in the way benefits would be assigned to workers for job-related injuries and deaths, with business groups and insurers triumphing in a long feud with trial lawyers and union officials.


Battle of New Jersey Goes to Seton Hall
LEAD: Seton Hall traveled down the highway tonight to play Rutgers in a hostile environment before a raucous crowd of 8,722 at the Louis Brown Athletic Center.
The Pirates were opposing a team that was primed for the challenge.
Selected by many publications to be the class of the Atlantic 10 Conference this season, Rutgers hoped to topple a team that became the darlings of New Jersey last season by making it to the National Collegiate Athletic Association final.


Topics of The Times; Health Data, Hidden
LEAD: Surgeon General C. Everett Koop left office recently, in a well-deserved blaze of glory.
But now there's reason to wonder about the way he handled a Reagan Administration request to investigate whether abortion is harmful to a woman's health.
Dr.
Koop reported there were not enough data to support such a conclusion.


New Coach Is No Stranger
LEAD: Gary Moeller, the 48-year-old offensive coordinator who was named today to succeed Bo Schembechler as Michigan coach, is no stranger to the Wolverine program.

British Air and KLM Acquire 40% of Sabena
LEAD: In a deal that gives them an opportunity to develop Brussels as a major airline center, British Airways P.L.C. and KLM Royal Dutch Airlines reached an agreement today in which each will acquire a 20 percent stake in the airline operation of Sabena S.A. of Belgium.

Adding Injury to Insult
LEAD: Ron Hextall, who has only two appearances in goal for the Flyers this season, was sent down to Philadelphia's farm team in Hershey for a one-game rehabilitation assignment.
Midway through the last period of last night's game, he was carried from the ice after injuring his right groin while trying to stop a shot by New Haven's Scott


Matsushita-Philips Deal
LEAD: The Matsushita Electric Industrial Company and Philips N.V. of the Netherlands will jointly set up a British company to develop devices enabling one remote controller to control different entertainment systems, a Matsushita spokesman said.
The device is called a domestic digital bus, or D2B.
Philips plans to sell televisions and videotape recorders with D2B in Europe, and Matsushita is considering it in Japan.


Manual on Treatment Under Professional Fire
LEAD: A new psychiatric treatment manual has come under increasing attack from critics in the mental health profession, who fear that disgruntled patients may use it as a basis for lawsuits, or that it may inappropriately promote certain therapies.


GATT Talks With China
LEAD: Chinese delegates were asked numerous questions about their economic policies as GATT member states reopened talks on Beijing's bid to rejoin the world trade forum, officials said today.


I.B.M. Sees An Advance
LEAD: Researchers at the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that they had for the first time succeeded in storing more than a billion bits of information on a single square inch of disk surface.


Car Sales Continue To Slump
LEAD: Sales of cars made in the United States plunged in early December, as the auto industry's slump showed no signs of abating.


22% Fall in Cotton Crop
LEAD: The 1989 cotton crop is expected to be slightly less than 12.1 million bales, down 22 percent from last year's harvest but almost the same as estimated in November, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday.
In its new estimate based on field conditions as of Dec. 1, the department's National Agricultural Statistics Service said a 20 percent drop in the acreage for harvest and slightly lower yields accounted for the decline.

LEAD: The new Coffee Consumers Caucus will meet with Government officials next month for discussions on American policies affecting the international coffee cartel and its effect on the United States, the caucus's founder, Godfrey Harris, said today.

Hill &amp; Knowlton Move
LEAD: David Wynne-Morgan, the chairman and chief executive of Hill &amp; Knowlton in London, has been elected to the board of Hill &amp; Knowlton Inc., the public relations and public affairs counseling firm owned by the WPP Group.
Mr.
Wynne-Morgan, who was also named executive vice president of Hill &amp; Knowlton Europe, will organize a European financial relations division that will have a mergers and acquisitions capability.

LEAD: The White House announced today that President Bush would attend a four-nation conference on narcotics in the Colombian city of Cartagena, but Administration officials said Mr.
Bush would spend only a few hours there because of security concerns.

LEAD: ''Episodes,'' a tough-minded new dance piece by Ulysses Dove full of energy, sexual connotations and technical polish from dancers who seem shot out of a cannon, is the kind of choreography that propels young audiences to their feet and sets them screaming.


U.S. Actions In Bond Loss By Columbia
LEAD: Federal regulators had placed tight restrictions on the Columbia Savings and Loan Association last month after new accounting rules forced the institution to recognize large losses in the value of its ''junk bond'' portfolio, company executives and Government officials said today.

Acquisition Fever Seen Taking Hold in Japan
LEAD: One of British advertising's grand acquisitors of the 1980's said yesterday that Japan was likely to assume that role in the 1990's.
Addressing the annual media conference sponsored by Paine Webber Inc. in New York, Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of the WPP Group, predicted that the slowdown of advertising growth in Japan would lead companies there to ''increasingly look outside for development, and Japanese ad agencies will follow them.

A.T.&amp;T.-Soviet Satellite Link
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company proposed increasing telecommunications circuits between the United States and the Soviet Union by using the Soviet Intersputnik satellite system for the first time.


Close to Home
LEAD: MY brother-in-law is impossible.
My sister is not so bad.
My niece is easy.
My aunt is as impossible as my brother-in-law.
My mother can be tricky.
My older daughter lives so far away that sending a check is the only sane stratagem.
My younger daughter provides a long list that always ends with ''lots of surprises.

LEAD: Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he supports plans by the New York City Parks Department this week to remove tents and other structures that homeless people have erected in Tompkins Square Park on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

Gen.
William Pierce Ennis Jr., who retired from the Army in 1962 after 36 years of service that included command of the Army War College, died Saturday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston.
He was 85 years old and lived in Newport, R.I.

LEAD: Oliver L. North told a Federal district judge today that John M. Poindexter's testimony before the Iran-contra investigating committees deeply affected him because Mr.

Great Lakes Campaign
LEAD: Eight Great Lakes states and the province of Ontario began a $6 million campaign today to lure visitors from abroad to the region with a promotion touting the area as ''North America's Fresh Coast.'' The initial focus of the campaign will be Britain, followed by West Germany, Scandinavian and other Western European countries.

LEAD: A gang armed with guns and bombs attacked a security post on the Irish border today, killing two British soldiers and seriously wounding a third, the police said.

LEAD: As they assessed the first test of New York City's campaign finance law, candidates and politicians agreed yesterday that they would like fewer restrictions and more public money for their campaigns.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Lakers 102, Heat 75: Magic Johnson and Vlade Divac each scored 6 points during an 18-2 second-half run last night to lead the Lakers in Miami.
The Heat trailed, 65-54, with four minutes left in the third quarter before Los Angeles scored 7 consecutive points.
After Sherman Douglas scored for Miami, Los Angeles scored 11 points in a row; Divac made three baskets during the run.

LEAD: Certain applicants for scarce apartments in several buildings for the elderly subsidized by the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Nassau County have been able to bypass long waiting lists, according to a former employee of the company that runs the buildings, as well as current and former elected officials.


Treasury Issues Little Changed
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities were little changed in very light trading again yesterday, as dealers shrugged off a report that suggested that consumers, who account for two-thirds of the economy, remained active last month.

LEAD: Six performers and a theater organization are the recipients of this year's Mayor's Awards of Honor for their contributions to cultural life in New York city.


63 Arrested in U.S. Protest
LEAD: Sixty-three people were arrested today in a demonstration outside the Federal Building here to protest United States military aid to El Salvador.
One hundred people, including priests, trade union members and the actors Martin Sheen and Edward Asner, took part in the demonstration and carried posters reading ''Death Squads Out of El Salvador'' and ''Stop Aid to Death Squads.

LEAD: The days of steeply climbing house prices are over, and the 1990's could begin with prices dropping by as much as 12 percent, according to a report released today by Rutgers University based on three million house sales in New Jersey.

LEAD: The United States Postal Service has violated the constitutional rights of job applicants by requiring them to undergo drug tests without good reason, a Federal district judge here has ruled.

LEAD: The New York City Board of Elections released the official mayoral election returns yesterday, showing that Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins defeated Rudolph W. Giuliani by 47,080 votes, the smallest majority for a mayoral candidate in more than 80 years.

U.S. Corn Sale to Soviets
LEAD: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 103,632 metric tons of United States corn to the Soviet Union for delivery in 1989-90 under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Tuesday.
The sales were made by unidentified private exporting companies, which are required to report large sales to the department.

LEAD: In a significant cost-cutting move, the Consolidated Rail Corporation said it would cut its nonunion work force by 12 percent, or about 450 administrative and management positions, and would take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of $70 million to $80 million for the cuts and other related restructuring expenses.

LEAD: Completions of new homes fell by 3.5 percent in October, to an annual rate of 1.31 million units, in the second consecutive monthly decline, the Commerce Department said Tuesday.

Study Supports Global Warming Prediction
LEAD: Direct measurements of atmospheric heat and water vapor have confirmed for the first time a fundamental feature of the theory that is central to predictions of future global warming, scientists at the University of Chicago report in today's issue of the British journal Nature.


Neighbor Sighted 160,000 Light-Years Away
LEAD: Astronomers have detected what they believe is the most distant star in the Milky Way galaxy, and they expect the discovery to lead to the first precise measurement of the galaxy's total mass.

Kigeme Journal; Why Worry About Crops When Fishing's Better!
LEAD: Pelagie Nyirahabimana watched hundreds of fish gather for feeding underneath the chicken hutch suspended over her commercial fish pond.
The fish get bigger and fatter faster from chicken manure than any other nutrient, the 30-year-old fish-farming expert explained.

CRUMBLING SPHINX: WAS IT SABOTAGE?
LEAD: The Egyptian authorities have reopened an investigation into what really happened last year when a 700-pound chunk of the Sphinx's shoulder plummeted to the ground.
In a nutshell, the question is: Did it fall or was it pushed?

LEAD: A woman who has been charged with her companion in the beating death of her 3-year-old son at a Queens hotel has had a deeply troubled and violence-scarred life in which she, her relatives and lawyer picture her as no less a victim than her son.

LEAD: Thousands of demonstrators calling for the resignation of President Mathieu Kerekou confronted riot policemen here today.


Birds Like It; Cats and Squirrels Don't
LEAD: When the last maple leaf has fallen, and there's virtually nothing flowering in the garden except stalwart winter heaths, and when the first snow blankets the ground, sensible gardeners come inside for the fallow season.
But still, through the windows, they can take joy in color and movement outdoors, if they have been provident and affixed bird feeders on suction cups to the panes of glass.


Retail Sales Increased By 0.8% in November
LEAD: In a report providing some reassurance that economic expansion will continue into 1990, the Commerce Department said today that retail sales climbed eight-tenths of 1 percent in November, the biggest gain since August.

LEAD: A Federal grand jury here is investigating reports that public money has been improperly diverted from a secret account administered by the Detroit Police Department, the United States Attorney said today.


Soviets Test Aircraft Carrier, Western Naval Officials Say
LEAD: The Soviet Union is believed to be conducting flight tests on its first full-scale aircraft carrier, Western naval officials said today.
The vessel's commissioning raises questions about Moscow's future naval strategy, they said.

LEAD: On the day after they added Tim Leary and his losing record to their pitching rotation and its losing record, the Yankees paused in their pursuit of redemption yesterday and said they were now looking at other areas to upgrade a team that ran fifth and finished 13 games below the .500 mark.

Corporation said it would sell its Great Southern Life Insurance Company for $105 million in cash and a $40 million 15 1/2 percent subordinated note to the Financial Holding Corporation of Missouri.

Topics of The Times; Underground Voices
LEAD: A New Yorker returning to the city after a long absence finds himself confused by the subway system but comforted by the conductors.
He is grateful to them for telling him at every stop where he is, where he is going next and what his travel options are.
The simple announcement ''14th Street - change for the L'' leaves him wondering if he will ever go to Canarsie, which is where the L train goes.

LEAD: The number of Jews streaming out of the Soviet Union has reached a record.

LEAD: Canada cleared two bids for the biotechnology company Connaught Biosciences Inc., letting the market choose between Institut Merieux's International S.A.'s offer of $942 million (Canadian), or about $813 million in United States currency, and a lower offer by a Swiss-American coalition.

Without them, the policy is unfair.

Money Fund Assets Fall
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased $336.3 million, to $366.81 billion, in the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of 144 institutional funds decreased $387.4 million, to $88.20 billion.
The assets of 228 general-purpose funds were up $148.8 million, to $119.68 billion.

Ruiz's Surrealistic 'Pirates'
Raul Ruiz's ''City of Pirates'' was shown as part of the 1985 New York Film Festival.
Following are excerpts from Janet Maslin's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6, 1985.
The film (in French with English subtitles) opens today with Mr.
Ruiz's ''Three Sad Tigers'' at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.
The Chilean-born fabulist Raul Ruiz makes surrealist films that are entirely self-contained; for ''intriguingly enigmatic,'' as the New York Film Festival literature describes Mr.
Ruiz's ''City of Pirates,'' you might just as well read impenetrable.
However, this film, like Mr.
Ruiz's ''Three Crowns of the Sailor'' (which was shown at the 1984 festival), has the strong imagery and confident, if solipsistic, visual style that make Mr.
Ruiz's work notable.


Dozens Get Subpoenas In Durenberger Inquiry
LEAD: A Senate Ethics Committee inquiry into Senator Dave Durenberger has issued subpoenas to dozens of organizations that paid a Minneapolis publisher in lieu of direct speaking fees to Mr.
Durenberger, the Senator's spokeswoman confirmed today.

Market Place; Making 'Junk Bonds' Respectable
LEAD: With more potential sellers in the ''junk bond'' market than buyers, some institutions with large junk portfolios are using a version of financial magic to turn their holdings into marketable securities with investment-grade ratings.

Hextall Injured
LEAD: While on a one-game conditioning assignment with the Hershey Bears of the American Hockey League, Ron Hextall of the Philadelphia Flyers had to be carried from the ice midway through the third period after injuring his right groin in a game Wednesday against the Nighthawks in New Haven.
The goaltender will be out six to eight weeks.


POLES DRAFT BILLS TO SLOW INFLATION
LEAD: Poland's Solidarity-led Government adopted a package of austerity measures today that is intended to reduce the country's inflation rate and create a market economy.


Judith R. Tishman, 54, Photographers' Agent
LEAD: Judith Rothenberg Tishman, a photographers' representative in Manhattan for many years, died of complications from a brain tumor yesterday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 54 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.


Andrei Sakharov, 68, Soviet 'Conscience,' Dies
LEAD: Andrei D. Sakharov, the indomitable human-rights campaigner who prevailed in official exile to become a relentless prod to the Soviet Union's new congress, died apparently of a heart attack late Thursday after a long and wearying legislative day.
He was 68 years old and lived in Moscow.

LEAD: A CBS executive said yesterday that the network's plan to name Jeff Sagansky president of the entertainment division had been delayed only by minor complications related to Mr.
Sagansky's departure as president of Tri-Star Pictures.

LEAD: The ramshackle tent city of the homeless in Tompkins Square Park was torn down yesterday as scores of city and park police officers mounted a long planned, long announced operation of nearly military complexity.

LEAD: Louisiana's Pardon Board today recommended to Gov.
Buddy Roemer a reduced sentence that could mean freedom in five years for Gary Tyler, a black whose contention that he was framed in a murder case 15 years ago has won international support.

Diner's Journal
LEAD:  Upscale Brasserie New York could surely use some authentic French brasseries, those bright, bustling, drop-in restaurants that serve traditional fare at economical prices.
La Cite, the dazzling new rococo extravaganza on West 51st Street, is a bit highfalutin to be called a brasserie.
A better term might be brassaurant, Manhattan style, where prices can escalate fast.

Image-Conscious East Germany Ran Drug Tests Before Trips
LEAD: For more than a decade, in an effort to prevent international embarrassment, East German athletes were tested for drug use before they were allowed to compete outside the country, Dr.
Claus Clausnitzer, the chief of East Germany's only drug-testing laboratory, said today that from 1978 until last month, his staff tested all athletes selected by officials to compete outside the country, where they might be tested again.

New Mexico Paper Sold
LEAD: The Gannett Company, the Weashington-based media company, said yesterday that it had sold The New Mexican, its Santa Fe, N.M., newspaper, to Robert McKinney, the paper's publisher and editor in chief, and his daughter, Robin McKinney Martin.
Mr.
McKinney resumed his jobs with the paper in 1987 after a nine-year legal battle with Gannett over his employment contract.

LEAD: Is Raul Ruiz a genius or the overrated remnant of a faded avant-garde?
Like his enigmatic films, this Chilean director's controversial reputation admits no easy answer.
But one thing is certain.
Anyone who approaches his imagistic, disjunctive tales as puzzles to be solved is bound to be thwarted.

Inmate Sentenced in Escape
LEAD: A Somers State Prison inmate who called himself ''an animal'' and said he would have committed violent crimes if his escape attempt had been successful was sentenced Wednesday to an additional 10 years in prison.
Judge Michael A. Mack sentenced Donald L. Williamson, who is already serving a 20- to 40-year sentence for kidnapping and rape, to an additional 10 years because he has shown no remorse.

LEAD: Swissair and Singapore Airlines signed a cooperation agreement and said they plan to work out details to exchange 5 percent of each other's shares by the end of 1990.
The agreement established the third link in a global alliance of airlines.
Swissair, Switzerland's national flag carrier, and Singapore Airlines signed bilateral agreements with Atlanta-based Delta Air Lines earlier in the year.

For Children
LEAD:  Shows, Nature, Museums  ''ALADDIN,'' a play performed by the Royal Buckingham Theater Company, 8 P.M. on Fridays and Saturdays, and 3 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, through Jan. 15, at the Nat Horne Theater, 440 West 42d Street.
Tickets: children, under 12, $10; others, $15.
Information: 279-4200.


Pinnacle Rejects Pacificorp Offer
LEAD: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation rejected an acquisition proposal by Pacificorp, the Portland, Ore., utility company.
Pacificorp, which had made an earlier cash bid for Pinnacle's Arizona Public Services unit, had offered to exchange 0.18 share of its common stock for each share of Pinnacle.


Brooklyn Couple Sentenced In Fake Investment Scheme
LEAD: A Brooklyn couple was sentenced yesterday to two and a half years in prison for defrauding friends and neighbors in a $3.9 million fake investment scheme.


Injured Ismail May Miss Bowl
LEAD: Raghib Ismail, the Notre Dame sophomore flanker, running back and kick returner, suffered a separated left shoulder in the loss to Miami on Nov. 25, and may have only a limited role in the Orange Bowl game against Colorado on Jan. 1.


Offering by Chicago Priced
LEAD: Chicago is offering a total of about $161.5 million in water and waste-water transmission revenue bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about a New York City towing operation referred incorrectly to a store that was hit by an unregistered car.
The store, Daffy's, sells clothing; it is not a restaurant.
A picture caption with the article misidentified the man in the foreground.
He was Franklin Sepulveda, a Transportation Department officer.


Shearson Announces Cash Plan
LEAD: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and the American Express Company announced a plan yesterday to raise badly needed cash for the brokerage firm by selling assets and issuing new stock and debt.


Byrne Joins Sports Authority
LEAD: Gov.
Thomas H. Kean today nominated his predecessor, former Gov.
Brendan T. Byrne of Princeton, to a four-year term as a member of the New Jersey Sports and Exposition Authority.
Mr.
Byrne will replace William Taggart, whose term expires on Jan. 11.

New Job for Ex-Leader Of Academy of Design
LEAD: Historic Hudson Valley, an organization that administers a half-dozen historic properties in upstate New York, yesterday named John H. Dobkin as its president.
Mr.
Dobkin, the director of the National Academy of Design since 1978, will become president on Jan. 1.


Video With Music
LEAD: The Nowhere Men, a performance-art ensemble, and Reek of Success, a rock band, will perform Kevin Carter's ''Ipsodefacto,'' a music and video piece, at the Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, tonight and tomorrow at 8:30.
Tickets are $10.
Information: 255-5793.

LEAD: A major lender to the suppliers of Bloomingdale's, Abraham &amp; Straus, Jordan Marsh and other regional retail chains owned by the Campeau Corporation said yesterday that it had stopped advancing funds to those suppliers.

LEAD: A warehouse fire in Piscataway, N.J., burned for several hours last night, spread to several nearby small workshops and a house and forced the evacuation of about 100 people, the police said.

LEAD: There has been a new look to flamenco dancing in New York in recent years.
It was exemplified by the glowing, quietly compelling performance of the Maria Benitez Spanish Dance Company on Tuesday that opened the company's two-week season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street).


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Bullets 105, Hornets 101: Mark Alarie sank an 18-foot jumper with 15 seconds left to snap a 101-101 tie for Washington.
After Rex Chapman brought visiting Charlotte even at 101-101 with a steal and a layup with 28 seconds to play, Alarie hit a jumper from the top of the key.
Washington's Jeff Malone added two free throws in the final second.(AP)  Spurs 104, Rockets 100: Willie Anderson sparked a fourth-quarter burst with 10 of his 19 points and San Antonio outscored visiting Houston, 19-9, in the final 7:24 to win.

West Germany Postpones an Agreement on Open Borders With 4 Neighbors
LEAD: In one of the first signs that events in Eastern Europe may complicate the European Community's integration process, West Germany postponed signing an agreement today to create a border-free region with four of its Western European neighbors.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Radio Revenue Up 7.5%
LEAD: The Radio Advertising Bureau has said that when 1989 is finished, radio advertising revenues will total $8.49 billion, up 7.5 percent from 1988.
Network radio advertising rose 12 percent, national spot advertising 9.5 percent and local advertising 6.8 percent.
Smaller increases are projected for 1990, when the bureau forecasts an increase of 5 to 7 percent.


Homeless Man Given $8.2 Million Judgment
LEAD: A jury has awarded more than $13 million in damages to a homeless man and the estate of his brother for injuries the men suffered after one of them fell onto subway tracks.

LEAD: In its first examination of overall United States trade policy, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that oversees trade, said today that its 96 member nations saw the United States as one of the countries most open to imports.
But it added that they were troubled by persistent protection for certain parts of the

Gallery of Science and Art misidentified a piece of furniture.
It was a Philadelphia high chest, not a Rhode Island chest-on-chest.

LEAD: Business inventories climbed to their highest level in two months in October.

Betting on What in China?
LEAD: Two big bets: President Bush gambles that China's embattled hard-liners will reward his sudden support with a big diplomatic payoff that will prove he's a savvy realist.
Deng Xiaoping, who has his own brand of realism, bets that the visit of senior U.S. envoys to China reinforces his domestic and international position at minimal cost.


Reynolds Metals Project
LEAD: The Reynolds Metals Company, based in Richmond, said today that it would spend $30 million at its sheet and plate plant here to expand and upgrade aluminum plate production for the aircraft and aerospace industry.
Scheduled for completion in 1991, the project will increase Reynolds's plate production capacity by 16 percent, to 80 million pounds a year, and plate machining capacity for wing skins by 50 percent.


Czech Inquiry Into the Fateful Beating of Students in November Accuses Party Chiefs
LEAD: A commission has concluded that beatings of peaceful demonstrators in November resulted from a decision by the political leadership of the country to suppress dissent.

LEAD: When the veteran saxophonist Spike Robinson was prevented by illness from joining the Dutch pianist Jack Van Poll as a duo on Tuesday night at J's, on Broadway at 97th Street, he was replaced by the bassist Brian Torff, a change that created a different kind of duo.

LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $900 million in debentures due 1996 through a nationwide selling group of various securities dealers led by the corporation.

Bavarians Seize Heroin Cache
LEAD: The police seized heroin with a street value of $20 million from a truck bound for Amsterdam from Turkey, Bavarian state officials said today.
Seventy-two bags, each with 2.2 pounds of the drug, were found Monday in a hidden compartment.


Treasuries Gain on 'Junk' Sales
LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher yesterday, pushed by renewed selling in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market and a larger-than-expected increase in weekly unemployment claims.


Philip Morris to End Support For Important Research Prize
LEAD: Philip Morris Inc., the tobacco and food company, said today that it was withdrawing financial support for the World Food Prize, a $200,000 prize for farm research that was considered the most prestigious award in the field.


Volcano Erupts in South Alaska
LEAD: The Redoubt Volcano erupted today, shooting volcanic ash seven miles into the air at its site in Cook Inet and prompting the evacuation of seven oil workers.

LEAD: For many donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, the generosity or selflessness of a relative, friend or colleague prompts the gift.

Mario M. Cuomo tonight signed a bill that would allow Staten Island to secede from New York City, but only after steps that would take at least three and a half years.


Coping: With Imperfect FM Reception
LEAD: You don't have to mount an antenna on the roof to get decent FM radio reception.
Many indoor antennas cost much less than a directional roof antenna with a rotator, and provide much better reception than the antennas that come with most FM sets.

G.M. to Buy Half of Saab Car Unit
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation surprised the auto industry today by announcing it would buy half of Saab-Scania A.B.'s troubled car-making operations.
The move enlarges G.M.'s European presence and plugs a hole in the company's product line, which needs models that can compete with imports like BMW and Mercedes-Benz.

Jacobs of $23 a share.

Convictions of 5 Apartheid Foes Voided
LEAD: In a stunning psychological victory for the anti-apartheid movement, South Africa's highest court today reversed the convictions of five blacks who were found guilty of treason or terrorism last year after the longest political trial here in recent memory.


Ban on Film for Blasphemy Is Upheld in Britain
LEAD: The Video Appeals Committee of the British Board of Film Classification has upheld a ban on ''Visions of Ecstasy,'' the first film ever to be banned for blasphemy in Britain.


Kodak Charge Cuts Earnings
LEAD: In a development that came as little surprise to the financial community, the Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that it would reduce its fourth-quarter earnings by $273 million, or 85 cents a share, because of write-offs of assets in discontinued businesses and payments to employees who are losing their jobs.

LEAD: A young advertising executive who was killed earlier this month leaving a Christmas party in the East Village was set upon by different robbers in two attacks within a few minutes, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: Top executives of some of the nation's largest newspaper companies predicted this week that 1990 would be another tough year for advertising sales, but most said they thought a recession was unlikely.


FREE TRAVEL FAILS TO CURB EXODUS OF EAST GERMANS
LEAD: East Germany's hope that the exodus of its people would drop drastically once travel restrictions were removed has not been fulfilled in the month since the travel curbs were lifted, and West Germany continues to receive a steady stream of immigrants.


Alcan Aluminium
LEAD: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said its directors had adopted a shareholder rights plan to discourage hostile takeover bids.
The giant aluminum company said the plan, effective immediately, would allow holders of the rights to acquire common shares at a 50 percent discount of market value in certain cases.
The rights would be triggered if someone acquired between 10 and 20 percent of the company's voting shares.


Bookmaking Case Nets Law Official
LEAD: A Federal grand jury today indicted the New Orleans District Attorney, Harry Connick, on charges that he illegally helped a well-known Louisiana bookmaker and his gambling business.


Bomb Plant Reopening Is Put Off After Mishap
LEAD: A nuclear bomb plant in Washington State that was shut last December because of safety problems has had an unexplained chemical reaction in a pipe that ruptured a gasket and sprayed acid into an area sometimes occupied by workers.


Harriet Reade, Environmentalist, 68
LEAD: Harriet Reade, a founder of the Children's Psychiatric Center who also helped environmental causes in New Jersey, died of cancer Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan.
She was 68 years old and lived in Middletown, N.J.

LEAD: Ernest N. (Dutch) Morial has announced that contrary to widespread expectations here, he will not seek to regain the mayoralty, an office he held for eight years.

LEAD: The Talking Deals column in Business Day on Nov. 30 and its headline, about an investment fund created by the leveraged buyout firm of Forstmann, Little &amp; Company, referred incorrectly to deals in which the firm has previously invested.
They have been only friendly transactions to buy companies - deals in which management of the acquired company has cooperated.

He was 86 years old and lived in Garden City, L.I.

LEAD: A sharp drop in the cost of gasoline helped to push producer prices lower in November, the Government said today.

LEAD: The wife of a senior partner in a large accounting firm was acquitted yesterday of murder and manslaughter in the stabbing death of her estranged husband.


Drug Official For New York Resigns Post
LEAD: New York State's top drug-treatment official resigned today, one day after the release of a blistering state report that said he had directed more than $2 million to drug-abuse programs that were run by his friends and that failed to treat anybody.


Valenzuela Stays With Dodgers
LEAD: Fernando Valenzuela, who had been on the verge of signing with another team, decided yesterday to return to the Los Angeles Dodgers for one year at a guaranteed $2 million.
The left-hander could earn an additional $500,000 in bonuses if he pitches 240 innings.


The Czech' History: A Waiting Game
LEAD: The Czechoslovakiadid it in their own style -peacefully, led by intellectuals and students in Prague's streets, after a long wait.
It was the quickest flip to democracy in the region.
It was also the neatest, and perhaps the one with the most promise.


Drug Smugglers And the Marines Exchange Shots
LEAD: A United States Marine Corps reconnaissance team, which has been quietly patrolling the Southwest border since Thanksgiving, exchanged fire with drug smugglers for the first time late Wednesday night along the Arizona border, Administration officials said today.


European Bloc Levies Bayer Fine
LEAD: The European Community fined the West German chemical producer Bayer A.G. $590,000 for violating competition rules in the marketing of an additive for animal feed.
The fine stems from Bayer's insistence that West German customers buy the additive, which promotes growth in animals, only for themselves.


Leland H. Watson, Lighting Designer, 63
LEAD: Leland H. Watson, a lighting designer for many years, died of leukemia on Dec. 8 at his home in Lafayette, Ind.
He was 63 years old.


Judge Allows Tests of Police For Drug Use
LEAD: A new policy by the New York City Police Department requiring all members of its 27,000 uniformed force to be randomly tested for drugs was upheld yesterday by a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan.


Brief Closing for Pisa's Tower
LEAD: The Mayor of Pisa signed an order today that will close the Tower of Pisa to the public from Jan. 7 to April 7 for safety reasons.
Mayor Giacomino Granchi said officials would at least consider adopting safety measures that would allow a limited reopening of the tower.
Shifting ground under the 180-foot tower left it tilting almost from the time that Bonnano Pisano started building it in 1173.


Upheaval in the East; New Measures Strain Poland's Ties to 2 Germanys
LEAD: Relations between Poland and the two Germanys are being strained by the side effects of the peaceful revolution that has swept East Germany since October, diplomats and Government officials in several European capitals say.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Is a Magnum Enough?
LEAD: The holidays mean toasts, and toasts mean champagne.
Champagnes are bottled in a greater variety of sizes than are other wines and that means you can generally buy what you need and no more.
Most French Champagne is sold in half-bottles, bottles and magnums.
Splits and jeroboams are also fairly common, and a few producers bottle nonvintage champagnes in sizes even bigger than the jeroboam.

At the Pump, Pollution Curb Yields Bonus
LEAD: Clouds, even the ones formed by pollution, can have a silver lining.
Regulators who have been trying to keep the chemicals that form harmful ozone from getting into the air have found that the same equipment that controls those chemicals can help control benzene, a toxic component of gasoline.

Devaluation By China
LEAD: In a long expected move, China said tonight that it would devalue its currency by 21.2 percent against the dollar, effective Saturday.
It is China's first devaluation since 1986.


Past-Due Mortgages Up
LEAD: The delinquency rate for home mortgages jumped sharply in the July-September quarter to the highest level in more than two years, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America said Thursday.
In the quarter, 5 percent of mortgage payments for one-family to four-family residences were 30 or more days late, up from a second-quarter rate of 4.52 percent, a 10-year low.

LEAD: Seven choreographers presented works on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater as part of Dance Theater Workshop's Fresh Tracks series of programs by new talent.
The offerings varied greatly in style.

LEAD: To great fanfare, the Ethics Reform Act of 1989 increased Federal pay and reduced honorariums.
It also attacked the revolving door phenomenon that has long plagued government.
The act clarifies and strengthens existing law requiring former high executive branch officials, all members of Congress and top staff members to wait one year before returning to lobby their old haunts.

LEAD: ON a recent morning, Naomi Drew gathered her kindergarten and first-grade class at the Cambridge School around her on the floor to talk about how learning to solve problems with the children's peers could make the world a better place.


Treed
LEAD: WITH ITS UNCATALOGUED FLORA and fauna - literally millions of species and genera - the tropical rain forest canopy is the natural world's richest frontier, a world unto itself, really.
And the latest best hope for scientists eager to explore it is, fittingly, a little on the otherworldly side.

LEAD: An article on Nov. 5 about elections in Uruguay gave an incorrect party affiliation for the vice-presidential candidate of the Broad Front, a leftist coalition.

Pastimes; Chess
LEAD: Some of the most dangerous illusions on the chessboard stem from one of the greatest geniuses of the game, Wilhelm Steinitz, world champion from 1866 to 1894.
This man, who was so adept at analyzing the structure of the game - embodied by the pawn formation - was cavalier about the factor of time and of rapidity of development and what it could do.

Persuading Americans To Save
LEAD: POLITICIANS here finally appear to be waking up to what economists have been telling them: The long binge of overspending and undersaving by government, business and consumers threatens to depress living standards and reduce the nation to a second-rate economic force during the next decade.
Already, there are symptoms, among them lagging productivity, slow wage growth, the sale of major assets to foreign investors, stubbornly high interest rates and the huge trade and budget deficits.

The New Takeovers
LEAD: SINCE the early 1980's, corporate America has been wracked by endless takeover battles.
Prices for companies soared, propelled by investors' seemingly insatiable appetite for debt.
Those heady days are gone, however.
And for the next year or so, takeover specialists predict that deals will be fewer, fetch lower prices and involve far less debt.

What to Do With the Cold War Money
LEAD: THE idea of a ''peace dividend'' first surfaced in 1969.
A Cabinet Coordination Committee was set up to report to President Lyndon B. Johnson on what the Federal Government should do with its savings when the War in Vietnam finally ended.
The committee proposed that the Federal Government dedicate $39.7 billion a year from its savings - in 1969 dollars - for the upkeep of the infrastructure.

The Trade Deficit Takes Off Again
LEAD: The U.S. merchandise trade deficit widened sharply to $10.2 billion in October, the biggest imbalance in 10 months, as imports reached a record level.
The Government also reported that inventories climbed four-tenths of a percent in October, to a seasonally adjusted $793.9 billion.
In November, wholesale prices edged down a tenth of a percent and capacity utilization also was down a tenth of a point, to 82.7 percent.


Is the Run On the Hits An Error?
LEAD: Are renters finding what they want when they go to the video store?
In this the year of big-movie cassettes for sale (''Batman'' et al.), some in the trade are concerned that rentals, still the real right arm of video with about 70 percent of the revenue, aren't getting enough attention. ''What renters really want in a video store is breadth and scope of selection,'' says Nicholas Santrizos, the chairman of Trylon Video, a New York-based distributor.

There Are Benefits In Homeschooling
LEAD: Not long ago, the Long Island Weekly published an article I wrote about homeschooling my 8-year-old son.
I had expected some reader criticism, but I was completely unprepared for the ferocity of the negative responses.
Since people tend to be uncomfortable with that which they do not understand, those who responded might feel less averse towards our choice of education if they knew more about it.

FICTION
LEAD:  BEAUTIFUL MUTANTS.
By Deborah Levy. (Viking, $17.95.) Although billed as a novel, Deborah Levy's rather thin little book, ''Beautiful Mutants,'' reads more like a short story.
Episodic, concise and poetic, this unconventional tale about social misfits and secret desires feels dreamlike in its quick passage and sometimes indelible imagery.

But now we have conflicting advice on where to go from there.
Some people tell us it is best to let the sandblasted shingles weather for several months, while others say they should be stained immediately.

LEAD: Christoph Hein, a writer and intellectual prominent in East Berlin, has long been an outspoken critic of his nation's Government.
A recent play of Hein's, ''The Knights of the Round Table,'' has been widely read as an allegory of the leadership crisis in East Germany; in recent months it played to packed houses in Dresden and has become a rallying point for the opposition.

MENCKEN made the first entry in his diary on Nov. 5, 1930.

Pastimes; Bridge
LEAD: Sneaky and improper dumping is a source of controversy and outrage for bridge players as well as for environmentalists and urban planners.

Christmas For the Thrifty: Yes, in Paris
LEAD: PARIS is one of the cheapest places I know to have a glorious Christmas - or rather have a glorious time escaping from Christmas.
Not a total escape; for that you'd have to go to Lhasa or Teheran.
But if this year you can't face another magazine-ad-type American family Christmas with the father in Santa Claus costume and everybody sitting happily around the tree amid mountains of gaily wrapped laptop computers, Cabbage Patch dolls and electric trains, while through the snowy window can be seen the front end of the new car ''we gave to each other,'' Paris makes a blissful change.

Here's a shopping list of ways to save or earn some money - many of them obvious but often overlooked and all of them free for the asking.

LEAD: A gang of 10 armed robbers invaded an apartment-house garage on the Upper West Side early yesterday, held up the attendant and made off with five late-model cars, the police said.
The last car was cut off by police officers arriving at the garage and one of the occupants was seized.


Campus Life: University of Connecticut; Converting Excess Dining Credits to Help Charities
LEAD: It was a combination of charity and protest as 150 University of Connecticut students waited in line last weekend at Jonathan's, one of three fast-food restaurants here on the campus.
The students were using the balance on their Vali-Dine cards to help feed the needy and homeless in nearby Willimantic.


U.S. Train, Champagne Class
LEAD: FOR many Americans notions about long-distance train travel have more to do with mythology than memory.
While few of us really knew the Santa Fe Super Chief or ever rode the 20th Century Limited, the mere whisper of such names evokes excitement and romance, in the same way we are still stirred by the sound of a faraway locomotive whistle.


New York G.O.P. Is Better Organized But Still Seeks Challenger to Cuomo
LEAD: As it prepares for a critical gubernatorial election, the New York State Republican Party is better financed and better staffed than it has been since the Rockefeller era.
But it still lacks an experienced and well-known candidate to challenge Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo if he seeks a third term and to end a 16-year Republican absence from the

LEAD: A high-ranking Ohio teamster official denied Friday that he took part in his own union's attempt to thwart the Government's disciplinary action against him.

LEAD: WITH English plum puddings, Jamaican rum cakes and Mexican ornaments, Laine Dyer and Nicole Shirley are hoping to promote peace.

LEAD: Whenever the Los Angeles Lakers visit, there is excitement in the air, a large crowd is in the stands, and the opposing team's level of play usually rises.


Maurice Stans's Offer Rejected by His Town
LEAD: An offer by Maurice Stans to donate his family home and a new museum to his hometown has been rejected because officials do not want to be responsible for the upkeep.

LEAD: THE Yale Center for British Art has never seemed more British than it does now, with ''The Desired Haven,'' a group of 89 photographs by Frederick H. Evans (1853-1943).

LEAD: DID an American Army sergeant kill more than 500 Japanese soldiers singlehandedly in one battle during World War II?

The Taxpayers' Campaign Chest
LEAD: THE New York City Campaign Finance Board is the rare government agency that didn't spend its budget.
Taxpayers may exult at the budgetary success the brand-new office had in substituting taxpayers' money for big special-interest contributions in this year's city political campaigns - the first large municipal experiment of its kind in the country.

LEAD: THE cultural needs of children are not being forgotten this holiday season, with more than a dozen attractions designed for younger listeners - and in some cases featuring them.

LEAD: Alison Poorvu, an assistant director of admissions at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration, and Daniel G. Jaffe, a geologist, plan to marry in March.

William J. Poorvu of Cambridge, Mass.


Hanoi Protests Over Boat People
LEAD: Vietnam opposes the forced return of boat people who sought refuge in Hong Kong and reserves the right to send them back to the British colony, the official Hanoi press agency said.


Sudan Hardens Crackdown on Internal Opponents
LEAD: The junta that squashed a democratically elected government in the Sudan nearly six months ago is toughening its stand against its opponents by imposing death sentences, bombing southern towns in an intensified civil war and saying that it plans to carry out a strict Islamic code.


THE MEKONS TAKE AIM AT ROCK-AND-ROLL
LEAD: ''Hey - rock-and-roll!'' Sally Timms shouted as she and her fellow Mekons crammed themselves back onstage for encores at the Knitting Factory a few weeks ago.
For most bands, the phrase is simply a sure-fire way to draw a yell from an audience.
But for the Mekons, it is anything but unexamined; when they say rock-and-roll, they're simultaneously loving, wistful, suspicious, defiant and gleeful.


More Housing For a Railyard
LEAD: AFTER a 12-year hiatus, residential construction has resumed at a 52-acre former railroad yard on this city's near South Side.

The problem for most theaters is finding ways to present this venerable classic so that audiences will continue to come back season after season.

PITCHING DOCTORS
LEAD: The materials that detail men disseminate are not bad or wrong or poorly presented (''Pitching Doctors,'' by Michael S. Wilkes and Miriam Shuchman, Nov. 5).
Rather, they are so professional, so slickly done, that it is hard to remember they are not necessarily the broad scholarly surveys that ought to form the basis for wise prescribing.

English Christmas
LEAD: To the Editor: We found ourselves in the same situation as the person who wrote (Q &amp; A, Travel, Oct. 8) about what to do in London during the Christmas holiday.


Collecting Crystal for Pleasure and for Profit
LEAD: In a bid for a share of the upper tier of the crystal market, more and more manufacturers are forming collectors' clubs.
Membership buys certain privileges - for instance, the ability to purchase exclusive pieces.
But the real intention of these marketing ploys is to lock in collectors to a given brand, thereby increasing the sales of both retailers and manufacturers, which market the clubs together.

Veteran Denied a Medal Sadly Vows to Fight On
LEAD: David Rubitsky, his hands trembling slightly as he read from a handwritten statement on lined notebook paper, today rebutted the Army's finding that he was simply an honorable old soldier with a foggy memory.


Pastimes; Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: Carry on with the holiday projects such as shopping, decorating, wrapping, mailing, baking, etc, but do not neglect house plants that will need watering, debugging and leaf cleaning with a damp paper towel.
Hold back on the use of fertilizer at this time of year as most indoor plants are in a dormant-rest period.


Who Was The Athlete of The Decade?
LEAD: The American diver Greg Louganis.
Since 1976, he has won four Olympic gold medals, 47 American titles, and 120 of 153 major events.
Beyond that, in this decade of million-dollar earnings and cocaine and steroid abuse scandals, Louganis exemplifies the true spirit of competition and the beauty of sport.

Style Makers; Konstantine Kakanias, Illustrator
LEAD: If Konstantine Kakanias had his way, most of the things that surround him in the world would be painted - and he would quickly volunteer for the job.
The 28-year-old artist, who was born in Athens, lives in New York and is well on his way to putting his imprimatur on scenic backdrops for shop windows, glossy magazine pages and table tops.


A BROTHER'S DEATH
LEAD: My brother's name was Doug, the partner he left behind is Skip (Hers: ''A Brother's Death,'' by Barbara Lazear Ascher, Nov. 19).
Doug's ashes rest in the sea off the coast of Maine, and he has been gone two years.
In every other respect (that he was 31 when he died of AIDS, that he was the brother of two sisters and that his parents were unashamed of the cause of his death) the circumstances of Doug and Bobby are the same.


Arnold Moss, 80, Popular Actor Famous for Shakespearean Roles
LEAD: Arnold Moss, the popular classical actor, died of lung cancer Friday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 80 years old.


Correction
LEAD: An article last Sunday about jigsaw puzzles with mystery themes misidentified a Bloomfield company marketing them.
It is Be Puzzled, not DePuzzled.

LEAD: ''It was an incredible experience,'' Ron Kovic said of watching Tom Cruise portray him on the set of ''Born on the Fourth of July'' in Dallas last year. ''I was looking at myself live through the most difficult periods of my life.
I was forced to deal with the reality of the hell that I had lived through in a way that I never dealt with it before.

No Aid to Mozambique Rebels, de Klerk Says
LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa says his Government has cut off aid to the insurgents in Mozambique, but he acknowledges the possibility that private citizens in South Africa might be helping the rebels.


Knicks Win 9th in a Row at Home
LEAD: The Knicks last night won their ninth successive home-court game since the beginning of the season, a franchise record for the fastest start.
The 118-97 victory over the Seattle SuperSonics came so easily that it was enough to lull the Madison Square Garden capacity crowd of 18,212 to sleep.


Evening Hours; The Faces May Be Familiar, but Not the Places
LEAD: There was a time when one could take a census of the rich and social in New York by poking a head into certain hotel ballrooms during the charity season and counting the hundreds of notable noses.
If they weren't at the Waldorf, they were at the Plaza or the Pierre.
Some nights they were at all three.


Nursing Enrollments End 5 Years of Declines
LEAD: The number of new students enrolling in college and university nursing programs increased for the first time in five years, but the increase is too small to overcome an acute nursing shortage, a new survey shows.


Style Makers; Leslie Hope Derene, Photographer
LEAD: Leslie Hope Derene studied historic preservation at Boston University and spent eight years working in the fashion industry before finding her true calling.
She now takes photographs and mounts them on gift and note cards, holiday ornaments and portfolios.

LEAD: Troops backed by tanks were rushed to Davao today after reports that rebel soldiers planned to stage a new attempt to topple President Corazon C. Aquino, this time in the southern Philippines.

And at times the goal is to alter the style of new residential construction.

Beyond Expectations
LEAD: MY CULINARY CHAUVINISM DISAPPEARED WHEN I got my first chance to eat in England.
Along with a whole bag of heavy sweaters for that mid-June jaunt, I had secretly packed a jar of pickled jalapeno peppers for my trip.
If British food was truly going to be as dismal as I had always heard, I wanted to be able to give it a little heat, if not life.


NONFICTION
LEAD:  LILY POND: Four Years With a Family of Beavers.
By Hope Ryden. (Morrow, $17.95.) It is likely that ''Lily Pond'' will appeal to nature lovers.
The startling thing, though, is how well Hope Ryden's study of a beaver family succeeds on other levels.
Her observations of a pair of wild beavers in New York's Harriman State Park is eloquent and suspenseful, educational without being didactic, and includes a reasoned analysis of whether humans should further disrupt nature's balance.

New Delay for Shuttle Flight
LEAD: A lag in preparations has caused the next launching of the space shuttle Columbia to be delayed one more day, until next Thursday, the space agency announced Friday.

Lapchick Event Is Embarrassing

Girls Should Quit Smoking - It's a Breeze
LEAD: FANS!
They're the solution.
Not screaming, frenzied rock-star fans, not electric fans, but hand-held semicircles of ribbed paper, lace and silk.
Fans held delicately in front of one's face, calling attention to flirtatious eyes.
Fans snapping shut for emphasis.
Fans gracefully fluttered to advertise allure.
