Texas Justice
LEAD: Texas has put 33 people to death since it resumed executions in December 1982.
Clarence Lee Brandley twice came within days of being a 34th - even though the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals now says that his 1981 conviction for rape and murder was a ''subversion of justice.''


Pastimes; Coins
LEAD: The wealth of the Americas flowed to Spain in the 16th, 17th and 18th centuries.
Each year, if wars permitted, two fleets would cruise the Caribbean, depositing Spanish trade goods and picking up gold doubloons, silver pesos, emeralds and pearls.
Goods from the Orient, brought by the Manila fleet to Acapulco and by mule across Mexico to Vera Cruz, were loaded aboard.

LEAD: SQUEAKY stairs are a comfort to some homeowners.

Under the Microscope At County's New Lab
LEAD: WHEN a suspect is arrested in a drug case in Westchester, the police have five days to analyze the drugs seized or the suspect must be released and the charges dropped.
Last year, drugs from 3,530 cases were sent to the crime lab and 88,705 tests were performed on the drugs.
This year's cases are expected to total 3,800.


A Small Flotilla of Unanchored Anchors
LEAD: Some months ago, NBC ran a full-page advertisement that asked if it mattered whether the anchor of a nightly news program was this fellow or that.
The ad's unastonishing answer was that it mattered a lot and that NBC's own man Tom Brokaw was the anchor of choice.
Unfortunately for NBC, that does not seem to be the opinion of most viewers.


Mexico's Colonial Heart
LEAD: IN many ways, the geographic heart of Mexico is also its spiritual and cultural heart.
Dotted with elegant colonial cities and villages that still hew to traditional folkways and crafts, the area extending in an arc west and north of the capital is rich both in character and history.
And unlike the Yucatan or the resorts of the Pacific Coast, the states of Michoacan, Guanajuato and Queretaro are readily accessible from Mexico

LEAD: The first reaction is shock.
The rather comfortable, familiar proscenium space at Manhattan Theater Club's Stage One has been temporarily transformed into a theater in the round.
To get to its seats, the audience must tiptoe through clumps of straw while instinctively trying to avoid fake pieces of manure.

LEAD: What makes Richard Goode such a splendid chamber-music pianist, I think, is not an anonymous personality, but - to the contrary - the restrictions on his own personal passions imposed by those around him.


THE DAZZLE OF GLASS, SEEN OVER TIME
LEAD: Every technique used to make glass over 3,500 years is represented in ''The Art of Glass: Masterpieces From the Corning Museum,'' an exhibition on view at the I.B.M.
Gallery of Science and Art, Madison Avenue at 56th Street.
The 116 molded, blown, cut, engraved or painted works in these dazzling displays were made during the peak periods of this craft, from ancient Egypt onward, and include some of the finest examples extant.

AMERICA'S RADIATION VICTIMS
LEAD: The following is from a letter my father wrote to me in 1981: ''In 1956, I went to Nevada to a field test of an atomic shot.
It was a 28-kiloton shot and we were in the trenches at three miles from ground zero. . . .
The ground rolled like the waves in the ocean, and the flash was so bright that, with my eyes closed and with my head cradled in my arm and my arm resting on my leg, I could see every bone in my arm and legs like you see in an X-ray picture.

LEAD: Any listener whose interest in Western classical music extends beyond superficial ''music appreciation'' to a concern with origins, formal principles and stylistic evolution must sooner or later come to grips with the rich musical heritage of the Arab world.


POSTINGS: The Metropolitan Club; Facade Mudpack
LEAD: The Metropolitan Club, which moved into its building at the northeast corner of Fifth Avenue and East 60th Street 95 years ago, is cleaning the exterior of the landmarked property, which was designed by Stanford White.
More than $1 million is being spent to dissolve as many as five layers of paint on the marble exterior, and then slather it with a chemical poultice to remove stains caused by the reaction between air pollutants and impurities in the stone.

LEAD: THE cobblestone streets of the medieval German city of Freiburg, near the French border in a valley protected by the lush slopes of the Black Forest, are lined by narrow canals filled with fresh, running water.

Volcanic Ash in Anchorage
LEAD: A slight wind shift brought a haze of ash from Redoubt Volcano drifting down on Alaska's largest city today, prompting the authorities to issue a warning to people with lung ailments.
The volcano, 115 miles southwest of Anchorage, began erupting Thursday and was belching ash skyward for the third day in a row, though in a somewhat reduced amount, said the United States Geological Survey.

Birding in Mexico's South
LEAD: AS soon as the plane lifts off from Mexico City and heads south toward the state of Chiapas, you can see plumes of smoke rising over the mountains.
A lot of the forest is already gone.
Some of it is burned off by peasant families who hope to raise one or two meager harvests of beans or plantains before the soil is exhausted.

Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; Not Too Sweet or Sour
LEAD: Remember sweet-and-sour pork?
It is one of the first dishes most people over 40 ate at a Chinese restaurant.
It was always a Cantonese restaurant; 40 years ago, Szechuan had yet to reach the United States.
Actually, the dish was mainly sweet; the vast quantities of sugar and the canned pineapple in heavy syrup disguised whatever sour ingredients had been added.

'Wozzeck' Speaks To Us by Mixing Two Musical Modes
LEAD: Alban Berg's ''Wozzeck'' was the first atonal opera to get anywhere near standard repertory status, and it is still the only one. (Berg's second opera, ''Lulu,'' is the only other remote contender.) It was first heard in 1925 and had almost 30 productions by the early 30's.
After a hiatus while Nazi disapproval halted its progress before German-speaking audiences, it resumed its place at home and spread to all the world's operatic capitals.

A Calendar of Holiday Music Events
LEAD: THE musical presentations planned at churches and concert halls in Connecticut for this Christmas season are noteworthy for their variety.
There will be traditional carols sung by congregation and choir in simple church services and gala productions of seasonal works performed in concert.
Esoteric anthems and obscure works by the great composers will be offered for the serious music lover, and elaborate productions with large casts will present an opportunity for celebration.

NONFICTION
LEAD:  AMERICAN POWER: The Rise and Decline of U.S.
Globalism, 1918-1968.
By John Taft. (Harper &amp; Row, $22.50.) The ascension of the United States as a world power, according to John Taft, was largely due to the efforts of a Northeastern, Ivy League-educated, internationalist elite.
This group, including George Kennan, Averell Harriman and Dean Acheson, believed that world order could be created through the Wilsonian ideals of free trade, democracy, anti-imperialism and world organizations.

Two Decades as 'Honest Brokers' for Medicine's Moral Issues
LEAD: THE philosopher met the psychiatrist by chance during a Christmas party in l968.
Over a punch bowl, they discussed matters many people would have regarded as the stuff of dreams or science fiction.
A biological revolution was almost at hand, they agreed, and the day was fast approaching when hearts would be produced artifically, organs could be transplanted and death itself would have to be redefined.

PITCHING DOCTORS
LEAD: The recent New York State public-health law has indeed reduced the number of prescriptions written for the benzodiazepines by virtue of the triplicate prescription requirement.
However, in addition to the triplicate form, the law requires that a prescription for benzodiazepine may supply a patient for not more than 30 days, and that a patient be examined by his doctor each time a renewal is needed.

Chicago.

Harvey W. Cohen of Livingston, N.J., plan to be married in April.
Their engagement was announced by Lucy Artiles of Miami, the prospective bride's mother.


East German Communists Confront Party's Collapse
LEAD: Confusion and insecurity reigned in East German politics today as the Communist Party struggled to redefine its role and new parties tried to take form.


A BROTHER'S DEATH
LEAD: I felt a grief similar to that of Ms.
Ascher when I read her article.
I am a 21-year-old man, attending college in New York, and I am also gay.
With these circumstances in my life, the horror and despair caused by AIDS is a reality that I must face every day.


How Chile Is Devising a Democracy
LEAD: THE easy triumph of a coalition candidate in the presidential elections in Chile last Thursday reflects, on the surface anyway, the end of the longstanding animosity between the leftists who supported the late Salvador Allende Gossens and the centrists who opposed him 16 years ago.


Correction
LEAD: An article on Nov. 19 about donating unwanted books gave the hours of the Bryn Mawr Book Shop in New York City incorrectly.
The shop is open Thursday through Saturday from 10:30 A.M. to 4:30 P.M., and on Sunday from 12:30 P.M. to 4:30 P.M.


Small in Size But Not in Scope
LEAD: SMALLNESS is currently the thing at City Without Walls.
Not one of the 46 works in the gallery's ''Eighth Annual Metro Show'' is more than 12 inches in any dimension.
It makes for easier transportation and distribution: Metro shows customarily go forth unto the people where they work, and the pit stops are not necessarily art galleries.


Taking the Squeak Out of Stairs
LEAD: SQUEAKY stairs are a comfort to some homeowners.
Familiar noises on the stairs signal the return of family members, while unfamiliar noises may warn of an intruder.


Fashion; Chic for the Last-Minute Shopper
LEAD: The holiday gift bought this week in a panic needn't be banal. ''At the last moment, people buy a plain tie, plain gloves,'' said Louise Maniscalco, director of the personal shopping service at Barneys New York. ''But that's not what anybody really wants.
People want something a little offbeat, a little whimsical.

Campus Life: Bard; Parietal Rules Under Attack At Special School
LEAD: A group of students at Simon's Rock, part of Bard College, is fighting the parietal rules against nonresident students' staying overnight in single-sex freshmen dormitories.
The administration is showing signs of retreat.


Misery Replaces Hope in a Battered Afghanistan
LEAD: As a volley of guerrilla rockets pounded the airport in the Afghan capital on a bitterly cold December day, a conscript in the Government army standing sentry near the runway laid down his Kalashnikov rifle, spread a blanket on the ground, and prostrated himself in prayer.

LEAD: Now that the excitement of New York City's election is over and a new mayor is in office, a critical task lies ahead.
A new beginning is at hand with the awesome responsibility of bringing this city out of a myriad of complex economic and social problems that affect the poor and needy.
But the responsibility for these changes does not lie with the mayor alone.

Fair Play
LEAD: To the Editor:


Men, Women And the Revolution
LEAD: I HAVE always told friends I would know the revolution had come when they put diaper-changing tables in men's rooms.
This year I moved to New Jersey and found that it had happened without me.
The tables are already in place at the Princeton MarketFair - and it was built two whole years ago.


With More Machines, That Phone Conversation May Be on Tape
LEAD: A growing number of Americans, accustomed to taping everything from college lectures to television shows, now own answering machines or other devices that allow them to record conversations with their families, friends and business associates.


Lotus Takes a Gamble on 'Notes'
LEAD: THE Lotus Development Corporation recently introduced a product called Notes, which was five years in development.
Notes is a new type of network corporate communications software sometimes referred to as ''super E-mail,'' a shorthand way of saying that it is a high-powered electronic message system.


John M. Alden, Engineer, 66
LEAD: John M. Alden, an engineer and the founder of Alden Electronics, died of cancer Wednesday at his home in Needham, Mass.
He was 66 years old.

Cockney Cuisine: Eel, Pie and Mash
LEAD: SUSAN HALL sits on a wooden bench in S. R. Kelly and Sons, an eel and pie shop in London's East End and, with shining blue eyes, surveys the plate before her.
An oblong meat pie with a flaky and ''ever-so-luverly'' brown crust dominates one half of the plate.
Next to it lies a huge dollop of mashed potatoes, swimming in a green-flecked sea of parsley sauce, or ''liquor.


Japanese Debate How to Enthrone Emperor
LEAD: With the formal enthronement of Emperor Akihito nearly a year away, Japan has become entangled in a debate among scholars and political leaders about what sort of ceremony would be appropriate.


Why Gold Is So Bright
LEAD: Gold prices have risen sharply since September, from about $360 an ounce to $425 an ounce in early December before falling back to $408.25 at the close on Friday.
Are we poised for another bull market in gold?
Four precious metals analysts offer their views.
Vahid Fathi  Vice president, Prescott, Ball &amp; Turben Inc., Cleveland.


Review/Dance; Semaphore Theater Performs Janice Margolis Fantasies
LEAD: Semaphore Dance Theater of Boston offered two imagistic productions by its director, Janice Margolis, on Thursday night at the Nikolais/Louis Choreospace.
Both had texts by Thomas Frick and taped collages that blended original scores with sound effects and solemn and frivolous music by various composers.

LEAD: The burst late in the third period began at his own blue line.
Pat LaFontaine, a few quick, quirky strides later, was at the other blue line.
There, he met the puck, and an instant later he had a step on James Patrick, the defenseman for the Rangers.


OPENLY GAY PRIEST ORDAINED IN JERSEY
LEAD: Bishop John S. Spong, head of the Episcopal Diocese of Newark, ordained an openly gay man as a priest yesterday, over the strong protests of traditionalist Episcopal Church bishops and members who argued that the ordination would disregard Christian moral standards.

LEAD: In sending a high-level mission to the unrepentant rulers of China, President Bush acted on the premises of a particular world view.
That is the one that Henry Kissinger brought to Washington as foreign-policy impresario for Presidents Nixon and Ford.

Body Found on Jersey Beach
LEAD: The body of a 26-year-old woman from neighboring Wildwood was found on a dune here this morning, the police said.
Detective Sgt.
Tom Stocker identified the woman as Tamara Davis.
Authorities had not determined the cause of death or where Ms.
Davis was killed, but it appeared she had been dragged to the spot, he said.

Deep in December, It's Time to Go After the Ruffed Grouse
LEAD: Although it is legal to hunt ruffed grouse deep into winter in much of the Northeast, few do so.
As summer wanes and the first frosts arrive in late September or early October, the grouse hunter begins to chafe at the bit.
He is waiting for a gale and rain to rip the leaves from their moorings, making it possible for him to see a grouse, or a woodcock, when it goes aloft through the ''bare, ruined choirs where late the sweet birds sang.

LEAD: A 563-page study of the Nazi gas chambers has been published in a limited edition in the United States by Serge and Beate Klarsfeld, the French Holocaust researchers and Nazi hunters.
They say the volume provides a new kind of definitive scholarly documentation of the murder of millions of Jews and others during World War

Business Scene; Theory of Decline Fails to Hold Up
LEAD: EXPERTS try furiously to explain why the United States is in decline as a manufacturing center while Japan and West Germany flourish.
The blame has fallen heavily on the work force (inadequately educated), consumers (wasteful spenders) and the Government (lacks a trade policy).
Now a new explanation is becoming popular - the high cost of capital - and like the others, it provides some useful insights.

This season is no exception.

LEAD: During the years of the Reagan military build-up, Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger let each service buy every weapon on its wish list, unhindered by any overall strategic concept.

T.
Byram Karasu of the psychiatry department at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine.

In most of the compositions, the performers suggested that they were archetypal Spanish images achieving a flesh-and-blood actuality on the stage.

LEAD: Suddenly, it is more than just a place: it is a fictional domain, as exotic as it is mysterious.
The pull of its ethnic gravity is so powerful that it is inspiring a new generation of writers, playwrights and film makers to portray the life of its neighborhoods.
So compelling is its geography that a cluster of recent book, film and theater reviews has actually used the word ''romantic'' in describing it.

Kahane Is Indicted
LEAD: Israeli Government prosecutors accused Rabbi Meir Kahane today of inciting racial hatred on the day after a Palestinian forced an Israeli bus into a ravine, killing 16 Jews.
The indictment said the far-right rabbi told a crowd of about 400 people in a Jerusalem park on July 7 that Jews who objected to calls for revenge were accomplices in killing the bus passengers.

Mortgage Rate at 9.75%
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.75 percent, according to a national survey released on Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
That rate was down from a rate of 9.76 percent last week.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.39 percent this week, the same rate as the week before.

Farm Income Report
LEAD: Farmers are expected to receive income next year of between $52 billion and $57 billion, compared with an estimated $53 billion this year, the Agriculture Department said last week.
The report estimates cash income that farmers will receive from sales of crops and livestock.

LEAD: The Soviet Government's brand new economic plan leaves unanswered whether perestroika - economic restructuring - is moving backward or is just on hold.
At first glance, the plan looks disappointing indeed.
It preserves strangulating central control and postpones perestroika's critical ingredient, decontrol of prices.

Toyota, Nissan Exports
LEAD: Japan's two largest auto makers, the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company, said today that their exports fell more than 15 percent in November compared with last year.
Toyota said its exports fell 17 percent, to 123,834 vehicles, while its overseas production rose by 90.3 percent, to 52,108 vehicles.

LEAD: For the first time, researchers have apparently eradicated the AIDS virus from a patient's body, but experts caution that many more patients must be treated before the effectiveness of the technique can be fully determined.

Mattel Sets Deal
LEAD: Mattel Inc., the toy maker, agreed to acquire Corgi Toys Ltd., a British maker of miniature model cars.
Terms were not disclosed.
It said the transaction is expected to be completed before the end of the year.
Mattel said the acquisition fitted with its primary strategy of adding to its strong brands, which include Barbie dolls, Hot Wheels and Disney infant and preschool toys.


For 90 Students, Contest Was Lost in the Mail
LEAD: Bad luck apparently prevailed over brilliance yesterday.
At least 90 seniors at Stuyvesant High School lost their chance for thousands of dollars worth of college scholarships after their entries in a national science competition were received after the contest deadline, even though school officials insist they were sent on time.


Campbell Soup Family Disbands Voting Trust
LEAD: Nine descendants of a founder of the Campbell Soup Company, have agreed to disband a family voting trust that controls 26.5 percent of the company's shares.


F-16s Collide Over Germany
LEAD: Two American F-16 fighter-bombers collided over a southern part of West Germany today, dropping an engine and ammunition through the roof of a vegetable market.
One of the pilots was killed but no civilians were hurt in the accident, the police said.
The other pilot escaped without serious injury.

Review/Music; A Mixed Bag for Christmas From the Chamber Society
LEAD: Like a slightly perverse Santa Claus, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center took the Alice Tully Hall stage over the weekend with a lumpy bag of unexpected and delightful oddities in tow.
The holiday program ranged historically from Heinrich Biber's ''Battalia'' (1673) to Arthur Maddox's ''Little Tricker the Squirrel Meets Big Double the Bear'' (1988) and sylistically from the raucous humor of Mozart's ''Musical Joke'' (1787) to the sophisticated eccentricity of Stravinsky's Three Pieces for String Quartet (1914).

Review/Theater; Generation Gap in Fugard's 'My Children!'
LEAD: In August Wilson's ''Fences,'' Courtney B. Vance had a job to traumatize any young actor.
In the role of a rebellious teen-age son, he had to challenge James Earl Jones for supremacy in a household and, by implication, on the stage.
Mr.
Vance, though not long out of the Yale School of Drama, wasn't fazed.


F.B.I. Discounts Salvador Inquiry Role
LEAD: The Justice Department said today that the Federal Bureau of Investigation played only a minor role in the questioning of a woman who linked the Salvadoran Army to the killings of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador last month.


Upheaval in the East; Sakharov Is Buried; Burden Is Passed
LEAD: The body of Andrei D. Sakharov, the Nobel laureate who labored to his last against his Government's abuse of democratic rights, was buried this evening after a long day of farewell in which tens of thousands of sorrowing partisans were exhorted to press his struggle forward.


U.S. Will Hold Up Restarting Of Savannah River Reactors
LEAD: In a concession to environmentalists, the Energy Department has decided not to restart its Savannah River nuclear reactors until an environmental impact study is completed, a department letter says.

LEAD: The pace of index arbitrage trading accelerated in the final week of November, but remained well below the levels that existed before many Wall Street firms agreed to abandon the practice for the own accounts, figures released yesterday showed.

Stewart Klonis Is Dead at 86; Directed the Art Students League
LEAD: Stewart Klonis, executive director of the Art Students League for 34 years until his retirement in 1980, died in his sleep on Saturday.
He was 86 years old, and lived at the Palm Beach Home for Adults in the Sheepshead Bay section of Brooklyn.


Metro Datelines; Youth, 18, Is Killed In Subway Stabbing
LEAD: An 18-year-old high school student was stabbed to death yesterday in a fight with another youth on a northbound F train in Carroll Gardens following a dispute the pair had a few days ago, the transit police said.


Answering Questions About Fonts
LEAD: THE so-called Font Wars rage on in the personal computer industry, but in the spirit of the holidays let us pause in a lull in the fighting to celebrate a major victory for Apple Macintosh users.
Adobe Type Manager, a utility from Adobe Systems Inc., (415) 961-4400, is a true gift to Mac owners, even though it costs $99.


Arthur Goldman, 83, A Housing Consultant
LEAD: Arthur S. Goldman, a construction economist who served as director of marketing and research for House &amp; Home magazine from 1940 to 1963, died of the effects of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C.
He was 83 years old and had been a longtime resident of Westport, Conn.


Chess
LEAD: The story is told about the time Anatoly Karpov's analysis team showed him their new idea for an opening in which he was looking for something better than what had been played up to that point.
They dug up a speculative gambit that had what they thought was a solid positional basis, a powerful initiative and great attacking chances.


When Life Is a Medical and Not a Legal Issue; Who Will Be Safe?
LEAD: To the Editor:


6-Week Strike Over At Rolls-Royce
LEAD: Rolls-Royce P.L.C., a maker of aviation engines, cut its workweek from 39 to 37 hours to end a six-week strike by 2,000 engineering workers at its Glasgow plant.
The workers voted by a 3-to-1 ratio Saturday in favor of a management offer to reduce the basic work week to 37 hours by November 1991, Rolls-Royce and union leaders said.

LEAD: Francisco and Gloria, who played the roles of Joseph and Mary in a Christmas procession here Friday, brought a modern message to a centuries-old story of rejection.


Cold Snap Sets Records Around the Country


The Limits of Transplantation: How Far Should Surgeons Go?
LEAD: AS organ transplantation becomes increasingly successful, surgeons are facing a new series of thorny practical and ethical issues.


Shannon Airport Plan
LEAD: A $122 million aircraft maintenance center will be built at Shannon Airport in Ireland, the three companies that will jointly own and operate the project said today.
GPA Group, the Irish leasing company that owns Guiness Peat Aviation, will own 30 percent, while Lufthansa and Swissair will own 35 percent each of Shannon Aerospace Ltd., the company formed to construct, operate and own the maintenance center.

2 U.S. Officials Went to Beijing Secretly in July
LEAD: The White House said today that the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, made a secret trip to China in July, shortly after President Bush suspended high-level meetings with the Chinese Government over the June crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators.
Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence S. Eagleburger also went on the trip.

LEAD: An article on Saturday about the Metropolitan Transportation Authority's increase in subway, bus and commuter rail fares gave an incorrect figure for the Transit Authority's 1990 capital budget.
It is $1.4 billion.

LEAD: Ethnic Hungarians in Rumania, who trace their proud history back to the Middle Ages and today comprise 2 million of the nation's 23 million people, have long struggled to sustain their linguistic, religious and cultural identity against Rumanian nationalism and Soviet Communism.

LEAD: Morris Furman, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died Sunday of complications of a stroke in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

Topics of The Times; Sentencing Policy, Disabled
LEAD: When Congress created the U.S.
Sentencing Commission in 1984, the idea was to get sentencing policy for Federal crimes out of politics.
The commission deserves credit for producing a new sentencing code but its deliberations have been marked by false starts and tormented by internal bickering.
And now its work is inhibited by three vacancies on the seven-member board.


Science Watch; Threatening Mistletoe
LEAD: Dwarf mistletoe, a close relative of the leafy mistletoe of Christmas lore and a major cause of tree loss, is more pervasive in older stands of spruce trees in the Northeast than once commonly thought, forestry experts say.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Margeotes Maintains An Allure CREATIVE people are a fickle lot, always seeking the next set of hot agencies and sending out their collected oeuvre of ads, hoping for a look-see, an interview and maybe a job. These days, the resumes of creative people seem to be arriving with great frequency at Margeotes Fertitta &amp; Weiss.   The artistry of its print advertising for clients like Remy Martin liqueurs, Godiva chocolates and Harper's Bazaar magazine certainly tends to lure wandering creative souls. The agency's art directors seem to sculpture images on pages using light and shadow as tools.   But even more attractive is that Margeotes seems to be a tranquil island in a sea of agency mergers, client defections and executive resignations. This despite the loss earlier in the year of Oldsmobile's Tri-State Marketing Group - the ''Good Olds Guys'' - after a tenure of barely six months.   ''We hardly ever lose business,'' said the agency's co-founder, president and chief executive, George A. Fertitta. ''Godiva has been with us for 12 years; Remy Martin, seven years; Bankers Trust, six years; Orrefors crystal has been here six years.''   But the greatest appeal may lie simply in that ineluctable thing called culture. The agency, just down the block from the Public Theater and next door to the Cheyenne Social Club in downtown Manhattan, is a happy place, and Mr. Fertitta is a buoyant man.   He says he has never felt constrained by the way agencies do things because, when he formed the agency in 1973 with John Margeotes, who is now retired, he had worked in advertising only six months. (The name of John Weiss was added when he joined the agency several months later.) While Mr. Fertitta was building the agency to about $80 million in billings, he insisted that one of its three rules for employment be that ''people love themselves.'' Inside his agency, he added, ''there's a lot of laughter - a lot of crying.''   While one could easily dismiss Mr. Fertitta's touchy/feely commentary as New Age hokum, he is too ingenuous to disbelieve. The staff banter and informal tone of the agency reinforce what he says: A stairwell is decorated with a painting executed by a local grafitti artist; staff members have access to a small ''reading room'' where magazines are strewn on blue-and-white canvas beach chairs and starch-white wooden tables topped by umbrellas.   With his shaggy brown hair, smooth complexion and voice that erupts frequently into boyish shouts, Mr. Fertitta not only looks younger than his 43 years, but he seems barely older than the twentysomethings who populate his agency.   ''She just had a baby and came back,'' he said, pointing to one employee. He stopped by an office where two women were chating: ''And she just had a baby,'' he said, glancing at one while the the other shot him a funny smile. ''Not you,'' he shouted. ''If you're pregnant, I'll kill you! You told me you wouldn't do that for two years!'' He laughed. She laughed.   That kind of chemistry has created an effective compound. The agency says it has grown about 30 percent a year for the last several years. Judy Wald, a leading ad agency creative recruiter, lists Margeotes with Korey, Kay &amp; Partners, Goldsmith/ Jeffrey, Angotti, Thomas, Hedge and Berenter Greenhouse &amp; Webster as the hot creative shops currently.   Alice Magdol-Conrad, another advertising executive recruiter, said Margeotes has ''proven they can compete in the mainstream with major agencies.'' Its success, she said, stems from its ability to attract business from major companies, including a confidential assignment from the General Foods Corporation.   ''That differentiates it from other small shops that may get pieces of business from small companies,'' Ms. Magdol-Conrad said. Because of its success in luring widely known clients, she said, and because, unlike many creative boutiques, it has demonstrated prowess in television as well as print advertising, ''it is a shop that can attract people who are not normally attractable to small agencies.''   Indeed, the media director of Margeotes, Susan Nanfeldt, came from Ogilvy &amp; Mather; the director of account services, Don Maurer, was at BBDO, and the co-creative director, Jeff Weiss, worked six years at J. Walter Thompson.   Mr. Fertitta has a term for what drew them: ''Naive freshness,'' he called it. ''It works in our favor.''


Corporate Boards Are Shrinking
LEAD: Corporate boards of directors are becoming smaller, and at the same time are adding increasing numbers of outsiders, according to a study by SpencerStuart Executive Search Consultants.


Assembly, Facing a Veto by Kean, Increases Pensions for Lawmakers
LEAD: The New Jersey Assembly approved bills today that would raise the salaries of the governor, members of the cabinet and judges in 1991 and improve the pensions of legislators in 1992.


Settlements By Imperial
LEAD: The Imperial Corporation of America, a savings and loan company based in San Diego, said today that it would pay $13 million and issue stock warrants to settle lawsuits filed earlier this year by disgruntled shareholders.

LEAD: The Federal Government was warned before 1950 that thousands of workers at nuclear weapons plants were being exposed to dangerous levels of radiation, but decided against telling them of the risks, according to a Congressional staff report made public yesterday.

LEAD: A stubborn four-alarm fire burned for six hours yesterday in the Bronx in a block-long strip of stores that was heavily damaged by a blaze set by arsonists a week ago, fire officials said.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi, Again, For British Air
LEAD: Six years after Saatchi &amp; Saatchi introduced its award-winning ''Manhattan Landing'' commercial for British Airways, in which the island of Manhattan appeared to land at Heathrow Airport, the London agency has once again produced a major image-building ad for the airline.


TWO MORE BOMBS STIR FEARS OF LINK TO JUDGE'S SLAYING
LEAD: Two days after a Federal appeals judge was slain with a letter bomb in Birmingham, a similar device was found in a Federal court building here today and a lawyer in Savannah, Ga., was killed when a bomb exploded in his office.


Rig Count Up in Week
LEAD: The number of working United States oil rigs climbed by 25 last week, to total a 1,079, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
A year ago the count was 930.
The rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

LEAD: Women have always got a kick out of purloining some piece of men's clothing.
Last week, it was their hats.
When icy winds and weather descended on the city, women who ordinarily walk around bare-headed went shopping for warm coverings.
A good many ended their search in the men's department.

The Supreme Court, on Line
LEAD: Dramatic changes are afoot in the way the public learns the official doings of the U.S.
Supreme Court.
The justices speak through written words that set forth their legal reasoning.
Since the beginning they have communicated with the public through the written word on paper, even as society has in recent years mastered instant, electronic dissemination.

Business and Health; Studying Hospital Costs and Quality
LEAD: AS industrial executives have learned, high quality does not necessarily mean higher costs.
Indeed, the opposite is often true.
An improved production line and a motivated work force can usually cut costs by reducing the parts that have to be scrapped or repaired before shipment.
The same seems to be true of hospitals.

Poland's Inflation Slows
LEAD: Retail prices soared 22.4 percent last month in Poland as industrial output fell.
For the 12 months that ended in November, retail prices were up 557 percent.
But a sharp slowdown in the monthly rise in prices - from 54.8 percent in October - offered some hope that the Solidarity-led Government's free-market policies were beginning to have a positive effect.

LEAD: The Rochester Telephone Corporation yesterday priced $100 million in 30-year debentures, through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.


Baseball; Brewers Sign Yount To $9.6 Million Pact
LEAD: Robin Yount's long-standing loyalty to the Milwaukee Brewers was a major reason the free-agent outfielder agreed to return to the team yesterday, but so was the contract: a three-year deal estimated to be worth $9.6 million that will make Yount the sixth player to average at least $3 million a year in salary starting next season.


GUNFIRE IS HEARD IN CAPITAL
LEAD: The United States launched a military operation in Panama early this morning designed to topple the Government of Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega.


Deficit-Reduction Bill Signed To Cancel Cuts in Spending
LEAD: President Bush today signed a $14.7 billion deficit-reduction bill for the current fiscal year, ending automatic cuts that were imposed across the board in October.

January Crude Oil Contract Expires in Volatile Trading
LEAD: The contract for January delivery of crude oil expired yesterday in volatile trading.
Prices set contract highs before closing with a sharp decline.


Plan for Monthly Refund to Offset Medicare Overcharge Gains Favor
LEAD: The Social Security Commissioner said today that she supported a plan to send monthly refund checks to nearly 27 million elderly people early next year to offset Medicare premium overcharges.


Bobby Capo, Pop Composer, 68
LEAD: Bobby Capo, a pop composer, died Monday at Beekman Downtown Medical Center after suffering a heart attack in his office at the State Department of Probation in Manhattan, where he worked.
He was 68 years old.

LEAD: Police Commissioner Richard J. Condon gave a gentle valedictory, Mayor Edward I. Koch made a sentimental farewell and Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins brought a hopeful hello to 1,224 New York City police recruits who graduated from the Police Academy yesterday.

LEAD: An 18-year-old youth fleeing three other youths on a fast-moving subway train was pushed to his death in the Fordham section of the Bronx last night, the police said.

Dresdner Bank Plan
LEAD: Dresdner Bank, West Germany's second-largest commercial bank, announced plans today to open an office in Dresden, the East German city where the bank was founded more than a century ago.
The bank was founded in Dresden in 1872.
Although its management was shifted to Berlin in 1884, Dresden remained the bank's legal headquarters until 1950.


9-Month Loss At Koor Unit
LEAD: Tadiran, the electronics subsidiary of Israel's ailing Koor Industries, reported today that it had a record loss of $96 million for the first nine months of 1989.
The unit, which said it would lay off up to 1,000 workers, lost $32 million in the period a year earlier.


Private Universities Hitting Tax Law Limit
LEAD: One after another, private universities are reaching the Federal limit on tax-exempt bonds they may issue and are revising or delaying the construction projects for which the bonds were primarily used.

Consumer Prices Up By 0.4%
LEAD: The Consumer Price Index rose by four-tenths of 1 percent in November, as food and shelter grew more costly while energy prices edged down, the Labor Department said today.


New Materials Altering the Aircraft Industry
LEAD: The race to develop stronger, lighter materials that will make aircraft sturdier and more fuel-efficient is intensifying.
After a sluggish start a few years ago, a lighter version of aluminum, called aluminum lithium, appears to be gaining a foothold in the aerospace industry.
But the use of advanced-polymer composite materials - plastic resins reinforced by materials like glass or steel - is also growing quickly.

CANADA TO LOWER PLANNED NEW TAX
LEAD: Bowing to months of public pressure, the Canadian Government said today that it would lower the rate on its proposed value-added tax to 7 percent, from the original 9 percent.

LEAD: Prime Minister Mudar Badran told the new Parliament today that his Government would lift martial law, which for 22 years has banned large public meetings and allowed the authorities to restrict freedom of speech.

Icahn's USX Stake
LEAD: Federal antitrust regulators have cleared the investor Carl C. Icahn to acquire a bigger stake in the USX Corporation, the Pittsburgh-based steel company.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission last month, Mr.
Icahn disclosed that he owned nearly 34 million, or 13.26 percent, of USX's outstanding common shares and that he might acquire as much as 25 percent.

Circle K Stores
LEAD: The Circle K Corporation signed a nonbinding letter of intent for the sale of 350 stores to PC Ventures.
It said the stores would continue to be operated under the Circle K name.
The transaction, to be completed before April, involves stores in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana, Utah and Colorado.

Ruling Allows Cuts in Crews Of Fire Trucks
LEAD: New York City can reduce the number of firefighters assigned to many of its pumper trucks from five to four, which is expected to save at least $25 million a year, under a ruling issued yesterday by the city's Board of Collective Bargaining.


Manville Trust Payment Plan
LEAD: The trust set up to handle the injury claims of asbestos victims against the Manville Corporation said Monday that the Denver-based construction and building material company had agreed to speed payments to the trust.


Stella Gibbons Is Dead; British Author Was 87
LEAD: Stella Gibbons, who won fame with her first novel, ''Cold Comfort Farm,'' died Tuesday at her home in north London.
She was 87 years old.
Miss Gibbons, who was a journalist before she turned to books, wrote more than 30 novels and volumes of short stories and poems, but none rivaled her most celebrated story, which parodied an earthy, regional school of writing popular at the turn of the century.

About Education
LEAD: For education, the decade about to end has been one of calling attention to the need for fundamental changes.
Optimists say the 1980's have the country tooled up for action in the 90's.
Pessimists scoff at a ''Waiting for Godot'' approach to changes in education.
They contend that, even though some schools have improved, reforms have largely bypassed the troubled urban schools.

LEAD: George Allen, who quickly transformed the Los Angeles Rams and the Washington Redskins from losers to winners after he became head coach, agreed yesterday to tackle perhaps his biggest coaching challenge.

Bridge
LEAD: There is little doubt that the world's greatest concentration of bridge players is in Norway, where one-fifth of the adults know the game.
In a population of 4 million, 16,000 belong to the national organization.


H.U.D. Is Called Weak In Its Policing of Ethics
LEAD: The Department of Housing and Urban Development has a weak system of policing for possible ethics violations by its officials and consultants, a Congressional study issued today says.


Texas Instruments
LEAD: Texas Instruments Inc. signed a letter of intent with the Toppan Printing Company of Japan to establish a jointly owned United States company that would acquire and manage Texas Instruments' photomask operation in Dallas.
The company said it would receive a cash payment of $19 million and would have a minority interest in the new company.

LEAD: Lawyers for Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company told a group of bondholders yesterday that it was prepared to seek Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation, the company it formed to acquire the Jim Walter Corporation last year for $2.4 billion.
A Hillsborough representative confirmed the report.

Upheaval in the East; GORBACHEV WINS VOTE ON ECONOMY
LEAD: The Gorbachev leadership won legislative approval of its revamped economic program today, easily rebuffing a no-confidence vote from a thin weak line of opponents who warned that it amounted to a retreat from the promised reforms of perestroika.

LEAD: There are no more members of the Communist Party working in the turbine balancing unit of the Bergmann-Borsig electrical machinery company on the northern edge of this city.

LEAD: Victory didn't come easily for Fernando Collor de Mello, the winner of Brazil's first popular presidential election in 29 years.

But by Sunday, when the final round of voting began, the contest against Luis Inacio da


Sabres Unwrap Their Many Gifts
LEAD: The breaks this past summer would usually come in the evening.
Rick Dudley, his ambition still keen but his vision slightly blurred from hours spent watching old tapes of the Buffalo Sabres, would drop down from the converted attic that passes for an office at the team's practice facility and make his way over to the rink.


Real Estate; Old Buildings Altered for New Times
LEAD: THE strategy has been called ''adaptive re-use'' of old buildings, and one Manhattan real estate executive says it can be very successful as well as profitable.


Make Room for West Side Students
LEAD: Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts may be one of America's most successful urban renewal projects.
Over the years it has weathered scary economics and disputes among temperamental artists.
Yet its esthetic whole continues to exceed the sum of its constituent institutions.

LEAD: Steuben, whose advertising account has been up for grabs since Doyle Graf Raj dissolved earlier this year, has chosen TBWA Advertising after a six-month search.


LITHUANIAN PARTY NEARS THE BRINK
LEAD: In the face of warnings and threats from the Kremlin, the Communist Party leader of Lithuania called today for independent Lithuanian statehood.
He said the republic's party organization wanted to create conditions ''in the immediate future'' that would allow the republic to secede from the Soviet


Homeless Hunt for Warmth in Belly of a Cold City
LEAD: Just after midnight, exhausted after another day of tramping the streets, Kevin Williams was killing time aboard a Brooklyn-bound No. 4 subway train.
There were a handful of other passengers, including three young women talking together in the seats opposite him.
Mr.
Williams, who is 28 years old and homeless, fought back the urge to stretch out.

Economic Scene; Foreign Investors: Fifth Column?
LEAD: THE Japanese are coming!
The Japanese are coming! warn assorted Congressional Democrats, union leaders and business interests who watch in horror as foreigners - specifically the Japanese - swallow up everything from computer chip makers to the best beaches in Hawaii.


AMR Deal On Eastern Routes Set
LEAD: American Airlines confirmed last night that it had reached an agreement to acquire the Central and South American routes and other assets of Eastern Airlines in a deal valued at $471 million.


EATING WELL
LEAD: MOST Americans had likely never heard of the diet supplement L-tryptophan until last month.
Since Nov. 11, when the Food and Drug Administration issued an alert to the public to stop taking L-tryptophan supplements, it has been in the news almost every week.
On Dec. 5, the agency recalled the product from stores and detained all imports of the supplement.


Construction of Housing Fell 4.7% in November
LEAD: Housing starts dropped by 4.7 percent in November, pulled down by a big drop in multifamily construction.


In Manila Coup Effort, Economy Is Big Victim
LEAD: In the weeks before the coup attempt against the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino earlier this month, the beleaguered Philippine economy had never looked so promising.


Citicorp Acquires Credit Card Unit
LEAD: Citicorp reached an agreement to acquire the merchant credit card processing business of FCC National Bank, a subsidiary of the First Chicago Corporation.
Subject to regulatory approval, Citicorp will acquire all the existing customers of the First Chicago business that provides merchants with credit card processing services.


Review/Dance; Proverbs And Mimes Are Merrily Embodied
LEAD: Choreographers from Albany, Atlanta and London were represented Sunday afternoon at the 92d Street Y in a ''Sundays at 3'' program sponsored by the Y's Dance Center.


Dollar Is Generally Higher But Is Down Against Yen
LEAD: The dollar finished slightly higher against most primary currencies yesterday but slipped against the Japanese yen in quiet trading.


Market Place; Big Slide in Housing Prices Is Latest Worry on Wall St.
LEAD: Once again, the ''wealth effect'' is bothering Wall Street.
This time, the worriers may be on to something.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Bulls 93, Lakers 83: Michael Jordan scored 37 points last night to lead Chicago to its fifth victory in a row.
The defeat snapped a Laker winning streak at four games, while the Bulls won their ninth in a row at Chicago Stadium.
Chicago led, 70-60, after three quarters, but the Lakers went on an 8-2 run in the first 2:06 of the final quarter, cutting the deficit to 72-68 when Orlando Woolridge dunked.

Review/Television; Beast Tries to Survive Loss Of the Other Half of the Title
LEAD: Catherine is dead.
The inconsolable Vincent can't stop weeping.
And the new villains, a truly nasty lot, have something to do with what's referred to vaguely as South American drug interests.
The question: Can television's ''Beauty and the Beast'' survive the departure of one of its stars, Linda Hamilton, who used her real-life pregnancy as an excuse for dropping Catherine from her repertory?


Upheaval in the East; Czechs Introduce Program for Free Elections and Free Markets
LEAD: Czechoslovakia's Communist-dominated Parliament voted overwhelmingly today to support an ambitious Government program that sets the country on the course toward Western-style parliamentary democracy and a free-market economic system.

LEAD: Whether global warming will raise the level of the world's oceans is still being debated, but engineers who build natural-gas production platforms at Shell Oil do not want to take chances.

LEAD: Testimony ended today in the trial of the bus driver charged with killing 27 people, and lawyers said the nation's worst drunken-driving case might go to the jury Wednesday.

11 Are Indicted in Atlantic City Influence Peddling
LEAD: A state grand jury today indicted 11 of 14 people who were arrested in Atlantic City in July on a variety of charges including influence peddling, bribery, racketeering, conspiracy and official misconduct.


Upheaval in the East; Leaders of the 2 Germanys Meet; Symbolic Reconciliation Cheered
LEAD: The leaders of the two Germanys met today for the first time since the East fell into the throes of protest and change, and in a symbolic reconciliation agreed to reopen the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin and introduce free movement across their border for all Germans by Christmas.

Low State Ranking Is Called Unfair by Outraged School
LEAD: The hallways are quiet and free of litter and graffiti.
Math and reading test scores have been steadily improving in every grade except the third.
In orderly but overcrowded classrooms, students are attentive.


Campbell Shares Up on Speculation
LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company's stock soared on renewed takeover speculation a day after the family-run company disclosed that a trust holding 26.5 percent of its voting shares had been dissolved.
Campbell rose $4.75 a share today, to $54.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 9.6 percent gain was the fourth best of the day.


Trump Shuttle, Pilots Reach Pact
LEAD: The Trump Shuttle, the airline service that Donald J. Trump bought six months ago, has reached a collective bargaining agreement with its pilots' union.
The four-year agreement, which must be ratified by the union members, provides for improvements in wages, benefits and work rules, the airline said.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sears Agrees to Pay $100,000 Civil Penalty
LEAD: Sears, Roebuck &amp; Company has agreed to pay a $100,000 civil penalty to resolve Federal Trade Commission charges that it failed to make required disclosures in its home insulation advertising.


Savannah Victim Is Called Quiet but Effective
LEAD: Robert Edward Robinson, the lawyer who was killed Monday by a mail bomb, was a Savannah success story, according to friends and associates here.


It's Official: Penn State Will Become Big Ten's No. 11
LEAD: Officials of the Big Ten Conference and Penn State University confirmed today that the Nittany Lions would become the conference's 11th member.


Veal That Is Rich But Not Expensive
LEAD: VEAL is one of the most delicate of meats and is the best to prepare in sauces.
The prime cuts like the rack and fillet are expensive, but in the shoulder, flank, breast and shank, you can find delicious veal for very little money.


Florida Orders Suspension Of Hialeah Park's License
LEAD: The Florida Department of Business Regulation said it would suspend Hialeah Park's parimutuel license because the race track had altered its racing schedule without approval.


Herbert Blaize, 71, Grenada Chief Who Won Vote After the Invasion
LEAD: Prime Minister Herbert A. Blaize of Grenada, a longtime political figure in that Caribbean island nation who regained power after United States armed forces invaded to oust a leftist Government there in 1983, died yesterday morning at his official residence.
He was 71 years old.

Lawsuit Accuses Housing Aides of Racketeering
LEAD: Two New Haven developers charged in a lawsuit yesterday that a group of local and Federal officials monopolized the subsidized housing market in Hartford by operating a racketeering enterprise that used extortion and harassment to freeze out small, independent and minority developers.


Apple Is Said To Settle Suit
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. agreed to settle a patent-infringement lawsuit filed against it by Quickview Systems Inc., people close to the industry said.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD: ALICE ARTZT is seated in the front of an increasingly crowded bus.
As the passengers climb aboard, they appear to be somewhat puzzled. ''Is this the 104?'' one woman asks. ''Yes,'' says the driver.
At the next stop a man enters asking ''Is this the 104?'' ''Yes,'' the driver says again.


Joseph Nathanson, Obstetrician, 94
LEAD: Dr.
Joseph Nathanson, a retired obstetrician and gynecologist, died of renal failure Monday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 94 years old.


Mosbacher Backs Soviet Fiber-Optic Cable
LEAD: Demonstrating a new American flexibility regarding high-technology exports to the Eastern bloc, Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher said today that a deal in which an American company would help lay a fiber-optic communications cable across the Soviet Union could go ahead if certain conditions were met.


WINE TALK
LEAD: WHERE is no better place to find last-minute gifts than a good wine shop.
There is always a chance of a final-hour run on the 1961 Petrus, but if you can settle for anything less there will be plenty to choose from.


Du Pont Case Conviction
LEAD: Three Argentine nationals were convicted today of trying to extort $10 million from E. I. du Pont de Nemours &amp; Company in exchange for documents the chemicals company contended were technological road maps to the manufacture of Lycra, a form of the popular stretch fiber spandex.


Oates and Ford to Read In Series at the 92d St. Y
LEAD: The authors Joyce Carol Oates and Richard Ford are to read from their works at 8 P.M. on Jan. 8 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.
The reading is part of a series sponsored by the Poetry Center at the Y. Admission is $10.


Oakley Isn't Missed As Ewing Dominates
LEAD: Surprisingly, Karl Malone did not score with ease against the Knicks last night, as was expected with Charles Oakley not on hand to guard him.
Malone had 29 points, just a bit over his 28.1 season average.


A Cooking Class To Call Your Own
LEAD: AT their first cooking lesson, Judy and Harold McMillan experimented with various oils, vinegars and spices, and made brown rice, vegetable salad and a quiche Lorraine.
At their second class, they made chicken breasts stuffed with pate, deboned a duck and stuffed a pheasant.
Their next lesson calls for preparing sesame noodles and stir-fried vegetables.


Upheaval in the East; Shevardnadze Calls for Links in East-West Pacts, but Warns on Germany
LEAD: As the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, became the first Warsaw Pact minister ever to visit NATO headquarters, he called today for cooperation between the two military alliances, but he also warned that rapid reunification of Germany could destabilize Europe.


The Challenge of Teaching History As the Cold War Recedes in Europe
LEAD: Many times this fall, Baiba Schletty was ready to throw away the lesson plan and make her high school history students look far beyond the orchards and fields that are the economic foundation of rural Berryville, Va.


Disclosing Financial Data, Reader's Digest to Go Public
LEAD: In moves that will give its shareholders greater liquidity and help it avoid potential tax problems, the Reader's Digest Association is going public.


Rogue Program Failed Its Own Test
LEAD: The unusual design of a destructive computer program mailed to more than 10,000 computer users around the world may have undermined an elaborate extortion attempt, computer security experts said yesterday.


Indonesia Palm Oil Plan
LEAD: Indonesia, a leading palm oil producer, plans to expand its export of the commodity as its output surges, the Trade Minister, Arifin Siregar, said Monday.
He said Indonesia's production could reach four million tons of crude palm oil before the target date of 1994.
Exports now account for about half of production but will soon take a larger share, he said.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it was introducing a personal computer based on the Intel Corporation's powerful i486 microprocessor.

Loans, Credits for India
LEAD: The World Bank said Monday that it and its sister agency, the International Development Association, had approved loans and credits of $165 million for India to modernize its irrigation system in the state of Punjab.
Punjab is one of the country's most productive agricultural areas.
The $15 million loan is for 20 years, including five years of grace, with a variable interest rate that is currently at 7.74 percent.

Western Europe Seeks Arab Economic Ties
LEAD: A meeting of 22 Arab and 12 European Community foreign ministers is scheduled in Paris this week to revive a stumbling political and economic discussion between Western Europe and the Arab world.


Rexene to Sell Plant For $88 Million
LEAD: The Rexene Corporation, a plastics manufacturer, agreed to sell its Bayport, Tex., polyethylene and polypropylene plant for $88 million to the Lyondell Petrochemical Company, the concern created by the spinoff of ARCO's Texas-based petrochemical operations.


Gen. Albert C. Wedemeyer, 92, Noted Military Planner for U.S.
LEAD: Gen.
Albert C. Wedemeyer, a noted American military planner and commander in World War II, died Sunday at Fort Belvoir, Va.
He was 92 years old and had been in declining health.


Lessons
LEAD: Frank Newman, president of the Education Commission of the States, has an irreverent question that he asks whenever some college president starts extolling the glories of American higher education: ''Would you ever hire an instructor who has never taught, never had a course in teaching and can't speak English?


3 Die and Dozens Are Hurt As Train Hits Truck in Fog
LEAD: In the dense, cold fog that hangs low over the San Joaquin Valley at this time of year, a truck collided with a passenger train here this morning, leaving three people dead and dozens injured.


PRESIDENT WAIVES SOME CHINA CURBS
LEAD: President Bush waived a Congressional ban today on loans to companies that do business with China and also approved the export of three communications satellites that will be launched by the Chinese.


Coast Guard Faulted in '88 Sinking of Boat
LEAD: The Coast Guard's failure to require life rafts and signal beacons on small commercial passenger boats contributed to the loss of life in the sinking of a vessel off the Oregon coast, the National Transportation Safety Board concluded today.


BOOK NOTES
LEAD:  The Reclusive Pynchon  Two days ago Little, Brown sent copies of Thomas Pynchon's forthcoming novel, ''Vineland,'' to some 200 critics and reviewers, few of whom have been neutral about the author's past work.


Florio Picks 2 Commissioners
LEAD: Governor-elect James J. Florio today named the people he wants to head the Labor and Commerce Departments when his administration begins on Jan. 16.


Doctor Gets 3 Years' Probation for Infanticide
LEAD: An obstetrician convicted of infanticide in the death of a fetus aborted in the eighth month of pregnancy was placed on three years' probation today and ordered to perform 300 hours of community service.

LEAD: Stock prices declined broadly yesterday, as investors' worrries about the economy and the real estate market contributed to violent swings in the market.

LEAD: A 3 1/2-ton bronze bull that arrived uninvited on Friday outside the New York Stock Exchange will be displayed two blocks south, on Bowling Green, the Parks and Recreation Department announced yesterday.

LEAD: A lawsuit by National Foods Inc., one of the nation's largest makers of kosher meat, against New York State's kosher law enforcement officer was dismissed yesterday.

Jets Need O'Brien's Successor
LEAD: During his coronation yesterday at the Jets' complex as their new vice president and general manager, Dick Steinberg twisted a green-and-white Jets key ring with two keys on it. ''They gave me a key to the front door and a key to the front gate,'' he said with a smile. ''I guess it's official.''


Review/Dance; A Brendel And Baker Program
LEAD: The program of solos and duets presented by Peggy Baker and Janis Brendel on Saturday night at St.
Mark's Church was a memorable one, not just for the skills of the two dancers but for the intelligence and taste with which the dances were chosen.


6 Arrested at Times Building
LEAD: Six people were arrested last night after blocking the entrance to the New York Times building in Manhattan as a part of a protest against the newspaper's reporting from El Salvador.
About 80 people marched and chanted behind police barricades across the street from the paper's offices at 229 West 43d Street.


Man in the News; The Choice Of Brazilians; Fernando Collor
LEAD: When Fernando Collor de Mello sought to sell Brazilians on his free-market vision of less government and more growth, he conjured up the image of the maharajah.


Comptroller Asserts Banks Face Growing Realty Woes
LEAD: Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency, said yesterday that bank problems with bad real estate loans were growing but were not yet serious enough to cause losses of the magnitude that led to the collapse of most large Texas banks a few years ago.

LEAD: The United States has won a 20-year fight with the European Community over European soybean subsidies, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

Stephen Hartdegen; Priest, 82, Compiled New American Bible
LEAD: The Rev.
Stephen J. Hartdegen, an internationally renowned biblical scholar, died of cancer on Tuesday at the Holy Name Friary in Ringwood, N.J.
He was 82 years old.
Father Hartdegen, a member of the Franciscan Order, served from 1944 to 1970 as editor in chief of a team of 51 scholars who issued the New American Bible, a translation from ancient Hebrew, Greek and Aramaic scriptures.

Meese's accounts about the matter.

LEAD: A 23-year-old record was decisively erased 11 days ago in Madison, Wis., when Sabine Zenkel won three sectional events.

LEAD: Gov.

Cuomo has ignored the rest of the city's, giving life to a frivolous law that statesmanship would have stopped.

Review/Theater; 'Art of Success' Makes Hogarth The Warhol of the 18th Century
LEAD: ''The Art of Success,'' the play by Nick Dear at the Manhattan Theater Club, had its premiere at the Royal Shakespeare Company in England in 1986, but an American theatergoer might well assume it had been written in New York this fall.
In our year of Mapplethorpe and Serrano, here is a scabrous comedy about the creation, purpose, promotion, merchandising, censorship and government patronage of art - all set forth in a theatrical palette that encompasses rough sex, scatological language, ribald political satire, urine and excrement.

Manuel Antonio Noriega.

PARENTS &amp; CHILD
LEAD: IT has been almost two years since the 30-year-old brother of Kay O. died of a bone-marrow disease.
Kay, a writer from Minneapolis who asked that her full name not be used, said she found herself thinking about him more often during the holiday season.
She is approaching 30 herself and is still trying to sort through her feelings about what happened, not only to her brother but also to herself and to members of her family.

Sale by Honeywell
LEAD: Honeywell Inc. sold a 7.5 percent stake in its Toyko-based venture, Yamatake-Honeywell, for $126 million to a group of Japanese financial and industrial institutions.
On Oct. 24, Honeywell sold a 16 percent stake in the venture and now holds 26.5 percent.
It said proceeds from the sales would be used to repurchase up to 10 million of its shares, which rose $2.25 today, to $82.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

Fed Said to Signal Lower Rates
LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board yesterday came through with a long-awaited signal that analysts said clearly showed the central bank wanted short-term interest rates to decline, but prices of Treasury notes and bonds were little changed on the development.


Ben Barzman Dead; Scriptwriter Was 79
LEAD: Ben Barzman, a scriptwriter who was blacklisted during the McCarthy era and whose movie credits include ''Back to Bataan'' (1945), ''El Cid'' (1961) and ''The Blue Max'' (1966), died on Friday after a stroke.
He was 79 years old.


Taiwan Monetary Policy
LEAD: Taiwan will temporarily relax its tight monetary policy to help local companies pay out billions of local dollars in salaries and bonuses before the Lunar New Year on Jan. 27.
Bankers said the measure would also keep interest rates and the United States-Taiwan dollar exchange rate stable.
They said the easing will start in mid-January, lasting about a month.

LEAD: Czechoslovakia's Communists ousted the party leader today and elected as party chairman a former Prime Minister who has emerged as one of the more conciliatory leaders in the recent weeks of dramatic upheaval.

LEAD: The Communist Party of Lithuania voted overwhelmingly today to break away from the leadership in Moscow, becoming the first local party organization in the history of the Soviet Union to defy the Kremlin by declaring independence.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section on Dec. 6 about holiday celebrations credited the copyright owners of the song ''Home for the Holidays'' incorrectly.
They are Robert Allen, who wrote the music, and Al Stillman, who wrote the lyrics.
The extracts with the article were printed by permission.


Review/Theater; Patients Sacrificed in the Name of Research
LEAD: When The Associated Press broke the news, it seemed almost incomprehensible.
In order to chart the degenerative progress of venereal disease in the human body, the United States Public Health Service withheld treatment from hundreds of poor, black men in rural Alabama.
The study lasted from 1932 until it was exposed in 1972.

CURRENTS
LEAD: IN 1939, Argentina introduced the butterfly chair: two triangular iron frames covered with a leather sling.
It was designed in 1938 by three architects - Jorge Ferrari Hardoy and Juan Kurchan, who were Argentinian, and Antonio Bonet, a Spaniard who practiced in Buenos Aires - and imitated worldwide in different versions: some collapsible, others with brightly colored canvas slipcovers.

18 Dead in Brazilian Flooding
LEAD: At least 18 people have died in floods which swept northeast and central Brazil, national newspapers reported today.
They said 17 people had died in the eastern state of Bahia, where about 12,000 people are now homeless.
Heavy rains have been falling in the town of Goias, an 18th-century gold rush town in central Brazil.

Fighting in Panama; Panama's Troubled Past
LEAD:  JANUARY 1964.
Riots break out in the Canal zone, which the United States has controlled since 1903.
Panama temporarily breaks dipolmatic relations with Washington to express discontent over American control of the canal.
Relations resume in April, when the two coutries agree to renegotiate their treaty relationship.

LEAD: William M. Benkert, a retired Coast Guard rear admiral who was a specialist in marine environment and maritime safety, died of lung and liver cancer on Dec. 14 in McLean, Va., where he lived.
He was 66 years old.

News Summary
LEAD:  International A3-20  U.S. forces in central Panama City hunted for General Noriega and tried to restore order as looters and bands of armed civilians defied a nighttime curfew.
Few areas in the city appeared totally secured.
Page A1  News analysis: The Panama affair still has at least three major problems unresolved: capturing General Noriega, getting the new Government up and running, and rescuing the hostages.


Armitage Watkins, 83; Was a Literary Agent
LEAD: Armitage Watkins, a literary agent who represented such authors as Pamela L. Travers, Roald Dahl, Peter DeVries, Glendon Swarthout, Alan Moorehead and Bill Mauldin, died of cancer on Sunday at a nursing home in Kings Park, L.I.
He was 83 years old and lived in Manhattan and Cold Spring Harbor, L.I.


Review/Art; Otherworldly Sculptures Of the Unsung Turku Trajan
LEAD: To see the 11 sculptures by Turku Trajan that are now at the Zabriskie Gallery is to be entranced and perplexed, for Trajan's legacy remains one of the genuine curiosities of 20th-century American art.


Will Readers Buy This 'Hot Book'?
LEAD: Dubbed a ''hot book'' not long after it was started nearly two years ago, 7 Days, the weekly magazine, now faces the difficult task of proving that Manhattan's trend-setters actually read it and are willing to pay for it.


Reviews/Art; Sculpture Shows at 2 Branches of the Whitney
LEAD: ''Out of Wood: Recent Sculpture,'' at the Whitney Museum of American Art at Philip Morris, underlines the continuing vitality of American wood sculpture.
Raoul Hague, Jene Highstein, Mel Kendrick, Michael Lekakis and Ursula von Rydingsvard have different roots and different approaches, and they represent several generations.


Police Dept. Is Praised By Next Commissioner
LEAD: Stepping nimbly through a mine field of questions, New York City's new Police Commissioner paid homage yesterday to what he called a ''premier'' department and in his first official visit to the city repeatedly declined to be drawn into his plans for change.


SOVIET JEWS SEEING FRUIT OF EFFORTS
LEAD: When Jewish families in half a dozen Soviet cities gather during the next few days to view a videotape of a popular animated film about Hanukkah, officials of the Memorial Foundation for Jewish Culture will have won a 20-year gamble.

LEAD: Ken O'Brien has decided to undergo exploratory surgery on his right shoulder on Friday, and will miss the Jets' final game Saturday against the Buffalo Bills.

Disputes at 2 Realty Trusts
LEAD: A Federal judge has sealed the votes collected yesterday at the shareholder meetings of two real estate investment trusts in Dallas pending a hearing on the adequacy of the disclosures made to investors by the two former executives of the troubled Southmark Corporation who run the trusts.


F.C.C. Alters Phone Policy
LEAD: Many local telephone companies will no longer be able to earn a guaranteed profit beginning Jan. 1, 1991, the Federal Communications Commission said today.


Joseph Bachelder, 78, Opinion Researcher
LEAD: Dr.
Joseph D. Bachelder, a public-opinion researcher, died yesterday at his home in Jamesburg, N.J.
He was 78 years old.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It's bloody cold out here.
I can't stand it.
I'd rather not be out in this weather, but we all get that Christmas spirit, so here we all are, freezing in Rockefeller Center.''  - Simon Jones, a visitor from London.  [ B4:1. ]


Fighting in Panama; Panama Canal Opens After One-Day Closing
LEAD: The Panama Canal reopened today after a one-day closing caused by the United States military strike, the only time anything other than natural disaster has halted operation of the 75-year-old waterway.


U.S. Alters Plan for Offsetting Excess Charges for Medicare
LEAD: The Government announced today that it would send two checks early next year to each of 27 million older Americans to offset continued deductions from their Social Security checks for a $5.30 monthly premium for extended Medicare coverage that was repealed last month.


Ouster Set At Centrust
LEAD: Florida state officials took action Wednesday to oust the head of Florida's largest savings and loan association, contending he used $45 million in depositors' money to bankroll an art collection and extravagant standard of living.


Cold Comfort, Indeed
LEAD: ''The life of the journalist is poor, nasty, brutish and short.
So is his style.
You, who are so adept at the lovely polishing of every grave and lucent phrase, will realise the magnitude of the task which confronted me when I found, after spending ten years as a journalist, learning to say exactly what I meant in short sentences, that I must learn, if I was to achieve literature and favourable reviews, to write as though I were not quite sure about what I meant but was jolly well going to say something all the same in sentences as long as possible.


Skippers and Clubs Back Effort To Strip San Diego Club of Cup
LEAD: Eight former America's Cup skippers and several yacht clubs have asked the New York State Court of Appeals to disqualify the San Diego Yacht Club from the 1988 America's Cup series, which it won, and return the cup trophy to New Zealand.


THE LAW: At the Bar; Jews on the Supreme Court: Were they different and why are there none now?
LEAD: No Jew has sat on the United States Supreme Court since 1969, when Abe Fortas resigned.
It is an odd phenomenon, given the prominence of Jewish lawyers in the United States.
In that period, Jews have led the American Bar Association, dozens of major law firms and virtually every major American law school.


William Hunt's Bankruptcy Plan Cleared
LEAD: A Federal bankruptcy court judge here today formally approved a reorganization plan for William Herbert Hunt, whose fortune collapsed after a failed attempt to corner the silver market 10 years ago.


Company News; Nynex to Take $45 Million Charge
LEAD: The Nynex Corporation said it expected to take an estimated $45 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings because of changes in its management pension plan that take effect on Jan. 1.


Review/Theater; 'Kingfish,' An Exercise In Absurdism
LEAD: The title character in Marlane Meyer's ''Kingfish'' is a Doberman pinscher portrayed by a black box with a green grin and a rope tail.
The dog's bark is supplied by an actor sitting at a microphone.
In this play, Ms.
Meyer, a playwright with a previously demonstrated talent for gritty realism, has taken a sidestep into self-conscious absurdism.

LEAD: A Federal district judge declared a mistrial today after jurors failed to reach a verdict in the case of a teen-ager accused of selling the crack that President Bush used as a prop in a nationally televised address in September.

Poindexter Trial Is Delayed Over Reagan Papers
LEAD: The judge in the Iran-contra case of John M. Poindexter today delayed the start of the trial and ordered former President Ronald Reagan to provide the court with excerpts of White House diaries and notebooks to see if they contain evidence relevant to Mr.
Poindexter's defense.


Dinkins Faces Tall Budget Deficit and Short Deadline
LEAD: A little more than four weeks after he takes office, Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins is required to present a plan to resolve what seems likely to be the biggest problem of his first year and one that might help shape an entire term: a New York City budget deficit that has been estimated at $395 million and that could grow to as much as $1.8 billion.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds increased by $208.20 million, to $367.11 billion, in the week ended last Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 144 institutional funds decreased by $378.50 million, to $87.82 billion.
The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were up by $831.10 million, to $120.51 billion.

LEAD: As Linda Brown recalls it, her father, the Rev.
Oliver Brown, was troubled that his 5-year-old daughter had to attend a distant, all-black school, passing a good, all-white school in her neighborhood.


Playoff Confusion Is Coming to an End
LEAD: National Football League computers, statisticians and prophets will finally get a rest as the regular season ends this weekend.
The games will mean sudden death, or sudden life, for the 17 teams that entered the final weekend with Super Bowl XXIV hopes dancing in their thoughts.


199 Counts On Ohrenstein Are Upheld
LEAD: An appeals court yesterday upheld the indictment of the New York State Senate minority leader, Manfred Ohrenstein.
But the ruling dismissed many counts that were at the heart of the prosecution's case.

Upheaval in the East; PARTY IN PRAGUE IS SUSPENDING 32
LEAD: Ending a turbulent two-day meeting marked by bitterness over abuse of power by former leaders, the Czechoslovak Communist Party voted today to suspend the party memberships of 32 former leaders and expel a former party ideologist whom it accused of instigating the Soviet-led invasion of the country in 1968.

Most of that music is quaint, good-natured and naive, rarely worthy of its ethnic sources.

Stiffer Rules Proposed for Mutual Funds
LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission today proposed new rules intended to give investors in mutual funds more and clearer information about the funds and their managers.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:  N.B.A.
Hawks 117, Heat 115: Doc Rivers stole the ball from Grant Long and hit two free throws with seven-tenths of a second left last night in Miami as Atlanta withstood a fourth-quarter rally by the Heat.
After a free throw by Dominique Wilkins put Atlanta ahead, 115-113, with 8.7 seconds left, Long took an inbound pass and drove to the basket.

Company News; Beacon to Acquire Coleman Division
LEAD: Beacon International Ltd. of Toronto has agreed to buy the heating and air-conditioning division of the Coleman Company.
Terms of the deal were not disclosed.
The transaction is scheduled to be completed in early 1990.
Beacon International is a subsidiary of the Beacon Capital Corporation.

LEAD: Gerard Depardieu is not only the greatest, most enthusiastic film actor in France, he is also the most generous.
Since 1971, he has made 64 movies, good, bad, great and indifferent.


Oakland Battles U.S. to Be Nuclear-Free
LEAD: The Federal Government is making a test case of this city's effort to turn itself into a nuclear-free zone.


Upheaval in the East; Yugoslav Loan Plan Is Seen
LEAD: Western creditors may lend Yugoslavia up to $4 billion in the next two years if it adopts Premier Ante Markovic's new market-oriented economic program, Yugoslav banking officials and news reports said today.
The officials said the International Monetary Fund agreed to grant Yugoslavia an 18-month standby credit worth $600 million.
