Upheaval in the East; Medical Aid for Poland
LEAD: The European Community said today that it would send medical aid to Poland as part of a medical aid program in place since 1982.
The 1989 package worth $2.9 million will buy medication and small medical supplies.
The aid brings total European Community medical aid to Poland since 1982 to $60.8 million.


Shifts at Corning Paper
LEAD: The Corning Leader will become a morning newspaper and begin publication of a Sunday issue in March 1990, its publisher, Neil C. Hopp, said this week.
The first morning issue is scheduled for March 5, followed by publication of the first Sunday paper on March 11.
The Leader, owned by the California-based Howard Publications Group, has a circulation of 17,000.


Review/Dance; 'Sarong Paramaribo,' a Trip Through Time and Cultures
LEAD: ''Sarong Paramaribo,'' the latest novelty for the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, is very much that -an unusual pastiche of Balinese dancing and show business by Lester Horton that had its company premiere at the City Center (131 West 55th Street) Wednesday night.


Dr. William Greenough, 75, Dies; Devised Variable-Annuity Fund
LEAD: Dr.
William C. Greenough, an economist and lecturer whose work transformed pension-fund management, died on Wednesday night at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center after suffering complications from a heart attack.
He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Roy Bennett, 77, Dies; Adviser to 3 Presidents
LEAD: Roy Bennett, an adviser to three Presidents on economics and foreign policy, died of a heart attack Wednesday at New York Hospital, where he was recovering from surgery.
He was 77 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.


Times Co. Sets Stock Buyback
LEAD: The New York Times Company announced yesterday that its board had authorized spending up to $50 million to purchase shares of the company's class A common stock.

LEAD: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times.
Stars are followed by the date of original publication.
Prices are current.
Indochine  ** (Nov. 25, 1988), 430 Lafayette Street (505-5111) - This still-trendy, somewhat noisy restaurant across from the Public Theater serves a vivid mix of Vietnamese and Cambodian cuisines.


Savings Bailout Cost Seen Rising
LEAD: Almost 500 more savings and loan associations than initially projected by the Bush Administration are likely to be taken over by the Government under the bailout legislation, according to numbers released today by the Office of Thrift Supervision.
That is sure to mean that the ultimate cost of the rescue, which has been estimated at $159 billion over the next 10 years, will be considerably higher.


Pan Am Bombing Suspect Convicted in Other Attacks
LEAD: A Palestinian suspected in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 was convicted today along with three co-defendants in a series of attacks in northern Europe four years ago.


Review/Cabaret; A Brother Nicholas Evokes Astaire
LEAD: Harold Nicholas's tribute to Fred Astaire, which opened on Tuesday at Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, is not, as such tributes often are, an attempt to emulate a bygone performer.
Mr.
Nicholas, who starred with his brother, Fayard, as the Nicholas Brothers in nightclubs and movies in the 1930's, 40's and 50's, is an established singer and dancer in his own right.

DURENBERGER SAYS HE BROKE NO RULES
LEAD: Apologizing to his Minnesota constituents, Senator Dave Durenberger said Wednesday that his personal financial dealings revealed poor judgment on his part but that they did not violate Senate rules.


Helmsley Rejects Plea Agreement in State Tax Case
LEAD: Already sentenced to a four-year Federal prison term for income tax fraud, Leona Helmsley yesterday rejected an offer to serve a concurrent state prison sentence in exchange for pleading guilty to charges of evading about $750,000 in New York State income taxes.

Upheaval in the East; Gorbachev Voices 'Alarm' On Lithuanian Party Split
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that a decision by the Lithuanian Communist Party to sever its links with the national party raised ''concern and alarm,'' and that the Central Committee would hold an emergency meeting in the next few days to discuss the issue.


Dresdner Bank Plan
LEAD: Dresdner Bank, West Germany's second-largest commercial bank, announced plans Tuesday to open an office in Dresden, the East German city where the bank was founded in 1872.
Although its management was shifted to Berlin in 1884, Dresden remained the bank's legal headquarters until 1950.
The headquarters have been in Frankfurt since 1957.


Benching by Laryngitis
LEAD: A severe case of laryngitis will force Texas-El Paso's head coach, Don Haskins, to stay away from his team for as long as two weeks.


The End Of a Fool
LEAD: In the end the man turned out to be a fool, just a fool like so many of his kind.


Gamecocks Coach Signs
LEAD: Ten months after being hired, South Carolina's football coach, Sparky Woods, signed a five-year contract yesterday that will pay him $95,000 a year and includes provisions regarding graduation rates and drug testing.


Fighting in Panama: The Press; Editors Say Journalists Were Kept From Action
LEAD: Some news executives criticized the Pentagon yesterday for keeping a 16-person pool of journalists away from the fighting during the first 24 hours of the invasion of Panama.


Islands of Calm Amid the Urban Bustle
LEAD: With the frigid professionalism of a dip picking pockets on a 42d Street bus, Jack Frost has been neatly working the midtown holiday throngs, stinging ears, freezing feet, snatching breaths and causing weary shoppers and tourists to look inward - not to the higher thoughts prompted by the season, but to places of refuge from the rigors of the street.


Neighborhoods Santa Has No Trouble Finding
LEAD: UNADORNED homes are rare commodities around Christmastime in Bay Ridge, Bensonhurst and Canarsie.
With thousands of plastic Santas and snowmen, armies of toy soldiers and multicolored megawatts of lights decorating block upon block of houses and apartment buildings, no one could accuse these Brooklyn neighborhoods of a lack of holiday cheer.

LEAD: David Storey describes his production of ''The Nutcracker'' as a contemporary version.

Corrections
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day on Dec. 15 about a method for turning ''junk bonds'' into investment-grade securities misstated the status of a regulatory review of the First Executive Corporation's attempt to repackage some bonds.
The California Department of Insurance is conducting an examination of the transaction and has not yet reached a decision on it.


Upheaval in the East; Rumania Since the 1940's
LEAD: 1944: Soviet forces enter the country with the overthrow of the regime allied with Nazi Germany during World War II.
March 1945: Under Soviet pressure, King Michael accepts the appointment of a Communist-led coalition Government.  1946: Elections usher in a Communist-dominated bloc with 89 percent of the vote, although opposition parties charge fraud.

Spurt in Travel Abroad Cuts Japan's Large Trade Surplus After fruitless years of struggling with Japan to negotiate down its yawning trade surpluses, foreign governments are getting help from an unlikely source: 10 million Japanese with a passion for overseas travel.   With all those yen and dollars being spent offshore as Japanese ''import'' hotel lodging, restaurant meals and myriad other travel services, Japan's financial surpluses are shrinking quickly, even while many thorny trade issues remain unresolved.   ''To our surprise, travel services have become Japan's second-largest 'import,' after oil,'' said Koji Watanabe, the deputy minister for foreign affairs and a top official representing Japan in current trade negotiations with the United States. Travel, Mr. Watanabe added, represents ''one of the most promising areas for Japan to increase its imports.'' A Large Travel Deficit    In the first nine months of this year, Japan ran a $14.5 billion travel deficit, meaning that is how much more Japanese travelers spent overseas than foreign travelers spent in Japan. With a year-end surge beginning - travel agents estimate that a half-million Japanese will go abroad for the holidays - the Government expects the deficit to top $20 billion for the year. That would more than double the $8.7 billion travel deficit in 1987 and would represent a fivefold increase from the $3.7 billion gap in 1985.   The total of 10 million overseas travelers includes both tourists and people on business trips and is nearly double the level of three years ago. Some experts maintain that the figures would be much higher were it not for serious bottlenecks at Japan's undersized, overburdened international airports, which can make overseas travel an ordeal.   ''Not only are people spending these huge amounts on travel, but they all bring back lots of omiyage,'' said Susumo Saito, chief economist here for a unit of Credit Suisse, using the Japanese word for gifts. ''The cumulative amounts have been getting very big,'' Mr. Saito said.   The typical Japanese tourist will go abroad for six to seven days, spending $1,750 on travel and an additional $1,000 or so on goods, according to the Japan Travel Bureau, the nation's largest travel agent.   The favorite destinations are in the Pacific Rim. More than a million Japanese visited Hawaii last year, and a similar number also traveled to South Korea and to Hong Kong.   Japan's travel deficit with the United States alone represented more than a third of its worldwide travel gap in 1988. This year, a growing number of young Japanese are booking trips to New York and San Francisco, Japanese travel agents say.   Just why the Government and economists are taking notice is clear from the impact the travel boom is having on Japan's current account, the broadest measure of a nation's trade performance with the rest of the world, including trade in both goods and services.   In the first 10 months of this year, Japan's current-account surplus shrank in dollar terms by 23.5 percent, to $48.6 billion, from the period a year earlier. Government economists now predict that for the full year the current-account surplus could be less than $60 billion, well under the $71 billion forecast earlier and down sharply from the peak of $87 billion in 1987. Would Slow Rise in Wealth    To be sure, there are many frictions between the United States and Japan that a reduction in the current-account surplus would not solve. These include American assertions that Japanese markets remain closed to items like semiconductors, wood products, supercomputers and satellites. But a sustained decline in the current-account surplus would slow Japan's extraordinary accumulation of wealth in recent years.   In the arithmetic of trade figures, the travel deficit is part of the ledger dealing with ''invisible trade,'' which includes services, fees, royalties and investment income. The other part of the ledger concerns merchandise, or ''visible,'' trade. Most of the negotiations between the United States and Japan have been over the merchandise trade balance.   A declining Japanese current-account surplus could have a significant impact on Japan's purchasing power abroad, reducing its investment in the United States on everything from real estate to Treasury bonds and hampering the competitiveness of Japanese banks overseas.   ''This is why you hear the Japanese Government talking a lot more about the current account than the visible trade balance, where there hasn't been as much progress,'' said Kenneth S. Courtis, senior economist here for Deutsche Bank. ''And the travel deficit is behind it.''   Some economists agree with Mr. Watanabe that the travel boom could do more to shrink Japan's capital surpluses than all the measures being planned for increasing the country's imports and opening its markets to foreign goods. 'An Enormous New Market'    ''What people are starting to realize is that this is not just a change for Japanese consumers, but is changing consumption around the world because of how much Japanese tourists are spending overseas,'' Mr. Courtis said. ''You have some 10 million high spenders going abroad each year. It's an enormous new market that is going to continue to grow.''   On the front lines of this new army of travelers, life can be hectic. Takeshi Saito, manager of the overseas sales department for the bustling Shinjuku office of the Japan Travel Bureau, said his office's sales had more than doubled this year from 1988.   As young people nearby studied pamphlets for package trips to Australia, Hawaii and Europe, Mr. Saito noted that he had increased his staff by 30 percent to keep up with the demand. He pointed out that domestic travel has also boomed. A Different Tourist Now    Along with the boom is a change in the tourist, reflecting Japan's growing self-confidence. The days of Japanese travel groups moving through museums, hotels, restaurants and stores in lockstep, wearing the same tour hats, carrying the official tour bags and following a flag-waving tour leader also seem to be ending.   ''No more hats, no more bags,'' Mr. Saito said. ''Things have changed 100 percent. Especially the younger people. They want more free time when they get someplace.''   Many Japanese who make up the country's roving army of frequent fliers had to be forced as recently as two years ago to take Saturdays off and use their vacation time.   The Japanese Government lent its rhetorical support to the new spirit. Three years ago it declared its ''10 million plan,'' an effort to cajole that many Japanese to travel abroad. But the Government took almost no practical steps to raise interest in travel. Nonetheless, and to everyone's surprise, the goal has been met two years earlier than hoped.   Japan enforced rigorous travel restrictions in the postwar years to keep the nation's precious capital resources at home and to help rebuild the economy. 'Saved All the Time'    ''People were used to being conservative and saved all the time because the Government told them it was necessary,'' said Manabu Kanematsu, president of the Japan Association of Travel Agents, a trade group. ''But when they heard the Government, even the prime minister, encouraging them to use their savings and to travel, people really became more positive, more relaxed.''   Mr. Kanematsu also said that overseas travel has become a way for Japanese, whose living standard at home has been stunted by dauntingly high costs for housing and luxury goods, to begin to feel the wealth they had been reading about.   ''People who live in the smallest houses here want the biggest hotel rooms when they travel overseas,'' Mr. Kanematsu said.  The Japanese travel boom appears to have a great deal of room for growth. Compared with people in many other industrialized countries, Japanese are still homebodies. Britain, for example, with less than half the population of Japan, has three times as many overseas travelers.   ''They're way behind other countries,'' Mr. Courtis said. ''I think we can still expect a lot of catching up.''

LEAD: The three children of John Dorrance Jr., the late patriarch of the Campbell Soup Company, said today that they were committed to keeping the company independent.

Company News; Air Canada Sells Some GPA Shares
LEAD: Air Canada said it had sold 37 percent of its shares in GPA Group P.L.C. for $650 a share, or a total of $212 million (United States), resulting in an after-tax gain of $110.3 million.
Ireland-based GPA Group, the world's leading aircraft leasing company, completed the share placement on behalf of Air Canada by placing 5.4 percent of its share capital with financial institutions in Canada, Ireland, Japan and the United States The sale will reduce Air Canada's holding in GPA to 9.3 percent from 14.7 percent on a fully diluted basis, making Air Canada the third-largest shareholder in GPA.

LEAD: The production lines at South Korea's largest car maker, the Hyundai Motor Company, came to a halt after workers put down their tools to press for higher pay.
The company said about 15,000 union members held a rally and then walked out, idling assembly plants in the southeastern city of Ulsan.

Australia Seabed Project
LEAD: The Government announced Wednesday that it would open up Australia's continental shelf to mineral exploration.
The exploration area will be extended to 200 nautical miles from the Australian coast, from the current three-mile limit, the Resources Minister, Peter Cook, said in a statement. ''The Australian seabed is largely unexplored but it is believed to contain many minerals, including diamonds and heavy mineral sands,'' he said.

U.S. Deficit Up in November
LEAD: The Federal budget deficit increased $28.96 billion in November, raising the imbalance in the first two months of the fiscal year to more than half the legislative ceiling for the entire year, the Treasury Department said today.

LEAD: The Stride Rite Corporation, a shoe manufacturer, received a takeover offer late Wednesday of $32 a share, but there were signs yesterday that investors were skeptical of the bid, which valued the company at more than $860 million.


One Kansas City Paper
LEAD: The merger of The Kansas City Star and The Kansas City Times will take place on March 1, the editor of the newspapers said today.
Plans to merge the morning Times and the afternoon Star were announced on Oct. 5.
Joe McGuff, editor and vice president, said the decision came about because of sagging demand for afternoon papers and changing life styles.

LEAD: Consumer spending rebounded in November from a sharp fall in the previous month, while personal incomes increased eight-tenths of 1 percent.

LEAD: Another of the six youths charged with rape and attempted murder in an attack last April on a jogger in Central Park was released yesterday on $50,000 bail.

Still in jail in the case are Raymond Santana, 15, whose bail is set at $25,000, and Kharey Wise, 17, with $50,000 bail.

LEAD: More caviar is sold in December than at any other time of the year.
And it's also when prices generally drop.
There is less expensive caviar than sturgeon roe, but none has the same delicacy.
Lumpfish is gritty and salty and its black color comes from dye.
Whitefish is better, especially when left its natural golden color.

Finally, Rumania
LEAD: What a year.
What a week.
What a Friday.
The Brandenburg Gate was reopened in Berlin by Helmut Kohl of West Germany and Hans Modrow of East Germany.
And stunningly, in the face of horrifying violence, Rumanians drove the despotic Nicolae Ceausescu from power.
Except for tiny, Stalinist Albania, one-party tyranny appears near an end in Central and Eastern Europe.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Upheaval in the East: Hungary; High Prices Dampen Hungary's Holiday
LEAD: As Hungarians make their Christmas shopping rounds this year, in and out of stores trimmed with silver wreaths and bright ornaments, they are discovering a shortage of good cheer.


Suspect in Burglary on S.I. Wounded by Police Sergeant
LEAD: An off-duty New York City police sergeant shot and wounded one of two burglary suspects yesterday evening when he found them breaking into a cousin's house on Staten Island, the police said.


Bethlehem Journal; O Little Town, Where Are Your Tourists Now?
LEAD: Their heads down, their cameras held close to their bodies, a small group of tourists hurried past the shuttered Arab stores and watchful Israeli soldiers that give this biblical city its feel of siege and arrived this morning at the Church of the Nativity.


Japan Economic Growth
LEAD: The Japanese Government today forecast that the country's economic expansion would slow next year but would still be one of the fastest growing of the major industrial nations.
The economy is expected to grow 4 percent in the 1991 fiscal year, which begins next April 1, down from the 4.6 percent estimated for the current year.


Pronouncing The Names
LEAD: SILVIU BRUCAN, an opposition leader: SEEL-vyoo broo-KAHN


How Rumania Came to Be
LEAD:  May 1877: Rumania gains full independence from Turkey at the Congress of Berlin, which concluded the Russo-Turkish War.
1916: Rumania enters World War I in the side of the allies.  1920: Under the treaty of Trianon, between Hungary and the victorious Allied Powers of World I, Rumania is awarded substantial territory from Hungary, including Transylvania.


At Least 32 Killed as Buses Collide on Australian Coastal Highway


Europe and Arabs to Resume Talks
LEAD: The European Community and 22 members of the Arab League decided today to resume a formal dialogue on political and economic issues, six years after talks between the two groups broke down.


Maryland Judge Seriously Hurt by Bomb
LEAD: A Maryland criminal court judge known for strong advocacy of gun control and harsh prison sentences was injured today when a package bomb exploded in his apartment in Hagerstown, Md.


Fighting in Panama; Protest of Panama Invasion Blocks Traffic in Manhattan
LEAD: About 200 people protesting against the United States invasion of Panama blocked rush-hour traffic in Manhattan for about 20 minutes yesterday.


Early Music for Today
LEAD: ''I may be fooling myself,'' said the harpsichordist and early-music specialist Frederick Renz, ''but I believe it's possible to perform early music in a way that represents what was done at the time the music was written, but also speaks to a 20th-century audience.''

LEAD: Johnny Rodgers, a former Heisman Trophy winner from Nebraska, and a Nebraska sports marketing company were fined $10,000 each today by the Texas Secretary of State, who charged that both had illegally contacted the 1989 Heisman winner, Andre Ware of Houston.

LEAD: A brief article on Dec. 12 about the acquittal of a student accused of painting anti-Semitic slurs in the Jewish Student Union at the State University of New York at Binghamton gave an incorrect account of testimony about a can of spray paint found in a desk in the group's office.

LEAD: Although the glasnost policies of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have taken much of the suspense out of the Victor Kamkin bookshop here, they have brought the largest Russian bookstore in the West a boom in business.


Holiday on Monday
LEAD: Monday is Christmas.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed.
Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Sunday rules in effect.
Sanitation: No collection, recycling or street cleanings.
Schools: Closed.


Jetliner, in Flight to Tokyo, Lands In Alaska After a 600-Mile Error
LEAD: A Thai Airways jumbo jet flying from Seattle to Tokyo mistakenly reversed course over the northern Pacific on Thursday evening and wandered 600 miles off its flight path before it was alerted by air traffic controllers, Federal aviation officials said yesterday.

LEAD: Eleanor Shaler Dickson, a socially prominent actress and singer of the 1920's and 30's, died of pulmonary problems yesterday at her home in Gladwyne, Pa.
She was 89 years old.

Ernest L. Sisto, 85, Photographer For The Times for Nearly 50 Years
LEAD: Ernest Ludwig Sisto, an award-winning photographer who worked for The New York Times for nearly 50 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Sierra Nevada Memorial Hospital in Grass Valley, Calif.
He was 85 years old and had been living with a son Daniel in Rough and Ready, Calif., for 18 months.

LEAD: Roger H. Hallowell, former president and chairman of Reed &amp; Barton, the silver company, and a decorated Navy commander, died of a stroke Wednesday at a nursing home in Peabody.
He was 79 years old and lived in Manchester, Mass.


Essex County Fined For Conditions in Jail
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday angrily ordered Essex County to pay $3.4 million in fines by Jan. 4 for failing to correct dangerous conditions at the county jail.


Bridge
LEAD: Going down in a slam that need not have been attempted is always irritating.
But the irritation is compounded when the post-mortem reveals that an esoteric line of play would have succeeded.
This was South's fate on Sunday on the diagramed deal from the Regional Knockout Team final at the Penta Hotel in Manhattan.

Manuel Antonio Noriega, is believed to be personally directing a hit-and-run counteroffensive by armed civilians as he struggles to avoid capture by American troops, a senior United States military officer said this afternoon.

LEAD: Twin brothers were arrested today in connection with the killings of two Trenton cabdrivers in November, the police said.

LEAD: The Boeing Company plans to lay off about 1,200 employees in the first half of next year, with most of the cuts to be made among production workers at its plant in Everett, Wash., its chairman, Frank A. Shrontz, said today.

LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee announced today that it would begin a formal investigation of charges of improper conduct and influence peddling by six Senators, including Alfonse M. D'Amato of New York, whose role in Federal housing projects has been questioned.

He was 78 years old and lived in Wichita.

LEAD: The Notre Dame offensive coordinator, Jim Strong, was named head coach at Nevada-Las Vegas yesterday.

LEAD: William John Bailey, chemist, educator and former chairman of the board of the American Chemical Society, died Sunday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Straub Hospital in Honolulu, where he was attending a professional meeting on polymers.
He was 68 years old and lived in University Park, Md.

LEAD: A tenant volunteer on watch in a Bronx apartment-house lobby was shot to death Thursday night with a stray bullet from a street dispute outside the building, the police said yesterday.

LEAD: The owner of a pit bull that mauled a 2-year-old boy to death was acquitted of second-degree murder today but found guilty of involuntary manslaughter and other lesser charges.

LEAD: The fire chief of New Hyde Park and two other men have been arrested and charged with running a $10-million-a-year sports-betting business, the Nassau County police said yesterday.


Donnelley to Buy Meredith/Burda
LEAD: The R. R. Donnelley &amp; Sons Company, the world's largest commercial printer, said it had agreed to buy the Meredith/Burda Company, the big printing company, for $570 million.
Donnelley, which prints many national publications - Time, Newsweek, Business Week and TV Guide, among others - said the deal is expected to close early next year.


Elderly Woman Dies in Fire
LEAD: An 80-year-old woman died yesterday in a fire in a two-story home in Brooklyn, a Fire Department spokesman said.
The woman, Teresa Palumbo, was found on the first floor of the house at 1413 36th Street, in the Borough Park section, said the spokesman, John Mulligan.
She was declared dead at the scene after firefighters responded to the blaze at 9:53 A.M., he said.

LEAD: Apparently in part because of his ethics troubles, Senator Alan Cranston has announced that his plans to marry this Sunday have been called off.
In a statement issued by his office here Thursday, the 75-year-old Senator suggested that local news organizations' attention to his wedding plans and the pressure of the Lincoln Savings and Loan affair were responsible for his decision.

It will be filled with her family -her husband and five children and three daughters-in-law and three grandchildren -and the aroma of, among other delights, the oatmeal cookies and the angel food cake she baked.

Pastimes; Bridge
LEAD: What must be considered the most remarkable bridge conspiracy occurred 40 years ago in the Philadelphia area.

It was played at the club she ran in her home in St.
Davids Mrs.
Petersen was one of the grande dames of the game, with a career as player, writer and teacher that spanned the evolution of auction bridge into contract.

Setting High Tech Free
LEAD: Earlier this month U S West Inc. made a successful bid to lay a fiber-optics network in the Soviet Union.
Last week, the Commerce Department indicated it would allow the deal to go through.
The decision could signal a willingness by the United States to ease restrictions on high-tech exports.
These exports are currently limited by the Coordinating Committee on Multilateral Export Controls, called Cocom, which includes 17 Western countries.

High-Tech Fortunetelling
LEAD: STRUNG ALONG THE 46 CHROMOSOMES of every human cell are some 100,000 genes.
Among them, in each one of us, are a few that can be deadly.
Every person has a unique set of these seven or eight lethal genes.
They are usually hidden, but in the wrong environment or in combination with certain other genes they can express themselves in dangerous ways.

Irish Harps
LEAD: To the Editor: We were disappointed with a couple of points in the article ''Finding an Authentic Irish Harp'' (Travel, Oct. 8).
My harps are played by classical and traditional players, and I make both gut- and nylon-strung harps.
My lever system is not operated by rotating an off-center screw, it's adjusted by doing so.

Schoenberg Festival Is Planned at Juilliard
LEAD: The work of Arnold Schoenberg will be studied in six concerts of orchestral, chamber and solo works at the Juilliard School, from Jan. 26 to Feb. 2.
More than 250 students of the music, dance and drama divisions will take part in the series, which is titled 'The World of Arnold Schoenberg' and which will include his own work and that of some of the composers who studied with him.

Bethlehem Without Christmas
LEAD: There are no decorations, no festivities in Bethlehem this Christmas.
There will be church services for visitors, and six foreign choirs have come to sing in Nativity Square on Christmas Eve.
But the people are staying silently in their homes.
The holidays have been proclaimed a time of mourning and of protest.

Corrections

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. We have thermal windows in our country home, manufacturer unknown.
On several windows, moisture is seeping in between the two panes of glass.
Is there a way to clean out this moisture and reseal the windows?


The No-Parent Child
LEAD: On Nov. 27, Baby Boy W. was born in Brooklyn four weeks early and with test signs of cocaine and syphilis.
He is the youngest of three children whose mother is an unemployed crack addict who has dropped out of drug treatment.
She has not seen Baby Boy W. since his birth and he is now a candidate for adoption.


DES Victims: Search Must Go On
LEAD: BY the end of this year, critical research into the effects of DES (diethylstilbestrol) will come to an end, despite the fact that millions of men and women born between 1941 and 1971 still suffer the effects of this ''wonder drug,'' and most of them still don't realize that the future may hold problems for them.


IN SHORT: Nonfiction
LEAD: HEIRESS: The Story of Christina Onassis.
By Nigel Dempster. (Grove Weidenfeld, $17.95.) Pity Christina Onassis: all that money, but it couldn't buy her love.
It was not for her lack of trying, however, and Nigel Dempster, a columnist for The London Daily Mail, tells all in ''Heiress.'' He divulges that a nearly 200-pound Onassis paid Luis Sosa Balsuado, an Argentine polo player, $1,000 a day for companionship and sex.


PRESSURING PERDUE
LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: Henry Spira's denouncement of the fur and leather industry is not substantiated by facts (''Pressuring Perdue,'' by Barnaby J. Feder, Nov. 26).
One of the biggest problems today is pollution created by man, and one of the major causes of this pollution is the manufacture of synthetics.

Prime Time Returned to the Past
LEAD: AS THE 1980'S AND THE REAGAN era came to a close, much of television's arts and entertainment programming, like the nation, seemed exhausted.
The optimism bubble that characterized the decade and its yuppie cheerleaders suddenly burst, exposing a series of long-festering crises: the homeless, AIDS, environmental pollution, political scandals, multibillion-dollar bailouts of financial institutions, mountains of governmental, corporate and private debt.


Mission of Hope for the Jewish Faithful in Poland
LEAD: THIS is a Hanukkah full of hope for Jerzy Kichler.
Mr.
Kichler, a Polish Jew, has struggled for nine years to help rebuild the Jewish community in Poland, which was nearly destroyed by Hitler and further reduced by postwar emigration.
As the leader of a small Jewish study group in Wroclaw, a city northwest of Cracow, he has met with the expected resistance of the Communist authorities and the unexpected resistance of the remaining Orthodox Jews.


Texaco Star Rises Again
LEAD: DURING the past five years, Texaco Inc. has earned some dubious distinctions.
It became the victim of the largest damage award in history when a court ordered it to pay the Pennzoil Company $11 billion for illegally elbowing it aside to acquire the Getty Oil Company in 1984.
It also became the largest company to file for protection from creditors under the bankruptcy law and the biggest target ever stalked by Carl I.

Escaping to Ireland for Christmas
LEAD: TO escape the commercial and familial hoopla of the holidays, my husband and I like to take our children to faraway places for a different kind of celebration - one that we create from the bits of experience and tradition we value most.
Traveling at Christmas is part of our general inclination to set out against the seasonal tides.

Abortion Viewed as Human Rights Issue
LEAD: In a recent article appearing in the Long Island Weekly, certain facts concerning my successful re-election campaign were incorrectly stated.
The article read, ''Mr.
Dillon, a Roman Catholic, said during the campaign that his opposition to abortion derives from his religious beliefs.'' I never said that and, to the contrary, I have always said that my position is based on the scientific evidence that human life begins at conception, and the ethical principle that it is always wrong to unjustifiably kill innocent human life.

A CHURCH WITHOUT PRIESTS
LEAD: IN ITS FORMER LIFE, SAN PATRICIO'S WAS A HIGH-SCHOOL band hall.
Even now, a placard announcing Sunday Mass at noon and a white wooden cross over the front door are the only outward and visible signs that this mustard-colored square structure with its gray tar-paper roof is a church.
A landscape of bare fields, punctuated by cattle, oil rigs, low, crawling cactus and mesquite stretches out from the church and the town of Throckmorton, Tex.

THE TREE THAT CAME TO STAY
LEAD: The day the tree came to stay the snow fell down with a hissing sound.
The children saw each flake, for just a minute, sticking to the car windows, and then they melted and were gone.
When the car climbed the big hill to the farm where they always found their Christmas tree, the wind whistled around them, and they felt warm behind the glass.

Pastimes; Coins
LEAD: There is a long tradition of giving money, called Hanukkah gelt, to children during Hanukkah.
Some believe the custom dates back to the original Hanukkah celebration when Judas Maccabaeus rededicated the Temple in Jerusalem.
But most scholars feel these gifts of pocket change to children originated in Eastern Europe during the Middle Ages.

LEAD: Poland agreed to far-reaching economic changes in return for as much as $4 billion in Western aid in a letter of intent signed today with the International Monetary Fund.


IN SHORT: Nonfiction
LEAD: THE DIVERTED DREAM: Community Colleges and the Promise of Educational Opportunity in America, 1900-1985.
By Steven Brint and Jerome Karabel. (Oxford University, $24.95.) The United States sends more of its young people to college than any other nation in the world.
Approximately half of them are enrolled in community colleges, where they are channeled into low- and mid-level technical and vocational programs.

Animal Rescues: Saving a Goose
LEAD: Joan Baron's account ''Rescue Mission: Saving a Swan'' (Opinion, Dec. 3) reminded me of the time, some years ago, when I foiled the kidnapping of a large goose at the pond located at Nassau Boulevard and Hempstead Avenue in West Hempstead.


A Gift Wrapped in Anticipation
LEAD: THE magic of Christmas is a fleeting gift of childhood.
Once gone, it can almost never be recaptured.
As the season approaches, a brief glimmer of a long ago Christmas will be recalled by a carol overheard, the sparkle of a decoration or the familiar scent of fresh pine.
It comes and goes so quickly that sometimes we can scarcely identify what it is that brings on that feeling of excitement and anticipation we associate with a more innocent time in our lives.

Dynasties of the gifted might argue otherwise.
But the explosion of exceptional dancing that marked 1989 had less to do with genes than with plain hard work - dedication and commitment from the performers.

Holiday Tomorrow
LEAD: Tomorrow is Christmas.
Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK  Government offices: Federal, state and municipal closed.
Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only.
Banks: Closed.
Parking: Sunday rules in effect.
Sanitation: No collection, recycling, or street cleanings.
Schools: Closed.

'Valentine &amp; Orson'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Civilization and Savagery Collide in Metaphor
LEAD: ''JUAN DARIEN,'' THE PUPPET MUSICAL by Julie Taymor and Elliot Goldenthal, is an eloquent expression of the power of theatrical transformation, which in this case approaches transmutation.
As the audience watches, objects and images shift and assume radically different, often metaphorical form.
A jaguar cub is reborn as a boy (named Juan Darien), and, suffering at the hands of his fellow man, he is driven back to his beastly origins.


Resorts in Snow-Shy Alps Go Beyond Skiing
LEAD: For the third year in a row, mountain resorts in Europe's Alps are expecting a brown Christmas instead of a white one.


A Nation Divided by a Common Passion
LEAD: ITALY, you might say, is a country where everyone likes football, but doesn't like one another.
In terms of soccer towns (which means almost all of them) and soccer teams, it remains essentially a collection of city states, which have only in name been welded into a single nation.
The longstanding notion in the north is that from Rome on down, it's no longer Italy, it's Africa.


New York's 30 Percent
LEAD: Here's a sad statistic to remember on Christmas Eve: While about 20 percent of the nation's children are growing up in poverty, the figure in New York City is closer to 30 percent.
Fifteen thousand of the city's youngsters are ''certified'' as homeless.
Thousands still live under hazardous conditions in welfare hotels.

IN SHORT: Fiction

By Tom Stacey. (St. Martin's, $13.95.) This very brief, sometimes annoying and often compelling adventure novel by a real Fleet Street foreign correspondent, which features a fictional Fleet Street correspondent, raises some essential questions about their profession.

LEAD: Christine Noel Gleichauf and Peter Metz, Cornell University graduates, plan to marry in October, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs.
George Gleichauf of Rochester, have announced.
Mr.
Metz, 25 years old, is the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Melvin Metz of Freeport, L.I.
Ms.
Gleichauf, 25, received a master's degree in nutritional sciences from Cornell.


PRESSURING PERDUE
LEAD: TO THE EDITOR: I am puzzled.
What do Henry Spira's cats eat?
A survey of the cat-food shelves at my local supermarket shows no cat food, canned or dry, that does not contain animal products.
After sharpening their claws on Mr.
Spira's politically correct Naugahyde furniture, do his cats hunt, kill and eat mice?

WHAT'S DOING IN: Singapore
LEAD: In a remarkable combination of will, foresight and happenstance, what began as a swampy island only 85 miles from the Equator has been transformed into the most modern, efficient and simply the cleanest city of Southeast Asia.
The last is not a bad attribute in a part of the world where sanitation is more talked about than practiced.

TALKING: Neighbors; Dealing With Noise Or Worse
LEAD: IMAGINE, for a moment, that the shouting and arguing from the apartment next door have been getting worse.
Drug dealing, or at least drug use, is suspected and there is concern about violence.
Or the woman down the hall holds regular psychotherapy sessions.
Patients start using the hallway as a waiting room, leaving litter and creating a din, as happened recently in a Manhattan co-op building.

How to Make Raising Money Cheaper
LEAD: THE acceleration of Japanese purchases of American corporate icons like Rockefeller Center, Columbia Pictures and CBS Records should come as no surprise, given the huge advantage that the Japanese enjoy in capital costs.
Recent studies have found that America's capital is between 2 1/2 and 4 times as expensive as Japan's.

But those days are long gone.

Shall We Dance?; As Two Worlds Warm, A Post-Postwar Order Awaits
LEAD: RETROSPECT often makes the most recent moments seem the most vivid.
That is usually a trick that our minds play upon us, but surely not in the 1980's.
The pictures of Berliners dancing upon, pouring through, chipping hunks out of their hated wall, symbolizing the end of 45 years of cold war, seem incredible now, and surely they and what they epitomize will still seem extraordinary in the next century.


Lifestyle: New Year's Eve Dining; Ending 1989 on a Festive but Frugal Note
LEAD: New Year's Eve is a merry bonanza for many restaurants.
It is the only night of the year when they get away with giving a couple a bottle of bubbly, an extra appetizer or two, a silly cardboard hat and maybe a lounge trio - and tripling their prices.
If your New Year's resolution is to start 1990 with a whopping credit-card tab, Manhattan awaits you with open arms.

Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; For Picadillo, Creativity Can Take Wing
LEAD: There are as many versions of picadillo as there are regions of Mexico.
Some call for picadillo, a mixture of ground meat, spices and some kind of fruit, to be made with beef or pork.
Most call for raisins as the sweetening agent, but one calls for pineapple, and another is made with eggs.
Some are spiced with hot chilies; some are not.

LEAD: The Government is moving to help unclog bottlenecks that have created shortages of heating oil and propane in the current spell of extremely cold weather, the Energy Department's top emergency planner said today.


Candied Fruit of Provence: Sweet Tradition
LEAD: ON Christmas Eve throughout the south of France a ritual takes place as it has for centuries.
To insure good fortune in the coming year a platter is passed around the dining table.
It holds the celebrated treize desserts, 13 of the region's delicacies.
Although the selection may vary, it is likely to include walnuts and almonds, apricots and figs, almond-based calisson candies and nut-studded nougats and what some consider the star attraction, colorful candied fruits confits.

4 Family Members Die in Fire
LEAD: A man tried in vain to save his family from a fire that destroyed their trailer home today, the police said.
The man, Robert E. Thomas, 27 years old, had gotten up to go to the bathroom just as the fire started at 7:20 A.M., the police said.
He ran outside and survived, but his wife, Heather, 27, and the couple's three sons, Robert Jr., 6; James, 5, and Christopher, 2, died, the state police said.

Mortgage Rates Drop
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.69 percent, according to a national survey released Friday by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac.
That was down from a rate of 9.75 percent last week.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.34 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent the week before.

Vehicle Output in Japan
LEAD: Japan's vehicle production fell 1.5 percent in November from a year earlier, to 1,134,520, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said Friday.
The figure compared with 1,123,416 in October, up five-tenths of a percent from a year earlier.
A total of 818,913 cars was manufactured in November, up 9.4 percent from November 1988.

LEAD: Fog was blamed for a 14-car pileup early today on State Highway 4 between Pittsburg and Concord, the California Highway Patrol said.

New Midway Fares
LEAD: Midway Airlines Inc. said it had introduced promotional fares of $19 to $99 one way on flights from Chicago to any city it served in the continental United States.

Requirements for minimum stays were waived to all destinations, and restrictions on advance purchases were also waived to all destinations in Florida, except Jacksonville.


Using Gamma Rays to Save Old Books
LEAD: The British Library has found a new weapon in the campaign to save crumbling books: gamma rays.
Book preservationists around the world now use alkaline baths or sprays to save important old volumes damaged by the acid in paper and inks.
But these methods can involve painstaking page-by-page applications and an average cost of up to $480 a book, said Marie Jackson, national preservation officer of the British Library, the largest in Britain.

LEAD: The dollar declined yesterday against most key foreign currencies in extremely thin post-holiday trading.
Gold prices fell after rising in Asia.


RESULTS PLUS


Official Thanks
LEAD: The corruption scandal that marred Mayor Edward Koch's third term made it easy to forget that he brought to city government some of the finest public officials ever to serve New York.
Those who worked tirelessly for the people of New York far outnumbered the losers.
Here are a just a few who have earned the city's gratitude.


Review/Theater; In His Apartment, a Puppeteer Wages a War Without End
LEAD: A puppeteer, a survivor of the Holocaust, is living in Germany in 1950 -and is convinced that World War II is still being fought.
He believes that if he steps out of his apartment, he will be arrested and returned to the concentration camp from which he escaped.
In the privacy of that room, the apparently insane puppeteer acts out plays about his incarceration while his landlady helplessly tries to awaken him to reality.

Organs of 3 Fire Victims Help Keep Others Alive
LEAD: When a fire killed their three young sons last month, Dubby and Diana Wilcox were approached about donating the children's organs.
At first they said no, but after considering what they thought the boys would have wanted, they changed their minds.


The Battle to Create Phones for the Future
LEAD: In the battle for the residential telephone market, two companies -A.T.&amp;T. and Panasonic - are so far the big winners among scores of equipment makers.
They lead the way in technology and innovation, and they have the market share to prove it.


Peres Delays a Soviet Visit; Economic Talks Unprepared
LEAD: Finance Minister Shimon Peres has indefinitely postponed a visit to the Soviet Union planned for early next month, his spokesman said today.


Arson Discounted in Fatal Fire
LEAD: A fire that killed 16 people in a high-rise retirement center started on the first floor, but investigators have not narrowed the cause, city fire officials said today.


I.M.F. Loan to Pakistan
LEAD: The International Monetary Fund said it would lend Pakistan $213 million to support an economic program aimed at reducing the nation's budget deficit, freeing trade and introducing flexible exchange-rate management.
The loan is the second installment of a three-year, $497 million I.M.F. credit.
The first $142 million was drawn in December 1988.


Heating Oil Prices Surge Following Plant Explosion
LEAD: Heating oil futures prices climbed dramatically yesterday after an explosion at the nation's second-largest petrochemical refinery.

Koch, in Veto, Discounts Risks In Computer Use
LEAD: Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday rejected legislation aimed at protecting New York City municipal employees who use video display terminals.


Thefts of Cargo Containers Are Up at Los Angeles Ports
LEAD: Thefts of shipping containers are increasing at the Los Angeles and Long Beach harbors and from nearby warehouses, the Los Angeles Police Department and the Federal Bureau of Investigation say.


At the Nation's Table
LEAD: TWO seaside hours north of traffic-choked Los Angeles, Santa Barbara is a well-heeled retreat of sandy beaches framed by scrubby hills, where Ronald Reagan repaired to his vacation ranch.


George J. Becker, 81; Taught at Swarthmore
LEAD: Dr.
George J. Becker, an author of books on writers and literary criticism and a retired chairman of the English department at Swarthmore College, died on Friday in a nursing home in Bellingham, Wash., after a long illness.
He was 81 years old.
Dr.
Becker was on Swarthmore's faculty for 25 years, heading its English department from 1953 to 1970, when he transferred to Western Washington University.


Chicken Soup For Obscurity
LEAD: JOAN and Lydia Wilen are headed toward the big time.
Sales of their books, ''Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1984) and ''More Chicken Soup and Other Folk Remedies'' (Fawcett, 1986), are soaring, and the sisters, who place their ages ''somewhere between Brooke Shields and Joan Collins,'' are the toast of the talk-show circuit.


Benny Binion Is Dead; Casino Owner Was 85
LEAD: Benny Binion, owner of the Horseshoe Casino in Las Vegas whose flamboyant promotional efforts included an annual monthlong ''World Series of Poker'' for high-stakes players, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at Valley Hospital in Las Vegas, where he lived.
He was 85 years old.

LEAD: Fifty slots on 50 signs on major roads connecting the five boroughs were waiting for official word on an 'N.'


Counseling, From Careers to Everyday Stresses
LEAD: School guidance counselors, whose original purpose was to assist high school students choose their courses and apply to college, are becoming a much more integral part of students' daily lives, especially at the elementary level.


Upheaval in the East; Rumania's 11 Days of Turmoil
LEAD: Dec. 15: Demonstrators ring a church in Timisoara, in western Rumania, to prevent security forces from arresting a clergyman who was active in promoting the rights of ethnic Hungarians.
Dec. 16-17: Security forces open fire on thousands of demonstrators in Timisoara, who have expanded their protest to demand freedom and a better life.

LEAD: Doug Harvey, who won the Norris Trophy as the National Hockey League's top defenseman seven times from 1955-62, died today in a Montreal hospital after a long illness.
He was 65 years old.

Joseph Livingston, 84; Won Pulitzer in 1964
LEAD: Joseph A. Livingston, a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter whose column appeared in more than 50 newspapers nationwide, died Monday at the age of 84.


Executive Leaving NBC
LEAD: Thomas B. Ross is leaving biNBC News, where he is a senior vice president, for Hill &amp; Knowlton Inc., the public relations and public affairs subsidiary of the WPP Group, where he will be a senior vice president and global director of media relations.
Mr.
Ross began his career as a journalist, and from 1977 to 1981 he was Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs.


Walton Is Dismissed as the Jets Clean House
LEAD: The Jets' general manager, Dick Steinberg, officially cleaned house today.
He dismissed Coach Joe Walton and his 10 assistants, accepted the resignation of Mike Hickey, whose college drafts had provided the bulk of the Jets' players, and reduced the role of Jim Royer, who evaluated and signed pro personnel.

LEAD: The two teams of military contractors competing for a contract to build a new generation of jet fighters are finding their gamble is even bigger than anticipated.


Upheaval in the East: The Baltics; GORBACHEV AGREES TO GO TO LITHUANIA ON SECESSION MOVE
LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has decided to go to Lithuania soon to consult with rank-and-file Communist Party members about the Lithuanian party's decision to break from Moscow, several people who attended an emergency party meeting here said today.
The two-day meeting of the national party leadership ended without agreement on how to address the problem.


Hearty Doe Stirs Hopes Of Caribou 'Transplant'
LEAD: Attempts to reintroduce caribou to Maine have been thwarted by disease and bears, but based on the success of a hearty doe named Daisy, officials hope Canada will provide more animals for ''transplant.''

Wine Talk
LEAD: WHICH is more important, where a wine comes from, or the grape from which it is made?
In California, it's the grape.
A wine is a cabernet sauvignon or a zinfandel or a chardonnay.
In France, it's the opposite.
We know the place - Chateau Latour, for example - and care little about the grapes from which the wine is made.

LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, the new chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today named William R. McLucas, who has been with the commission for 12 years, as the agency's chief enforcement officer.
Mr.
Breeden also announced the formation of an enforcement unit to protect individual investors against fraud at banks and savings institutions.

LEAD: THE last few months have been terrible times for bank stocks, as losses from real estate lending at some New England banks have raised fears of similar problems in other regions.


Book Notes
LEAD:  In Need of Rewriting


Handing Down Lebanon's Rich Tradition
LEAD: SINCE she does not drive, Malvina Azzi cannot get to George's Bakery as often as she would like.
But sometimes Mrs.
Azzi, 78 years old, persuades one of her four sons to drive her the 30 miles down the Merrimac River to George's, in the gritty old mill town of Lawrence, Mass.
There she buys the ingredients she needs to cook her favorite Lebanese dishes, rich and buttery, meat-filled celebration foods, aromatic with cinnamon, allspice and coriander.

LEAD: Harold Ellis Klue, a principal at the Riverdale Country School for Boys for 29 years, died on Monday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center.
He was 84 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

LEAD: In a year-end interview in which he seemed at times to be addressing historians as well as reporters, Mayor Edward I. Koch insisted yesterday that New York City was ''far better off now'' than when he took office and was confident that he would be well remembered.

He was 86 years old.

LEAD: New York City has begun to reverse a legacy of physical decline.

Munitions Plant Explodes
LEAD: A clandestine gunpowder factory exploded today in northeastern Brazil, killing four people, injuring more than 100 and destroying nearby homes.
Fire-rescue workers dragged more than 100 people from the wreckage of their homes after the blast in the city of Feira de Santana, more than 900 miles northeast of Rio de Janeiro.

Billy Martin's Two Worlds
LEAD: The sadness of Billy Martin, who died Monday on an icy road near his farm in upstate New York, is the sadness of a badly disconnected life.
Inside a baseball stadium he came as close as he ever did to joy and self-control, even when he was railing against umpires and defeat.
But outside lay another world that he never seemed to grasp and certainly couldn't control, a world in which his pugnacity, combined with alcohol, produced behavior as pathetic as it was predictable.

Death and Rebirth in Rumania
LEAD: ''The sentence was definitive and was carried out.'' So ended the announcement on Rumanian radio of the Christmas Day execution by firing squad of Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife.
It is hard to feel pity for the Communist autocrat responsible for the wanton massacre of his ill-used people.
Yet summary justice is a treacherous substitute for rule of law.

Eating Well
LEAD: EVEN at this time of year, when everyone is doing it, predicting the future is almost as dangerous as making resolutions: it is almost impossible to be successful at either.
Year-end wrap-ups, on the other hand, hold no such uncertainty.
They provide a sense of satisfaction for those who do the wrapping, and also for those who have posed the questions.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in Science Times on Oct. 17 about competition for Nobel Prizes referred incorrectly to Oreste Piccioni.
As he notes in a recent letter, he was not a student assistant but a scientific associate of Owen Chamberlain and Emilio Segre, who shared the 1959 Nobel Prize in Physics.
The article also gave an incomplete description of a dispute between Dr.

LEAD: The NEC Corporation won a $64 million order from Brazil's telecommunications company to set up a public mobile communications system in Rio de Janeiro, a NEC spokesman said.
NEC will build about 30 stations from mid-1990 to early 1991, and supply a total of about 10,000 hand-held, portable and car telephones, he said.

After Noriega: Noriega; MILITARY COMMAND BELITTLES GENERAL
LEAD: The United States military headquarters here, which has portrayed Gen.
Manuel Antonio Noriega as an erratic, cocaine-snorting dictator who prays to voodoo gods, announced today that the deposed leader wore red underwear and availed himself of prostitutes.


After Noriega: United Nations; CUBA ASKS COUNCIL FOR ACTION ON U.S.
LEAD: Cuba called today for an urgent meeting of the Security Council to hear its complaint that American forces in Panama have surrounded the ambassador's residence there and are harassing its diplomats.


Toasting a Decade as the Ancients Did
LEAD: BEVERAGES, like foods, have intimate links with the seasons.
Icy blends of rum and fruit juice, for example, are ideal for the dog days of summer.
The coming of winter provides a long-awaited excuse to make special drinks usually reserved for the holidays: wassail, hot mulled wine and eggnog.
The days don't seem quite so cold, or the nights quite so long, with a sustaining mug of holiday cheer.


Hostages in Colombian Jail Are Freed by Police Assault
LEAD: The police stormed a cell block controlled by drug traffickers holding 18 hostages.
Six traffickers were killed and five hostages wounded, officials said today.
All hostages were released, and the situation at the La Picota jail in southern Bogota returned to normal, a Justice Department spokesman said.


U.S. Stake Abroad Is Up
LEAD: American companies are increasing their investments overseas, particularly in Europe, where they do not want to miss growth opportunities, economists for the Conference Board say.


Soviets Lose to Islanders
LEAD: Pat LaFontaine scored two goals and Derek King had three assists as the Islanders beat the Soviet Wings, 5-4, tonight for their first victory ever against a team from the Soviet Union.

Landmark Buying Cigna Partnerships
LEAD: Landmark Ventures Inc. said it would acquire 54 venture-capital partnerships from Cigna Venture Capital Inc. for more than $100 million.
The partnerships have 1,200 investments in nearly 800 companies.
Landmark, previously known as Technology Transitions Inc., manages about $60 million in 25 technology-based growth companies that include computer-based systems, software and support services and advanced electronics.


Launching of Titan Is Delayed a 6th Time
LEAD: Cold weather and high winds today forced the Martin Marietta Corporation to postpone its first commercial rocket launching for a sixth time.

LEAD: An anonymous benefactor is enriching the lives of faculty members at Whitworth College, providing free vacations, expensive food and other gifts.

Bush Signs Pay Rise Bill
LEAD: President Bush signed an executive order today carrying out legislation raising top Government salaries by up to 35 percent next year and giving all Federal workers a 3.6 percent cost-of-living pay increase.
House salaries will rise from $89,500 to $96,600 in 1990, while Senate salaries climb from $89,500 to $98,400.

LEAD: The Walt Disney Company said today that it had licensed a joint-venture company to produce nine new comic books featuring Disney characters for publication in Latin America.

LEAD: Stock prices ended narrowly mixed yesterday in extremely slow post-Christmas trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 2.13 points, to 2,709.26, but advances on the New York Stock Exchange edged out declines by 712 to 664.

Samuel Beckett Is Dead at 83; His 'Godot' Changed Theater
LEAD: Samuel Beckett, a towering figure in drama and fiction who altered the course of contemporary theater, died in Paris on Friday at the age of 83.
He died of respiratory problems in a Paris hospital, where he had been moved from a nursing home.
He was buried yesterday at the Montparnasse cemetery after a private funeral.

Manuel Antonio Noriega over to the United States.
The deposed Panamanian leader is in refuge in the Papal Nuncio's residence in Panama City. .


Kabul Is Hit With Rockets
LEAD: Rocket barrages on Kabul by Afghan rebels killed eight people and wounded six today, the official Kabul radio said.
Government forces killed 30 rebels in a counterattack, the radio report said.
Five rebel bases were destroyed by air and artillery strikes near the capital.


Police Officer and a Guard Wounded in Queens Chase
LEAD: A New York City police officer was shot and slightly wounded last night in a foot chase that started with a report of shots fired at Lefrak City in Elmhurst, where a security guard also was wounded, the police said.


Chief Executive Resigning At Bank of New England
LEAD: Troubled by problem real estate loans and mounting losses, the Bank of New England Corporation announced yesterday that its chief executive would step down and that the bank would continue to seek some kind of reorganization, possibly including the sale of the bank.

And one weekend each month, the young guests are invited to help prepare the brunch in the hotel's bakeshop.

Billy Martin Never Beat Injustice
LEAD: This was in the summer of 1961, while Billy Martin was serving what would turn out to be the first of many sentences of exile from New York.
He was finishing up as a player with the Minnesota Twins, wearing a gray road uniform in his old ball park, Yankee Stadium.


Israel Conducts 2 Attacks in Lebanon
LEAD: Israeli warplanes bombed and apparently destroyed a Lebanese Communist Party base south of Beirut today shortly after a ground attack by an elite paratroop unit on another Communist Party camp in southern Lebanon, the army said.


Israel and Relevance
LEAD: Now starts the 21st century, argues the Israeli philosopher Yirmiyahu Yovel.
The 20th century was not only brutish but short.
It started in 1914, with the conflict President Woodrow Wilson called ''the war to end wars.'' It ends, Mr.
Yovel claims with some intellectual justification, in 1989.
This year, the most heavily armed parts of the world learned that force is not strength.


Shamir Pledges to Press for Arab Voting
LEAD: In a noticeable shift of tone, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of Israel said today that he preferred friendship to enmity with Palestinians and pledged to press ahead with proposals for elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip despite opposition both within his own party and from many Palestinians.

LEAD: The United States Government is giving the International Red Cross $500,000 to buy medical supplies for victims of the fighting in Rumania and is considering plans to send more aid, Bush Administration officials said today.


Judge Voids New York Rule Requiring Judges' Retirement
LEAD: A Federal judge yesterday invalidated a provision of the New York State Constitution that requires certain state judges to step down at the age of 76.


Man Is Accused of Killing His Ailing Wife
LEAD: A retired police officer who was facing major heart surgery fatally shot his ailing wife because he was afraid he could not take care of her and did not want her to suffer anymore, the authorities say.

LEAD: Within a few months the Energy Department plans to end its decades-old practice of paying all bills, including environmental fines and other penalties, incurred by the companies that run the nation's 17 nuclear weapons plants, department officials say.

LEAD: Sales of existing homes, spurred by a big jump in activity in the South, advanced 3.2 percent in November, climbing at their fastest pace in 11 months, the National Association of Realtors said today.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday this week about Bo Schembechler's final game as Michigan's football coach misstated the date of his first heart attack.
It was 20 years ago this week, on Dec. 31, 1969.

Two Men and a Gyroscope May Rewrite Newton's Law
LEAD: Japanese scientists have reported that small gyroscopes lose weight when spun under certain conditions, apparently in defiance of gravity.
If proved correct, the finding would mark a stunning scientific advance, but experts said they doubted that it would survive intense scrutiny.

It was the west side of 160th Street, between 107th and 108th Avenues.

LEAD: As a child I suffered from frequent upper respiratory infections that lingered for weeks, far beyond the usual seven-day duration of a cold.

LEAD: The Conair Corporation, a maker of hair driers, said yesterday that it had bought the assets of Cuisinarts Inc., the maker of food processors, which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in August.
Conair, based in Stamford, Conn., said the purchase price was nearly $27 million.

The Credibility Gap on Drugs
LEAD: ''Drug abuse and the crime, violence and human suffering it engenders is the most urgent and intractable problem of our time,'' thundered Mario Cuomo back in January.
President Bush and others have similarly raised their voices in a year of public outcry over the crack epidemic.

LEAD: Florida's Attorney General said today that the state was investigating whether the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company had underpaid commissions to governments in several Southeastern states for pay-telephone use.

Tokyo Firm Is Punished
LEAD: The Daiwa Securities Company of Tokyo has been punished for compensating a customer for losses in stock transactions, a company official said Tuesday.
The official said the company had not violated any laws, but he quoted Masahiro Dozen, Daiwa's president, as apologizing for unfairness to other investors.


President of Microsoft Plans June Retirement
LEAD: Jon A. Shirley, the president and chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation since 1983, will retire in June at the end of the company's fiscal year, Microsoft said yesterday.

LEAD: Keith Waggoner, a manager for Jujamcyn Theaters, died on Saturday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.

LEAD: ''This is the first revolution on live television,'' said Ion Todan, proud and tired this afternoon amid the chaotic but businesslike clutter at the heart of the videocracy that has replaced the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu.


Exxon Plant Shut
LEAD: The explosion Sunday at the Exxon Corporation's refinery in Baton Rouge, La., has forced an adjacent Exxon chemical unit to suspend production, company officials said.
The chemical plant, though undamaged by the explosion and subsequent fire, uses naphtha from the refinery to produce compounds like propylene and benzene.

LEAD: The Westchester County Executive said today that he would neither sign nor veto the county's 1990 budget, meaning that the budget, which mandates more than 600 layoffs, will take effect on Monday.

PARENT &amp; CHILD
LEAD: THERE is no single pattern to the closeness of childhood best friends.
They may show their affection and alliance through whispered confidences, shared favorite toys or swift punches to the arm.
The relationship often reflects each child's stage of social development more than it does the goals, values and beliefs they hold in common.

California Rule On 'Junk' Sales
LEAD: State regulators, spurred by the collapse of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, intend to prohibit the sale of high-risk ''junk bonds'' from the offices of California's state-chartered savings institutions.


Small Quake in California
LEAD: A small earthquake struck today seven miles northwest of here, but there were no reports of damage or injury.
Hall Daily, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology, said the quake measured 3.2 on the Richter scale of ground motion.

LEAD: ''ALTHOUGH my garden is never quite what I want it to be,'' said Bernice Steinbaum, ''I've come to realize that gardens represent man's control over nature.''

World Growth Outlook for '90
LEAD: World economic growth will continue next year, but only barely, a business research group reported yesterday.


French Bank to Be Sold
LEAD: Australia and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd. said today that it had agreed to sell its French retail bank subsidiary, Grindlays Bank S.A., to Monte Dei Paschi di Siena of Italy for an undisclosed price.
The company said in a statement that the 14-branch bank, which it bought in 1984, was an efficient retail bank but no longer fit with its strategy in Europe of expanding wholesale cross-border banking.


U.S. Textile Imports Up
LEAD: United States textile imports rose by 13 percent and their value climbed to more than $32 billion in 1989, the American Textile Manufacturers Institute said today.

LEAD: The partner of a mugger who was stabbed to death by a subway rider this month was arrested yesterday, a police spokesman said.

LEAD: Panama faces the daunting task of rebuilding an economy ravaged not only by bullets and bombs but also by two years of economic war with the United States.

LEAD: An increasingly emotional battle over the safety of breast implant surgery is being waged within the Food and Drug Administration, in state legislatures and in the courts.

LEAD: American Jews concerned about the security of the 20,000 Jews living in Rumania have been reassured in recent days that the Jews were safe and had not been singled out in the revolution that toppled the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: LARGE damaged areas of wooden strip flooring can sometimes be satisfactorily repaired by an experienced installer.
But large repairs are almost always visible, and the results may not be permanent.
Often, a more practical solution is to minimize the visibility of the repair by replacing damaged sections of floorboards with small patches, making as close a match as possible.

LEAD: The DIG Acquisition Corporation's bid for the Di Giorgio Corporation has been cut to $30 a share, from $32, and extended until midnight, Di Giorgio said.

G.M. Cutting Jobs
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation, said it would lay off 2,050 workers indefinitely at two plants that build Corsica and Beretta cars.
The G. M. compact-car lines compete with such Japanese models as the Toyota Camry, Honda Accord, Mazda 626 and Subaru Legacy.
G.
M. will lay off 1,600 employees at a Linden, N.J., plant, and 450 workers at a plant in Wilmington, Del.

LEAD: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 9.3 percent rise in open positions on short sales in actively traded securities in its national market system for the month that ended Dec. 15.
The advance was sharply higher than the 2.8 percent increase in the previous period.

LEAD: The sparkle of the Seine and the glow of its floodlit palaces, tour boats and riverside restaurants do not reach a barge anchored at a dark, quiet quay here.
Outside it every night men stand in line, some nodding to a mate, others stone-faced, all clutching a pink card that grants a meal and a bed.

How Do You Define Status? A New BMW in the Drive. An Old Rock in the Garden
LEAD: The famous Zen rock garden of Ryoanji temple is a model of austere, tranquil beauty.
But many of the Japanese who come to view it these days arrive in BMW's and Mercedes-Benzes.
The men often wear Armani suits, the women carry Chanel handbags and both may wear Tiffany jewelry.
They are of a generation that seeks status rather than tranquillity, and this has transformed the place of the rock garden in Japan; owning one has become an important new status symbol.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sunday about programs to prevent transmission of the AIDS virus by drug addicts referred incorrectly to one at the community research branch of the National Institute on Drug Abuse.

LEAD: When the temperature plummeted into the low 20's over the weekend, making much of Florida colder than Anchorage, Ben Abbitt prayed for warmer weather to save the 7,000 acres of oranges owned by him and 250 other members of the Haines City Citrus Growers' Assocation.


A Rope of Pearls Needs a Good String
LEAD: PEARLS seem synonymous with classic style, habitually draped around the necks of fashion editors and the current First Lady.
But pearl necklaces need to be maintained, so what is the procedure when a strand breaks or needs routine restringing?
How does one find a reliable restringer, especially in light of horror stories about jewelers who substitute cheap pearls for fine ones?


Review/Television; 'Anything but Love': A New Twist on an Old Gimmick
LEAD: Will they or won't they?
The somewhat prurient question, or gimmick, has bolstered the ratings of countless television series. ''Moonlighting'' and ''Beauty and the Beast'' are among the more recent examples, and in each instance the hero and heroine did.
Now there is ABC's ''Anything but Love'' (Wednesdays at 9:30), the show that asks: Can carefree Hannah Miller, former schoolteacher and aspiring writer, be just good friends with angst-ridden Marty Gold, award-winning magazine reporter?


Energy and Pragmatism: 3 Who Will Serve; Mark Green; Consumer Affairs
LEAD: Ten years ago, a politically troubled President Jimmy Carter asked Mark Green to become the White House's consumer affairs director.
He declined.
A decade later, Mr.
Green not only accepted the job as New York City's commissioner of consumer affairs, but also actively sought the position.
Why the change in attitude?


Ernest A. Weymuller, Surgeon, 82
LEAD: Dr.
Ernest A. Weymuller, an otolaryngologist who was surgical director of the New York Eye and Ear Infirmary before his retirement in 1981, died Tuesday, apparently of a heart attack, at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I.
He was 82 years old and lived in Manhasset.


CLOSE TO HOME
LEAD: I AM trying to decide when it all went wrong in New York, when it was that one could no longer walk down a street without feeling guilty about having a destination.
The people I see every day don't have a destination. ''See you around,'' they say to one another, and sure enough they do.
They are like pigeons, rising suddenly to wheel in the air, then settling back on the same old perches.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: Painting Wrought Iron  Q.We have a wrought-iron fence around our patio that has been painted several times with a flat black rust-preventive paint.
We scrape off all peeling paint and sand down rusty areas each time before repainting.
We used a widely sold brand of rust-preventive paint one time, and another brand that contains epoxy the second time.

What 'Godot' Hath Wrought
LEAD: In January 1938 a panhandler named Prudent drove a knife into an Irishman living in Paris, narrowly missing his victim's heart.
Upon recovering, Samuel Beckett sought out his assailant in jail to ask what had prompted the attack. ''Je ne sais pas,'' replied Prudent.
The same cryptic words turned up in ''Waiting for Godot,'' spoken by a character called Boy, who deflects Vladimir's thirst for answers with, ''I don't know, sir.

Crew Keeps Stadium Flushing
LEAD: A work crew of 23 was assigned to do nothing on Christmas weekend but flush the 503 toilets at the Gator Bowl to prevent a freeze-up at the stadium before the annual New Year's college football game.
A freeze in 1983 caused about $400,000 damage in broken water pipes, so during last week's record cold, officials hired a brigade of flushers to keep water moving through the plumbing.

LEAD: Weeks after this city and more than 150 villages were devastated by some of India's worst Hindu-Muslim fighting, police officials are still uncovering graves from massacres that they say have left as many as 1,000 dead.

BUSINESS DIGEST
LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  Federal regulators and banking experts are concerned that mounting losses from troubled real estate loans could lead to a wave of bank failures, straining the Federal insurance program that protects depositors' funds.
The danger, regulators and analysts say, is that when the country enters an economic downturn, as most economists say it eventually must, the losses at commercial banks may be so large that the Government might have to raise insurance fees on the banking industry or rescue some banks with taxpayers' money.

Medieval Origins
LEAD: The Ensemble for Early Music is to perform ''Herod and the Innocents,'' a production based on two medieval Nativity plays, at the Cathedral of St.
John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at 112th Street, tonight at 7:30.

LEAD: A pickup truck slammed into an overturned tanker carrying 1,100 gallons of fuel Wednesday night, causing a huge explosion and the death of four people.
The driver of the tanker was not in the vehicle and thus escaped injury in the crash, which occurred on Interstate 10.
All those killed were inside the pickup truck.

Correction
LEAD: The main front-page article on Tuesday about Rumania misidentified Ana Ipatescu, for whom a street in Bucharest is named.
She was a heroine of the 1848 uprising against the Turks and the Russians, not of the Communist takeover after World War II.

Blast at U.S. Offices in Chile
LEAD: A bomb exploded today in the offices of the American-Chilean culture center in Santiago, causing damage but no injuries, the police said.
No group asserted responsibility for the blast at the center, which is partially financed by Washington.
But Chile's most active left-wing guerrilla group, the Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front, warned last week that it could strike at American interests in Chile to protest the American invasion of Panama.

Sales of crop insurance are well below expected levels.

Germany Fund's Shares Up Again
LEAD: Stock in the Germany Fund Inc. rose for a third straight day despite a warning that the fund itself now thinks its stock is overvalued.
The fund, a mutual fund that manages a portfolio of West German stocks in industries like chemicals and autos, rose $1.75, to $19, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, where its gain of 10.1 percent was the sixth best of the day.

LEAD:  THE ECONOMY  The index of leading indicators edged up 0.1 percent in November after modestly declining in October, the Commerce Department reported.

LEAD: The Chicago Blackhawks and the Minnesota North Stars engaged in a pregame free-for-all Thursday night that was not free at all.

Player suspensions, she said, could follow next week.

LEAD: EVEN among the minority of people who have wills, relatively few have completed what can be an equally important document, a letter of instructions to heirs and executors, says Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y.


Union Pacific Cuts
LEAD: The Union Pacific Railroad, a unit of the Union Pacific Corporation, said 190 management employees had accepted retirement or agreed to leave the company.
The move represents a 4.4 percent reduction in the railroad's nonunion personnel, it said.
The company's management staff now numbers 4,350, down 27 percent in four years.

LEAD: In 1988, Damian Johnson, the Giants' starting right offensive guard, suffered back spasms while warming up for the seventh game of the season.
He underwent surgery and was gone for the year.
