Burmese Capture Key Rebel Base
LEAD: Burmese forces backed by more than 800 rounds of mortar fire captured a major base of the Karen rebels on the Thai border today, the Thai police said.
Dozens of people were reported killed.
The border police said that as many as 3,000 Burmese soldiers fought hundreds of rebels for four days before overrunning the camp at Pa Loo, about 10 miles southwest of the Thai border town of Mae Sot.


Human Rights: Now the Hard Part
LEAD: The cause of human rights came triumphantly of age in the liberating 1980's.
The decade began with the collapse of military rule in much of Latin America and ended with the toppling of one-party absolutism in Eastern Europe.
Seemingly impregnable tyrannies were humbled by ordinary people who risked their skins demanding fundamental rights.

LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said its Philadelphia refinery had a fire Thursday that was quickly extinguished by Chevron staff with no injuries.

SCIENCE FICTION
LEAD: The Ramans are back - if indeed they exist.
In 1973 Arthur C. Clarke published a classic puzzle-story about enigmatic aliens, ''Rendezvous With Rama.'' In that novel (set in the year 2130) an enormous spaceship shaped like a hollow cylinder entered the solar system; all attempts to communicate with it were unsuccessful, yet the spaceship (dubbed Rama) allowed itself to be boarded by a team of human explorers, who discovered many marvels of bioengineering inside but no sign of the Ramans, the advanced beings who presumably built the impressive craft.

In Short: Nonfiction
LEAD: MEMOIRS OF A BASTARD ANGEL.
By Harold Norse. (Morrow, $22.95.) Question Of the Week; How Will Sports Change in The 1990's
LEAD: Innovative equipment design will have a significant impact on sports in the 1990's.
The larger baseball glove will give that average runner the extra reach to make the play.
Air pumps in shoes may give a 6-foot-2-inch basketball player the dunk he needs to make the college squad.
The best of these innovations will require significant input from the player to get the full effects of the product.

'Open Outcry' Works Well and Cheaply
LEAD: FOR a number of very basic reasons, I think the open outcry system of trading futures contracts will be with us for a long time to come.
The pit system is cheap, efficient and enormously successful.
In contrast, the architects of computerized trading systems have yet to show that they can compete economically with the pit system.

LEAD: To the Editor: A warning for readers regarding duty-free shops in airports.

ANTIQUES: The 1990's Await What Was New A Century Ago
LEAD: ''Old, not modern'' is how Dr.
Johnson defined ''antiques'' in his 18th-century dictionary.
In 1930, when United States Customs tackled the question, it came up with the more precise regulation that an antique was a work of art or a handicraft made before 1830, giving rise to the accepted notion that a genuine antique must be 100 years old - at least to pass through Customs duty-free.

Can There Be Too Much Power?
LEAD: EACH human brain cell can store the equivalent of 10,000 bits of information, and the brain has about 10 billion brain cells, according to The Body Almanac.
The memory capacity of the brain, therefore, is estimated at 100 trillion (100,000,000,000,000) bits, or slightly more than 10 terabytes.
Each brain cell can discharge an electrical impulse about 200 times a second.

LEAD: In regard to the article ''Helping Women With Child Support'' (New Jersey Q &amp; A, Nov. 19): The efforts of Sandy Feld and Aware are to be applauded.
The fact that there are deadbeat dads who don't pay child support is reprehensible.
It makes all dads look bad.
However, on behalf of the innocent children of divorce everywhere, there might be other factors to consider.


Lifestyle: Sunday Menu; When Onions Are Stars of the Show
LEAD: To enjoy the full flavor of cooked onions, it isn't enough to cook them just until they are soft; they must be soft and golden brown.
It takes a little longer, but it is worth the time.
In this Indian-style lamb recipe, the onions are used as a topping, preserving their texture and their sweetness, which is usually partly lost when they are combined with other ingredients.


Nautical Flavor for Mixed Use
LEAD: A new mixed-use development with a nautical motif has been completed in what was once an industrial area in South Norwalk, Conn.
Named Windsway, the project comprises 12,000 square feet of office space and 39 rental apartments.
It is in one of six so-called enterprise zones created by the state to stimulate renovation and development through tax-abatement incentives.

LEAD: CALL on Carol Ilson expecting to discuss the book she wrote about the producer Harold Prince during summers at her Ocean Beach retreat and it is just as likely she willtalk about her life as a psychotherapist.

LEAD: Yet another mighty artifact of the cold war is crumbling with startling speed: the complex of plants that makes America's nuclear bombs.

LEAD: Franthea Price had 25 points and Iowa scored the first 19 points of the game tonight on the way to a 106-81 victory over North Carolina.

The bold words underline a dark silhouette.
Choosing a silhouette for illustration was not just a design concept.
We don't know what Arif looks like.
We don't know what he looks like and yet we continue to work on his behalf.

How'd I Do?
LEAD: Dear David, When you and I recently appeared together before a large crowd out in Brighton Beach, I began by telling the people, ''I want to thank everyone out there who voted for me.
I appreciate it.'' Then, I added, ''I also want to thank everyone who didn't - you liberated me.''

Cliffhanger
LEAD: The Shawangunk cliffs tower like gothic ramparts over a sleepy valley west of New Paltz, N.Y.
Seen from a distance, they appear as impregnable as a fortress, and one might wonder how anyone could scale them.
But then at the base of the cliffs you discover that whenever rock is deposited in such a massive formation, it is never entirely sheer.

Resolution For 1990: Renew Passport Soon
LEAD: NEED a New Year's resolution?
Here's one: Renew your passport first thing.
If it expires any time in the coming year, this is a must, but even if it has longer to run, the United States Passport Service says that at this time of year you can get your new passport back by mail in two weeks.
Things may not run that speedily again until well into the fall.

LEAD: Consistency is not a keystone of the coming year's styles.

Small World
LEAD: Brace yourself, the world is getting smaller.
Fax machines and the Concorde have brought the ends of the earth together with record speed.
Now as we enter a new decade, designers are addressing a universal problem - lack of space.
Many have created sophisticated and ingenious objects that address every need from fitness to storage.

Wait Just a Second
LEAD: Poised on the brink of a new decade, the world will pause Sunday night for one second.
A ''leap second'' will occur at the very end of Dec. 31, 1989, making it the longest day of the year.
The reason is that the extra second is needed to keep the world's clocks in time with the rotation of the planet, according to Government timekeeping officials.

Mr.
Sorvillo, an art teacher, and Mrs.
Sorvillo, who works for Newsday, have been welcoming the new year in this manner since the birth of their eldest son, Paul.

I count it a great privilege to receive permission to hunt on private land.
The landowners become my friends.

Sustaining a New Year's Eve Tradition
LEAD: I NEVER wonder where I will be on New Year's Eve.
As long as my friend Beverly has New Year's Eve parties, I'll be there.
Her parties are the most luxurious highlights of my social calendar.
But this year I will be smarter.
I am ready to have a great time without eating myself silly and waking up in the morning without my self-respect.

LEAD: I SAW my first television in 1932 - a BBC production of Pirandello's play ''The Man With a Flower in His Mouth.'' I have seen a lot of television since, in most of the countries of the world, and have spent three years as a television critic.
I am convinced that the future of broadcasting rests with radio.

Headliners; Christmas in Berlin
LEAD: As Leonard Bernstein and an international orchestra churned through Beethoven's Ninth Symphony in a concert in East Berlin Christmas Day, it was evident that the maestro had not played a better house in many a year.
The musicians came from East and West Germany, the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain, and the performance came on the first Christmas in 28 years that East and West Berliners had mingled freely.


Review/Dance; Linked by Chairs, in Dove's 'Vespers'
LEAD: Ulysses Dove's ''Vespers'' drew tumultuous cheers in a performance by the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater on Friday night at City Center, and it is easy to see why.
Like ''Episodes,'' his new work this season, ''Vespers'' is an explosive dance set to driving percussive music.
But the older dance, performed to music by Mikel Rouse, is a purer conscious venture into formalism.

Wall Street Prepares For a Failure Boom
LEAD: AS the Hillsborough Holdings Corporation prepared its filing for bankruptcy last week, it became the darling of Wall Street.
A parade of investment bankers, having sniffed out the fact that the highly leveraged company, formed in 1987 by Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &amp; Company, was planning to file for protection from its creditors, came peddling their skills at reorganization.


Christmas Just Keeps On Going
LEAD: DON'T think that because tomorrow is New Year's Day, Christmas is finally over.
The holiday does not end officially until next Sunday, Jan. 6,- which is Twelfth Night, also known as Epiphany.
On this day, all decorations must come down in order not to invite bad luck for the coming year.

Campus Life: Missouri; Now, Fraternities Must Check Ages Of Party Guests
LEAD: In October, four fraternity-associated sexual assaults prompted the University of Missouri to suspend the 28 ''little sister'' organizations that had paired their members with fraternity members in rush and fund-raising activities.
All of the attacks, the university's police said, were alcohol related.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Dec. 10 about a stock transaction involving Mayor-elect David N. Dinkins of New York City misstated provisions of Federal gift-tax laws.
The maximum each taxpayer can give without paying gift taxes is $600,000 in total, not per recipient.


Adding Insult
LEAD: To the Editor:


All About New Year's Eve
LEAD: What is it with New Year's Eve, anyway?
I don't think I've actually ever met anyone who liked it, and yet we all persist in celebrating.
It's a silly holiday, one of forced revelry, a night when - like the senior prom - reality can't possibly fulfill expectations.


Brilliant Silks Woven by Hand In Thailand
LEAD: ''PEEP SHOW,'' a mostly routine 1950 revue produced by Mike Todd, deserves at least a footnote in theatrical history as probably the only Broadway show ever to contain a song by a ruling monarch.
The number was ''Blue Night,'' written by Thailand's jazz-loving young King Bhumibol Adulyadej.
The show also brought Thai silk to the New York stage for the first time.

LEAD: President Bush conceded today that American troops in Panama committed a ''screw-up'' when they searched the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama City on Friday, but questioned why the diplomat had weapons ''up to his eyeballs'' in his house.

Hermann Oberth, 95, German Rocket Expert
LEAD: Hermann Julius Oberth, a pioneer of the space age who worked with Werner von Braun to help develop Germany's V-2 rocket, died on Friday.
He was 95 years old.
Mr.
Oberth died at a hospital in Nuremberg after a short illness, the Hermann Oberth Museum in Feucht said in a statement.


Pastimes; Bridge
LEAD: The end of the 1980's prompts a review of the top echelon of American bridge.
Almost all the veterans who made their reputations in the 1930's have died, like Waldemar Von Zedwitz, Oswald Jacoby, B. Jay Becker and Richard Frey.
Others have retired from tournament playlike Charles Goren and Sam Fry Jr.

BIRDMEN OF HARLEM
LEAD: I only wish my father were alive to read John W. Miller's article ''Birdmen of Harlem,'' (Nov. 19).
My Dad raised and raced pigeons, in Brooklyn, for more than 40 years.
His obsession started when he was about 9 years old.
He even secretly kept some pigeons in his bedroom until my grandmother got wise to him.

Christmas Just Keeps On Going
LEAD: DON'T think that because tomorrow is New Year's Day, Christmas is finally over.
The holiday does not end officially until next Sunday, Jan. 6,- which is Twelfth Night, also known as Epiphany.
On this day, all decorations must come down in order not to invite bad luck for the coming year.


RECORDINGS: The Past Raises Its Voice Once More
LEAD: As early as 1902 singers started putting their art on Mr.
Edison's fairly recent (1877) invention, only they recorded on flat disks rather than the cylinders favored by the inventor.
It is safe to say that every great singer, and thousands of lesser ones, made records.
Eventually their original records disappeared, but they were not lost.

LEAD: ALTHOUGH it's much too soon to be nostalgic for the 80's, it's hard to picture them being anyone's good old days.
For me the last decade had no memories as sweet as charlotte russes or mello rolls.

China Condemns British Decision To Take In Hong Kong Families
LEAD: China today condemned a British decision to grant full residency rights to 50,000 Hong Kong families, calling it ''a gross violation'' of an agreement between the two countries and threatening to take unspecified retaliatory action.


Printing What Cameras Catch
LEAD: YOU see the image in your camera's window and press the button.
The film advances - and there is another scene, moving you to press the button.
With the device around your neck, you are a director, an auteur - an imagist with the power to preserve your experience.

LEAD: PROSPECTIVE tenants in New York often have to contend with costly real estate brokers, cranky landlords and choosy co-op boards.

Work, Women and Men
LEAD: A FEW months ago, I mentioned to some associates that I was thinking about writing an article on why I liked working with women.
Men invariably responded with flippancy, raised eyebrows, ribald chuckles or lewd innuendo.
Women unhesitatingly gave the topic a serious context.
Most wanted a full discussion of the subject right then and there.

THE ULTIMATE DECISION
LEAD: My mother is in the later stages of Alzheimer's disease.
Although she is otherwise in general good health, I know that one day I may face the same situation Andrew Malcolm did.
I struggle to remember any snatches of conversation that indicate what my mother's desires would be.
But each recollection that suggests yes is counterbalanced by another that suggests no.

DANCE DANCE VIEW: Ailey's Troupe Weathers a Season of Sorrow
LEAD: TONIGHT, THE ALVIN AILEY American Dance Theater will close what has been one of its most difficult - and yet most successful - seasons.
Ailey died on Dec. 1, five days before the troupe's opening at the City Center.
Out of the red-hot crucible of grief and mourning, the Ailey dancers performed as never before.

Palmy Days At a Hideaway In Morocco
LEAD: THE entrance to the Gazelle d'Or, the old converted hunting lodge of Baron Jean Pellenc in Taroudant, southwestern Morocco, is a long drive lined with whispering eucalyptus trees that bend and touch 30 feet overhead.
The road passes through a tall wrought-iron gate, its guard in a white djellaba, a hooded overgarment for both men and women.

LEAD: Kappa Sigma is the oldest nationally chartered fraternity at Washington State University.
It scheduled a dance for late October, and it needed some way to decorate its house.
So a group of students pledging for membership set out to round up a variety of materials around Pullman that included 50 sheets of plywood, a dozen rolls of tarpaper, five bales of hay, two fake geese and a cement statue of the Virgin Mary.

Christmas Just Keeps On Going

When Justice Goes Wrong
LEAD:  JUSTIFIABLE HOMICIDE: Battered Women, Self-Defense, and the Law.
By Cynthia K. Gillespie. (Ohio State University, $24.95.) The idea in our law that it is excusable to kill in self-defense goes back to medieval England.
The cases that led to the development of the common law on self-defense fell into two classes: there were the highway-robber cases, where an unknown assailant sets upon someone who, in fighting back, kills his attacker; and then there were the barroom brawls, in which a dispute between two men escalates into a dangerous armed battle.

Upheaval in the East: Espionage; It's Still Business as Usual for Spies, Even as the Eastern Bloc Rises Up
LEAD: For years, experts have dubbed Czechoslovakia's spy agency the ''two Czech'' service.
Agents of the Office for the Protection of State Secrets got one check from Prague, the pun goes, and another from their real bosses at K.G.B. headquarters in Moscow.


Fashion; Two New Stores That Cruise Fashion's Fast Lane
LEAD: One shop has a faux French accent and the other a real Spanish one, but they both speak the same fashion language.
It's a language understood by young fashion followers on a budget who nonetheless change their clothes as often as the color of their lipstick.
Two new boutiques on Lexington Avenue within a block of each other are now vying for these young women constantly seeking out the latest trend.


Review/Music; Alexander Schneider and Strings
LEAD: The annual holiday concerts of the New York String Orchestra under Alexander Schneider celebrate youth and experience.
This year's orchestra consisted of 63 players (including winds and a percussionist) between the ages of 15 and 22, assembled for the 81-year-old Mr.
Schneider's 11-day seminar.
The teaching, one suspects, must somewhat contradict what the students learn at modern academies, just as some of the conductor's interpretive choices depart from current notions of correct period practice.


Banking's High-Tech Retail Chase
LEAD: IN the battle among banks for retail customers, the victors are likely to be those that use high technology best.
So banks are now spending more than $10 billion a year on electronic technology to attract more customers, serve them more efficiently and keep staffs free to sell more profitable products.


Hunter Addition
LEAD: A $67 million addition to the Hunter College Campus Schools that would eventually make possible an increase in enrollment from the present 1,600 students to 2,200 is under consideration by the city.
The proposal would add about 100,000 square feet to the school, enough for 20 new classrooms and a new gymnasium.


Compensating for Filling In a Wetland
LEAD: A CENTURY of draining and road building, mosquito eradication and waste dumping has reduced the Hackensack Meadowlands to a featureless reed-choked vista that greets motorists driving the northern reaches of the New Jersey Turnpike.
Few birds sing, and about the only thing that nests in the once-fertile mud are discarded tires.


Q And A
LEAD:  Tax on Condominiums  Question: How are the real estate taxes on condominium apartments calculated?
Should similar apartments in the same building pay the same taxes? . . .
K.
B., Manhattan  Answer: According to Jeffrey Schanback, deputy commissioner for the property division in the city's Department of Finance, when tax apportionment assignments are first made for condominiums, the portion to be paid on each unit is also established.

Pastimes; Coins
LEAD: Money may at first seem an unlikely venue for propaganda.
But any coin in any pocket has a message.
Whether a bust of George Washington reminding us that we were the first of the great revolutionary governments or a profile of Lincoln reminding us of the Civil War and our experience with slavery.
Each coin has some meaning underlying the mundane utility of money.

Aiming High Under the Big Top
LEAD: IN Europe, the circus is not just something to take your kids to - grown men and the government fight about it passionately in the popular press.

In Vermont, a Proposal to Ban Disposable Diapers
LEAD: Dotty Schnure, a mother who has a job away from home, always used disposable diapers on her two young daughters.
She estimates that she used 90 small diapers a week per child when they were infants, 60 medium-size diapers a week per child for the next three months, and 30 large diapers for the next two years - roughly 4,920 diapers per child.

FILM: Again, Sidney Lumet Ponders Justice
LEAD: SIDNEY LUMET IS PLAYING A familiar role.
He is at work, directing the latest movie in his long and prolific career.
He is on his native soil, or, more accurately, native asphalt - the streets of New York, streets that have spawned so many of his films.
He is wearing his customary clothes, a work shirt and jeans, and chewing Juicy Fruit gum in the same frenetic way he shoots takes.

Correction
LEAD: An entry in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today mislabels an exchange rate for Brazil's currency of a year ago.
A dollar on Dec. 22, 1988, was equal to 935 old cruzados, not new ones; the new cruzado, equal to 1,000 old cruzados, was not introduced until Jan. 14.

Baroque Concert
LEAD: Bach's Magnificat and Vivaldi's Gloria will be the major works in a concert of holiday Baroque music by the Taghkanic Chorale and Orchestra at the Church of the Ascension, Fifth Avenue at 10th Street, at 9 o'clock tonight.
The 120-member choral ensemble, conducted by Dennis Keene, will sing Venetian antiphonal pieces, the Rondeau from Jean Joseph Mouret's Symphony of Fanfares, and Handel's ''Coronation'' Anthem.

RECORDINGS: At Home in the Top 40 And Still Full of Kitsch
LEAD: It's taken 10 years for the imes to catch up with the B-52's.
With the Top 10 successes of their seventh album, ''Cosmic Thing'' (Reprise 9 25854, all three formats) and its hit single ''Love Shack,'' the group has finally moved beyond cult status.
The B-52's were always popular on college radio stations, but from the perspective of the early-80's mainstream, the group was a novelty act, at once studiously retro and unnervingly futuristic.


Memorable Meals: A Critic's Choices
LEAD: WHILE 1989 was not a banner year for discovering restaurants rated excellent, there was one clear winner in that league.
La Provence (86 Washington Street, South Norwalk, 855-8958) combines a comfortable decor inspired by the south of France, with food to match.
The restaurant, operated by two graduates of the Guy Savoy restaurant in Paris, features some of the most original and delicious fare to be found in Connecticut in years.


Confessions of a Soap Opera Extra
LEAD: Andy Warhol was wrong.
In my case, at least, fame clocked in at only 6:42 minutes, and that was before the final cut.


Threatened Northwest Flight Lands Safely
LEAD: With fortress-like security thrown up to meet a threatened attack, an almost empty Northwest Airlines jumbo jet from Paris landed here today, uneventfully except for the crush of reporters and television crews assigned to greet the few passengers.


Commodity Prices Spurred by Cold
LEAD:  Cold weather drove prices up sharply for several commodities last week.
Futures contracts for heating oil reached six-year highs, peaking at $1.02 a gallon before profit taking caused declines at week's end.
In November, heating oil futures sold for slightly less than 60 cents a gallon.
An explosion that shut down the nation's second-largest refinery, an Exxon complex in Louisiana, added to the upward pressure.


State Lags In Treating Cocaine Addicts
LEAD: FOUR years after crack flooded into New Jersey, state support for drug treatment programs remains oriented primarily toward heroin addiction, and the programs can handle only a fraction of the cocaine and heroin addicts, private health and drug experts say.

VIDEO: The Living Room Is Now the Stage
LEAD: A WAGGISH SCHOLAR once observed that the writing of history might be classified as one of the performing arts because it calls for so much interpretation.
Mere facts can be read any number of ways.

Mr.
Pope's parents also live in Westfield.

New York State to Start Restricting Smoking
LEAD: Acceptable behavior in public will change on Monday, when one of the nation's strictest anti-smoking laws will go into effect in New York State.
